name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: I declare resumed the session of the European Parliament adjourned on Thursday, 29 October 2015.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Colleagues, I want to bring to your attention two very serious incidents which occurred. We want as a Parliament to express our concern and sympathies to those who have been affected, so thank you for your silence. On Friday, 30 October, a terrible fire broke out at a nightclub in Bucharest, where up to 400 people, mostly in their teens and early twenties, had gathered to attend a concert. The death toll has risen to at least 46 people and about 100 are still in hospital, many in a serious condition. Our thoughts and our sympathies are with the families and the friends of the victims. We are also very deeply distressed by the news that a Russian airliner crashed in central Sinai, killing 224 people, and again we offer our sympathies to the victims’ families and to the Russian people.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I spoke because I was the one who asked the European Parliament, together with other fellow Romanian MEPs, to commemorate the 50, already, of people who lost their lives in the tragic fire that took place on Friday, 30 October, in a local in the Romanian capital. Dozens of people, generally young people of my generation, are still struggling between life and death, and a message from you is a sign of solidarity for Romanian society, in this extremely tragic context for my country. I want to thank all the Member States that have offered their assistance to support us at this extremely difficult time.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Thank you for your words.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The Minutes of 29 October 2015 have been distributed. Are there any comments?

name: Udo BULLMANN
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her As the chairman of the SPD Members of the European Parliament, I would like to say – and I think I can do this for the whole House – for ourselves and for our group, the Socialist Group – that we mourn Helmut Schmidt, the former Chancellor of the Federal Republic of Germany, a great statesman, a great Social Democrat, a great European. I would ask the Bureau, in our next plenary session in Strasbourg, to pay tribute to his personality so that this can be properly prepared. Thank you for your understanding and thank you for your support.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Thank you for your words, Mr Bullmann. ******* (The minutes of the previous sitting were approved) *******

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: – Madam President, I have a point of order if I am allowed to make one. Yesterday we heard the British Prime Minister’s speech at Chatham House in London, and he also sent a letter to Mr Tusk. It is clear that the changes that Mr Cameron is asking for are important but, at the same time, we also have a number of other problems in the European Union that we have to solve. As you know, we in this House requested the presence of Mr Cameron, inviting him to come to explain his demands before this House. This is the house of European democracy. This is the European Parliament. My request to you is to ask our President what is now the status of the invitation that has been sent to Mr Cameron to come before this House. (Applause)

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: We will indeed request information from the President on your question. We know the invitation has been sent so we will ask for an update to answer your point. Thank you for raising it.

name: Marcel de GRAAFF
text: Madam President, before the start of the meeting, I would like to raise a point. Today, 11 November, we commemorate the end of the First World War, a terrible event in our history that has caused millions of deaths. In many countries in the European Union, this day is also a national day on which these deaths are remembered. Nevertheless, we are holding a meeting here, with the result that a number of Parliamentarians cannot be present because they consider that commemoration so important. I want to do two things. Firstly, I would like to express my regret for the fact that we are meeting today. Couldn't that have been another day? Secondly, I would like to ask whether, as President, you can dwell on the dead of the First World War.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Thank you for bringing this to our attention. Colleagues, I think we will express our sympathies just by listening to your fine words, and we will also pass on your message about the plenary sitting to the President and his Cabinet.  Colleagues, with your permission I will now move on to make some announcements and bring to your attention the following: The screening of the three contending films for the 2015 Lux Prize has started. The three films nominated are: Mediterranea; Mustang; Urok (The Lesson). You can watch these in the Lux Theatre in the Yehudi Menuhin until 20 November or on the VOD or, by request, DVD. The films are subtitled in all EU official languages. Members of Parliament can cast their votes until 23 November. Moreover, today is a very special day, and for the first time ever one of the films competing for the Lux Film Prize, Mediterranea, will be screened simultaneously in eight cities of the European Union, with the film director Jonas Carpignano attending the screening here in Brussels.

name: Silvia COSTA
text: Chairman of the Committee on Culture and Education. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would just like to thank you for mentioning this very important event, namely the possibility for MEPs – and I say this above all to the new MEPs, who may not have known about this initiative, which is now in its eighth edition – to vote for the winner of this European exhibition of anolyto films, films by particularly young film-goers.  I would like to tell you that this year these are three films of exceptional beauty, which have already been presented in some European festivals (Karlovy Vary, Venice) and are shooting these days, which are the "Lux days", even in your cities. So it would be very interesting to enhance this projection. These are three films that are all three very mature first works on issues of great attention to Europe. I think it is very nice that in Strasbourg this prize will be solemnly given by President Schulz to the winner who will be proclaimed by us. I would therefore really urge these young filmmakers to be given the signal of attention, as well as remembering that the original Lux Prize prize consists in subtitling the three finalists in the 24 official European languages to promote circulation in Europe and outside Europe.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Thank you, Ms Costa, for the additional information for colleagues.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The final draft agenda as drawn up pursuant to Rule 149 by the Conference of Presidents at its meeting of 29 October 2015 has been distributed.

name: Ashley FOX
text: – Madam President, pursuant to Rule 152 of the Rules of Procedure, I would like to move that we postpone the debate on zero-rating practice to the November II part session in Strasbourg and replace it with Council and Commission statements on the outcome of the 9 November Competitiveness Council in relation to the steel sector. As many colleagues are aware, the steel industry across Europe has been facing unprecedented pressures in recent years. We cannot ignore the fact that the industry is facing unfair competition and anti-competitive market behaviour. Chinese steel exports have risen by 28% in the first six months of the year, flooding the market with steel that is sold at a loss. This is dramatically destabilising the global steel market and the flow of trade, risking European steel manufacturing as a whole and in my country in particular. This matter is urgent and no harm will be caused by postponing the debate on zero-rating by two weeks. Can I therefore ask colleagues to show support for the steel industry in Europe and vote in favour of adding this urgent debate to our session agenda? On behalf of my group, I request a roll-call vote on that matter.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, it is well known that steel mills throughout Europe are facing enormous problems. Especially since the financial crisis of 2008 we now have a competitiveness crisis, we have too many redundancies, we have job losses. At the same time we are seeing unfair competition from external competitors in the European Union, mainly from China. So at a time when support for employment is necessary, at a time when we need new jobs, it is necessary to support the European steel industry and the conclusions of the Competitiveness Council show that we have unfair illegal competition. This issue must therefore be discussed and we support The Proposal by Mr Fox and the ECR.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: – Madam President, I believe that, as Mr Fox and Marias pointed out, this is a significant, important issue, not only because of its economic dimension, but also because of its social and environmental impact.  And precisely because this is an important issue, we want to have the opportunity to prepare it properly, so I propose that this matter be discussed at the part-session of November II, that is, in just ten days from today. This would give groups the opportunity to agree on their position and to be able to prepare properly for a consistent discussion.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: There is no change to our agenda and the order of business is thus established but, in agreement with the political groups, the title of the first item on the agenda has been changed to: ‘A statement by the Commission on the European Semester package – Annual Growth Survey 2016. (The order of business was thus established)

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission statement on the European Semester package – Annual Growth Survey 2016 (2015/2924(RSP)).

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, the Commission will soon publish its Autumn European Semester package, and this package will start the 2016 European Semester. I am very pleased to be here to outline the main points which are new and to discuss with you the key ideas that we are considering. To engage with the European Parliament at a plenary debate even before the Annual Growth Survey is presented is one of the initiatives to increase democratic accountability that the Commission proposed in the Communication of 21 October on ‘Steps Towards Completing EMU’. As you will recall, the European Commission substantially streamlined the European Semester last year. To enable a more genuine dialogue with the Member States, the Commission published its Country Reports in February, three months before the country-specific recommendations were finalised. The recommendations have become fewer and more focused, and these changes have met with a mostly positive response. The Commission’s Communication on ‘Completing Economic and Monetary Union’ proposed some further changes, in line with the Five Presidents’ Report. The autumn package will therefore include recommendations for the euro area, and there will be increased focus on employment and social matters. This package has been prepared against a background of still moderate economic recovery. But the recovery is boosted by temporary factors and is subject to downside risk. Unemployment is still high in many Member States, with high numbers for long-term and youth unemployment. Macroeconomic imbalances are adjusting, but we need to continue to reduce high public and private debt. Divergence across countries is still large, and this shows in employment and poverty indicators. The 2015 Annual Growth Survey, the first under the new Commission, recommended pursuing an economic and social policy based on three main pillars: a boost to investment; a renewed commitment to structural reforms; and the pursuit of fiscal responsibility. Since then, important steps have been taken both at EU and national level. Member States continue to undergo fundamental and sometimes difficult structural reforms. The Commission has submitted initiatives aimed at restoring growth, improving convergence and promoting social fairness. The Investment Plan for Europe is operational. Parliament and Council adopted in record time the European Fund for Strategic Investment. The Commission has made ambitious proposals to strengthen economic governance. These cover the operation of the European Semester; the macroeconomic imbalances procedure; banking union; and strengthening the social dimension, while reinforcing transparency and democratic legitimacy. Moreover, the EU Internal Market is being strengthened through a new Internal Market Strategy, and Action Plans for a Digital Single Market and Energy Union. All these tools and instruments must now be fully deployed and deliver concrete results for our citizens. Given the economic and social situation in Europe, the three main priorities of the previous Annual Growth Survey remain valid. Of course they need to be updated to take account of the progress made, notably in the Investment Plan, as well as of the new challenges that have emerged, including the refugee crisis. Concerted action on reforms both at the EU and national level is needed to rekindle investment, foster economies that are both competitive and fair, and to run responsible public finances, and we hope that this year’s Annual Growth Survey and European Semester will contribute to these objectives.

name: Burkhard BALZ
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Mr Vice-President, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for his work As the European People's Party, we welcome today's debate on the European Semester. The European Parliament would like to send a few messages to the Commission before the new annual cycle of the semester begins next week. We welcome the fact that the Commission's ideas for fine-tuning the European Semester take into account the legal framework of the European Treaties. We also welcome the fact that the Commission has now made it clear that it will apply the existing budgetary rules and, above all, enforce them. But we will also be very careful to ensure that the Commission will keep this promise in the 2016 semester. We want to underline the focus of the semester on economic policy factors, because where the economic basis and labour market policy are right, employment and social indicators are also developing positively. We also see the positive economic development so far in programme countries such as Portugal, which have made great efforts and where the economy has steadily increased thanks to strict reforms under Christian Democrat government. We cannot fully share the Commission's proposal to introduce a view of the euro area. A view at the euro-zone level must not reduce or even weaken the national responsibility of the individual Member States. And in order to strengthen competitiveness in Europe as a whole, some countries currently have to do more than others. We therefore welcome the establishment of national competition councils. An independent Council of Experts can certainly be helpful if its mandate is geared towards following up precisely where, as we know, economic and reform policy is most urgently needed. We are therefore giving the Commission a mandate for this semester cycle: tackle the problems at the roots! Stay true to yourself as guardian of the Treaties! And apply the budgetary rules as we have created them together! This is how the new semester process can start well.

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, I would like to say to the Vice-President that it is very important at this time for Parliament to express its concerns on the economic and social priorities for the European Union over the next year. Yes, there are some signs of recovery, but it is still a mild recovery. My question is about the strategy to foster growth in Europe. We can see that, so far, this strategy is mainly led by exports. We do, of course, need to have a competitive economy, but we believe that this is also the right moment to invest more in domestic demand. We need to foster European domestic demand. This means, first of all, pushing for more private and public investment. It also means encouraging consumption, particularly among the middle classes and those who are more impoverished. So we are calling for a new policy mix where investment is really at the top, where reforms are needed. But the reforms should focus mainly on growth potential, innovation, education and energy transition, making sure, too, that we can keep sustainable social welfare systems. To add to this policy mix, we should also focus on reducing social inequalities. This means a very active social policy. We think that fiscal consolidation should indeed be pursued, but in such a way that it is consistent with these previous goals. I would say that this new policy mix should be particularly rigorously applied in the euro area, and that is why we need to reduce the macroeconomic and macro-social imbalances which we have in the euro area and which are undermining its long-term sustainability. Parliament will be very active all through this cycle of the European Semester. We will come forward with a strong and clear position before the Spring European Council, but we are also concerned by the recent package presented by the Commission, because we think that Parliament should be more involved when designing the new instruments – competitiveness boards, the European Fiscal Board, the way for the euro area to manage its external representation and, finally, the way to conduct the European Semester with a proper interinstitutional agreement.

name: Stanisław OŻÓG
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Dear! The European Commission has already improved the European Semester in some way by changing the calendar of analyses and discussions on the economic situation in the euro area and the Union as a whole. The next steps are aimed at deeper economic and fiscal integration. The new European Semester is also expected to focus more on social aspects and employment, with the social partners playing a central role. I support the fact that the Commission therefore intends to focus regularly also on the social impact assessment of macroeconomic adjustment programmes. This will undoubtedly have a positive effect, but I would like to remind you that the European Semester is above all a process of enhanced coordination of member states' economic policies, the main objective of which is to better take into account the European dimension in the planning of national economic strategies, rather than making decisions strictly the responsibility of the Member States to debate and analyse at European level. I cannot get rid of the impression that any failures of the euro area and the problems resulting from differences in the various economies of the Union are given as an example of further deeper integration. The Commission gives an example of the United States, which speaks with one voice in international economic and financial for a. Turning to the Honourable Commission, comparing Europe with the United States is completely out of place. After all, the United States is one country and the European Union is twenty-eight sovereign states. While I support better coordination of economic policies, especially in euro area countries that share a single currency and depend on each other, I cannot support the Commission's plans to create more transnational beings, such as the European Fiscal Council.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: Mr Frunzulic has presented a 'blue card', but the following happens: those who have so far intervened – and so will mrs Kappel – have done so on behalf of their groups.  I would prefer the 'blue cards' to be presented to ask a question to speakers who speak not on behalf of their groups, but in a personal way.  I therefore give the floor to Mr Torvalds.

name: Nils TORVALDS
text: On the other: – Mr President, Commissioner Dombrovskis. Of course, we look forward with some excitement to the proposals that we are expecting from the Commission. The tension is not least due to the fact that, during the last session in Strasbourg, we actually dealt with the corresponding issue from last year, and it turns out that our tendency to ideologize issues meant that we could not agree on the substance.  However, as we know, macroeconomics are not an exact science, and so I shall concentrate on two different issues in the following. The first question is not really about macroeconomics, but about a medical problem. The European Union and, above all, the Council seem to be suffering from some kind of schizophrenia in this matter. The rules for the European Semester are approved by the Council. Then the members of the Council, i.e. the Member States, give complete credit for following the decisions they have taken themselves.  We thought that we had hit rock bottom of this development when we felt that only nine Member States had somehow managed to fulfil these councils. But later it turned out that the following year we were down to seven. We must somehow manage this kind of schizophrenia in the decision-making process.  The second question I would like to highlight could actually be described with the word asymmetry. What we experience in almost all decisions is that the 28 Member States are, in many respects, extremely different. At the same time, however, there is a tendency both within Parliament and within the Commission and the Council to take decisions on the basis of the old and bad rule that the same size of the pantyhose should be good enough for everyone.  That is a bad starting point. We must learn that the asymmetric forces in the European Union are extremely powerful and that we must be able to take decisions that reconcile these asymmetric tendencies in a way that keeps this Union together. And that we don't need to hear too many exclamations from, for example, Britain that they want to leave us. We do not need that kind of discussion in this context.

name: Fabio DE MASI
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the This sentence is not by me, but by the French star economist Thomas Piketty: the European Semester is a European disaster! It is hardly being implemented anyway, and that is a good thing, otherwise the situation in the euro area would be even worse. Since the crisis, government spending and wages have been cut, but unemployment has risen. The eurozone remains in depression, and public debt has exploded rather than fallen. Monetary policy is at its limit and fizzled out. If this policy were a scientific experiment, then the Dijsselbloens and Schäubles would now have to pack everyone up and go home. The experiment failed. Every year the Commission talks about an upswing, but the people do not see it. With the problem in China, hopes for an export-driven upswing like ice in the summer are also melting. The five presidents' report is intended to continue this crazy policy: competition committees should intervene in collective bargaining autonomy, wages should fall until all export champions are world champions. But every child understands that not everyone can be export world champions at the same time. The euro is in danger of breaking up in this policy. Everywhere this policy is being voted out – in Greece, in Portugal – and that is a good thing. Mr Juncker said before the Greek referendum that a 'no' to this crazy policy was incompatible with the euro. I would like to answer him with Bertolt Brecht: if the people do not suit those in power, they should choose a new one.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, welcome Vice-President Dombrovskis, I have listened very carefully to you. I do not see much new in your speech, but if I listen carefully to the weak signals, I hear the adjective or the noun "social" several times. And so I'm curious to see the contents of the fall package. Since you are talking about this and your boss wants the European Union to be given a triple-A rating for its social policy - and we are a long way from that - I would like to make some suggestions. In the fight against poverty, as you have noted, the results are not very good; however, when it comes to tackling inequality, you have instruments at your disposal in the Semester. Today, your answer is that you have to continue to deregulate labour markets, because ultimately it is easier for those who are excluded from the labour market to enter. But the result is that those who have a job see their working conditions, wages and non-wages, deteriorate simply because of greater competition between workers. What you could do is decide to focus your recommendations on tax instruments, because the tax instrument is the first redistribution instrument. If you really want to fight poverty effectively, maybe that is the direction that needs to be taken. Do not tell me that tax policy is not a competence of the European Union, because I have already seen in many country-specific recommendations recommendations on the tax system. And so rather than focus on competition in the labour market, you could say: 'I encourage the Member States, in fact, to introduce a tax shift of labour incomes towards other forms of income', but we have to be careful because, if you say 'work income to VAT', it is again the weakest classes in society who are affected. So perhaps you could focus on the issue of tax progressivity. We have been witnessing a reduction in the progressivity of income tax in Europe for decades. Perhaps there is something to be done on this side that would in any case allow you to recommend greater social justice to the Member States. Same thing when it comes to competitiveness, it's not a bad word! I've heard you talk about reviving investment. The two areas where investment is absolutely necessary if we are to be competitive are energy efficiency and resource efficiency - in other words, for the same unit of gross domestic product, we should be using both less energy and less resources than our competitors. It is a question of Greater independence for Europe, which is known to be poor in resources and energy, but also a condition of competitiveness. It would be nice to find that in your recommendations, since the European Commission talks a lot about the circular economy, having said that, I have not seen much action yet. I would like to finish with two specific countries, I have one minute left. Firstly, Germany: the Barroso II Commission had once again protected Germany by preventing excessive surpluses from being really targeted by the macroeconomic imbalance procedure. Where are we today? 8.4% forecast by Ifo in terms of Germany's trade surpluses. I hope that the macroeconomic imbalance procedure will point the finger at the inadequacy of German domestic demand and ask Germany to permanently rebalance its balance of payments. A surplus of 8.4% is completely insane from a macroeconomic point of view. Secondly, I would like to say a very small word about Greece, above all for our colleagues. I believe that it is important, in terms of democratic legitimacy, for our Parliament to closely monitor what is happening in terms of the implementation of the assistance programme for Greece. And I think we need to stop procrastinating. We have an economic and monetary commission, an employment commission and a REGI commission. Let us bring them together and summon - I have no other word - not only the European Commission, but also the Eurogroup, the European Stability Mechanism and Greece so that we can judge for ourselves the current stakes of the implementation of the plan.

name: Marco VALLI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I too would like to thank you for the opportunity to have this dialogue, because it is very important to try to understand what the future of this Europe and of this governance will be. As far as we are concerned, this Europe has failed profoundly because it has put profit at the centre of its economic ideology, not man and, therefore, not the whole economic and social situation, which is disintegrating. Democracy is reacting violently and we are seeing how, precisely, an attempt is being made to rebel against what is a technocratic imposition that is coming from the European Commission and the Member States, which only listen to the financial lobbies when they tell them to make a certain kind of reform – I have in mind the reforms in the world of work, which are further widening the social fork and inequalities : we are getting richer and poorer or more exploited.  This is the current situation, and I do not see any interesting reforms, for example in the field of taxation: countries with immoral conduct continue to do so, showing a very poor will to move towards real fiscal justice, precisely because the interests of multinationals are still being done.  This neoliberal approach is not working and will collapse on your head precisely because, by taking away the economic and monetary sovereignty of the countries, you are taking away the possibility of deciding on their own future, of being able to make economic manoeuvres that can really help to emerge from the crisis.  The direction the Commission is taking on financial deregulation is crazy. We have a system that is in danger of imploding and we are moving forward with systems that have proved to be bankrupt, such as the use of financial products to revive the economy instead of seriously regulating finance, making a real structural banking reform that separates business banks from commercial banks. These are the reforms that should be carried out, but they are being shelved because there are lobbyist interests which, I repeat, widen the fork and when there are so many poor people who complain, I repeat, everything will fall on your head and democracy will react violently.  So we absolutely must change dogma in order to be able to put man before him and not the interest of profit. That is the problem: not to aim for profit, but for the interests of society, the poor and those who are sick.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the ENF Group for his excellent work and for his excellent work. Thank you, Commissioner. The European Economic Policy Coordination Semester was introduced four years ago, together with the Europe 2020 strategy, and it is no more effective in implementation than this strategy. It was certainly well-intentioned, and it is important to coordinate economic policy, only that Europe's economic policy practice shows us that the European Semester does not seem to be a truly effective element of governance for the coordination of economic policy. With review I mentioned that the balance sheet of the Europe 2020 strategy; it is sobering: unemployment remains high – 9.8% in Europe, as we know from the Commission's autumn forecast – investment in research and development is too low and there has been no real progress in the fight against poverty either, and the aim of the 2020 strategy was to reduce the number of people at risk of poverty to just under 100 million. We are a long way from that.  Equally sobering is the results of the European Semester: only 11 percent of the country-specific recommendations are adhered to. We have heard it: nine Member States out of 28 do so. The review of the macroeconomic imbalances procedure discourages a few Member States from passing such macroeconomic imbalances. The same applies to possible measures in connection with an Excessive Deficit Procedure. Here, too, it can be said that some people make it easier. Crisis countries, former crisis countries that have been successful in implementing structural reforms, are making it. We have already heard this today, and the European Commission's autumn forecast has shown it: take Ireland, take Spain and Portugal, here we are on a growth course, here we are going up again, because the structural reforms have been implemented. This is not being done in other countries – regrettably – and because it is not being done, the European economy will not go up. Without structural reforms, without growth-friendly fiscal consolidation, there will be no further growth that Europe needs to get back on the road internationally and succeed and create employment.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: – Mr President, the 2016 Growth Survey is part of economic governance and it wants to uniformise economic policy for the Member States. The Commission intends to set the same objectives for 28 Member States. I quote from the question discussed in plenary in October, submitted by the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs: "The Member States are very different in terms of their social, economic and budgetary circumstances." "What flexibility is possible within national budgetary rules?" I can already hear the answer that will come with country-specific recommendations. Another report demonstrated that these Member States are not being respected because they are not responses to their real problems. I must therefore state that the European Semester of Economic Governance is a straitjacket for the Member States. It does not provide sufficient room for manoe d'2 for truly country-specific economic decisions.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: – Mr President, I would begin by welcoming Vice-President Dombrovskis and this work of the Commission in the prospects of the European Semester 2016 and, in particular, the focus he takes on the issue, in particular, of growth, structural reforms and the social effects that, of course, taking these measures together has on the different Member States. I would like to welcome all that work that has been done; to say that, in general, I agree with the Commission's guidelines and, in particular, with those pointing to the idea that all this work should be done with respect for fiscal consolidation. However, I did not want to fail to draw attention, at this very moment, to the particular situation in Portugal, where it has just been dismissed by the Assembly of the Republic, with full legitimacy, the Portuguese Government, but where an agreement was made by the forces of the extreme left with the Socialist Party, which calls into question, taking into account the figures that are presented, the balance that is , so far, has been followed in Portugal.  I am extremely concerned about the increase in consumption that will be done in a completely disorderly manner and therefore, in this sense, that we may be jeopardising all the efforts that the Portuguese people have made during these years and which have ensured a very significant decrease in unemployment, a growth which, not being exceptional, is relatively already inspiring and therefore drew the Commission's attention to these budgetary objectives and these overall policy objectives being pursued and that we should not throw away all the effort that the Portuguese population has made over these four years and that was having such promising and inspiring results, leaving Portugal, moreover, out of the excessive deficit procedure from 2016. All this is committed to the agreements made and, therefore, I would like to draw attention to this point. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162(8)).

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: It asks according to the procedure "blue card". – (2) I would like to ask Mr Rangel if he does not know that Portugal's problem is really unemployment, lack of demand, poverty and the miserable situation to which the Government has brought us with the help of structural reforms; and to explain to me, then, what is the contradiction between improving wages, improving the labour market, improving demand and economic growth and development, because if the European Semester has as a priority economic growth and development, tell me how to improve wages, pensions and demand is contradictory to this.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: Response according to the "blue card" procedure.  "It seems to me that what can happen is evident. Look, no one is against relief in the austerity situation. But the issue is a question of speed and gradualism.  We know that for the Left Bloc, which is a party of the radical left, which is really a party against the European Union, as we conceived it, and against the euro itself, as we have conceived it, that it is a party that is not concerned about the deficit, for whom one can spend, that it thinks that there should be a unilateral debt forgiveness of 50 % or 60 % , none of this makes sense.  Now, for those who are committed to the European objectives and the strategic objectives of the European Union, it is clear that this can be a disaster and we do not want Portugal to go to disaster and to return to the bankruptcy in which it was in 2011, which the Socialists have already put us there and now they are promising us again that it will happen.

name: Roberto GUALTIERI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Dombrovskis, as you mentioned and as the European Commission's autumn forecasts have told us, the economic recovery in the euro area and in the European Union will continue to be modest. Despite the fall in oil prices and the relatively weak value of the euro vis-à-vis other major international currencies, the positive growth rates we have in our economies manage to compensate for the huge losses accumulated during the years of the crisis, but fail to substantially affect the still present investment deficit and generate a substantial increase in the employment rate. In the light of this situation, it is essential to intervene with an appropriate policy mix, as my colleague Maria João Rodrigues has already mentioned. The right monetary policy choices that have already been made and those recently announced are certainly heading in the right direction. However, as Governor Draghi himself has repeatedly pointed out, monetary stimulus alone cannot solve the problem of anaemic growth. Fiscal discipline and structural reforms are necessary conditions for rebuilding investor confidence, attracting investment from abroad and improving the competitiveness of our economic system vis-à-vis the rest of the world.  However, relying solely on foreign demand to strengthen our growth is extremely risky. History, as well as the difficulties of the Brics in recent months, teach us that economic systems only become virtuous if they are able to govern their economic cycle on their own, without overly depending on fluctuations in world demand. This means working to relaunch all components of domestic demand, both consumption and investment.  Some countries, with the presentation of their stability laws, have shown that they want to move along this line and at European level many things have already been done, I am thinking, for example, of the Juncker plan, but much remains to be done. I therefore hope that the Commission will show the right degree of ambition in the preparation of the next annual growth survey.

name: Anthea McINTYRE
text: – Mr President, the Commission’s work programme for 2016, encouragingly, states that it is not business as usual. Many challenges are still to be faced in terms of economic recovery and cutting unemployment. Commissioner Thyssen indicated yesterday that progress is not unified across the Member States, and I agree. The Five Presidents’ Report recognises that there is no one-size-fits-all solution, which is something I very much welcome. The Commission has indicated its intention to develop a European pillar of social rights that takes into account the changing realities of Europe. It suggested that it start with the eurozone countries. That is, frankly, where it should stay. In his letter to Mr Tusk, the British Prime Minister outlined the two types of Europe – those that are inside the euro and those that are outside. The UK is outside, but we do not want to stand in the way of any measures that eurozone countries decide to take to secure the long-term future of their currency.

name: Cora van NIEUWENHUIZEN
text: We have already heard it from several speakers: if you want to drive the economy and really create growth and jobs, it is about fiscal discipline, it is about structural reforms and then you have a monetary policy at your disposal. We are now seeing Mario Draghi pumping 60 billion of some kind of financial growth hormones into the economy with the ECB every month. That does give some relief, but it's actually the same as a bodybuilder taking growth hormones. On the eye it all looks a bit better, but when you want to stop, there is nothing left if you have not actually trained and worked your body. In other words, we are not going to make it with the ECB's monetary easing policy alone. I would therefore urge the Commissioner not to let the reins be celebrated, either with regard to tight budgetary discipline or structural reforms. We simply cannot afford that. If we don't get through now, all the trouble was for nothing. Just when the first signs indicate that things are getting a little better, people in Portugal and other countries seem to think: well, it can go a little less. In Italy, Matteo Renzi has made statements that these reforms are politically clumsy. That may all be true, but if we really want to create economic growth again, they are inevitable and all countries will have to implement them.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: Mr Vice-President, well, first of all, I would like to calm you down a little bit. There is no need to be concerned about what is happening in Portugal, because what is happening in Portugal is democracy and should not cause strangeness in the house of democracy. With regard to the European Semester, it is in itself contradictory and brings profound contradictions. I would like to say, Mr Vice-President, if you would bother to listen, but, as you do not, I will say in it, that coming from a country where structural reforms have theoretically applied and have had an increase in public debt as never before, there has to be special attention to employment and social issues. But it is not enough for you to put it in your speech and say that you will pay that special attention when, at the same time, you say that structural reforms have to be implemented without any minimum change in adaptation to the country and the circumstances of each country.  Therefore, this application is nothing other than the generalization of precarious ties, very low wages, poor workers, immigration. These are the social consequences of labour market reforms, structural reforms. Therefore, this contradiction has to be resolved. Either it's more social, or there are more structural reforms. You cannot repeat the same policies without taking into account the results they have had.

name: Ernest MARAGALL
text: – Mr President, European Semester: we use it more to act as an observer-commentator than as a useful concealer and a common government. We contemplate the game of chess; we tell each player what he does well or what he does wrong; we sanction some behaviors, but not others; we formulate forecasts that are not always confirmed and recommendations that are not always met. The real deficit we face is European economic governance, global, democratic, responsible.  Everything seems to stay the same here: we have moderate growth," they say. We have some new problem, such as refugees, but we must continue with the usual policy: jobs and growth, structural reforms and fiscal balance. We want to believe, it seems, that it is enough to repeat the mantra of austerity so that everything ends up being solved. We insist on the misconception that problems lie exclusively in countries where specific symptoms appear: imbalances, imbalances, mainly deficits and unemployment; and in the also misconception that it is these countries that must and can solve them.  There is no deficit without a symmetrical surplus or debt without equivalent credit. Excess debt is an equivalent excess of credit. Insisting on claiming payment for what should not have been borrowed ends up drowning the debtor and dragging the creditor.  For this reason, the United Nations has just adopted in September the basic principles for sovereign debt restructuring as the only way to break the pernicious loops of "debt, austerity, more debt, more austerity".  We issue recommendations for each country and none for the common government: for countries, the European Union is guilty; for the European Union, countries are. Isn't it time to admit that we are all equally guilty and responsible?  Without resolving disparities, increased demand would grow deficits and debt in less competitive countries. If to contain these imbalances we maintain austerity globally, aggregate demand falls and unemployment soars. We will not get out of this loop without a European fiscal policy, both on the revenue side, now diminished by fiscal dumping between countries, and by that of spending diligently designed to increase supply where there is unemployment.  I conclude, therefore, with three pleas: to democratise European governance in order to put it at the service of citizens, to move quickly towards fiscal union and to apply it to the service of full employment as a common and shared objective.

name: Patrick O'FLYNN
text: – Mr President, for all the grand talk about investment and structural reform, the truth is this: that the European Union countries in general have experienced another year of paltry growth and are failing to tackle mass unemployment and, particularly, sky-high youth unemployment. To the extent that the vista ahead is any less bleak, the prime cause is not a sound basis for long-term progress; it is the belated application of quantitative easing across the euro area and the accompanying weakening of the euro. A few years ago one pound sterling was worth only EUR 1.10. Now it is worth EUR 1.40, and yet this exchange rate will surely merely further demonstrate the folly of holding so many divergent economies within a single currency. A somewhat weaker euro will tend to increase trade surpluses in Germany, while it will not be sufficient to stimulate recovery in Greece. After 15 years of failure, it is surely not too early for supporters of the euro to admit it has been a calamity. It has failed for precisely the reasons we sceptics forecast. Weaker economies on lower productivity paths have had economic activity sucked out of them while stuck in a fixed exchange rate with Germany. Artificially cheap money, loaned under the misapprehension that the might of Germany stood behind the borrowings of others, has destabilised economies across the euro area. Yet now you seem to want to integrate further to create a common treasury which will remove tax and spending decisions from national democratic control, and yet the productivity path of the southern periphery will still not match that of Germany. The southern countries lack the scale, the brands, the R&D budgets, the technical education, the smooth industrial relations, the communications infrastructure and the exceptional cultural reverence for work and organisation of Germany. You will need enormous and permanent transfer payments to compensate the weaker parts for living in this straitjacket, and yet the levels of social solidarity required for that will not be forthcoming. You will, I am afraid, have reawakened the latent national hostilities you hoped to banish and locked these countries into an age of economic stagnation. I am full of sorrow that you cannot see the folly of your ways.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am sometimes surprised to hear that the key thing to do to revive our economy is structural reforms.  Yes, there is certainly waste that has to be taken away and there is so much to do and to operate. However, it almost seems that we do not want to realize that there are policies, including international policies, that affect our economy: especially during this period we have seen it with the fact that the euro has fallen, with the fact that the energy bill has fallen, that the price of oil has fallen, and this has certainly given our economies some breathing room. I do not know whether these structural reforms will then give us the opportunity to revive the European economy, as they say. What I do know is that having done them and having had austerity has created serious problems, especially from the point of view of poverty, unemployment and the increase – especially in those countries most in difficulty in this respect – of taxes, which then caused business bankruptcies and therefore caused more unemployment.  Now those people who have made these great structural and economic reforms, and who have told us and forced us to do so, are now telling us that there may be an increase in the economy. By the way, it is curious to note that the countries of the euro area will grow less than the countries outside the euro, and this should make the Euro-enthusiasts, those who believe that the single currency is the most important thing, reflect.  I would ask you to reflect on other issues as well. For example, sanctions against Russia have caused economic damage. What are we going to do about China's want to become a market economy? Be ware, because if China has a market economy, that will mean that we will have competition in certain sectors that will be devastating. And then, as far as TTIP is concerned, some people say that it will increase our gross domestic product, but are we really sure?  Unfortunately, I fear, seeing certain strategies of the European Union, that this will be yet another rip-off.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: NI). Mr President, the European Union's autumn forecast for weak GDP recovery rates in the euro area and the European Union for all Member States foresees a greater intensity of unpopular measures, surveillance, memoranda and sweeping restructuring. The aim of the European Union and governments in the context of the European Semester is to further reduce the price of labour to enhance capitalist profitability in international competition. The European Union's decisions on refugees seek to supply the European monopolies with the hard-working force they currently need.  At the same time in Greece the government, by exempting business groups from insurance contributions and other charges, the recapitalisation of banks to ensure the financing of monopolies, is loading on the backs of the people even greater and exterminating taxation of workers, the self-employed, small and medium-sized farmers, with the demolition of the insurance system, auctions and exits from the first residence of working families. Tomorrow's strike in Greece is a response to all the material and an escalation step to recover losses in the direction of total reversal.

name: Markus FERBER
text: Mr President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work and for the work he has First of all, I look forward to working in the coming months. I have the honour of accompanying next year's Annual Growth Survey and all the resulting measures within the framework of the semester for the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats. We need to keep three points in mind: firstly, improving the financing environment. The autumn forecast of Directorate-General ECFIN shows that economic growth will increase moderately. In other words, further measures are needed to ensure that we can achieve a further improvement in growth. Measures on the capital market are necessary. In particular, of course, it is important to implement the Capital Markets Union quickly, and it is a question of addressing the banking union and banking financing issues in order to create a favourable refinancing environment. Secondly, as I would like to say at odds with many of my colleagues in this House, structural reforms are needed. We must move away from the idea that the state can deliver everything that people expect without any contribution being made, or that the states are no longer able to refinance themselves on the capital markets. That is why the key word is structural reform and competitiveness. On the other hand, however, we must also be careful not to have a downward quality competition. So when liberal professions are called into question – in Germany, for example – I have no understanding of it either. And we need a credible and responsible fiscal policy to ensure that the rules of the Stability and Growth Pact are respected. I hope that Portugal will be looked at closely here. However, I would also like France to finally be looked at clearly – France, which has been violating the Stability and Growth Pact for many years and is unable to achieve its own objectives. Appropriate action must be taken here. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr Ferber, I would like to thank Mr Ferber for his work on this I have heard that you believe that measures are needed to stimulate growth in the euro area. I did not even know that you belong to a party that pursues such centralist-dirigiste concepts. It used to be the case that there was growth in Europe without any action being taken. Today, other regions are still growing without government action. Why are you promoting this instead of simply concentrating on the forces of free competition and the competitiveness of individual companies?

name: Markus FERBER
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Look, sir, you can understand that in a different way. "Measures" can also mean that things are taken back, that market forces are released. I cannot share your interpretation of the concept of measures. However, I would like to point out that we in this House, in the European Commission and, of course, in the various capitals, have a fundamental question to resolve between supply policy and demand policy. Here, both systems always collide neatly. It will be a particular pleasure for me to take part in this in the context of the European Semester. In doing so, of course, I am relying on the support of all the wise economists of this earth, but only the wise ones.

name: Elisa FERREIRA
text: – Senhor Presidente, lamento que não me tenha sido dada a possibilidade de falar quando o meu colega interveio, o Sr. Paulo Rangel…  but in the meantime I will speak in English for the benefit of the Commissioner. My first sentence is just to confirm something. In spite of what party politics may inspire in my colleague, Paulo Rangel, I want to reassure you that the Socialist Party in Portugal has always been the most pro-European party and that the programme of the government that has been prepared as an alternative to the one that has just been dismissed complies fully with Portugal’s commitments in relation to Europe and, in particular, compliance in the governance framework. This is a reassurance that I do not think any party politics should put in jeopardy, and I hope and trust that, if this government is brought to power with the support, in the Portuguese Parliament, of the parties on the left, this is considered as a normal, democratic procedure and that as Commissioner, you will be thinking and acting independently of party politics. So this is something I want to reassure you on, and I really regret that after such a dramatic, negative attack on democracy and on his own country, Mr Paulo Rangel just left the Hemicycle and is not here for a complete debate. Having said that, I have other matters to which I would like to draw your attention. One of them is, necessarily, the need to reassess the other instruments, apart from monetary policy, that we can use to relaunch growth in Europe. This is somewhere where Europe is lagging behind when compared with the United States. The second is on the completion of banking union. However, the fact that this terrible attack on my own country was prepared and made here in this Parliament has forced me to diverge from my previous organised speech. But I hope you will be sound and institutional in the assessment of democracy and its consequences in Europe. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: It asks according to the procedure "blue card". – Well, until now, we do not know in Portugal any programme of the Socialist Party, contrary to what you said.  What I would like to know is very simple: if your lines of action, these five that have already been presented, increase public spending and reduce revenue, how can you guarantee at this time that we in Portugal will maintain the balance of public accounts and that we will fulfil our European obligations.

name: Elisa FERREIRA
text: Response according to the "blue card" procedure. – If you are talking about the programme which the Socialist Party has presented and worked on, and which has now been readjusted on the basis of a legitimate agreement, in accordance with the votes of the Portuguese citizens, you must say here, and confirm that you do not put at all at risk either the commitments to the fulfilment of the Stability and Growth Pact, nor the commitments to the MTO. This was the fundamental beacon in which all the proposals were worked on, and were worked in detail, which never existed or existed in the EPP program, and did not exist or existed in the coalition program for Portugal. And that is regrettable, is that you talk about politics [...] (The President withdrew his floor to the speaker.)

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Mr President, Commissioner Dombrovskis, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and for the work she has I have heard you speak many times. But I have to say that I keep hearing the same thing from you. Sometimes I almost get the impression that you are always taking the same manuscript that you read, because I never get an answer to the question: why is it that the eurozone is not growing properly, because why are we still floundering in the sixth year after the crisis, while the United States of America is already on the upswing? It's not because it's down because deer is low. It is not because of oil, because that is cheap. It is not because of interest rates, because they are low. It is not up to the raw materials, because they are cheap. All the foreign economic reasons do not count here. What we are seeing, however, is that in the European Union, in the euro area, unemployment is very high in some countries and very low in others. What we are seeing is that some of the debts are very high and sometimes very low. What we are seeing is that economic activity is partly good and sometimes very bad. Mr Dombrovskis, it is because some countries are competitive and others are less, some are productive and others are less so. But everyone must operate in the same market, at the same prices and with the same currency. That cannot be done well! We must dissolve the euro – that is the only way to solve Europe's economic problems.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: – Mr President, since everyone is talking about Portugal, I will just put in my two cents as well. I think Social Democrats across Europe are in shock that a modern party has formed an alliance with the extreme left and the communists and people who are against NATO. Europe is in great danger, and I hope that you will take responsibility for your actions and that, in a few years from now, you will take responsibility and own up to what you have done. I think you have acted in bad faith. Commissioner, I welcome the streamlined European Semester process, but I will never get tired of repeating that the single marketplace is of major importance in growth creation. We really need to make it happen. We need a single market pillar in the European Semester. I will be very specific: we need to press for full implementation of the Services Directive. Services can really bring us a lot of benefits. Structural reforms of products, services and labour markets in Member States are what will get us out of the crisis: better-functioning, less bureaucratic and more digital public sectors.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: Mrs Ferreira, I regret not being able to give you the floor because there are many speakers inscribed.  This House has to end today, not tomorrow, and it is therefore not possible to give it the floor, especially since this is a debate at European level, not exclusively Portuguese.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, Mr Dombrovskis, your general speech and weak and fragile growth cannot hide the great failures of the unilateral austerity that you have been applying for years in the euro area and the great divergences. Poverty has increased, unemployment has increased, inequality has increased, public debt has increased, investment has fallen. And because we are here to answer specifically, I ask you: are Germany's excessive surpluses, Mr Dombrovskis, in breach of European rules? Yes or no? Why is the Commission not taking action on them, too, as it deals with excessive deficits? You say that transparency and democratic accountability and the role of the European Parliament should be strengthened. Then why are you denying the role of the European Parliament in implementing these legislative initiatives for the proposals you published on 21 October, and when will you finally accept the programme for Greece, as requested by the European Parliament, not only behind closed doors in the Commission and in the Eurogroup, but also in the relevant committees and plenary of the European Parliament?

name: David COBURN
text: – Mr President, it seems to me almost laughable that the EU is to publish a report on growth when it is at the centre of Europe’s relative global decline. The EU is about nothing more than the erosion of national sovereignty and the centralisation of powers in Brussels. And what is Brussels but an autocratic, bureaucratic Leviathan wallowing in red tape and destroying any competitiveness that Europe could possibly have with regulations on everything imaginable? At the centre of this political project is an economic anomaly, the euro. This currency never was – and never will be – an economically-sound project. It was a political project and not an economic project. While this may make the federalists here feel fluffy and warm, it certainly does not make the people of Europe feel fluffy and warm as they are entering into an economic crisis. For the stifling of Europe’s competitiveness and the euro as the common disease, the only medicine with a hope of curing Europe is a euro exit and a return to the original currencies. Thankfully, the case for the UK is not so dire. In the last five years the UK has generated more jobs than the rest of Europe put together. Unfortunately, the Brits are not feeling the benefits, because of endless supplies of cheap European labour flooding our markets and reducing our standard of living. This is also increasing the housing problem. We have a housing crisis in the UK, and we have to build a new house every seven minutes just to keep up. That is a scandal, and we cannot have any more of it. There are only two ways to sort out the UK housing market: firstly to increase supply and, secondly, to halt open-door European immigration. Now that Cameron’s pathetic list of demands – well, rather pleas, really – have finally been published, we know definitively that free movement of people is not up for negotiation. It may please UKIP ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: Mr President, Commissioner in your communication of 27 October, you say that it is the results that matter and not the good intentions. So let's look at your results!  You want to maintain confidence in the Schengen area, but it has collapsed under migratory pressure: borders are re-emerging everywhere. You want to put people back to work, but you are the one who is putting them out of work by your ultra-liberal policy. You want to protect public health, but you give in to the lobbies that spread endocrine disruptors. You want to reconcile the economic with the social, but you do the opposite by selling your soul to the wildest financial capitalism.  You want to ensure the survival of Europe, and now, rest assured, Europe will survive, but it will be without you, Commissioner, because it will be the Europe of nations.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI). Mr President, the Annual Growth Survey for 2016 is tangible evidence of the difficulty of european policy implementation. Fiscal consolidation programmes, sustainable development plans, the creation of quality jobs and the Juncker Development Plan are, a priori, doomed to failure.  Economic distortions between Member States, the economic crisis, the emerging market crisis, the slowdown in world trade and uncontrolled illegal immigration need brave decisions and policy change. So far the results of the implementation of the reforms have contributed to undermining the European social model and ultimately to the loss of public faith in the European idea.  A great example is my country, Greece, of the three memorandums. For five consecutive years, the troika fraternity has been demanding more austerity, pension pay cuts and spending cuts. Is it true that a German or a Frenchman can live on a three hundred euro pension or five hundred and fifty euro salary The propaganda of the European media is limited to the grossly false wrong texts of the Greeks. The Greeks pay the cheques of the European Union with the blood of innocents.  The so-called democrats accuse the nationalist parties of fascism. In Greece in cases we say folk "the donkey said the cock's head".

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, you said that the commitment to structural reforms must be renewed. I can't agree more with you.  Spain is an example: it has been one of the most ambitious countries in terms of structural reforms and there are the results. We are the country at the forefront of economic growth, we are the country that has gone from destroying, not more than two years ago, half of the jobs that were destroyed in the European Union to creating more than half of the employment that is created in the whole of the European Union.  Therefore, I insist: there are the results. But we must not forget that the social dimension of economic and monetary union must also be strengthened. We can't forget about it, ladies and gentlemen.  And finally, this progress will be of no use if we do not move forward in providing greater democratic legitimacy to the whole European Semester process. If we don't, we'll be acting with our backs to the citizens.  (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr President, I would like to thank my colleague for his work How do you think international developments could contribute to the European Semester, for example the WTO negotiations now in Kenya, if trade facilitation is effective? Could this not also lead to additional growth?

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: "blue card" response. – There is no doubt that some of the economic growth is explained by the boost of exports.  In the Spanish case, we have moved from a serious trade deficit to a trade surplus and that is undoubtedly the result of the trade agreements being pushed by the European Union, but also thanks to the important agreement that could be implemented at the next WTO Ministerial Conference to be held in Kenya.  I therefore welcome the words of Mr Rubyg and have no doubt that this is the only way.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: Mr President, I am sorry that Mr Ferber has left, because I would have liked to reassure him about the state of the French economy and to question him on his assessment of the Spanish economy, which Mr Zalba has just described, where obviously his political friend, Mr Rajoy, had to benefit from complicity in not being called to order as to the situation of his economy. , in light of this famous stability pact. Mr Vice-President, you are not presenting us today with the annual growth review, so it is time to send you a few messages and in particular to give you the following idea: in principle, you will present the recommendation of the euro area; we want to make it a tool for macroeconomic debate among politicians before the Spring European Council. Do not make it a statistical tool to conduct no political debate and simply strengthen the application of the rules in deficit states. We want a tool that will allow us to organise the real economic policy debate that we need, the one that - in line with the Juncker plan - will allow us to examine the situation in terms of investments in the euro area, the situation in terms of convergence between economies, the situation in terms of the fight against tax dumping and the ability to carry out real tax harmonisation within the European Union. I ask you, Mr Vice-President, to conduct this debate within the document that you will present to us next week.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: Mr President, Mr Dombrovskis, I would like to thank mr Dombrovskis for his excellent work and for his excellent work. The European Union has always been very talented in making grand plans. Not only the European Semester, but also the Europe 2020 strategy paint a beautiful future. But the reality is different and mostly sobering. Their plans are unrealistic and therefore useless. They often even hurt, for example, the Juncker investment programme displaces private investment. There is real damage. Or your fine plans for debt, which are at odds with the monetary policy of the European Central Bank, which is flooding the southern countries with money, and France is always taking on debt instead of reforms anyway. You pinch regularly. What Europe needs are principles, not plans! For example, less bureaucracy, the same yardstick for everyone and adherence to their own rules – that will bring much more for the future!

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: – Mr President, Europe, the European Union, remains stagnant, despite a favourable exchange rate, of the low energy cost, despite a colossal injection of liquidity by the European Central Bank, which totals, it is good to say, almost half of the GDP of the euro area. There is no such thing as a solid recovery in the economy, as the weak level of private investment attest. As for the European Semester, the European Commission still does not want to call into question the rules, even though the overwhelming majority of countries do not respect them. It notes that the vast majority of recommendations by countries are not followed but, instead of questioning these recommendations, it prefers to blame governments for their non-implementation and thus proposes, in practice, mechanisms to increase pressure on national states in order to impose their neoliberal view on economies. While preaching democratic legitimacy, it creates anti-democratic institutions, such as fiscal councils which, in practice, will only strengthen the mechanisms of interference that prevent any possibility of alternative development.

name: Dariusz ROSATI
text: – Mr President, I am very happy that we are having this debate ahead of the publication of the Annual Growth Survey, because it gives us a unique opportunity to convey our views to the Commission and actually, I hope, to influence the Commission’s thinking on policy priorities for the next year. On those priorities, I fully agree with Vice-President Dombrovskis. I think the priorities as formulated this year will also remain valid for next year – that is, number one: investment; number 2: structural reforms; and number 3: fiscal responsibility. And to all those who do not like fiscal responsibility, I would like to assure them that these are precisely the means and the instruments, not the goals themselves, but the means and instruments to accelerate growth and create more and better jobs. There are still some weaknesses in the framework, and weakness number one is of course the very low rate of implementation of CSRs in Member States. I think we are going to hear from the Commission how it wants to incentivise Member States in order to ensure better implementation. The other weakness is the lack of national ownership, and this is again something we have been talking about for quite a long time. I would like to see the proposals from the Commission aimed at increasing national ownership. There are also some new threats ahead. We see that growth is still weak in the European Union. We are lagging behind the US in terms of recovery, and there are also new risks on the horizon, like slow growth in China and geopolitical risk. Mr Vice-President of the Commission, all of this requires ambitious and determined effort. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: blue-card question. – In fact I was listening to our colleague, Mr Rosati, and I thank you for accepting the question. Speaking about more jobs, social security, growth and so on, I would like to ask him his opinion on whether the Commission should have to take into consideration the lack of crisis management response, considering the migrants that have come, are still coming, and will come in the next year, to Europe. How will this influence the growth of European employment and so on?

name: Dariusz ROSATI
text: blue-card answer. – I do not think this is directly relevant to the macro-economic political priorities for the next year, but this certainly is one of the most important challenges ahead of us. We are definitely making progress in addressing this issue. We are not just talking now about distributing refugees across countries, but we have started to talk about creating safe zones around Syria; we are talking about hot spots and about better controls at the external borders. But certainly the economic impact of refugees is a mixed issue; to some extent refugees can contribute to economic growth, and we have many examples of those contributions. On the other hand, the whole process has to be controlled better in order not to create chaos.

name: Alfred SANT
text: – Mr President, the Commission is right in seeking to streamline and prioritise the approach of the European Semester. However, the political rhetoric used to frame and run initiatives has an influence that extends beyond their scope. On the issue of taxation, for instance, the need for Europe-wide action should be restricted to the need for transparency. Widening this approach to open the way for tax convergence and harmonisation is outside the present scope of the Treaties. It is also counterproductive, since it further limits the flexibility of the regions and peripheral countries which most need it. So I would agree to all measures intended to ensure transparency in the assessment of tax dues, but not to measures that contribute to tax convergence and harmonisation. First, there need to be viable programmes that really compensate for the growing economic divergence between the centre and the periphery of the European Union. Too often, EU programmes are assessed on whether they contribute to greater or lesser union. This focus is misplaced. We should be asking all the time how programmes will directly benefit citizens – which citizens, how, when? – taking into account national realities and avoiding one-size—fits—all solutions. With the right answers, asking whether we need more or less Europe could become irrelevant. There is no better way of generating growth in Europe.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, the European Semester is an undemocratic institution aimed at limiting the rights of national parliaments to decide sovereignly on how to shape national budgets. In Greece, since 2010, the troika has abolished all power of the Parliament to exercise its sovereign rights to shape the state budget. The troika of memoranda has turned Greece into a huge social cemetery with millions of poor and huge armies of unemployed.  Memorandum three passed by the Memorandum of Understanding SYRIZA, ANEL, SW, PASOK, POTAMI dissolves the insurance system, cuts pensions and salaries, makes a tax resalto in the pockets of the Greeks, hammers the homes of my fellow citizens and dissolves the agricultural sector.  Mr Dombrovskis, on your recent visit to Athens you insisted on the pursuit of this harsh memorial policy. So be aware, Mr Dombrovskis, that the Greek people no longer tolerate troikas and memoranda and with the general strike of 12 November it sends you a message of resistance and struggle.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: – Mr President, I think the Commission seems very concerned that the Government of Spain will not meet the deficit targets. We will look forward to your opinion on the rest of the budgets to find out whether the Spanish Government has emerged to you or rather the European Semester is the one that raises impossible demands.  In fact, we believe that the European Semester is a method of 'discipline' of austerity that violates the popular will of our states. In any case, much more than the level of deficit or the level of debt, we should be concerned as an absolute fact about the unbearable level of unemployment we endure in my country: more than 25% unemployment. And this lasts about seven years, which is unusual in our economies.  Such a fact cannot be sustained on paper and in its economic models, but as a social reality it is unbearable. 20% of unemployment means more social exclusion, more poverty and more young migrants. This is not our Europe, this cannot be the Europe we are building.

name: Joachim SCHUSTER
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent report and for the In recent years, the European Semester has not only been the framework for European coordination of economic policy, but has also been the means of enforcing a neoliberal economic policy. This policy has proved to be wrong: economic problems have not been solved, and the social division has deepened. I believe that Mr Dombrovskis has said this in principle by announcing that the annual economic report will state that, despite the extremely favourable environment, there is only subdued growth, high unemployment, and that far too many people live in poverty or are at risk of poverty. It is clear that the absolute priority that austerity policies place on fiscal consolidation is wrong. And if one had not only approached economic policy with an ideological drive, one should have already known that austerity cannot overcome a crisis.
