And only for the German colleagues, who sometimes take this particularly vehemently: Germany, too, did not overcome the crisis by fiscal consolidation from 2008 to 2010, but we launched a comprehensive economic recovery plan in Germany, supported the banks, extended short-time working, and we financed this by significantly increasing new debt. This is why it turns out that you need a change of course in the European Semester. The promotion of growth, of investment, including public investment, must be given to the centre of attention. For a change, this could be financed by combating tax avoidance and tax evasion – the only key word is LuxLeaks. We need to combat precarious employment, and we need to include the social impact of our policies much more in reporting.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: – Mr President, I wonder whether the Commissioner heard the remarks of the Irish Taoiseach Enda Kenny at the PPE conference in Madrid recently? I wonder, Commissioner, did you hear him describe the arrival of the Troika in Ireland as a bloodless coup, and I wonder if you agree with him? Undoubtedly, the Taoiseach’s remarks were more about absolving his own government’s responsibilities of continuing the Fianna Fáil agenda of crippling austerity that has financially devastated Irish families and, in fact, devastated our domestic economy. Joined by the EU institutions, it has been an agenda that has forced the Irish people, representing 1% of the EU population, into 42% of the costs of the European banking crisis. While the Commission and the Irish Government celebrate economic growth as a vindication of their agenda, do you, Commissioner, know that in Ireland we have a severe crisis in our health services, for example? Do you know that Ireland has an unprecedented homelessness crisis? Will you accept, Commissioner, that the EU economic agenda that is epitomised by the European Semester is a failure driven by a political ideology that has put the interests of financial markets ahead of the needs of citizens, and in fact has devastated our economies?

name: Esther de LANGE
text: – Mr President, I think that anyone in this House who has children might actually know the story of the very confused, very mixed-up chameleon. He tries to be every colour at the same time and every animal at the same time, and in the end he is not even able to catch a fly. If I listen to this House, we are trying to turn the Commission into a very confused chameleon. We want to push them further to the left, further to the right, we demand that the country-specific recommendations have more focus, including on social issues, and then at the same time we complain that not enough elements are taken on board when preparing these country-specific recommendations. If I listen to this House, we not only want this Commissioner to be a European politician but also a Portuguese one. I think that in last year’s Annual Growth Survey there was a very smart triangle of reform for competitiveness, budgetary responsibility and investment – and may I remind you that that is not only public investment but also private. I hope that this so-called holy triangle or trinity will remain in next year’s Annual Growth Survey. Of course, this House rightly has demands. We demand more political oversight in the future, for example though the adoption of convergence guidelines. We want checks and we want balances in the process of making economic policy. So for my part, the European Fiscal Board could have been more independent than is currently proposed. But I warn colleagues that we will not get any of our wishes respected if we forget the foundation which is this holy trinity. So, reminded of the chameleon, I would like to say to this Commissioner: stay on course, remain yourself, and move steadily but carefully forward.

name: Anneliese DODDS
text: – Mr President, I hope that as Commissioner Dombrovskis drafts the new Annual Growth Survey, he will rectify two major problems with its predecessor. First, last year’s report ignores the disaster of competitive wage devaluation. The economic evidence speaks for itself. Where there has been recovery, in many cases this has been driven by exports, with the notable exception, of course, of my own country, the UK, which has an appalling current account deficit. Across much of the EU, demand from domestic consumption has stagnated, and it has often stagnated because wages have stagnated or even fallen. Increasing the incomes of the least well-off people across Europe is one of the most effective and sustainable ways of promoting growth. I hope this will be acknowledged, rather than dismissed, in the new report. Second, last year’s report only promoted the involvement of social partners in implementing decisions – decisions that were taken by others – yet trade unions in particular often play an essential role in increasing workforce skills and productivity. Five minutes from where I live, there is a factory that produces three mini cars every minute. Trade unionists in that factory, working hand-in-hand with management, have introduced radical innovations, both in production methods and also in management of the workforce. Commissioner Dombrovskis, we have got rid of many relics from the 1970s: flares, kipper ties and Abba have all gone, whether we like it or not. Please can we also get rid of outdated attitudes about trade unionists and put them right back at the heart of decision-making around the economy, where they belong.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: – Mr President, I think it is important that the Commission takes note of two things in its Annual Growth Survey. One is the change in and the challenge of the global economy. When I listen to the debate in this House, it is as if the changes in the global economy are not there – we are maybe looking at the internal market but not at the external one – but the fact is that it is very much the increased supply, increased productivity and increased competition we see today in the global economy that is the challenge to the European economy. Where we lack competitiveness we are also suffering increased deficits, and that will not help with the increased spending. And that is the other thing to take note of in the survey report: that wherever you are trying to perform a policy without considering the realities of the global economy, by leaving the rules of the Stability Pact you are undermining the national economies. That is a very clear and obvious pattern. Where you have stabilised public finances and fiscal stability, you have in most parts of Europe growth or growth has returned, but where you are trying to solve the problems by increased spending, you get increased taxes and increased deficits and less employment. That is the truth and we need to know that. That gives hope for Europe, because then we see what to do; maybe less hope for Socialists.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: S&D). Mr President, addressing the Commissioner, I expect you to put on your headphones because I want you to listen to it, I am firstly expressing my disappointment, because while we are talking about strengthening democratic accountability and legitimising the democratic process centred on the European Parliament, Commissioner, your Commission is modifying the tools of economic governance without the legislative contribution of the European Parliament - and this is not a matter of opinion , it's a fact.  I now continue on the subject of development. While we have macroeconomic conditions which are favourable, the investment element is absent and the element of serious and long-term investment is absent. The Younger project is indeed a proper policy involving public money with private capital and the SNT has played an important role in this direction but we are still waiting. And using eurozone recommendations to ensure that the level of investment in the euro area is the right tool.  But I am also addressing a colleague I have heard say that the European South has been flooded with Money from the European Central Bank or something. I don't think he's watching. The European South has been flooded, my dear colleague, by the souls of the persecuted who are dying and by children washed up by the sea. So wake up!

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: – Mr. President, this debate before the very beginning of the new Cycle of the European Semester is an opportunity to highlight all that is good and insist on it in a new cycle, but also to highlight the weaknesses that we must address together. Good and quality changes are simplification of the procedure, orientation to a limited number of most important priorities, earlier publication of analyses by Member State.  What are we missing? Strong political will at Member State level is lacking, stronger partnership with local and regional units is lacking, the inclusion of national parliaments is also lacking. I hope that in the new cycle of the European Semester we will make better progress in strengthening these elements. Countries must independently design measures and activities to meet the European Semester objectives and recommendations.  However, there is no need to waste time trying and making mistakes, when at the same time other Member States have already been looking for the best solutions. Sharing experience and knowledge in implementing reforms, accelerating investment, strengthening competitiveness, sound financial management, smart fiscal consolidation and more is our great asset in the European Union.  And that is why I welcome the incentives from the European Commission to help Member States through the establishment of a structural reform support service, a competitiveness committee and a fiscal board. Togetherness and partnership can help what we lack, which is the implementation of the European Semester.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: – Mr President, for the fourth time, this Parliament has been told that it is actually discussing a single instrument of economic policy coordination in the European Union. Indeed, this is where we see the meaning of this new instrument, because it gives us the opportunity to interpret the progress or regression of the economic policies of the various countries in a single structure. Obviously, in the case of budgets, growth, employment, i.e. competition policies, comparisons are really necessary, because otherwise we will never understand what makes the difference in European wages almost 20 times, depending on which corner of Europe we are looking at, and that is also where the problems arise in terms of taxation.  I accept, believe, that tax policy is a very important instrument in the hands of all governments. At the same time, there may be cases, such as food, where it would be worthwhile to pursue harmonised policies only in the interests of the people, european citizens. Well, what is the current experience, and this is a new phenomenon compared to the progress made so far, is that the European Commission is almost displacing the European Parliament by restructuring, restructured the logic of the European Semester. It leaves the European Parliament much less time to do its work, and in doing so, we must say, gives European citizens less opportunity to have a say. The five presidents' reports also stated the need for more democracy, and believe me, Commissioner, democracy has never harmed or harmed the development of the economy.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: – Mr President, as I see it, this discussion is about jobs and growth. It is about how to make our economy more competitive and able to meet the new challenges ahead of us. Some say we need to turn challenges into opportunities; for instance that the migration flow can increase regional growth and help us address labour market productivity and demographic challenges. I am actually unsure how straightforward this would be: without the skills and competences, asylum seekers could fall into irregular employment, with disruptive effects on the labour market. We must remember that challenges are not always opportunities and that they must always be carefully addressed at the same time. What we need to do is make Europe’s economy strong enough to respond to difficulties if they arise instead of simply looking at the best-case scenario for the moment. This means serious structural reforms in places where they are most needed, and investing in Europe’s growth. One point I would very much like to emphasise: making the investment plan truly European is also key to the European Semester. It must support the Member States and regions that were hardest hit by the crisis and those with fewer internal resources. It must also invest in value-added areas, such as technology, innovation, digitalisation and small businesses. This, in turn, means that the investment plan for Europe must absolutely go hand in hand with the Capital Markets Union, the European single market and the development of the digital single market. Therefore, I call on the Commission not only to ensure the continuity of its policies, but also to enhance the link between its separate initiatives.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Mr President, the European Semester is one of our most important tools in tackling structural weaknesses, achieving sustainable growth and healthy finances, and promoting the competitiveness of the European economies. The recent emphasis on employment and social aspects can also be considered very welcome steps towards creating a better balance between the economic and social dimensions of EU governance. Nevertheless, despite the efforts of the Commission towards streamlining the process, the potential of this instrument in delivering economic reforms in the Member States cannot be truly exploited as long as the implementation rate of recommendations is as low as at present. Considering that only around 9% of the country-specific recommendations were fully implemented by the Member States in 2013, I am eagerly looking forward to the measures that the Commission intends to take in order to increase the national ownership of CSRs and to improve their implementation so that we can reap the full benefits of the European Semester in the future.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: – Mr President, I would ask you to confirm that I do not have time to speak, since my group's indication that I would have a minute and a half to speak as Parliament's rapporteur for the Committee on Employment, on a list that has been corrected and in which the coordinator of the Committee on Employment did not intervene. I'm asking you to do that check, please.  (The President responds to the speaker.)

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Mr Ribeiro, I am very pleased if you speak, but you were not on the list of speakers. If you wish, I give you the floor, we certainly have an extra minute, so you can speak. But then talk to your group, because they did not communicate it to us. Catch-the-eye procedure

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: – Mr President, I am glad to know that the Commission wants to make more use of the defence of social issues in this annual growth survey and we need to address problematic structural issues such as unemployment, youth unemployment, long-term unemployment, poverty indicators and an ageing population. As rapporteur for employment, this European Semester aims to defend the balance of a social and market economy in order to be able to respond to internal and external challenges in the European Union. Understanding that it is in this line where greater competitiveness contributes to greater social justice and that this greater social justice stimulates, on its own, competitiveness and, therefore, people have to be sure, they have to have a guarantee that they can predict and organize their lives and this is only possible if we can ensure the sustainability of public accounts , fiscal responsibility and budgetary balance.  I am also glad to know that the Commission intends to do different things differently. We must fight for the Union in Europe that stimulates social cohesion by paying particular attention to the most disadvantaged regions so that we are not a two-speed Europe. This is the responsibility that is required of us.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: There are many interventions. I am in a position to give the floor to everyone, but no one must exceed one minute, because otherwise someone will not be able to speak.

name: Ana GOMES
text: – Mr Rangel tried to call into question the democratic legitimacy of a government on the left in Portugal that, in keeping with European commitments, tries to correct the devastating drift of austerity that has dramatically impoverished the country, forced more than 500,000 Portuguese to emigrate in the last four years and has not reduced, only increased, public and private debt.  But, Commissioner Dombrovskis, are you wondering if the European Commission is not ashamed of the inequality actively fostered by the policies that the Troika has blessed in Portugal, including the 2012 tax amnesty, which served to wash, legalise and keep billions in tax havens, without even forcing them to go through, despite being the product of tax fraud and evasion and corruption?  Or still do not see the scheme of benefits and tax exemptions that, in total opacity, the Portuguese Government has continued in these four years, favouring large companies and large capital, while burdening taxes on those who work.  Will the Commission use the European Semester to correct regressive and obscene tax policies in Portugal and other Member States with pro-European, pro-growth, pro-social justice and fiscal justice policies?

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The data provided show that the Union is slowly coming out of the economic crisis. Economic growth has taken place in most Member States and unemployment has decreased in 23 European Union countries. This year has brought with it events that will certainly determine the economic situation in Europe in the coming years. It is becoming increasingly clear that China, one of the engines of the global economy, is starting to experience huge problems. Many European companies will have to review their growth strategy and, perhaps, reduce employment. The second problem, which will certainly cause significant economic repercussions, is the influx of refugees into Europe. No one is currently able to estimate what the consequences of this labour market process will be in the Member States and what the budgetary costs will entail. These labour market consequences and the increase in budgetary expenditure will certainly have to be taken into account in the Framework of the European Semester. Stable growth, which guarantees the creation of jobs, is extremely important for labour markets. Our priority should continue to be to maintain the sustainability of member states' public finances while financing well-thought-out structural reforms with long-term positive effects on the economy and employment. It is also necessary to deepen integration within a common market based on the free movement of workers, services and capital.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Mr. President, the European Union's competitiveness on the global market has fallen significantly in the last decade, with more Member States crying out for structural reforms that would restore their economic stability. In this context, the objectives of the European Semester are a major step forward. But if we were to view the European Semester as a medical procedure by which we want to cure the European economy, we could say that the correct diagnosis has been made, but ineffective therapy is prescribed. In Croatia, real structural reforms have not been implemented since independence, and membership of the European Union and participation in the European Semester have led to the adoption of exclusively firefighting measures, often only for pre-election purposes.  That is why I believe that we need to work more significantly on implementing concrete measures in the Member States, rather than focusing on setting noble targets that, if ever achieved, will certainly not be within the planned deadline. It is precisely time that Croatia and the European Union do not have.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: " Mr. President, what we need is simply economic growth. What the European Semester needs to be focused on is tackling unemployment, and of course we can only do that with real economic growth.  In this context, I want to make it clear that we need a complete synergy between member states, local and regional self-government units, all European institutions, including the European Investment Bank, other financial institutions, and what I particularly want to highlight is the high expectations that the economy and the Member States have from Juncker's future fund. All these elements must be together, they must give synergy in order to reach economic growth and in order to really make this small recovery that is felt in some places, and sometimes not, still allow Europe to get back on its feet and thus finally see the economy in better shape.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, for another year we are here to discuss with the Annual Growth Survey. Let us actually discuss how the budgets of the euro area Member States will be mutated to serve the supposedly free market. In other words, they serve the hegemony of the market, thus intensifying social and labour inequalities. In some Member States they even say that unemployment has fallen. At the same time, however, precarious work is now the rule, not the exception. Poverty is increasing in Europe and the distribution of wealth is increasingly concentrated in the hands of the richest. As a GUE we insist that the European Semester should be abolished. Member States must regain the right to formulate their budgetary policy, which is of a strong social nature. The Stability Pact must also be abolished. We need a real Employment and Growth Pact based on social criteria that will benefit the peoples of Europe. Far from the logic of memoranda and the violent deregulation of work. Finally, we insist that public investment must be made to create sustainable and quality jobs and support the social state.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, thank you particularly for taking all of us in the catch-the-eye. It makes us feel valued and makes it worthwhile for us to stay here for the entire debate. Yesterday, the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom, Mr Cameron, outlined his requests for reform within the European Union. He put emphasis on one point in particular: competitiveness. He is, of course, absolutely correct because, without it, we are not going to be strong in Europe, we will not have growth, we will not have jobs, and we will not have influence in the world. Certainly there have been many instances in the past where we have regulated – maybe in isolation, sensibly – but it did have a very negative effect on competitiveness, and that certainly needs to stop. He is right in that regard. The other aspect is, in relation to the Semester, that it is an opportunity for us to ensure there is proper discipline in budgets, etc. in the Member States. For that reason, the first Member State that steps out of line must be dealt with because, if they are not dealt with and they get away with it, everything will fall apart again.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, consolidating Europe's economic recovery requires further and decisive political commitment. Many Member States face challenges such as high public and private debt and lack of investment, which continue to lead to high unemployment and deteriorating social conditions.  Member States must work to ensure economic recovery by implementing responsible budgetary policies and encouraging investment through the removal of funding barriers and the full implementation of the Juncker Plan.  However, investment and fiscal responsibilities must be compatible with sustainable economic growth and the creation of quality jobs. Employment policy must be improved as a matter of priority in order to ensure greater social cohesion. The new six-month period must, in my view, be opened up in the name of employment and social issues which, only if dealt with in the right way, can lead to a reduction in the poverty rate and an increase in domestic demand.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: – Mr President, I hear my colleagues say that supporting wages, improving social benefits, recognising labour rights, etc. is bread for today and hunger for tomorrow; that these measures do not work in the long term. And I ask: what does the long term mean to you?  Eight years have passed since the start of the crisis and, where reforms have been implemented more harshly, growth remains below other developed economies or the world economy; where austerity has been applied there is more unemployment and public debt continues to rise. Spain is a clear example of this. Don't you realize you're getting harder and harder to keep this charade going? Review Roosevelt's New Deal or Lord Beveridge's "full job" and do what they did in times of crisis: stop sacrificing workers to maintain a failed project like this Europe of finance.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: PPE). Mr President, Vice-President Dombrovskis, in my country Greece the Commission's autumn forecast figures are extremely worrying for our future, despite the looming recovery of the euro area: a recession of 1.4% in 2015, a recession of 1.3% in 2016, unemployment of 25.7% in 2015, unemployment of 25.8% in 2016. In such an environment, the Commission must encourage structural changes, showing that their implementation ultimately leads to relief for citizens. At the same time, you have to address the issue of the competitiveness of each country individually taking seriously the assessments of the National Competitiveness Councils. In Greece there is no room for wage cuts, there is no room for reductions, there is room for reducing government spending, there is room to cut red tape and to increase the absorption of EU funds.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, we are speaking about the Annual Growth Survey 2016; we are talking about strategic investments in Europe in order to create jobs and to bolster the Member States’ economies; we are talking about labour and social market policies – but what kind of recovery, what kind of growth are we going to have, taking into consideration, once again, the challenges that Europe and the European Union will have to face in the near future? You know that our growth – our very small growth – has been built mainly on exports, not on big infrastructure projects, not on big investments in Europe, and especially in Central and Eastern Europe. There, as you know, we are very far from the levels existing in Western Europe, especially regarding infrastructure and harbours, airports and so on. Once again I would like to ask the Commissioner to give us an answer: what is going to be the European Commission’s influence on European development, taking into consideration that the European Commission is moving money to cope with the influx of migrants in Europe?

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, today we are talking about growth that is supposed to be based on the three pillars, investment under the Unger plan, structural reforms and fiscal stabilisation. But in reality, the Younger plan is over-optimistic, not to mention utopian. Structural reforms consist of deregulation of the labour market and the insurance system, i.e. a reduction in consumer purchasing power, which means that a recession is under way. Finally, fiscal stabilisation does nothing but ultimately raise the ratio of public debt in relation to Gross Domestic Product, through the recession it is causing.  We need something different, something that emphasises job creation, and to make this a precondition, in particular, for small and medium-sized enterprises, which will create employment, to have equal access to credit from banking systems with the guarantee of the European Central Bank, i.e. with bail out and not with bail in as is currently the case for the banking systems of the Member States.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, first of all thank you very much to the honourable Members for their input, which I have duly noted, and we will continue the debate after next week. We will be presenting the annual growth survey (AGS) in detail in a joint meeting of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON) and the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs (EMPL), so I will be doing this together with Commissioners Thyssen and Moscovici. The European Semester package is specifically designed to shape discussions between EU institutions and in the Member States, including with national parliaments. The various documents will therefore be the subject of debate with the Council, the Eurogroup and this Parliament, and the ensuing common understanding will shape the remainder of the 2016 European Semester. Now let me come back to some of the specific questions which were raised during the debate. First, on strengthening the euro area dimension. Some concerns were raised as regards the practicality of this approach, but here I must note that we are doing this, of course, while respecting the rules in the Stability and Growth Pact, and our intention is to very clearly communicate this also in our documents. A number of questions were raised on strengthening the demand side of the economy, including by investment and consumption, and this was certainly among our priorities in the last European Semester and will remain so in this European Semester too. There is an obvious need to strengthen the demand side of the economy as well as the questions which were raised concerning strengthening the social dimension, reducing inequality, reducing poverty – these are important policy goals. As I said too in my introductory remarks, strengthening the social dimension within the European Semester is one of the work directions we are pursuing, and we will continue to do so in the next European Semester. Some questions were raised on tax policy, including on tax fairness and the effectiveness of the tax system. Here it must be said that the Commission’s recommendation to the Member States typically is to shift the tax burden away from labour – especially low paid labour – to other tax bases which are less detrimental to growth, such as property, consumption, capital. So this emphasis on actually reducing the tax burden – the tax wage on low paid labour – should also contribute to tax fairness. There were probably a number of other issues that were raised, but to give a rather more general summary, I think the approach we are now preparing in the next European Semester in the Annual Growth Survey is a balanced approach which takes into account different concerns, and we hope it will also ensure sustainable and balanced economic growth and strengthen job creation, something we need in Europe very much.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This debate on growth and the 2016 package of measures to achieve this in Europe via the European Semester is just another mirage, and we know in advance that the proposed solutions will not change anything. Austerity, mass immigration, ultraliberalism, the single currency and submission to finance have ruined the European Union and none of these policies challenge these dogmas.  In addition to this debate, I would like to express my indignation at the fact that the European Parliament has authorised the holding of a plenary session on 11 November in Brussels, which will oppose the respect of its principles of respect for The Member States' public holidays. While the Great War has claimed 9 million lives in Europe, we must respect the duty of remembrance that the Union flouts, so I have decided to leave the Chamber and not take part in the votes. One author said that "Those who know the past are best able to build the future", it seems that today the Union quickly forgets its history.

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The Annual Growth Study published by the European Commission starts a new cycle of economic governance each year and includes the EU's economic priorities and policy guidance for Member States for the following year. The starting point for the 2016 growth analysis in preparation is the 2015 targets, in which the Commission recommended an economic and social policy based on three pillars: investment, structural reforms and fiscal responsibility. The priority has been and is to ensure europe's return to sustainable jobs and growth. However, it is worrying that, despite efforts, the economic recovery in the EU weakened significantly in 2014 and the unemployment rate in the euro area remains at a record high of 12%. Investment has fallen by around €470 billion since 2008 and the investment gap is estimated at around €230-370 billion. Clear progress is needed in the fight against high unemployment and poverty. Growth across the EU can only be ensured if cooperation between Member States and structural reforms are put in place. Decisive action is needed at national level with the participation of the parliaments and social partners of the Member States. The principle of fairness of public accounts must be the basis for the creation of national and European budgets in order to ensure economic stability in the EU.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. – The 2015 Annual Growth Survey, presented last year, recommended pursuing a social and economic strategy based on three main pillars: the pursuit of fiscal responsibility; a boost to investment; and a renewed commitment to structural reforms. Even though some of the objectives have been achieved and others are ongoing, I believe it is essential for 2016 to introduce also new concepts in the context of the new social and economic situation, namely: a clear social dimension in the policies implemented by the Commission; to refocus investments on the creation of growth and jobs, and especially sustainable growth and decent jobs; a policy regarding migration issues focused on long-term solutions and security of European citizens; and the development of new cooperation mechanisms that strengthen the European dimension at different levels of the EU society.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. – In my opinion, structural reform and compliance with the rules of the Stability Pact are particularly necessary.

name: Theodor Dumitru STOLOJAN
text: in writing. – The European Commission launched the new European Semester for 2016 by publishing the 2016 economic growth forecast. The good news is that the European Union's economy is growing in 2016. The bad news is that this economic growth of 2.0% in 2016 is below that which the US will achieve. Therefore, the economic gap between the US and the European Union is growing and the causes are clear: the European Union is delaying structural reforms to relaunch the competitiveness of the European economy. For example, the major European banks are only now announcing their real restructuring, labour mobility is still being obstructed in some Member States, and the burden of European and national regulations is putting European firms at a disadvantage compared to US ones. The British prime minister's call for competitiveness is welcome.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. – During the recent economic crisis, it appeared necessary to ensure better economic governance and more effective policy coordination between EU Member States. That is why we are debating the European Semester today. However, I fear that certain political decisions have nevertheless slowed down. It is important that we start implementing the objectives of the European Semester. Since mid-2013, we have been able to record weak growth, but the EU recovery is below expectations. The solution lies in the start-up economy, new jobs, increased investment and the well-educated and skilled workforce. If we are to achieve all the main objectives of the European Semester, we must tackle the challenges we face in an integrated way. I therefore also call on my country to actively engage in brain drain, as the outflow of the young population will have many consequences for them, namely the impact on social systems, social security, pensions and healthcare.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. – The European Union remains stagnant. Despite a favourable exchange rate, the low energy cost, despite the ECB's colossal injection of liquidity, which accounts for almost half of the eurozone's GDP, no solid recovery of the economy is envisaged, as the weak level of private investment attest.  As for the European Semester, the European Commission still does not want to call into question the rules, even though the overwhelming majority of countries do not respect them. It notes that the vast majority of recommendations by country are not followed but, instead of questioning these recommendations, it prefers to blame governments for their non-implementation. And thus, it proposes in practice mechanisms to increase pressure on national states in order to impose its neoliberal view on economies.  While preaching democratic legitimacy, it creates more anti-democratic institutions that only answer to the Commission and will strengthen, under the cover of a neutral and scientific investigation, all interference mechanisms that prevent any possibility of alternative development by Member States.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing. – As is apparent in this year's annual EU Growth Survey, Europe is still a long way from finally exiting the crisis. It is obvious that we need to do much more.  Structural changes are necessary, but in themselves they are not enough. We need to encourage investment in every way. Unemployment rates, particularly in the countries of the European South, reveal the scale of the problem, but also the impasse that the Union has found itself in recent years. Such coveted new jobs can only come through the strengthening of small and medium-sized enterprises, the reduction of red tape and the access of businesses to bank lending.  It is certain that if the cannula of business loans does not open soon, any economic recovery plan will be doomed to fail.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission statement on the future aviation package (2015/2933(RSP)).

name: Violeta Bulc
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, let me start by saying that I am really pleased that we are here today in order to discuss the upcoming Aviation Strategy for Europe. I really welcome the interest Members have put in this topic and I am pleased to see that our views and assessments converge in many aspects. As you know, aviation is a strong driver of economic growth, jobs, trade and mobility. That is why a strong and competitive European aviation sector plays such a crucial role for the EU economy in delivering on the core priorities of the Commission. Europe must maintain its leadership position, in the interests of its citizens and its businesses. The Commission warmly welcomes the support for this approach in Parliament’s draft resolution and the emphasis put on the aeronautics industry as a major contributor to EU growth and jobs, and on innovation as a prerequisite of a competitive and sustainable aviation sector. We fully agree with the call for a long-term strategy for Europe’s aviation sector. Therefore, the upcoming Commission initiative on an Aviation Strategy for Europe, to be adopted on 2 December, will stand as our contribution to help shape the future of the EU aviation system in a comprehensive, holistic manner. Regarding Members’ specific demands, and considering that our work is still ongoing, please allow me to highlight several points. First, in relation to the global perspective, the global aviation market is changing – it is reshaping. We should not be afraid of that but should engage and play a major role in shaping this new world. In this context, I agree with Members that it is essential for EU aviation to be well equipped to compete with strong players in the global marketplace. We face new and relentless competition from regions such as Asia and the Middle East. I just came back from the Middle East today and I can only confirm that. By pursuing an ambitious external aviation policy, the EU could greatly contribute to that, notably through negotiating comprehensive EU-level air transport agreements with key third partners. In particular, market access should be based on a regulatory framework which promotes EU values and standards, enables reciprocal opportunities and prevents distortions. I welcome the call for measures which can effectively address distortive market behaviour in international aviation, which is why the Commission is currently considering new measures to address unfair commercial practices from third countries and third country operators. Second, the internal market. From an internal market perspective, we see that, whilst some airlines continue to struggle with problems, other airlines are doing quite well. Similarly, whilst large airports are profitable, smaller airports struggle to make money. So, despite the industry performing well compared to other world regions, overall financial performance unfortunately remains mixed. Against this background, we have taken a close look at the EU’s regulatory environment. We know that further improvements are necessary to make the sector more efficient, provide stability to investors, encourage new research, innovation and technical solutions, and ensure safety is maintained to its current high level. Third, EASA. I am confident that the proposal to revise the EASA Basic Regulation will allow EASA to continue its good work while adapting to the evolving needs of citizens, industry and regulators. The main objectives will be to introduce new mechanisms for more efficient safety oversight and new methods for more risk-based, proportionate and performance-based rule making. Within this revision, we intend to lay down the basic legal framework for the safe development of all drone operations in Europe, in proportion to the risk. I would like to congratulate Parliament on its work on its report on drones. The fourth issue: social matters. There are many social matters that need to be addressed to ensure competitive and sustainable growth in aviation. I fully agree that we must maintain leadership in aviation, including through a highly-educated, qualified and experienced workforce. At the same time, new businesses and employment models have emerged; their consequences on employment should be looked at closely. An active and comprehensive social dialogue is therefore really essential in this regard. Fifth: improvements and innovation. We welcome the highlighting of the importance of implementing the Single European Sky. SES2+ is an important enabler for modernisation of air traffic management and also ensures better safety oversight of air navigation services. Furthermore, it allows for improved capacity and environmental performance, less congestion and delays for passengers, and reduced costs for the aviation value network. Regarding SESAR, we now have a coherent project, governed by a strong legal framework, driven by innovative partnerships and supported by Union incentives, that is capable of deploying innovative air traffic management concepts in a coordinated manner. Therefore, we agree and share Parliament’s desire to implement SESAR as quickly as possible. For this reason, I can only echo the dissatisfaction with the legislative files on aviation that are still pending – the Slots Directive, Single European Sky 2+ and Passenger Rights. Parliament’s political support is highly welcomed. The sixth topic: the environment. We must deal with the environmental impact of an ever—expanding sector. I am confident that innovation and technical solutions can contribute to a reduced carbon footprint for aviation. I witnessed this myself at the recent Paris and Dubai air shows. The technology is here to serve. At the same time, the EU has put in place powerful regulatory tools to address CO2 emissions. In ICAO, we need to play a critical role towards developing a global solution. We will do everything to enable this to happen. I believe that by working together we can ensure a strong European aviation sector, and I look forward to hearing Members’ views on this.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I think that the Commissioner has already said how important this mode of transport is, which provides connectivity, mobility, economic development, jobs. I think you can see what can happen without this mode of transport even these days, when there are strikes and it creates the big problems that are created in such situations. That is why we must support this industry in absolutely all areas, starting with infrastructure, with airports, with regional airports, with new infrastructure, because airports need this, and then with airlines, to which we need to provide a fair environment for competition. To do this, we need global agreements with the main states, with the main areas that comply with European rules. In particular, I hope that you will receive a mandate from the Council to start negotiations with the Gulf countries. We need the SES (single European sky), just as you said, but you must also insist that these dossiers be unlocked. We need the implementation of SESAR on a new airspace architecture, not the one that it is now. Otherwise, it would be a waste of money and time. The ESA Must get into the role, get the very important role, and internationally we have to have one voice at ICAO. Of course, the social aspect is important. No industry works without people. I insist on unblocking the files. The dossiers that are currently being blocked in the Council are extremely important, and I would also ask you to use what we, the European Parliament, voted on in those dossiers in the new package that you will propose in December.

name: Ismail ERTUG
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. You mentioned much of what we share, Mrs Bulc: the European aviation industry, with 5.1 million employees, contributes approximately EUR 365 billion a year to the EU's gross domestic product. In this respect, the importance is very great. Nevertheless, we have problems with international competitiveness – that cannot be denied. Today we are deciding what we, as a Parliament, expect from the European Commission in the air transport package. We know that European airlines are exposed to strong international, global competition, which, it must also be said, gains a certain competitive advantage through state support in various ways, whether that is the Gulf States or countries in Asia. However, we should not respond with foreclosure, but rather with a smart and proactive strategy to establish a level playing field for all. We want cooperation based on fairness and transparency. That is why we would like to see the revision of Regulation (EC) No 868/2004. Internally, too, we must first do our homework in order to achieve various objectives internationally through the air transport agreements. In this context, I would also like to mention the social aspects of the European Union. As you mentioned, Commissioner, we need well-trained, motivated workers. But we also have a lot of precarious jobs in this area – whether it's zero-hours contracts or pay-to-fly – and various other things that we need to improve. In this matter, I would also suggest that we do our homework here first and then involve the others internationally.

name: Jacqueline FOSTER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteur for his work on this resolution. I shall focus on the content of that, and of course the effort he has made to gain support across the groups. But whilst we agree with a great deal of the content, unfortunately there are three key areas which we cannot support. The first is in paragraph 7 and the reference to competition issues. In my view, it is not the EU’s role to determine how third-country global carriers run their businesses or are funded. Provided they are complying with the terms of their air service agreements and international obligations, we are not in a position to interfere. This approach would without doubt seriously damage the credibility of the EU, and it would also undermine our businesses. My second point focuses on the social agenda section. We stress that the aviation industry is recognised as a growing sector that has attracted and provided highly-skilled and motivated professionals, and that in order to continue this trend, current employment legislation on working conditions, standards and practices, including collective bargaining, should be maintained. Unfortunately, the additional paragraphs are extremely overly prescriptive and go into details on employment contracts, job location, etc, which are issues that come under the auspices of national and EU employment law and are not directly dealt with in the Committee on Transport and Tourism (TRAN). Thirdly, paragraph 23 makes a reference to EASA’s role in ICAO, and whilst fully supporting proper recognition of EASA as an extremely effective safety agency, I should stress that we do not support a single EU voice in this area. Worldwide, individual countries are contracted directly to ICAO under the Chicago Convention, and therefore I do not support the removal of the representative from each Member State. To conclude, these are the key reasons why we have tabled a separate ECR resolution, and we will be unable to support the joint resolution at this time. But we would like to thank the rapporteur and we do look forward, Commissioner, to receiving your proposals in December.

name: Gesine MEISSNER
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ALDE Group. Mr President, Commissioner, thank you very much for the input you have given and your recent impressions of your trip to the Gulf States. It is very important, because it has already been said that the air transport sector is a very important economic factor in Europe, and of course it is very important to us, because many jobs are also attached to it, also indirectly, that we maintain this sector well and strongly. At the moment, we really have various things that we need to make possible: firstly, of course, it is a question of achieving more innovation and, for example, making this possible with new energies and new materials, for example. Three years ago, I got an idea of what the plane of the future looks like, that it flies with seaweed fuel, for example. We are far from that far off, but we must see that we are really making research in this area possible. We need aircraft that are quieter, we also need the opportunity for frequent flyers to go through the security controls more easily, a lot of things that we can achieve. I am convinced that we need global solutions to emissions trading, and we naturally need a solution for competitiveness. As has already been said, it is true that not only the Gulf States, but also others, are making competition for European airlines some whatsoever, and we must see how we create opportunities. It has already been said that we should re-examine this Regulation (EC) No 868/2004 and see whether or not we are actually well equipped to deal with unfair conditions. This should be put to the test – and I am absolutely in favour of this – but at the same time it is also important to consider, we not only have the airlines, we also have jobs at airports and we also have jobs in the aircraft industry, in the aviation industry. I believe that when the Commission comes up with the proposal later, we must ensure that we have a sensible, balanced proposal as a solution on how we want to improve Europe's competitiveness in this area. This is, of course, also possible through air transport agreements, as we have mentioned in our joint resolution. A few more points that I would like to mention: working conditions are of course also important, we need attractive jobs and good training, and we also need good safety options for passengers and crews, too, in order to find satellite systems and aircraft whenever they really have a problem, better provision for the mental health of pilots and also the possibility that new systems for communication between aircraft will also take into account small aircraft. Finally, I would like to stress that we need a single European sky, as we have stressed. We want to work on this and we very much hope that we will succeed in the future.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, I would first like to refer to the social issue in aviation in line with the Commissioner's intervention. Consumers are also or, rather, are first and foremost producers and any benefit achieved by the erosion of their social and working conditions cannot be considered a real benefit. I mention this because aviation, and in general transport, is one of the sectors most affected by social dumping. The situation is so serious that it affects even air safety, as recent studies have reported.  I therefore ask the Commission not to delve into the liberation of the aviation sector at the expense of workers, as already raised in agreements such as the ACS or in its commitment to the single sky. We must start from the prior harmonisation of wage conditions, job security and collective bargaining, or quality employment will continue to be destroyed and working conditions forced down. I take this opportunity to express my solidarity with air france workers in their recent conflict.  I would like to raise two additional issues. The first is public property: in connection with the liberalization of the sector, we have seen serious privatizations of airlines and air infrastructure in recent years. We oppose these privatisations because, as the case of AENA in Spain shows, they are real scandals: a gift from the public to financial investors with the support of the Commission.  Finally, a note on climate change. The aviation sector contributes greatly to global emissions and, at the gates of Paris, I would like to ask the Commission to intervene in this regard as well.

name: Karima DELLI
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, aviation is the most greenhouse gas-emitting mode of transport. Per passenger and per kilometre travelled, this mode of transport is three times more harmful to the climate than the car. Imagine that a round trip from London to New York generates about as much greenhouse gas as a single person to heat for a year. And yet, bizarrely, this transport is tax-free: no tax on kerosene or no, or little, VAT for cross-border flights. It's simple, airlines are the champions of the tax gift. We're walking on our heads! Is it normal that kerosene is the only fossil fuel that is not taxed? And why are trains overtaxed, when the air is not, or so little? The result, since 1990, has been that as airfare has decreased, airfare emissions have increased by 110%, and they could even triple by 2050 and take us well beyond 2oC of global warming. With less than a month to go until COP 21, the end of recess must be sounded. Finally, let us tax kerosene like other fuels and end it with the minimum VAT in the air sector. The other challenge is social. The air force has become an economic jungle where all moves are allowed: zero-hours contracts, fake independents, mailbox companies. Employees must have rights guaranteed by EU law. Mrs. Bulc, I trust you. You told us last June that you will not look away from this issue. So let's go, let's end with social dumping and tax dumping in the air, which are always at the expense of employees. Let us reopen Regulation (EC) 868/2004, which has never been implemented to combat unfair tariff practices. Finally, let us put airlines like Ryanair, Norwegian Airlines and others on the right by forcing them to respect the law. This regulation must also enable us to combat unfair competition from Gulf companies. Qatar, Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates provide their airlines with tens of billions of euros in state aid to gain control of the air market. How do you want European companies to follow? New regulations are needed against state aid and unfair tariff practices that distort competition. So you see, ladies and gentlemen, we face three challenges when we talk about aviation: the climate challenge, the social challenge and the international challenge. They need to be raised today. The EPP resolution does not answer this at all, but the resolution of the environmentalists brings concrete solutions. Failing that, it is still the planet, employees and consumers who will once again pay the price.

name: Daniela AIUTO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the best European airline of the last 5 years, according to Skytrax, is not from a Member State, but turkish airlines. The world is changing and air routes are moving more and more from our continent to Asia, via the Middle East. If we look around, in fact, the largest airlines, in terms of passenger volume, are Emirates, Qatar Airways, Etihad and precisely Turkish Airlines. We cannot fail to acknowledge the failure of European strategies and policies, which see, among other things, an increasing presence of third-country capital in our industry. I am thinking, for example, of what happened in Italy with the sale of a large part of the capital of Alitalia, our former flag carrier, to Etihad, which has been resold to us, among other things, as a great success of the Renzi government, in order to remedy the many shortcomings and bad managements of past years. But what is the result? A weak, non-competitive industry, bewildered by a lack of planning at the level of flows, hubs and local connectivity. We wonder at this point what the Commission intends to do: reverse the trend of past years and give new vigour to European industry, protecting it and protecting it from foreign companies, or marking its inexorable decline?

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, in the preamble, I would like to make it clear that I am rather circumspect about the single European sky. The best intentions of the world may well be included, I fear that under the pretext of simplifying the operation of European civil aviation, we will end up creating a gas plant, hit by gigantism and lacking greatly flexibility. However, the resolution we are proposing to address to the Commission seems to me to be interesting on a number of points. First of all in terms of security, and of course we are always in favour of strengthening security, regardless of the field. The uniqueness of civil aviation, which I am familiar with having worked for 35 years at Air France, requires that the safety requirements be maximum. It would be more than time for action by the civil aviation authorities to take action on, for example, the medical follow-up of flight attendants, following the Tragedy of the Germanwings Company.  I am pleased that the joint motion for a resolution calls for supporting the competitiveness of European airlines, we cannot actually stand idly by and watch our historic national airlines, which are part of our country's heritage and influence, sink. Of course, efforts must be made by everyone, including employees, but our companies will not survive if they are not finally put on an equal footing with their competitors, especially the companies of the Gulf countries and Turkey. The latter are heavily subsidised, it has been said, by their governments, not to mention indirect aid, such as exemption from social charges, almost free fuel or exemptions from airport taxes, all of which weigh heavily on European companies and cannot be compensated by any aid, since the Commission prohibits them in the name of the same competition.  Unfortunately, ladies and gentlemen, you are not going to the end of that logic. By recommending to the Commission to accelerate the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions, you will inevitably increase the already heavy constraints on our companies and thereby penalise customers, since inevitably the price of airfares will be increased again by one or more taxes.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI). Mr President, the air transport sector has all the conditions for it to become an important factor in the economic development of the Member States of the European Union in the near future. For this to happen, however, the relevant strategy of the European Union must be amended so that it can meet the challenges of the present and the future.  Firstly, the industry will have to become competitive in order to cope with the economic pressures it is under from airlines from countries outside the European Union. Important steps in this direction are tackling unfair competition, upgrading flight safety and finally the possibility of adopting high-end and environmentally friendly technologies.  Jobs should also be increased, and staff working at airlines should be highly qualified and able to assimilate modern technological developments.  Finally, the Member States should also take the necessary legislative measures to strengthen the efforts I have mentioned.

name: Wim van de CAMP
text: Firstly, I would like to express my gratitude to My Colleague Marian Marinescu, but also to Ismail Ertug and Gesine Meissner, for the fact that we in Parliament have succeeded in putting forward a clear and clear resolution in the field of aviation. I can tell you that expectations are certainly high in the PPE Group. On 2 December, we really want to receive an innovative and competitive piece which shows where Mrs Bulc wants to go with the European aviation industry in the coming years. I now understand that it will actually happen on 2 December. I would like to cite four elements. First, competition. In fact, the European aviation industry is already too small. We must be able to compete at world level. But that has to be done in a fair way, and as you know, we have our doubts as to whether that is the case with some Far Eastern countries. So that is a big concern. The second point concerns innovation. The European aircraft industry, as well as developments in drones and satellite systems, are of enormous importance to European industry and we must cherish and promote them. The third point is the social agenda. In the aviation industry, things are sometimes going well and Europe needs to look after its social agenda. And finally, safety. Safety of the aviation industry is and remains a challenge for us and Mrs Bulc, as we saw recently in the accident in Egypt, although it was actually more a question of security there.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I would just ask you, when you carry out the development of the package we expect by the end of this year, to keep in mind the 850 million passengers flying on European territory. So we ask you to ensure, because you are already urgent, for the rights of passengers: the right to safety, comfort, accessibility and, also, that of the defense against companies that boast today of mistreating their passengers , and the others, in case they sneak, go after. We also ask that you consider the 500,000 workers and professionals in the sector: under the strong pressure of so-called competition, we have young pilots today who not only do not receive their wages, but pay to work so as not to lose their license, or to a cabin crew who are chaining weeks without returning home , with all that it means. I know you're sensitive to that, and I hope you'll consider them. And finally, consider European citizens: territorial cohesion, the ability to access nodal but also regional airports and all aspects related to the impact of industry.  We need a strong industry that builds, also recycles when do the recycling of aircraft, and also an industry that is competitive.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for Airlines today face many competitive challenges , both internally and globally. The internal market is primarily a series of legal, financial and constraint provisions, such as, for example, an intra-EU emissions trading scheme, which clearly weakens Europe's fleets. Personally, I am counting – and I ask you very much, Commissioner – that the Commission's Proposal in December, which will be presented, increases the competitiveness of the sector and presents a long-term strategy for its development – for the aviation sector.  In this context, I would also like to emphasise the very important role of regional airports, as in my constituency, in my region, the port of Jasionce, which today is in a complementary network and absolutely predisposed to ultimately be a very important port relieving the large ports in my country. I therefore ask you, Commissioner, that this proposal, which we are waiting for, be a proposal that will make a strategic contribution to the development of the aviation industry in the European Union.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: – Mr President, I appreciate the fact that the Commissioner appreciates the resolution. It looks, Madam Commissioner, as though we are heading in the same direction and there is a large degree of overlapping. I find the resolution is a balanced one. It is not perfect, but I think that we have set out the objectives. Let me first reflect something that some of my colleagues have said. It seems to me that the fact that some airlines are not doing well is not the fault of the airlines or of the national Member States. We always had the EU to blame for it. Certainly we need an aviation package. Clearly, we will have to address the burden. We will have to have a look at the internal market and we will have to have an equal level playing field, as you have said. If there is state aid somewhere, we have to address it. The Commission will have to make the effort. But protectionism is not the way out. I do not think that this is what we should be doing. I must say, Madam Commissioner, that we are impatient too. We believe that if the seven points that we have outlined are well elaborated and developed, there would be a solid basis for our interaction. I am looking forward too, but I think that the principles should lead to real competitiveness and not just protection, and I am sure that we are on the same page on that.

name: Nikolaos CHOUNTIS
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, as we await the Commission's final proposals on air transport, we are asking, among other things, that all kinds of privatisation in the air transport sector be banned. At this time in Greece, following the imposition of the blackmail memorandum, the government is proceeding with the sell-off of fourteen regional airports of enormous tourist importance with the approval and pressure of the Commission and the Eurogroup. These airports are under the jurisdiction of Fraport, which is owned by the German State and Lufthansa. In this way we have an economic imperialism and an economic humiliation of Greece, since with the contracts that will be signed Fraport will have the upper hand in the Greek tourist market. It will bind the Greek property for forty years. It will bind the Greek State to colonial-style contracts and will eventually have the upper hand in the pricing policy of the other state airports.  The Greek people, together with tomorrow's general strike in Greece, are fighting to force the Greek government to stop bowing to the colonial demands of the lenders.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: I wanted to greet the large public and point out that there is no distraction on the part of Members: this is a very specialist debate with the Commissioner and with the Members who are members of the relevant committees, in particular the Committee on Transport, on the future of aviation. Then the Chamber will soon fill up, because today is voting day.

name: Markus PIEPER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. European aviation is under pressure: industrial action, emissions trading, taxes, special levies, passenger rights, subsidised competition. The consequences are dramatic. European airlines have cut 20 000 jobs in recent years alone. That is why the airlines need to do so, which is why the industry needs a blow of liberation. First of all, it has to take care of this itself. Innovations, outsourcing, mergers – these are painful adaptation processes. But Europe, too, must improve the framework conditions. The Commission, Mrs Bulc, must finally take competition law seriously and intervene in the face of unfair competition. Please not just announcements, not just communications, but legislation, Commissioner! The Member States must finally agree to the efficiency and environmental improvements of a single aviation area – Single European Sky. Church tower thinking is not appropriate in the sky, ladies and gentlemen! Parliament needs to think even more about whether we have something to offer, in addition to unilateral burdens, requirements and emissions trading, that strengthens competitiveness. We are taking a first step today. There are many important, good points in the motion for a resolution in terms of technology promotion, fair competition and competitive airports. These are good, very good tasks for the Commission. We look forward to the next steps you will take!

name: István UJHELYI
text: – Mr President, I, too, welcome the Commission Member, because this is a debate in which we seem to need to work together. I myself am one of the voices of the tourism sector in this Parliament, and I would like to comment on this issue on behalf of some two million businesses and on behalf of more than ten million workers. The tourism industry – and not just the association of airports, not only hotels, but all the industry trade associations with which we keep in touch on a daily basis – says that Europe is still the world's number one tourist destination, but that this could easily change in the coming years. We have two big hurdles. One is our visa system, and parliament will soon be discussing the new visa package system. The other is aviation regulation and the barriers preventing tens of millions of new tourists from third countries, such as China, from being welcomed in the coming years. The new aviation regulations are also important for maintaining jobs and the tourism sector.

name: Peter van DALEN
text: Unfortunately, this Parliament is trying again to undermine its own credibility. Everyone knows that the European Commission has written and completed the aviation package, but we are now, shortly before the European Commission's presentation, coming back with a laundry list. Too bad for all the trees that died for this waste of paper. We look forward to the Commission's presentation in a few days' time and I hope that the package will cover three aspects. Firstly, a level playing field for aviation, both within Europe and in competition with Middle Eastern airlines. Secondly, security when flying over high-risk areas and also when checking in baggage, such as at high-risk airports, in particular Sharm el-Sheikh, is closely monitored. Finally, that it describes fair working conditions and prevents dumping practices such as norwegian air. I look forward to meeting this package.

name: Dominique RIQUET
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, this motion for a resolution, which we support, shows you how hopeful and impatient Parliament is in a sector that has been said to be important. Nevertheless, there are still a number of concerns about issues such as passenger rights, slots and the single sky, for example, because the Council remains focused on defending sovereignism and corporatism. It has prevented legislation from moving forward. Will the new Aviation package move the Member States forward? My second question is this: at a time when we are entrusting new responsibilities to the European Aviation Safety Agency, is it reasonable for the Commission, like the Council, to propose to reduce its budgetary and human resources?  Finally, participation in the growth of the airline industry has been a tremendous lever for us, following a movement of significant efforts in research and innovation. The "Aviation" package should therefore accompany this momentum and not bury it.

name: Luis de GRANDES PASCUAL
text: – Mr President, thank you for your presence, Commissioner. My initial words can only be of praise to this Resolution and its content. It seems to me that this sector needs a new impetus to ensure its sustainability and competitiveness, as well as the strengthening of European companies, airports and the aeronautical industry.  The fact that this resolution is endorsed by three important groups in the House is, in our view, a guarantee of a certain diagnosis of the problems afflicting the sector.  With regard to competitiveness, the Commission should take into account reciprocity in relations with third countries. Forecasts must be made for a sector that has very high-skilled jobs.  Finally, it is inexcusable to emphasise safety, which must be reinforced, Commissioner. We look forward to the Commission's own measures and its proposals.  Having said that, there is one issue we cannot avoid: paragraph 28. In the Spanish delegation of the EPP, we know that it is a section which, although it does not cite Gibraltar, contains the old mantra of blame for the use of Gibraltar airport an alleged blockade that is non-existent.  This is a problem of sovereignty, Commissioner, and therefore neither the Commission to which it is urged nor the Council to which it was urged have anything to say.  This is a problem between two sovereign states, the United Kingdom and Spain, which are still in dialogue and will settle their old conflicts, which has nothing to do with this issue.  We look forward to continuing to discuss and fix our problems with the UK, if you are right to stay in Europe, which we fervently want.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I think it is very important that we have an aviation package in the near future to identify the challenges facing the sector, the aim of which must be to strengthen airlines and airports. In view of the expected increase in traffic and competitive pressure at European airports, an effort by the Council is needed to ensure that the proposal for a regulation on the allocation of airport slots is approved as soon as possible. With regard to the aviation package, it will be important to promote and enhance the implementation of the Single European Sky in order to ensure optimum use of airspace and to meet the needs of all users. The positive impact of this package will also affect the tourism industry because it will facilitate travel planning.  Liberalisation must not, however, be at the expense of social and security standards, given the recent news events that must not be quickly forgotten.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for The steady increase in the number of passengers travelling by air is a cause for pride and undeniable success for European airlines. However, customer confidence and the increasing price availability of this mode of transport have splendour and shadows. The European Commission rightly wants to address the problems of the present and future of this sector by designing an aviation package. However, such a set of regulations must not hamper the dynamic development of the European aviation industry, in particular by imposing a significant financial and administrative burden on entrepreneurs.  First of all, we need to take care of the safety of pilots, passengers and ground handling and find a way to eliminate air traffic risks early. It is also important to support innovation, which is the key to building effective air control tools. We should, albeit more sensibly than before, invest in infrastructure, both in airports and in road connections that improve communication between airports and urban areas.  We must also ensure that European airlines are not unfairly pressured in the global aviation market by competition that does not accept free market rules. I would like the Commission's proposal to respond to these challenges.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the European Union has a new opportunity with this package on the aeronautics industry to show that we are able, above particular interests of some States, to take advantage of the opportunities that the Union opens up to our entrepreneurs, businesses and citizens. And that is why the definitive implementation of the single sky is necessary, the measure that can contribute more and better to the efficiency and sustainability of our airlines. In addition, only together can we, in a global market like this, have any option to avoid unfair and external competition against airlines and aircraft and component manufacturers, and avoid bad internal practices that impair conditions of employment in the sector and can harm safety.  Looking inwards, we need to reduce administrative burdens, integrate air transport into an integrated mobility system that combines, with a single ticket, the aircraft with other modes of transport, that integrates regional airports in the supply and that, to meet increasing and demanding demand, drives innovation at all levels, from airport management to the creation of applications aimed at the end customer.  That is why, Commissioner, we look forward to your proposal with great interest.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna ŁUKACIJEWSKA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for The aviation industry contributes significantly to economic growth, employment, the development of tourism and its accompanying services, people-to-people contacts, citizens' mobility, as well as the regional and social cohesion of the European Union. The aviation sector provides more than five million jobs and contributes nearly EUR 365 billion to European GDP. These figures show how important and forward-looking this sector is, and at the same time we are aware of the many problems this industry is facing in Europe. We should therefore take action, which, on the one hand, aims to ensure fair competition, to create a good network of connections, to ensure the safety of passengers, which is made possible by the increased safety of the whole sector, and to ensure the rights of workers and passengers.
