On the other hand, the implementation of the Single European Sky should be accelerated, as fragmentation to this day is a heavy burden on European air carriers, which in turn reduces the competitiveness of the sector as a whole. I hope that the European Commission will take appropriate and swift action in this area, and I am convinced that the adoption of the resolutions will be an important step towards formulate a long-term effective strategy for the entire European aviation sector.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: – Mr President, I would also like to comment on the forthcoming aviation package. Most of us are well aware that the aviation market is one of the most liberalised markets in the world. The competition is huge. Nor is it new that, in order to gain competitive advantages, practices are taking place that lead to a weakening of social standards. This also applies to the current unsatisfactory situation of air crews, which is also caused by various atypical forms of employment. Indeed, we must not underestimate the social aspects in air transport. All the more so if they could affect transport safety. Above all, passengers' confidence in air transport safety will depend on their future.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: – Mr President, aviation is key for economic growth. Ryanair and EasyJet have done more for regional development than countless billions of our regional development aid, and that is the private sector. Aviation is also a global business, so we have to be open and competitive, and we need innovation. We should support new business models and new solutions in air traffic management, integrated ticketing and alternative fuels. We should also speed up the implementation of the Single European Sky and the Single European Sky ATM Research (SESAR) programmes and conclude comprehensive aviation agreements with our partners. In a time of limited capacity, we should also be promoting the importance of our regional airports, for example Birmingham, which is in my constituency. Aviation is not free of tax, no matter what our Green colleagues think. Many Member States levy airport tax. This is GBP 71 or EUR 100 for a long-haul flight per passenger from the UK. It is EUR 42 from Germany. I think these taxes should be scrapped by these Member States. This is a brake on our competitiveness. We need to realise that we need to be flexible, open and innovative. We are in a global marketplace.

name: Matthijs van MILTENBURG
text: I would like to dwell on a point that is also addressed in the resolution. It concerns passenger rights and the revision of Regulation (EC) No 261 from 2004. Let us be clear, this dossier is stuck in the Council. I fully understand the political sensitivities in both the United Kingdom and Spain, but these sensitivities are holding the entire European aviation sector hostage. Passengers and airlines want clarity on their rights and obligations. I understand that the European Commission is considering coming up with interpretative guidelines to clarify the existing regulations pending new regulations. Personally, I am a little less happy with that because I think it is really crucial to put pressure on the Council to come up with new rules. Only new rules will create the clarity they want. I would therefore urge my compatriots who are going to hold the Dutch Presidency of the Council to actually get on with it and deliver what Europe expects.

name: Georges BACH
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner, thank you very much for what you have said about the aviation package. I agree with you that aviation urgently needs the necessary impetus to put European airlines, airports and the industry as a whole in a stronger position, as I said. In order to achieve this, we need, as you said, a long-term strategy. Many direct jobs – tens of millions – are asking us: with all due respect to economic considerations – as colleagues have pointed out across the political groups – we must not forget the social dimension. Working conditions have a direct impact on safety, the top priority in aviation. The problems were recently listed in the conference on the social agenda for the transport sector. We need highly qualified and motivated professionals, and that is why we need to stick to practices and standards such as collective agreements and social dialogue. We need a clear definition of the concept of home base. We need better application of the rules of mobile workers in the sector. What we do not need, what we absolutely need to abolish, are the dubious business practices of flags of convenience, atypical employment, bogus self-employment, pay-to-fly systems, zero-hours contracts and other precarious working conditions.

name: Jens NILSSON
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on his I am very much looking forward to this proposal coming in December. Over the last few years, we have seen how the labour market in aviation is increasingly beginning to look like the Wild West, where airlines are flagged out, safety margins are being squeezed, wages and working conditions are being dumped by rogue employers. This threatens security in the long run.  That is why we must stop it and then we must have legislation in place. Stronger European cooperation in this area is important. We cannot allow security issues to fall between the chairs of different national authorities. The mandate of EASA, the European Aviation Safety Agency, must be strengthened.  If there is one issue on which there is popular support for a stronger European mandate, it is with regard to air safety. Finally, i.e. there is therefore a link between deteriorating employment conditions and poorer security. Therefore, these issues must be dealt with together.

name: Dieter-Lebrecht KOCH
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. First of all, I very much welcome the fact that we are once again talking about a whole legislative package, so that coherent legislation can be expected and no individual measures are proposed that run the risk of contradicting each other. This is a promising concept, which we have not only realised since the fourth railway package. I am therefore also looking forward to the future: after the aviation package, we can count on a road transport package and, finally, a legislative package on maritime transport. Commissioner, class! The air transport sector has a strong global component, so we should avoid European solo actions and seek action at global level. For example, on the issue of aviation emissions, where only global regulation within the framework of ICAO makes sense. For me, aviation issues also belong in trade agreements such as TTIP. Global regulations play a crucial role, not least because of the competitiveness of the European aviation industry. I am pleased that in our resolution we want to promote competitiveness in particular. Today, European airlines are exposed to strong competition, including from the Gulf States. However, there is virtually no use of existing legislation on protection against unfair pricing practices in the air transport sector. It is therefore desirable for the Commission to address this issue and to present appropriate amendments to the air transport package. Finally, a very urgent request to our Member States: the EU can only be a serious negotiating partner at European level if we succeed in making a single European aviation area work within Europe. Thank you very much.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: – Mr President, the problem in the aviation sector has for years been that we continue to treat it as a sector. We ask questions about the sector, rather than asking questions about how the sector fits into the economy and society as a whole. That is why we end up with ridiculous situations, like in the UK, where we have a review of aviation and decide to build a 77th airport in London, when what we actually need is to increase the capacity of regional airports like Birmingham. Birmingham airport delivers over GBP 1 billion to the regional economy and nearly GBP 2 billion to the national economy. It should – and could – be a lot more. When we are considering the strategic importance of our airports to the whole economy, we need to consider the working conditions of the people who work in them. We do not want zero-hours contracts, pay-to-fly and these kinds of exploitative conditions in such important places.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the challenges facing the European aviation industry are enormous. We talk about airlines, we are talking about the aviation industry, but also airports, and airports that face exponential competition, many of them unfair competition against third countries.  Over the past ten years, the connectivity of European airports has been decreasing in contrast to an increase in non-European airports and these changes, and some changes in the routes of some flights, have particularly affected regional airports.  That is why I would like to miss this opportunity to address the Commissioner and to say that I believe that it is crucial that the Commission, within this package, presents a strategy for regional airports that take account of the Guidelines for State aid and that considers regional airports as part of the solution to the decongestion of central airports. To finish, I believe that we need a clear view from the Commission, because these regional airports connect people, places, goods and services. Air transport and its infrastructure, the infrastructure they support, it must be remembered, are also gateways for tourists. And what a sector so important to the economies of the regions! Airports are central to social and economic cohesion, also in outermost regions such as Madeira.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the European aviation sector faces many challenges, risks and changes, and that is why the European Commission expects an ambitious aviation package, based on the concepts of sustainability and competitiveness.  It is no longer possible to overlook the impact of aviation on the climate if we consider only that the transport sector is in second place for greenhouse gas emissions and that the International Civil Aviation Organisation has been expressly invited to work towards a drastic reduction in emissions by 2016.  I therefore hope that the Commission's package will include solutions geared to combating CO2 emissions, as required by COP21, and that it will give priority to the development of aviation biofuels capable of reducing this reduction, the ecological development of airports and new commercial models, such as the issuance of integrated tickets. But I believe that the Commission must also work the competitiveness of the sector by putting in place measures to strengthen the structure of European airlines and to encourage Member States to improve the infrastructure of EU airports, in order to enable the sector to compete internationally under favourable conditions.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: – The aviation industry is an important employer with an important impact on the development and growth of the European economy. Around ten million flights a year take place over Europe. About half a million people are employed in the area. Increasing the competitiveness of this sector is therefore a necessity. The proposed measures should aim to improve the functioning of the single aviation market in Europe. This could eventually be extended to some other countries. It is also important, when liberalising, to genuinely guarantee the quality of existing consumer rights for passengers. This applies, for example, to financial compensation for significant flight delays or lost or damaged luggage. The new rules should also apply to the safety of air passengers. However, these should not lead to harassment of passengers at airports in terms of trying to increase security, because the situation at some European airports in relation to passenger rights is sometimes indeed in very poor condition.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: – Last May, research by Ghent University showed that almost half of the planes on low-cost airlines such as Ryanair are operated by mostly young freelancers with a pay-to-fly contract. Cabin crew from Southeast Asia, as with Norwegian Air, are also becoming more common. Cheap workers from shipping are now also expanding into aviation. This type of practice is bad for employees, risks passenger safety and harms airlines that treat their employees properly. Commissioner Thijssen said earlier this week that precarious work in Europe must be addressed. That is a great task that requires more work than one Commissioner can handle. Hence my question to Commissioner Bulc: what are you going to do to tackle social abuses in international transport? For example, will you link landing rights to just good work in the aviation package?

name: Clare MOODY
text: – Mr President, the future Aviation Package is a perfect opportunity to revisit the arrangements for the Safety Agency for Aircraft, commonly known as EASA. The aerospace manufacturing sector is vital for both our industrial base in the EU and also for innovation, particularly in areas like composites. In my region, for example, Airbus employs 4 000 people directly and thousands of others in the supply chain, but there is a backlog of planes: 6 000 waiting to get certification as a consequence of the delays in EASA. The industry desperately needs the rules covering the agency to be revisited. We need this to stay competitive in a global industry and, best of all as a Budget Committee member, this need not be at any more cost to the EU budgets. So please take this opportunity to make sure that we can make the agency work for the industry and to maintain the security and the high levels of safety that the industry has a record of as well.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: – Mr President, Commissioner Bulc, I very much look forward to your aviation package next month. Aviation has been very good for Europe. Liberalisation of our airways has been extremely good for passengers and, most importantly, for businesses, and yes, you are right, some airlines are doing well, others are not doing well at all. We have seen consolidation. We have seen the birth of new airlines that are serving our regions extremely well and, as has been mentioned by previous speakers, we speak of Ryanair and EasyJet that are getting to our outermost regions. But I urge you to act on issues such as the Single European Skies, passenger rights and slots. We need to address them – you appreciate that, I know – to improve competitiveness of European airlines. On another point, I welcome the fact that we are going to engage with airlines outside the EU such as the Gulf States. I think it is important that we try to build comprehensive aviation agreements with these airlines. It is an important step, because they are not going to go away. Our passengers and businesses in Europe are using them now, and they will not appreciate us building a fortress around Europe and being protectionist about our airlines here. We need to engage in comprehensive agreements, and I wish you well in that, and Parliament will be engaging, because it is essential that we do so. We are operating in a global economy now and we cannot be inward-looking, trying to protect what we have historically. We must look forward for the benefit of our consumers and those that are doing business on a global scale.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, the aeronautics industry is one of the European Union's most important contributors to growth and jobs, while at the same time being closely linked to the aviation sector in Europe with a turnover of EUR 100 billion per year and some half a million direct jobs. In Greece, the troika and the Memorandum of Understanding granted, at Merkel's behest, for forty plus ten years fourteen regional airports to the state-owned German company Fraport, which also operates Athens Eleftherios Venizelos airport.  A state-owned company thus gains a dominant position in the operation of airports in Europe and also gains a dominant monopoly position in the Greek tourism market in violation of the European Union's rules on free competition and state aid. Thus the Greek airports are German-held and Greek tourism is now turning into a German tsifliki and this is something that the Greek people will not allow.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, I strongly support the future Aviation Package as it will provide a boost for a more sustainable European aviation industry, improve the competitiveness of the sector, strengthen European airlines, airports and the aeronautic industry, ensure a level playing field in the global market, and set out a long-term strategy for Europe’s aviation sector. The Commission should take into account and support innovation in the fields of air traffic management, airport security, digitalisation and multi-modal solutions. It is very important that the package supports global environmental solutions, such as global market-based measures to address carbon dioxide emissions from international aviation. European airports are facing significant competitive pressures. Therefore the Commission should take these developments into consideration in implementing the Airport Charges Directive. Moreover, the package should include a long-term EU strategic plan to address the challenges and opportunities for regional airports within the European Union.

name: Urmas PAET
text: – The European Commission decided on Saturday that the contributions made by the owner of estonian air, the Estonian State, to Estonian Air, were not in accordance with state aid rules and should be repaid. This led to the closure of the Estonian airline, which significantly deteriorated Estonia's competitiveness and left 160 people out of work. The argument was that payments made by the Estonian State as owner distort competition, while what competition is we talking about? There are few people in Estonia and the distances with European centres are long. Most European airlines have never wanted to fly to Estonia. At the same time, the cessation of Estonian Air's activities will significantly increase the risk of reducing Estonia's competitiveness and will make it even more difficult to connect between Estonia and the rest of Europe. How is it in the interests of the European Union as a whole to significantly degrade the associations of one small Member State?  The new aviation package must take into account that aviation competition does not operate normally in countries with a small population and far-flu and far away from the central part of the European Union. They cannot be taken by the same yardstick as short distances between europe's major cities. European Union legislation needs to be amended so that small and remote countries can also have direct flights to europe's major cities. It's not just the market that's going to guarantee it.

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, Commissioner, what is the point of talking today about the competitiveness of European air transport, international cooperation, affordable prices for consumers, a social agenda and high levels of safety when all this does not work for the benefit of citizens with the blessings, of course, of the European Director? Or is it a monopoly, after all, only when it is state and German?  What am I going to say? While we are discussing the future of European air transport, in Greece, as has already been said by colleagues, fourteen state regional airports are being granted to the German consortium Fraport Sientel on bandit terms and with the blessing and pressure of the Troika. A selective grab only of airports deemed economically viable for which, vaguely, their upgrading is evangelize.  In fact, it does not provide any development prospects since it does not make any serious investment commitments. A sacrifice concession to the blackmailing mnemonic policy that creates an unacceptable monopoly for the benefit of the German government and burdens the Greek State with compensation to existing suppliers. A concession that not only does not guarantee workers, but puts them in a hostage situation.  Is that what Europe means, Commissioner?

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, d’éisteas leis an díospóireacht. Bhaineas an-taitneamh as agus d’fhoglaim mé mórán uaidh. Dá bhrí sin ba mhaith liom trí phointe a lua anois. Firstly, unfair practices in third countries as referred to by the Commissioner: obviously this is something that needs to be tackled at a global level, because our aviation industry deserves a level playing field. Secondly, the carbon footprint has been referred to, and obviously that is a worry because it is huge, and the Commissioner referred to having powerful regulatory tools to limit CO2 emissions, but also, as one of those representing Parliament in COP21 in Paris, I hope that both the aviation and maritime industries can be included in a global agreement, which we hope we will be able to reach there. Thirdly, the competitiveness of the airline industries in Europe was referred to. Ryanair is an Irish airline which is highly successful, its market share is growing, its stock is generally improving and recently it promised the Irish Government that if it got rid of the travel tax it would increase passenger numbers by a million – which it did. A huge boost to the tourist industry in Ireland.

name: Violeta Bulc
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, this has been a really incredible debate which shows me how important the topic is. In spite of the big challenges, I know that we are going to address it in the best possible way, with all stakeholders included. Let me quickly reflect on some of the Members’ questions and comments. Unfortunately I will not be able to reply to all of them because of the limited time available. I could speak really fast, but then our interpreters would have a real challenge, so I will try to address as many as I can. Please send us additional questions if I am not able to respond to everyone. First, the issue raised most frequently was that of the safeguards on fair competition. The Commission supports the objective of ensuring fair competition in the aviation sector and we have different tools in order to do this: first, by promoting sound principles of competition enforcement in the bilateral air service agreements, and second, by promoting EU-level air service agreements – especially with important trading partners – that lead to comprehensive agreements and revising the standard ‘fair competition’ clause in order to make it more usable in negotiations with third countries, while ensuring that the exclusive competence of the Commission and national competition authorities in applying EU competition rules is fully respected. That will be stated very clearly. The next question related to subsidies. Let me underline that the existence of subsidies is alleged and not yet proven. Even if subsidies exist, we would need to see whether they have a negative impact on EU companies. That is what we are really after. Let us not forget that the loss of competitiveness in the EU aviation industry is due to a number of reasons, from the continued fragmentation of the European air traffic systems and lack of implementation of the Single European Sky to insufficient infrastructure, and also the lack of a level playing field. The Commission intends to address this in the aviation strategy. The next questions were related to Regulation 868/2004. So far – which is really interesting – no complaint has been lodged by the EU in the industry under the regulation, despite frequent claims and concerns about unfair practice from third countries. The Commission is therefore in the process of finalising the internal revision of Regulation 868/2004. A legislative proposal as a follow-up initiative for the aviation strategy could then be expected by early 2016. Regarding working conditions, in a competitive air transport market, pressure to reduce operational costs is high, which can have an impact on social matters. The Commission, through the aviation strategy, aims to tackle all these challenges. EU aviation players across the entire value chain should be able to benefit fully from the growth potential to allow the maintenance of a strong social agenda and the creation of high—quality jobs. In this context, the most important thing is a very strong social dialogue. I think we established really good conditions for that at the Conference on social issues in transport in June 2015. Atypical forms of employment was the next most frequently mentioned challenge. It is important to have all the factual and legal elements of the developments on the market to understand the implications of the use of atypical forms of employment in aviation and the implications for the EU aviation policy. To this end, the Commission will publish shortly a study on employment and working conditions in air transport and airports. Furthermore, the European Aviation Safety Agency (EASA) has set up a working group to assess the safety aspects of new business models. Training and skills and safety and security in Europe meet the highest standards, and they must continue to do so. Some skills and competences are not yet widely available and will have to be developed. Training should be given a high priority. On this matter, the EASA Virtual Academy is developing into a true European network of accredited aviation training institutions and institutes. Common standards regarding the competences of aviation safety inspectors is also a matter we are looking into. The environment: the EU has also put in place powerful regulatory tools, such as the emissions trading scheme, addressing CO2 emissions in the EU. A global market—based mechanism should be pursued to achieve carbon-neutral growth from 2020, as well as the option of the first ever CO2 standards for aircraft. The challenges of Gibraltar were also mentioned, and I would really like to address them. The Gibraltar issue risks jeopardising several years’ work of three institutions, while preventing the EU from upholding its commitments in this field. We therefore continue to urge both parties to take a constructive approach and find a pragmatic solution. The aviation strategy should provide the political momentum to make progress in this field, in particular for passenger rights and SES 2+, which many Members mentioned. Finally, the Commission intends to put forward its aviation strategy in early December. This will not be a one—off exercise – there is no magic wand – but it the beginning of a process that should lead us to a strong and competitive aviation sector and an ever-stronger single aviation market. I really look forward to continuing this close cooperation with Parliament. I am hopeful that we will achieve a really important breakthrough and that European aviation will continue to be the leader on the European market and globally.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I have received seven motions for resolutions pursuant to Rule 123(2) of the Rules of Procedure to wind up the debate. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 11 November, at 7.00 p.m. I would like to remind all my fellow Members that we are in the process of concluding the 9th edition of the LUX Prize, the European Parliament's film prize, which awards the three best ae author films to promote European film production. All the films that have reached the final – Mediterranea, Urok and Mustang – are subtitled in all the languages of the European Union. The prize will be awarded by MEPs, so I invite you all to see the three films and vote by 23 November, because on the 24th there will be the award ceremony.  I would also like to inform the public that they are present in the Chamber and that they are attending this sitting that there will also be a vote by the citizens to give a judgment on these three films, so there will be recognition of the people's jury on the sidelines of the prize. To vote you must visit the "Luxprize" website and click on the banner "Vote for your favorite film". I believe that this is an interesting way of involving citizens in the promotion of European film production. I therefore repeat: by 23 November, Members will have to vote, and I hope that as many Members do – I say this as responsible for the LUX prize, that is why so much participation; At the beginning of the sitting, the Vice-President-in-Office of the Council announced the vote, and Mr De Clercq( Costa added more information. I think it's really important for all of you to participate in the choice of the film that you think is best. I repeat: it is the Mediterranean film, the film Urok and the movie Mustang. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. This resolution aims to set out the European Parliament's priorities for the future Aviation package to be presented by the European Commission. Among its priorities, Parliament explicitly recognises the importance of regional airports within the Union and to ensure cohesion within European regions. It calls on the Commission and the Member States to present a long-term strategic plan on the issues and opportunities of regional airports in the context of the Union. This is obviously extremely important with regard to the development of Charleroi Brussels South Airport, which is obviously - by its dynamism and remarkable results - an essential tool for the socio-economic redeployment of my region, for its image and for the creation of jobs.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. We must take note of the changes taking place in the world and forge our policies with a look to the future, not to the past. The main routes for aviation and the expanding ones are increasingly those heading east from our continent. It is no coincidence that the airlines with the highest number of carriers have, in recent years, been Emirates, Qatar Airways, Etihad and Turkish Airlines. We therefore need to change our strategy at Union level and focus on sustainability, safety and new technologies, also in order to reduce the impact on the environment. Supporting and innovating the European aviation industry according to these parameters should also be a priority in order to make it competitive, and the resolution put to the vote is not strong enough in this perspective.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. – In order to maintain the competitiveness of the civil aviation sector and to maintain the current level of safety, updating the existing rules is essential.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. – The aeronautics industry should remain a solid backbone of the development of Europe's innovative industry. Constant changes in the airline industry market require continuous adaptation of the airline industry to these changes in order to maintain a high place on the world market. The European Commission must also fight against incorrect practices by third countries.  Furthermore, it is necessary to maintain the competitiveness of major European airports, but clear investments in regional airports are also necessary. Discussion and conclusions on drones at the last session of the European Parliament must be an integral part of the policy of the new Package for European Aviation.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. I support this joint motion for a resolution on most points, as a strengthened and, above all, more competitive EU aviation industry is of enormous importance and will ultimately have a positive impact on passengers and the European economy.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. This Aviation package, which is being voted on this afternoon, aims to develop measures to stimulate the air transport economy in the European Union while maintaining high standards of safety and the social sector. I draw your attention to the fact that working conditions in the aviation sector can have an impact on flight safety. It is therefore essential that this "Aviation" package contains ambitious social provisions and provides for the necessary safeguards as agreed and in line with the high-level conference entitled 'A Social Agenda for Transport', organised on 4 June by the European Commission.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. – The air transport economy is essential for Europe, with the direct support of 2.6 million jobs and contributing more than 2.4% of EU GDP. Various factors require radical changes in the context of regulation of this area.  These factors are, above all, the cancellation of a large number of jobs – it is worth noting that European airlines have cancelled or are yet to cut more than 20,000 jobs since 2012. The effects of air transport on climate change are also significant. It contributes around 13% of eu transport carbon dioxide emissions. In addition, in 2014 the number of air passengers in the EU increased by 4.4%.  The International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO), the EU and the Member States need to improve various legal and financial regulations, such as the intra-EU emissions trading scheme, increasing passenger rights, duties and national taxes, reducing noise at airports and limiting operating times.  The Commission's new package, which will take into account all the changes and factors, seems to me to be urgently needed and important. In particular, there is the need to improve the competitiveness of the aviation industry, for a greater international dimension, the lack of involvement of the social agenda in the aviation sector and the need to ensure a high level of safety in EU airspace.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. – Europe could not today be the number one tourist destination in the world without the contribution of the European aviation sector, one of the best performing in the world. 850 million passengers travelled to the European Union in 2014 alone, and the number is increasing year on year! This impressive demand for mobility is supported by an innovative industry that creates 2.6 million jobs and fits perfectly into Juncker's plan for economic regeneration. Unfortunately, the sector faces a number of challenges arising, on the one hand, from unfair competition from operators outside the Union and, on the other hand, by market fragmentation, the costs of implementing environmental legislation and the lack of a unified vision of industry competitiveness. As co-chair of the Intergroup for Tourism Development and as a member of the Committee on Transport and Tourism in the European Parliament, I can only welcome the aviation package announced by the European Commission for December. The aviation and aviation industries are key elements in the European Union's economic recovery plan. Instead, we need a set of solutions that put the European aviation industry back on the global competitiveness map.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: in writing. – There are countless examples of cases in which state aid, whether in the form of financial aid or monopoly rights, is legally granted to companies operating a under a public service obligation, in other words a service that is in the public interest but not commercially viable.  Unfortunately, with its recent decision the Commission caused the bankruptcy of Estonian Air. Connecting a country of 1.3 million people in the periphery of Europe to the rest of Europe and the rest of the world is a political choice based on our European values, and is not necessarily a commercially viable business plan. While the rest of us are politically striving for ‘an ever closer union’, the Commission acted against European values and the interests of the EU project. Regardless of the Commission’s technical evaluation, in practice Estonian Air was operating a service in the public interest. The Commission can talk about alleged market distortion in the abstract, yet there are no competitors waiting to jump in and substantially fill the gap left by Estonian air. Having a viable transport connection with the rest of Europe is a necessity for Estonia’s livelihood.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: in writing. – The future aviation package is intended to enhance the EU’s air transport economy. The European Union’s aviation sector is exposed to constant change, therefore the Commission proposes ideas that will hopefully adjust to that situation and help to improve the effectiveness of that area.  I believe that the aviation package should focus on sustaining the social, as well as safety standards, especially regarding the fact that currently we are facing issues such as pay-to-fly contracts, and therefore we have to approach that subject with a rational consideration. Moreover, there has been an idea of introducing the necessity of enhancing the medical assessment of the cabin crew as well as pilots, which I agree with. I believe that this constitutes the safety standard of the aviation which is a crucial matter in this area. All in all, I believe that it is important to establish such a package, mostly because of the fact that the aviation sector constitutes 2.4% of the EU’s GDP and supports around 2.6 million jobs; however this is not a matter that should be prioritised.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I would first of all like to draw attention to the three most important points. The aviation package proposed by the Commission should support the development and innovation of remotely piloted aircraft systems, commonly referred to as drones, as it is an extremely fast and thriving industry.  However, the regulation of safe use and marking of drones should not be taken into account, as this is necessary for proper identification and safety. Furthermore, I am pleased that the report includes elements that strengthen EASA's position and encourage the use of civilian satellite systems at the EU's disposal in order to ensure better flight safety in the EU. This is a very good direction.

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Member of the Commission, in writing – "Declaration on article 16 of the Proposal for a Decision of the European Parliament and of the European Council to establish a programme on interoperability solutions for European public administrations, businesses and citizens (ISA²) – Interoperability as a means for modernising the public sector" (Report: Carlos Zorrinho (A8-0225/2015)) The Commission regrets the insertion of a provision and of a recital which merely restates the applicable law on data protection in breach of basic principles of legislative quality and against the provision of rule 12 of the Joint Practical Guide for the drafting of Union legislation for the Institutions. text: The text is: 'calls on the Commission to strengthen the protection of workers and consumers in the event of the bankruptcy of an airline'.  I do not think there is any need for any explanation of what has happened and what is going on in the future.

name: Jo LEINEN
text: – Mr President, the third part does not make any sense. We do not want ‘gender equality... in 2024’; it was mixed in with the ‘zipped lists’, so that part falls. We want gender equality next time, not just in 2024, so we should vote against if that is put to the vote.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item is the Council and Commission statements on the practice of zero rating (2015/2916(RSP)).

name: Nicolas SCHMIT
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the European Parliament on the one hand for its essential contribution throughout the legislative process on the open internet and the end of roaming, and on the other hand, in particular for its vote on 27 October. By this vote, the barrier within the internal market represented by roaming charges was abolished and non-discriminatory access to all services offered via the internet was confirmed.  Indeed, it has taken us some time, but together we have achieved, for the benefit of consumers, a common vision that also opens the door to innovative services that we want to see grow more and more in Europe. The issue of zero, which you wished to discuss today, deserves to be addressed in the context of the open internet. It is true that leading experts, including Mr Tim Berners-Lee, on 26 October called on the honourable Members of Parliament to adopt amendments that would allow Member States to create their own rules to regulate the practice of zero rates. In our discussions, whether in the Council or in Parliament, the zero rate has indeed been studied. Why then did we not choose to include these elements in the agreement or, indeed, to propose amendments? I believe that for Parliament and the Council it was important to achieve real European coherence in order to continue to develop the single telecoms market. We wanted to avoid the proliferation of divergent national laws that could create new barriers to the digital single market. In this sense, the adoption of a European regulation would of course be ideal. On the other hand, when we looked at the zero rate, we listened to the opinions and took into account the experiences of the countries that had banned the practice, and the experiences of those who accept it within certain limits. However, we have seen that the practice, while risky, also has a number of tangible benefits, particularly for the consumer.  The main risk is related to the power of operators who could favour their own services or choose the services to be preferred instead of the consumer. We recognise that if there is insufficient competition between operators or between services, this practice poses real risks to the open internet. In the light of these benefits and risks, we did not wish to abolish this practice, but wanted to put in place in the regulation a security system based, in particular, on the control carried out by national regulators or the relevant national authorities.  In practical terms, the regulation obliges the relevant entities to supervise and ensure that the rights of end-users as defined in the regulation are not infringed. In this context, the competent entities are empowered, on the one hand, to intervene against agreements or practices harmful to the rights of end-users, and on the other hand, if necessary, to sanction.  I believe that at the end of the discussions, within the institutions and among co-legislators, we have reached a balanced compromise with this regulation that guarantees an open internet and preserves the interests of consumers and Internet users, excludes abusive behaviour, but leaves whole opportunities for innovation for both new and established operators, and which encourages investment by both.  I would also like to recall the context in which we find ourselves: the Council, Parliament and the Commission are constantly working to improve the internal market, and in particular the digital internal market, and, Commissioner, I heard you this morning - live from Brussels, in Luxembourg - strongly advocating for this digital internal market, so I believe that we are on the right track and of course for the digital attractiveness of Europe. And that is the fundamental issue. In particular, we are advancing very high-speed infrastructure. The more present and accessible this infrastructure is, the less attractive zero-rate practices will be.  Finally, with the end of roaming, we have created additional opportunities for competition between operators at European level. I believe that this increased competition should also contribute to the reduction of the risk associated with the practice of zero rates. In conclusion, I would like to emphasize this great step forward, which we have taken together. With our definition of the open internet, we are definitely putting an end to practices that have been harmful to the consumer for too long.

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Mr. The Commission. Mr President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, Minister Schmit, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. There is no conflict between the Council and the Commission. The TSM Regulation aims to ensure a coherent approach to access to an open Internet in the Internal Market. National regulators will be responsible for ensuring the effective implementation of net neutrality rules. The TSM regulation, adopted here in Parliament in plenary session on 27 October, is the first time that binding net neutrality rules have been incorporated into European law. These rules are genuine common rules based on full harmonisation. And since this is a regulation, the rules are directly enforceable by national courts at the request of citizens or other end-users, as well as by regulators. Until now, most Europeans have not had comparable legal protection for their right to access or disseminate information, content and services of their choice via the Internet. The Regulation also prescribes the principle of non-discriminatory data traffic management – for the first time ever in the EU. It contains a clear anti-discrimination clause that must be respected. Incidentally, by deciding this as a Parliament and the Council, it has become a law, it has far more stability and legal certainty than an administrative decision in the United States, which can be collected or amended at any time overnight. The Regulation is clear in relation to commercial agreements and practices such as zero rating, under which the use of certain services is not counted against the data volume of the end-user. It is neither a blanket ban nor a free pass – zero rating. Such practices are only permitted if they are compatible with net neutrality rules. Our TSM Regulation includes three safeguards to protect end-users from any adverse effects of business agreements and practices, including zero rating. And these safeguards should and can and will ensure that the right of all end-users to access and disseminate information, content and services of their choice via the Internet – which is the cornerstone of the net neutrality provisions in the TSM Regulation – can be effectively applied and enforced. These safeguards ensure that regulators and courts examine the pros and cons of zero-rating and other practices on a case-by-case basis to ensure that the objective of effective choice of end-users is not undermined. According to the first safeguard, commercial agreements and practices are not compatible with the Regulation if they restrict end-users in the exercise of their right of access to or dissemination of information, content, applications and services of their choice via the Internet. This applies to all possible situations in which the choice of end-users is significantly restricted in practice. The second safeguard relates to the fact that all commercial agreements and practices, including zero ratings, must comply with the principle of equal and non-discriminatory treatment of all data traffic, from which no unilateral and contractual deviating must be made. This means that Internet access providers must not apply discriminatory traffic control measures to comply with their contractual arrangements or business practices. The third safeguard concerns the role of national regulatory authorities and other competent authorities. The TSM Regulation gives national regulatory authorities the task – entitles them, obliges them – to ensure, through monitoring and enforcement measures, that the rights of end-users are not adversely affected, including the rights of content, service and application providers. More specifically, national regulators must be empowered to take action against agreements and business practices, including zero ratings, which could lead to situations where the choice of end-users would be significantly restricted in practice. Let me be clear: I have fundamental confidence in the national regulators. They are independent and will further develop independence. They are democratically determined and they are doing a good job. A basic confidence, not a basic mistrust, is my position. Together, these three safeguards provide a future-proof approach that makes it possible to respond not only to current but also to future practices. These provisions leave room for both independent regulators and courts to the concrete impact of commercial practices. They need to examine, taking into account the specific national circumstances, whether a particular practice circumvents the guarantees of an open Internet and whether the choice of end-users is significantly restricted in practice. In addition, the competition law enshrined in the Treaty is directly applicable and can also be enforced. Moreover, the TSM Regulation requires the body of European regulators for electronic communications – BEREC or BEREC, in close cooperation with the Commission and after consulting stakeholders, to issue guidelines for the implementation of the obligation of national regulatory authorities in order to contribute to consistent application. The Commission, in close cooperation with BEREC, will ensure that end-users' choice is ensured, thereby ensuring competition, pluralism and cultural diversity. BEREC and the Commission have already started work on these guidelines. BEREC is expected to adopt it within nine months with our cooperation. The guidelines will provide national regulatory authorities with a common benchmark for examining agreements and commercial practices so that they can take and enforce identical, coherent decisions. Let me add: we are monitoring market developments and if there is abuse in the market, we will react, we will improve our legislative text. In other words, it is up to us and you, to observe the market development, to observe practice and then to see in a year or two: has it proved its worth? I expect: Yes. If there are gaps, it will be possible to rectify them, to amend them.

name: Pilar del CASTILLO VERA
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, President-in-Office of the Council, zero rating is a commercial practice whose beneficiaries are consumers, and to ban commercial practices without having demonstrated, I stress: without having demonstrated that they are harming competition is to have a very interventionist view of the market, it is not to believe, in substance, in one of the founding principles of the European Union : that the market must be free and competitive.  Moreover, in this case, the Single Market Telecommunications Regulation cannot be clearer: Internet service providers must guarantee the right of any user to access the contents of their choice, without suffering any discrimination and without reducing their choice as a result of commercial practices, be it zero rating or any other practice.  National regulators now have the power to assess any type of practice and will be able to intervene in any abusive use by applying the appropriate sanctions. But it is also a regulation and, therefore, these rules are directly enforceable by national courts.  The Commission and ORECE will work on a guide for additional action. I call on the Commission to speed up these work so that they can assist in this regard in the implementation of the best compliance with the standard in each of the Member States.  (She agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question. – Mrs Representative, the argument put forward by the Representative of the Commission is roughly the same as that in the United States. There are loopholes there too, there have been loopholes in Europe, but even these loopholes seem to be in the interests of large companies. What you've put in place would be a lasting start for the greats, and they could destroy everyone else. Do you think that's right?

name: Pilar del CASTILLO VERA
text: "blue card" response. – I have just explained, my dear colleague, that it must be shown that commercial practices are being misused and that they are harming competition to intervene.  In a free and competitive market it is not prohibited at entry, but it is shown that there are such problems and then intervenes.  There have to be intervention bodies, as is the case, in this case, with national regulators, and there has to be evidence in this regard. All this is guaranteed by the Single Market telecommunications Regulation.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Net neutrality is the be-all and end-all in the digital market economy and in opening up to citizens. That is why my group has insisted on asking the Commission such a question to ensure that it is actually excluded from a zero-rating practice offered by some entrepreneurs. The answers we have now received – both from the Council and from the Commission – show that the concerns that my group has are entirely justified. Because this practice of zero-ratings is – that sounds good – Internet for free, services for free. However, I maintain that zero-rating is a pseudo-consumer-friendly business practice, because it is a means of infiltrating net neutrality. We must be very clear about this, that we cannot let it run. I cannot allow myself to be fed up with an answer that in two years' time we will see what happens next. Because then the dice have fallen and we will not be able to catch up with them. We only need to look at what the project is doing Internet.org, for example, and how it is questioning precisely this net neutrality and infiltrating, preventing, preventing the possibility of pluralistic access to services on the Internet, and preventing it from being there. And I find that very worrying. I find it all the more worrying that both the Council and the Commission, obviously still do not want to see this and are not prepared to address these issues very quickly. This zero rating also has a direct impact on the competitiveness of innovative young tech providers and app developers, as well as restricting access to a pluralistic Internet. Ladies and gentlemen, it is time for us to address this issue, because the dangers in this area are enormous and we must not allow the Internet to be used profitably for the great monopolists and for the opportunities for start-ups to be simply undone. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr. President! I would like to ask Mrs Gebhardt the following: if you are against zero-rating, are you also in favour of paying fees in future when linking? Because you are now in favour of paying for the fact that there is no zero rating. In other words, are you also in favour of having to pay for links, or have I misunderstood this?

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. It would, of course, be very nice if it were actually free and free of charge for these services. Payment is a different currency from the currency we otherwise have with the euro. After all, this is the data that is being tapped, the data that is used, partly and very often without the consent of the citizens who accept these services. That is the other part of the danger inherent in this area, and we must also think very carefully about this: do we really want data to become a new currency on the Internet? I say no to that.

name: Vicky FORD
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, every person in Europe has the right to access the online content they want and use the applications they wish without discrimination or interference, and all internet traffic must be treated equally. We have just agreed new rules across Europe that enshrine these principles into our law. But now the left wants to go further and to start picking and choosing what commercial offers individual companies can make. If a mobile phone company wants to offer free access to certain content, some consumers might want to choose that offer – consumers should have that choice. And in the traditional world this is totally acceptable. Every time I leave my home to do my food shopping, I can choose: do I go to the supermarket that charges me more but gives me a free newspaper, or do I go to the supermarket with a lower price but no free newspaper? That is my choice. Of course, we need a fair marketplace, and we must make sure our competition laws are upheld. But this is why we have just empowered our national regulators to deal with anti-competitive behaviour. Introducing haphazard bans at will, without thinking through the impact or discussing their full consequence, is not the right way to approach the digital revolution.

name: Kaja KALLAS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I think we should start this debate with a question: what kind of internet do we want? Do we want a closed internet or an open internet? If we have made the choice that we want an open internet, we should stick to that choice and make the rules and regulations fit for that choice. A few weeks ago we adopted the Telecoms Package, where we agreed that net neutrality principles should be applied across Europe in a uniform way. It is therefore very unfortunate that today we have to discuss these zero-rating practices. Zero-rating practices do eventually lead to a closed internet. They will lead to fewer choices for consumers, less innovation and also fewer opportunities. The Commissioner referred to how the national regulators should implement the law, but I think there is the rub, because if national regulators implement rules that are not clear, we will have 28 different types of rules and we will not have the clarity we very much need for the internet to function and for digital services to flourish in Europe. Therefore I call on the Commission to be very clear and to come up with their clear solutions for zero-rating practices as well as net neutrality so that this can be applied across Europe in a uniform way.

name: Cornelia ERNST
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Anyone who wants net neutrality must simply ban zero-rating. Just as it was done in Chile in 2014. Otherwise, there is no really permanent and very clear way to prevent customers from being lured on the pages of a particular provider with free offers, to some extent free of charge. And if you want more, more information outside the platform, for example to compare opinions, you have to pay. There we have the payment barrier, which is there. Google, Facebook – the big ones – can dominate content, can, if you like, carry out controls on content. That is not what we want. Our concern is that this will create a kind of parallel Internet. This is certainly not the intention, but the danger is certainly a fact, and non-discriminatory access to the Internet, the equal transport of all data – and thus net neutrality – is gone. The consequence is the loss of freedom of communication and information, freedom of expression and freedom of the press, in other words fundamental human rights. Instead of zero-rating, we need strict respect for net neutrality. That is why, on 27 October, our decision on this issue was not a good one. We need European regulations that are strictly strengthened in order to maintain and also save net neutrality. Let me make it clear that there is no other way.

name: Michel REIMON
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the Zero-rating is clearly a violation of net neutrality, without any ifs or buts. It is clear that the proponents of this regulation, and also those who engulfed net neutrality in Europe a few weeks ago, are arguing unclearly. They argue that consumers have a choice between different free tariffs. Let us assume that is true. They argue that there is competition between telecomcompanies over who offers the better tariff. Let us assume that is true. Then, in any reasoning that they have put forward here, they ignore the third side, namely the services that provide the data, the companies that provide services on the Internet, and they are massively disadvantaged. There is a service, a service that buys zero-rating on a tariff, which is transferred from T-Mobile, Vodafone or wherever it is to buy into the data volume. Who can afford it? Big corporations, big companies and those that are already big, i.e. Google, YouTube, Facebook, similar companies on this scale. Any small European start-up that is now starting to compete with these big companies will not be able to afford to enter such a tariff and will automatically have a competitive disadvantage. It is downright perverse that the parties that define themselves as pro-business and say that they are doing all this in the interests of the economy, with this violation of net neutrality, are penalising small, new European companies – in favour of the large American corporations, in favour of telecoms companies – and thus promoting the large corporations that already exist and damaging all the small platforms that could be set up in the coming years and decades. That's the problem. It is not just the problem of end-users and not a problem of telecoms competition. They have a blind eye there, and that is why, even in this debate, it never falls to the proponents of zero-rating and net neutrality. To say zero-rating is fine if it doesn't violate net neutrality, that's like the pope saying group sex is fine if chastity isn't violated. It's impossible, it's a violation of net neutrality.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I had prepared another speech, but I am really grounded in some of the things I have heard in here, for example when Schmit talks about the end of roaming as if it were a newsason of Italian people telling smoky things and we know that it is not the real end of roaming, because it is a conditional, delayed and conditional end to impact studies on the profits of companies and communications. I hear Commissioner Oettinger – with the utmost respect for him – mentioning net neutrality, when this word, unless I was struck by sudden blindness, is not in the text that was approved only two weeks ago.  And then I hear colleagues from Parliament, in the corridors, in committee and here, who, just two weeks after the approval of the TSM, are already saying that they realise that they have voted practically a Trojan horse. I wonder where they were when it came to voting on the amendments for a clear definition of net neutrality. So I'm pretty worried that I can trust a neutral and open internet and I'm very concerned about the presence of this zero rating feature within the TSM package.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI). Mr President, the Union maintains that one of the main pillars of its existence is the free movement of people and goods and its main objective is to promote the single market. Firstly, with this in mind, the decision to abolish roaming charges is a very positive step since these charges are nothing more than pure speculation on the part of companies.  On the contrary, however, the way in which taxation is carried out in Europe at different rates per state inevitably leads to inequalities. Worse still, when the Union essentially obliges a country, and I am referring to Greece in my own country, to impose a savage tax on citizens and companies, then the single market becomes a tool to destroy all the productive potential of the nation.  Five years of austerity that were supposed to bring growth, consolidated the recession and led citizens to impoverishment and businesses to close or flee in order to survive. The results of this policy are the prosperity of numbers and banks and not of peoples. So as long as the Union tries to consolidate this ideal without taking into account the needs of the States, we will be against it. Because above all treaty or economic agreement lie the needs of the people.

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Mr President, I would like to congratulate the Commission and also the Council on the fact that there has been a conclusion in the area of net neutrality in the first place. In doing so, we have laid good foundations for an era – for the next generation – to improve communication behaviour in the future– without discrimination. One should also read the original texts – I put them on my homepage, because there is a lot of disinformation on the way here too – one should really read the text of the regulation and see how hard one was here to regulate this area properly and fundamentally. Some people are now taking action here in the House against the free use by consumers – so consumers should pay twice for it in the future, once for the use of the network and the second time extra. For me, this would mean that you are also against a free link. That would be contrary to the point at all. When I think of the fact that consumers with little money will also have access to the information world with free use, I cannot understand why they do not advocate zero-rating. It will be extremely important, especially in the developing countries, to provide access for the poorest of the poor, so that they can use the Internet. If they don't have money, do you want to exclude them? I find that irresponsible.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, free access to various applications and services is often seen as positive by users due to lack of associated payments. On the other hand, it allows operators to closely cooperate with specific third party service providers by making their services such as app stores, for instance, much more attractive, precisely due to being free of charge. In essence, in relation to competitors this may be seen as discrimination. In this respect, companies employing zero rating practices can be criticised on the grounds of open market distortion due to acting anti-competitively. However, the recently—adopted legislative package does not ban the zero rating practice, and whilst it does, at least partly, antagonise the principles of net neutrality, quite a few end users view the practice positively. Even when the monthly data quota is exhausted, zero—rated applications and services would still work as long as the internet signal is accessible.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: – Mr President, zero rating is a honey trap for consumers, especially young consumers. While enjoying free access to some sites, they do not fully realise that they are being led down the path to a habit of spending all their money and data in that one place. It is creating a social addiction to one content provider over another. Such practices are not new. There is no such thing as a free lunch. They have existed in the marketing world since the start of advertising. But just as we must control misleading practices in the physical world, we must be equally careful in the digital world. As the Commissioner has just said, national authorities will have the power to prevent the misuse of such zero-rating practices. But, if they cannot prevent abuse, this should be part of any review of telecoms regulation. This is not only a question of defending the principles of net neutrality, but also of fair competition in the digital single market.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, many citizens are grateful to be able to connect to a platform without deducting megas from their data rate. The issue, however, is the threat posed by this practice to fair and fair competition on the Internet.  There is broad consensus in this Parliament and on the street on the need to ensure net neutrality, and providing access to a particular platform or service free of charge is a way to guide and prioritize traffic to those particular platforms or services to the detriment of their competitors.  In my view, this is a major risk to the net's own neutrality and fair and fair competition, and it also opens the door for the strongest economically – and not necessarily the most innovative – to emerge victorious, putting at risk the diversity of supply for citizens.  Developing, therefore, the digital single market is a priority. Doing so with respect for equal rules of play for all must be indispensable.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: Mr President, the Telecom package was adopted at the last plenary session of the European Parliament, and I am satisfied with that. However, the principle that all internet traffic must be treated equally by internet service providers is still unregulated. The zero-rate point is not in the package as adopted, and I deplore that. Indeed, this point has undoubtedly remained unclear because of too much divergence of views between Parliament and the other institutions. The Commission proposes to intervene on zero-rate problems on a case-by-case basis only, but this is not enough. We must legislate in this area, clearly for all operators, in order to ensure equal access to the internet for all. We cannot accept that such a practice is still tolerated to the extent that we all agree to complete the single market. The latter must ensure perfect competition between operators and service providers.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I have listened with interest to the debate and the questions of what kind of internet we want or whether the rate should be zero. I think that has indeed been answered in the adoption of our previous resolutions on net neutrality. And I am a bit surprised to my colleagues that they exclude the zero rate, that they consider it inappropriate, that they want to make a decision for consumers in advance, without actually clearly demonstrating the negative effect. I don't know if we really want to literally lead consumers in this way, to predict their future. I would leave the responsibility in a market that should not be interfered with at first, the market should be liberal, and the harmfulness of those effects must first be demonstrated and then it can be affected. I am surprised at the approach that someone actually wants to stand up against zero rates at the moment.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, we supported the abolition of roaming charges immediately and not from 2017. We supported it unconditionally and without asterisks, loopholes and exceptions, as was finally the case with the vote by the European Parliament on this issue.  We see the zero-rate practice as a threat to the open Internet which must enable unlimited use and we also see this practice as a threat to the neutrality of the Internet.  Net neutrality presupposes equality for Internet service providers and no website and service is blocked. However, with the practice of zero rate websites are not presented in the same way to consumers, since some are provided free of charge, and thus Internet traffic is not done on equal terms for everyone.  Finally, this practice restricts consumer rights to an open and accessible Internet. We therefore need uniform rules on zero-rate practices.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Mr. President, let me say right from the outset that I have already spoken here in this Parliament on a number of occasions that internet freedom must become the fifth European freedom.  If we are creating a single market, if we are creating a single monet and we really want to create a single market, which we are making decisions about and trying to create this digital single market that is part of the agenda of this Commission, then the internet, internet use, internet access, should become our fifth European freedom.  This includes, then, everyone's right to access the internet, to use the internet and to make the internet available to everyone in the same way. Only in this way can we protect the overall European market and every European citizen so that they can truly have the internet as their fifth online freedom.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: – Mr President, the law passed last October is manifestly ambiguous. If, on the one hand, it prohibits data discrimination in order to ensure the neutrality of the Internet, on the other hand, it makes multiple exceptions of unclear contours that give operators ample field for abuse, thereby favouring their own services and harming other operators. It allows, among other things, specialized services that have privileged access to normal Internet traffic, among other things.  This theme is part of the struggle for the dominance of this vast virtual territory that is the web and which today represents a huge revenue potential to the gluttony of the great capital. It is in this context that this debate on the relevance of a zero rate should be beneficial to the citizen is understood, but which, in the light of this law of savage capitalism, can become a weapon at the service of large groups to destroy competition and increase their monopolistic incomes.  We therefore stress the need to continue to strive for public control over this fundamental infrastructure, through which a predominant and growing part of our economy is now circulating.

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Mr. The Commission. Mr President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work he has done. Our legislation, which you decided by a large majority, will enter into force on 30 April. It will give our citizens and users significantly more rights – the same in all Member States – than before. It is clearly a strong improvement in the position of consumers with regard to non-discrimination. That is why Parliament voted in favour by a majority. Secondly, I have the impression that the speeches were mixed – some were in agreement, some were very critical. But no digital doom is to be expected. Once again, my request is that the Commission makes proposals, parliament and the Council decide. Now to give the black Peter back to me, two weeks after your decision by a large majority, I call it a transparent game. Nevertheless, I am following your requests. But you could have refused. It is not me, you have decided in Parliament. Sorry – democracy means majority, nothing else, unanimity is unfortunately in the European Council, such a nonsense! We have a majority here, which is an advantage. Parliament has always wanted majority voting, full co-determination and majority voting. You have that, now you have to accept it! This is a strict civic duty for democrats who are subject. Then to speak of "perverse" outrages me. "Perverse" is a term that I totally reject in terms of subject matter and technical issues. That is under every European belt! Then bringing in the issue of Greece here and linking it to zero ratings is also absurd. These are speeches that are not worthy of a Member of Parliament. Then there is Mrs Reda – she is not here, but she tweets around, presumably she has a pirate-sinking session, so she cannot be there, wants to save her seat – who is constantly tweeting against it. She has the right to speak here, she has the right to vote here. Not me! If it bothers me from the outside in my work here, in the attention to you, I don't call it okay. Only her youth protects her from sharper assessments of her person by me. We want the open Internet. Incidentally, we do not want monopolies, either from Silicon Valley or from powerful large European telecoms. That is why it was the Commission that started the platform consultation. I note in San José, San Francisco and Washington, D.C., there is a lot of interest and nervousness. In the course of next summer, we will make a proposal to you as to whether and to what extent European rules for new players in this market are necessary for fair competition, for competition and for a level playing field. Please support me then! Our telecoms companies – let's take the big ones: Vodafone, Orange, Telefinica, Deutsche Telekom. I think it is also about consumers. And we have achieved a great deal for consumers since liberalisation and privatisation. Today you can buy far more services in mobile communications and the Internet for 100 euros than 20 years ago – far more! We have done our duty to the consumer. But I also do industrial policy. I am with works councils, with trade unions such as ver.di, I am with workers, and I want the telecoms market and the Internet market to be shaped by powerful European telecoms and not just by Americans and Asians. That's what I want. If you want something different, you should say it – to me, but also to the works council of Deutsche Telekom, that of Vodafone, that of Orange, that of Telefinica. I broadly agree with the Italian colleague's intervention. But my main concern in your place would be that the very weak Telecom Italia will be taken over these days. Italy has hardly any more independent companies. Fiat gone, others gone, Alitalia is practically broken. In other words, you must want to work with me to ensure that in some sectors Italy also has independent players with sales, revenues and prospects in the European market and is not taken over by two French investors. Then: Arrivederci, Italia! I trust the regulators a lot. I am sure that the regulators will do their job. If not, we will address it, but now we have a crucial point: we have made a proposal as to what the Competence of the Commission, which you are requesting, should look like. I'll read you the original English text when my services work digitally. Before that, however, there is another point. We have promised to monitor the market, development and, if necessary, to react. Why don't you trust me? That is my word! I I have a few more years of office, and I keep the floor! I have never lied to Parliament and I am constantly talking to rapporteurs and others so that we can respond to abuses – if it shows up – through regulators or through legislation. It is up to you and us alone. By the way, the regulatory authorities – I have looked at a few speeches at their national origin – I would ask Members to ensure a little more independence and a little more staff and a little more authority and competence and quality of some national regulators, who are extremely weak. I am happy to say in four eyes who is meant. They are citizens there, have weight there, I have only limited weight. Support me in the ten or twelve countries where I am not satisfied with the regulation in any way. The Commission has proposed the text proposed by the Commission. 'The Commission may adopt implementing acts defining uniform conditions for the implementation of the obligations of national competent authorities under this article. Those implementing acts shall be adopted in accordance with the procedure procedure referred to in Article 33.'
