The amendment from Parliament – I respect that, I am a Democrat, I have no right to vote, you are an adult yourself – reads as follows and was adopted as follows: Within six months of the adoption of this regulation BEREC shall, after consulting stakeholders and in close cooperation with the Commission 'lay down general guidelines defining uniform conditions for the implementation of the obligations of national competent authorities under this article, including with respect to the application of traffic management measures and for monitoring of compliance.' In other words, the Commission went in with long trousers and came out in shorts – your work! They cut off my pants. I also get along with shorts. I have enough voice. I can also cope with this competence. However, it is only to take away my competence because Parliament is reluctant to accept implementing acts and then to ask me to be stricter is, in my view, only to a limited extent fair. Thank you very much!

name: Nicolas SCHMIT
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, I do not have much to add to the Commission's explanations and statements. I think we all share a major concern which is to finally develop the digital internal market in Europe, because we have fallen behind enormously. Indeed, the strength of the European economy in this area is at stake, since it is digital that will dominate the economies of tomorrow and today already. And our goal today is indeed to develop this internal market.  So, of course, an important step has been taken thanks to you, thanks to the European Parliament, thanks to the Parliament's vote which took place in October. It is also clear that this single market needs what the Commissioner has called a level playing field and, of course, we must ensure that positions that tend to become monopolies do not develop and that there is free access, open access to the internet. I think that is the other major principle that has been adopted. Of course, you have to be able to ask yourself the questions that one or the other has asked themselves precisely about the level playing field and precisely about possible risks. But there is also the question: how are we finally going to configure each other's offers among operators? I think it's a problem, too. So I believe, as the Commissioner has just said, that there are nevertheless certain safeguards that have been provided, there is first of all the important role of regulators in preventing, avoiding and correcting all kinds of abuses, including one of the abuses mentioned by one or the other, that is, discriminatory practices that would in one way or another challenge the very idea of the internet.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I close the debate. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Catherine BEARDER
text: in writing. – Last month’s vote was a significant step forward, enshrining the principle of net neutrality for the first time into law in all EU countries including the UK. The blocking and throttling of online content, apps and services will now be banned across the EU. However, important loopholes still remain, most importantly the possibility for zero rating, in which telecoms companies allow customers to access certain websites and services for free without using up their data allowance. There is a real risk that mobile operators could use zero rating as a way to incentivise the use of their own services, while lowering overall data allowances. These uncompetitive practices would be bad for consumers, bad for start-ups and bad for competitiveness and innovation in the digital economy. It is now up to national regulators to uphold an open, competitive internet which allows entrepreneurs and start-ups to thrive and compete on a level playing field. If operators are using zero-rating practices to limit competition and favour their own services, immediate enforcement action must be taken. I, along with other MEPs, will be carefully monitoring developments and fighting to ensure the principles of net neutrality we voted for are properly upheld.

name: Beata GOSIEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – A few weeks ago we celebrated the adoption of a telecoms package that will abolish roaming in 2017 and our citizens will not have to worry about bills when going on holiday. The compromise reached is the first ever EU regulation that provides an open internet and net neutrality rules at European level. I therefore find it difficult to understand why, a few weeks after the adoption of this package, the overwhelming majority of fellow Socialists and greens are trying to overturn this order. Consumers have the right to choose and the market should be free. Free services are good for consumers, so as MEPs elected by our citizens, we should not be against solutions that benefit them. I would like to remind my colleagues that, under the agreement adopted, national regulators will have the right to intervene in the event of abuse.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. – Zero-rating is a practice of mobile operators and telecommunications network providers to offer their end customers the data volume free of charge for specific services. This practice is particularly used for 4G networks, but has also been offered for SMS and other Internet services in the past. Zero-rating allows customers to use pre-selected content or data services, such as app stores, without having to pay attention to volume limits. As part of the telecoms package, the European Parliament has allowed zero-rating. The TSM Regulation follows the principle of non-discriminatory data management to safeguard end-users. The focus is on free use by the consumer! As far as transposition into national law is concerned, it is up to the national regulators whether or not to allow zero-zating. BEREC, the European regulatory authority, now has nine months to send relevant directives to the regulators of the Member States.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – Trust is central to the success of one of the EU’s most ambitious projects – the digital single market (DSM). It is the cornerstone of the information society, allowing citizens and businesses alike to make use of technology and expand their activity online. The lack of trust and understanding is the main obstacle to the digitalisation of Europe and one we need to address. Trust is also instrumental so that practices such as zero-rating are beneficial for Europe by providing businesses with more freedom to innovate but at the same time obliging them to use this freedom cautiously. For the first time ever net neutrality is recognised as a principle in Europe. Providers across the continent need to respect this and manage the future development of their services accordingly. Now that we are about to abolish roaming charges in Europe, we should put more effort into providing consumers with a broader choice of high-quality services. Only then will we create the right digital environment that encourages innovative business thinking and delivers the best services to our customers. Furthermore, we should explore the possibilities of using zero-rating to improve digital skills in Europe – the main prerequisite for the success of the DSM.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item is the Council and Commission statements on the financing of two new EU trust funds for Syria and Africa and the contribution of Member States to these funds (2015/2915(RSP)).

name: Nicolas SCHMIT
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I do not need to remind you once again of the seriousness of the crisis we are still facing. It is quite normal that this crisis, its difficulties, its problems and also its solutions, should be debated in Parliament. This crisis is not over and may not end any time soon, especially as winter approaches and the situation of tens or even hundreds of thousands of refugees deteriorates. Europe, the European Union and the Member States have not been left inactive in the face of this most complex situation, because there is no quick and easy solution to this problem. A number of proposals have been made. They are being implemented — perhaps too slowly, I grant you. But additional efforts at all levels remain absolutely essential. At their meeting on 23 September, the Heads of State or Government made a number of commitments to address what is already a major challenge for Europe today. The first step is to support refugees who need help and are close to their country of origin. In these camps, housing conditions are often poor, sometimes even catastrophic. There is often no school education for children who are the first and main victims of this crisis and conflict. Food security in these camps is sometimes extremely precarious. The consequence, you know it, is of course the departure to Europe for these refugees who ultimately have no other choice. It is therefore now important to live up to our commitments and implement them. An increase in contributions to various humanitarian organizations and financial instruments are part of these commitments, including the two new trust funds that we can talk about today. The heads of state or government have pledged to increase the European Union's support to international organisations and NGOs supporting Syrian refugees to the tune of EUR 1 billion. These include the World Food Programme, the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and other agencies. Half of this amount must come from the EU budget and the other half from the member states' bilateral contributions. The first commitment is being made, starting in October. The Member States have given us important additional commitments. The Union will exceed the planned EUR 1 billion, and bilateral discussions with the recipient bodies are already under way to translate these commitments into concrete projects, just as the Commission is doing - I think the Commissioner will tell us. With regard to the new trust funds, these are important tools for pooling financial resources from many sources, both from the EU budget, from the Member States and also from third countries, as well as from various budget lines, including humanitarian aid and development aid. The fund in response to the Syrian crisis is consistent with the contributions to humanitarian organizations I have just mentioned. The focus, particularly in this context, must be placed on the resilience and stabilization of the situation, which, as I have indicated, is extremely precarious. At this stage, the state of contributions to this fund, admittedly, is not yet satisfactory. We must now increase our collective contribution, given the chronic underfunding of resilience projects financed at only 20%, according to the UN, in addition to the contribution of EUR 500 million from the Member States through the EU budget. Let me also point out that the European Union has already committed more than EUR 4.2 billion for humanitarian action since the beginning of the Syrian crisis. The Luxembourg Prime Minister joined the President of the European Council and the President of the Commission in reminding all Member States of their collective responsibility in this regard. In Africa, it is our responsibility to create sustainable conditions so that people seek a better life elsewhere and find opportunities in their home countries. Their families need them; their talent, their energy are needed. The money they have to pay to smugglers and criminals for their passage to Europe would be better invested in the economies of their home countries. But let's face it, it's not going to happen any day! Indeed, we need a new approach to development that focuses on the creation of activities, decent jobs in African countries, on investments that we will make or support in these countries, on the training of young people which is often insufficient, on the development of traditional sectors that sometimes suffer from competition, even In Europe, in agriculture, at the level of fisheries, and we therefore have an absolute obligation to support what we are committed to supporting sustainable development. At this very moment, the Valletta Summit is being held in Malta, where the European Union, together with its African partners, aims to make important decisions on a range of migration-related issues. And as I just said, who says migration, who talks about migration, cannot ignore development issues. One of the measures within this package is the European Union's Emergency Trust Fund for Stability and Combating the Root Causes of Irregular Migration and the Phenomenon of Displaced Persons in Africa. Of course there are political issues, issues of human rights violations, issues of oppression that are very concrete - moreover, when we look at the countries from which illegal migrants come, they often come from countries where, indeed, human rights guarantees are completely absent, if not quite the opposite. As far as the European Union's contribution to this fund is concerned, it will be divided into two parts. The first comes from the European Development Fund (EDF) and the EU budget. That is why it was possible to clarify it at the outset. It is clear that our commitment to sustainable development in Africa must cover the medium and long term, because the problem we must solve is not a short-term problem, it is a problem that can only be solved in the longer term. The Commission has announced funding of EUR 1.8 billion by 2020. In addition to their substantial contribution through the fund, the EDF, which is an intergovernmental fund, some 20 Member States have so far announced an additional national contribution, to the figure of 1.8 billion. Switzerland and Norway also intend to contribute. At the same time, of course, the Member States' bilateral development aid programmes continue to be implemented. The trust fund is part of the answer, but it cannot be a substitute for the usual programming of our financial assistance, especially if we are aiming for a lasting impact — which I believe is our goal for all of us. The Valletta Summit, which is taking place right now, will be an opportunity to make additional commitments with our partners. I therefore ask your understanding if I am not in a position today to give you more precise and definitive figures on the bilateral contributions of Member States to the emergency fund. These will depend, for some, on the outcome of the negotiations in Valletta. My own country, Luxembourg - just to inform you - will contribute 3.1 million euros to the trust fund. We have a development aid contribution of 1.03 per cent of GDP. I would remind you that we have all made commitments in that regard; we made a commitment of 0.7% some time ago. It is true that not everyone reaches this 0.7%, and the situation is such that some countries have cut their development aid. I am not criticising and it is not for me to do so, but I know that, even in my own country, there have been calls for us to actually save a little on development aid because, in the end, it does not hurt anyone. We must then know that, even under budgetary discipline, under budgetary constraints, making these savings represents a cost that could be called a "deferred cost", because we see today that migration and underdevelopment are two sides of the same coin and that, if we do not take the issues of underdevelopment, poverty and exclusion of young people in developing countries , the solution for them will ultimately be migration at the cost and risk of their lives. We have often discussed - I think the President of the Commission has also said this - that it will not be barbed wire or walls that will prevent them from coming! What is at stake today is of course an investment in solidarity with our neighbours in Africa, but it is also an investment in our own security. I believe that this is what is at stake and that is what we need to do today and give an important signal at this valletta meeting.

name: Kristalina Georgieva
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, our world has become so wealthy that on an annual basis, we produce the incredible amount of over EUR 67 trillion. In this world of ours, unfortunately, the number of people that depend on aid to survive has been growing exponentially. Today, we have 120 million people needing help for their very survival. If they were a country, this would be the 11th largest country in the world, between Japan and Turkey. Half of the population of this country are homeless. They are displaced by conflicts or by natural disasters. Of those displaced, the largest share live in our neighbourhood. They live in Africa, North Africa and the Middle East. It is very clear that we in Europe are being tested not only to help the one million that have made it to our shores, but also to help the 59 million. That task is morally right, but it is also in our own self-interest. If we want to have a more manageable situation in which we can be good citizens and help people, we absolutely must increase our attention and support for people where they are – in Lebanon, Jordan and Turkey, as well as in the countries of the Horn of Africa and the Sahel. That is why we in the Commission have decided that, in addition to our normal development and humanitarian work, we are going to make use of the new Trust Fund instrument, because this has the capacity to pool large sums which otherwise may be dispersed in small and not sufficiently effective programmes. It allows us to make quick decisions and finance activities, and it gives us the flexibility to adjust to changing demands. It gives us a chance to bring in more donors and, by doing so, to reduce the administrative costs and increase the effectiveness and impact. We have taken decisions recently to create two trust funds. As we have heard, one of them is on the table of the Valletta Summit – the Emergency Trust Fund for Africa. I will start with that. It has already been discussed by High Representative/Vice-President Mogherini and Commissioner Mimica with the Committee on Foreign Affairs (AFET) and the Committee on Development (DEVE) in September. On 9 September, President Juncker framed the proposal for the creation of this trust fund with the objective of helping people, addressing the root causes of instability and irregular migration, and helping displaced populations in Africa. I am very pleased to say that, between 9 September and 20 October, work had advanced to a point where we in the Commission were able to adopt the relevant decision with the draft constitutive agreement to get the trust fund up and running. It focuses on providing economic opportunities, supporting the resilience of communities, building more security and development opportunities and providing better migration management in the Sahel, Lake Chad, Horn of Africa and North Africa. It is very important to stress that the trust fund helps us to tackle the root causes of migration and to help people with immediate priority needs. It is flexible, it allows immediate and concrete actions, and it is also a very good framework for more EU visibility for doing what our people fund us to do. The specific targeted actions include creating employment, especially for young people and for women; building links between development and security; and supporting very concrete actions in terms of migration and refugee management. We are looking forward to the outcomes of the Valletta Summit. We hope to see additional resources. Today, as we have heard from Mr Schmit, we have EUR 1.8 billion in the trust fund, plus an additional EUR 70 million committed already by Member States, and I hope that we will see additional commitments at the Valletta Summit. I want also to flag up that in this trust fund we are proposing to allocate EUR 200 million to a specific window for Morocco, Algeria, Tunisia, Libya and Egypt. I do not need to explain why these countries are such an important target area for that kind of assistance. The second trust fund we have created is the Regional Trust Fund in response to the Syrian crisis. It was established in December 2014 with the objective of providing a more coherent and comprehensive aid response to the Syrian crisis on a regional scale, primarily focusing on the needs of Syrians in neighbouring countries. But we are also able to use this fund to help Syrians in Syria, and to help Syrians that have already taken the route to Europe and are in some of the countries neighbouring the EU on the western route. This fund has actually got a very appropriate name. The name is the Madad Fund. Madad means hope, and it is about sending a signal to the Syrian refugees that the world has not forgotten them, that there is hope. Many of them are on their way to Europe because they lost hope for themselves and for their children. One of the objectives of the fund is in fact to support education for Syrian children. This has been one of the biggest tragedies of this five-year war. Syria is a country that used to be very high in educational achievement, with a 97-98% literacy rate. It was a country where you would ask children what they wanted to be they would say a doctor, an engineer or a teacher. Almost two-thirds of these children are either out of school or are attending school irregularly. Having a chance to help them to get the education they deserve is also a way to help their families to stay and not to be on the move. To date, we have received pledges from nine Member States to contribute to the fund. This is an additional EUR 2 million, and we certainly hope that there will be pledges from Member States but maybe also from third countries. I want to thank the Member States that have already contributed, but also those that have contributed directly to UNICEF, UNHCR and the World Food Programme. It is a critical moment for us, as Europeans, to stand up and be counted and to convey to the world the confidence that Europe is a force for good.

name: Reimer BÖGE
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Commissioner, Minister, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. I have heard your incantations. But at the same time I confess: I am disappointed. I agree with you on one thing, Minister: anyone who thinks that he can solve the problems with fences and barbed wire is mistaken, he is only obstructing one's own view. But you obviously cannot say today who wants to contribute to these two funds, when and how much. So that we do not misunderstand, we all worked together in a fast-track procedure a month ago to ensure that EUR 9.2 billion was allocated from the European budget in 2015 and 2016 through massive reallocation and a change of priorities. But if you listen to what the United Nations Commissioner for Refugees, Mr Guterres, has said – 5 000 every other day until the end of February, more than half a million people – small signs are not enough if we want to help them stay in the camps near their home countries. And what is now being spent on the World Food Programme, including what has now become more of a budget for UNHCR in October, is very modest and cautious, but at least something is moving. But you're far from winter-proof – far from it! That is why I say here too: the question of the distribution mechanism should not have been used in Article 78(3), but should have been used to rely on Article 79(3), a common system for the temporary protection of displaced persons in the event of a mass influx. We did not dare to do that. Many Member States are partly responsible for this. That is why I would ask you now to make sure that this fund solution works. Otherwise, we will have to call them into question again. And please, Commissioner, at every meeting of the Committee on Budgets, report on who, when and how much, otherwise we will lose credibility and humanism and solidarity in the European Union will go bankrupt.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, Commissioner, Mr Minister, I believe that there are no longer any qualifiers for defining the refugee crisis we are experiencing and the challenge that is taking place for the European Union: legal challenge, social challenge, humanitarian challenge and, also, budgetary challenge, and on the latter I will focus on. When the European Commission presented the European Agenda on Migration, it included the necessary funds – almost EUR 10 billion, including those EUR 2 300 for trust funds for Syria and Africa – and I sincerely believe that a commendable effort is being made from the European Union, through the budget, to address this crisis. But the needs and commitments do not end there, because that is the part that corresponds to the European budget, but what about the part that corresponds to the Member States?  Both at the informal Council on 23 September and at the October European Council – and Minister Schmit recalled – Member States undertook to contribute, together with UNHCR, to the World Food Programme and other agencies, worth EUR 1 billion, as well as to equal european contributions to trust funds. Unfortunately, despite the efforts of some Member States, we still lack more than EUR 2 billion. But it is not going to be bad news, and the European Commission recently informed us that Member States will receive EUR 9.4 billion from the European budget for various adjustments, but also for extraordinary revenue from fines and tariffs.  We have already let the Council know: this Parliament does not call into question either the amount or legality of that reimbursement, but it would certainly seem to us a commendable political gesture if the 28 committed to using some of this extraordinary revenue from the European budget to finance their corresponding share of the trust funds.  Making our actions match our commitments is the greatest test we face and it is a test that we cannot afford to fail. This ends the letter that President Tusk, Prime Minister Bettel and President Juncker have sent at 28. Let's see if it's true!

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her It is clear to all of us that the Member States of the European Union must assume their responsibilities in dealing with the current crisis. This includes our agreement to this motion, because it is Precisely Syria and the African continent as a whole that need our help right now. That is why EUR 2.3 billion is an adequate – certainly not sufficient – sum, but at least. This is not only necessary from a budgetary point of view, but is also a question of how money can be used efficiently. We have always believed that we must use our resources as close as possible to the hotspots, because we are much more effective there, because we can achieve more there for the same money: that is, we should ensure that people do not flee thousands of kilometres, but that we should be as close as possible, on the ground. Help. We are talking about the budget here, and that is the issue. What we always criticise, however, is that we usually only talk about the budget. We're just talking about money. I still lack a clear concept worthy of the EU, so that we can finally look at these many aspects and come up with a real solution. We will not only be able to solve this crisis with money. We will need money, but not only. We must finally return to the point where the law and order of law applies in the EU, but also to apply it uniformly. Thanks.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Madam President, Mr President, Madam Vice-President, I have listened attentively to you and I do not hide from you that I have remained somewhat hungry. It seems to me that you are a little underestimating the seriousness of the situation. The latest figures published by the Commission speak, for the next two years, of an additional 3 million refugees. If this is the situation we are facing, we must have the courage to say so! So I think you're a little below the truth. But I find you a little above the truth as to the results you expect from the actions you have just taken or are about to take.  Agree with the funds, but let's look at the Syrian fund, which is one billion, if the Member States contribute up to the 500 million they must add to the Commission's 500 million. One billion while there are 2.5 million refugees in neighbouring countries and 4 to 5 million displaced people in Syria itself.  A billion! In Europe to relocate 160,000 refugees, we will spend a billion. Make the comparison and tell me if objectively you do not expect this billion excessive results.  Overall, I tend to say that when you look at the instruments that are already operational, such as the European Development Fund or bilateral cooperation, one billion from the Syrian fund and 1.8 billion from the African fund is a drop in the bucket! I would like to think that it will change something, but only on the margins. What would be fundamental is for the European Union and the Member States to define a comprehensive strategy and pool all the instruments to try to see how we can achieve better results than we have achieved so far. Especially since there is still a question. Who will distribute these funds to in Turkey? To Erdogan who is asking for them, or to organizations specializing in helping refugees?  Cooperation yes, but submission and curves no!

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: thar ceann an Ghrúpa GUE/NGL. – A Uachtaráin, ba mhaith liom a rá leis an gCoimisinéir go gcaithfimid an fód a sheasamh ar son na dlúthpháirtíochta. Caithfear feabhas a chur air, agus cur chuige atá coitianta agus comhtháite a ghlacadh chun tacaíocht a thabhairt do chabhair dhaonnúil agus chun tacaíocht a thabhairt don phróiseas síochána agus forbairt inbhuanaithe taobh istigh de fhrámaíocht atá trédhearcach agus cuntasach. Cé go gcuirimid fáilte roimh an tsolúbthacht agus an éifeachtúlacht, tá na cistí iontaobhais fós róbheag chun aghaidh a thabhairt ar an ngéarghá agus ar an bpráinn atá ann faoi láthair maidir le cobhsaíocht agus cabhair dhaonnúil do thíortha ar nós an tSiria, an Tuirc, srl, mar aon le réigiúin san Afraic ar an dtaobh eile. Is cosúil amanna go bhfuilimid ag infheistiú níos mó i dtroscán sa tigh seo seachas i ndaoine. Caithfear tosaíocht a thabhairt do chiste iontaobhais don Afraic ar bhonn daonnachta. Buiséad an AE is ea príomhdheontóir den chiste iontaobhais. Tá sé riachtanach – laistigh dá inniúlachtaí – go gcinnteoidh an Coimisiún go mbeidh Ard-Stiúrthóir an Mhéadaithe freagrach agus go dtiocfaidh an stiúrthóir sin os comhair Pharlaimint na hEorpa chun ceisteanna ar an straitéis fhoriomlán maidir le cistí iontaobhais an AE a fhreagairt. Ba cheart don Choimisiún tuarascáil bhliantúil a sheachadadh ar an gcabhair dhaonnúil, ar fhorbairt shóisialta, ar an tionchar eacnamaíoch agus ar chobhsú na dtionscadal maidir le maoiniú na gcistí iontaobhais sna réigiúin. Ba chóir go mbeadh eolas iomlán tabhartha maidir leis na heintitis atá freagrach as na tionscadail a chur chun cinn agus a chinntiú go bhfuil comhlíonadh iomlán ann le rialacha airgeadais an AE. Tá sé tábhachtach go gcuirfí feabhas ar ionstraimí airgeadais ionas go mbeidh i bhfad níos mó solúbthachta ann agus go mbeidh siad níos éifeachtaí i mBuiséad an AE. Tá sé riachtanach a chinntiú gur próiseas trédhearcach agus daonlathach a bheidh i gceist.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, I remember very well when Commissioner Georgieva paid her last visit to the Committee on Development before she became Vice-President responsible for budget matters, and I remember very well that you, Madam Georgieva, said that if we are not going to address the root causes of the humanitarian crisis, nobody will be able to cope with the cost and suffering of those crises. I think you were absolutely right. Of course we all should have seen the signs, which were there already. I must say this time that I am happy to have the Luxembourg Presidency on board. Luxembourg is a small but very consistent donor and development partner, and you should not be shy about the reductions in the development aid budgets in other EU Member States. I regret very much that my country, Finland, is reducing its development aid by 42%. This is not a reduction; it is a collapse. Under these conditions, even Commission President Juncker said that it is abnormal for Member States to cut their development aid budgets. We nevertheless have the trust funds and we have to make the best of them, but I do have a few questions. When we are dealing with emergencies and very urgent situations, how are we going to stick to the principles of aid effectiveness? How are we going to respect country ownership? How are we going to stick to our human rights-based approach to aid? How are we going to avoid fragmentation of aid, which is a plague – however much we try to avoid it? This money is mostly not new money, and we have to understand that it is going to be at the cost of some ongoing activities. How are we going to ensure that there will be complementarity of these trust funds with other funds, and so on?

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, both Commission President Juncker and High Representative Mogherini, as well as Commissioner Georgieva, have repeatedly stressed the importance of tackling migration in their root causes, also calling on the Member States to commit themselves. In fact, my feeling is, to quote Fabrizio De André, that the European Union is consternation, committed, indignant, and then throws in the towel with great dignity, or perhaps without any dignity when we refer to official development assistance, which has been mentioned by the Council and which is not actually respected. These are commitments, they are words that are not followed by deeds. Now, when we talk about this trust fund, we know that these are funds that are being distracted, that they are being shifted from development funds and therefore there is a risk of having a methadone effect with a drug addict, because we are in danger of not curing anything at all, while we know very well that if we want to tackle seriously what are the roots, what are the problems that lead to large migrations we must intervene at the root with serious programmes helping small and medium-sized enterprises. , helping education and health.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, we have learned this morning that the Syrian army has finally managed to break the siege it has been under for more than two years now around Kweires airport, a strategic military airport on the outskirts of Aleppo, a martyred city of this never-ending conflict. I want to salute this key victory in the fight against the Islamic State, and I hope that this is the beginning of the end for this Islamist terrorist organization. Since the outbreak of the Syrian conflict, the European chancelleries have singularly lacked pragmatism. All they did was throw oil on the fire by closing their embassies and then supporting rebel factions that had only the name. Last March, together with my colleague Marie-Christine Arnautu, I tabled a motion for a resolution calling for the resumption of diplomatic relations with Syria, prior to any resolution of this conflict. For once, I must acknowledge to the European Union a certain lucidity, because the head of the European Union's delegation to Syria has never broken off the dialogue with the Syrian authorities. In fact, Mr. Anis Nacrour continues to visit Damascus several times a month. With regard to the aid to be provided to the Syrian people, I regret that the Commission is relying on organisations such as Doctors Without Borders, which only intervene in rebel-held areas. Instead, we should help organizations that work throughout Syria and carry out their true humanitarian mission without taking sides. I am thinking of the Red Cross and the UN agencies which, overwhelmed by the scale of the tragedy, are now short of funding. I also invite you to support NGOs that have proven themselves, such as the Work of the East and SOS Christians of the East, whose young volunteers, as dynamic as they are effective, work as closely as possible to the people in Syria, of course, but also in Iraq, Lebanon and Jordan. These well-known and recognized organizations are doing a remarkable job through the dialogue they have established with local authorities. So take inspiration from their pragmatism!

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: – Madam President, the most important task in solving the migrant crisis would be to eliminate the resource. This would need to bring peace and stability to countries affected by the Arab Spring through international cooperation. This decision, the establishment of an African Emergency Fund, is a positive step towards a way for refugees to remain close to their country of origin. However, the protection of the Schengen border in Greece must be solved at the same time. If this does not work, the fence will be left to prevent illegal border crossings, which we Hungarians call it, and our Austrian friends will say "door wings". So to date, the EU has only tried to manage migration. It is time to stop the migration and defend Europe's identity and culture.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: – Madam President, the Member States will now receive EUR 9.4 billion from the European Union budget at the end of the year. Revenues that were not foreseen, additional revenues, extraordinary. Of this 9,400 million euros, 2,300 million are revenues from fines and also customs duties. An amount exactly equal to that which the Council owes, the Member States, should put into these two trust funds for Syria and Africa. This means that, without any additional financial effort, without seeking any effort from national budgets, Member States can use EUR 2.3 billion to make their commitments to these two funds.  This refugee crisis, which is an obligation, this refugee crisis, where problems must be solved at the origin, is something that we have to assume, all institutions must participate and these two funds will give hope, they will give guarantees of a better future. They're going to contribute to the education of the people at their origin, they're going to prevent it. It is always better to be safe than sorry and I hope that the additional amounts that the European Union budget will give to national budgets will be used to help solve this problem.   (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162(8)).

name: David COBURN
text: blue-card question. – May I just ask the gentleman a question and see if he agrees with me? At the moment, Great Britain has put more money into camps on the Syrian-Turkish border than anybody else. Would it not be better if these countries handed the money over themselves, or set up their own camps in Syria, rather than the European Union taking the money, which it will no doubt waste in the usual way it does? At the moment, the European Union has not been properly audited for the best part of 20 years. Let us leave it to the national governments to do it and keep the European Union’s sticky fingers out of it.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: Response according to the "blue card" procedure. – Mr President, the United Kingdom, like the other Member States, will receive additional funding. It is in your availability, it is in your will, to use these funds for this purpose.  What I have tried to mention is that no taxpayer from any country, with this 2,300 million euros of additional revenues from fines and customs revenues, no national taxpayer would be penalised for this purpose and with this way of acting.  It is also too clear that these funds should be well used, they must be well managed. The objectives must be achieved, they must be monitored. Seriousness, efficiency are unquestionable in the management of these funds. It is clear that this is not always achieved in any Member State, in any organisation.

name: Jens GEIER
text: Madam President, Minister Schmit, Vice-President Georgieva, I would like to thank the Rapporteur on the work she has done on this. Let us imagine for a moment a patient on the couch of a psychiatrist who says something like this: 'Mr Doctor, I am the head of government of a Member State of the European Union. When I am in Brussels and i am sitting with my colleagues in the European Council, I take decisions in which I call on myself, as head of government, to make payments, for example, to the EU trust funds in order to be able to combat effectively the causes of the refugee crisis. And when I am back in my office in my capital and head of government, I say to myself: oh, this is only a general declaration of intent and not legally binding at all. This invitation to myself, I ignore it." What would a psychiatrist do? Prescribe medication? Surely he would recommend therapy. Unfortunately, however, what this little anecdote describes is a European reality at the moment! European Council meetings rightly recommend setting up trust funds to tackle the root causes of the refugee crisis, and Member States do not respond at all, or with rather small amounts, but which are sufficient to secure the right to vote in the allocation of funds. And this in a situation in which the Member States are faced with a warm rain of money from the EU: the European Commission has just presented Amendment Budget 8 in 2015, which will relieve the Member States by as much as EUR 9 billion. So the money is there. And it is more than 100 times more than the €82 million that the Council intends to withhold in the EU's draft budget for 2016 in order to be able to "respond to unexpected developments" in tackling the causes of flight next year. I can only appeal to the Council: use the political instruments now and make them strong. After all, the faster the trust funds effectively combat the causes of flight, the fewer unexpected developments there will be!

name: Stanisław OŻÓG
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur The European Commission has set up trust funds to support stability building and contribute to better migration management. By definition, a trust fund is a mechanism used in the field of development cooperation to pool significant resources from different donors. The European Union has allocated considerable resources to mobilising these funds, but expects Member States to complement this support. So far, few countries have provided concrete assistance. Question: What steps will the European Commission take to make this situation change? And the second thing. Some Member States, including Poland, will invest significantly in other programmes, such as the World Food Programme. Next question to Commission representatives: How consistent are the new trust funds with existing funds and programmes?

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: Madam President, the Syria Fund targets children and young people. I welcome the focus of education, livelihoods and food security. But for Africa, it is a question of combating the root causes of migration, including implementing the Khartoum process in partnership, including, with the world's worst regimes, including Sudan, which is still bombing its population - 3 million displaced - and Eritrea, an open-air prison where the European Union wants to install solar panels. These governments are the very cause of instability. They themselves participate in human trafficking, as a UN report has shown. This EUR 1.8 billion will be mainly taken from the EDF. African governments seem to have understood this and are beginning to say that they do not want to be the gendarmes of the European Union. Cynicism, fantasy? The European Union continues to turn its back on its duty of humanity, refusing to see that 90% of African migration is intra-African.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Every life lost on the way to Europe is one life too many and that regardless of what the reason is that you are fleeing, whether you are fleeing the war in Syria or whether you are fleeing poverty in Africa. As Minister Schmit said, these barbed wire fences will not stop either the refugees or the other migrants.  Maybe you can come in but then be sent back, because we want to send the other migrants back according to what is said all the time here, so they will still come back again. Unless we work on the root causes of why people have to go on the run. That is where I think we need to put in the great work.  What I am a little afraid of when I read the Council decision of 20 October is that there will be too much focus on what is migration-related and to stop borders and more, and too little focus on what is the long-term work for better development in the home countries. I fear that we are taking the focus away from the long-term, in addition to money that we also take from long-term aid work, and are spending more on border controls and other things. I hope that is not the case.  But then there is another problem, and that is the budget, as several have mentioned; that many countries are reducing their contributions. It is also the case that reception centres in Europe are also counted as aid and there are also large sums of money.

name: Nathan GILL
text: – Madam President, the idea of dealing with the problems of mass migration at source – or as close to source as possible – is one that we welcome. In fact, we have been calling on world governments to provide a global solution within the countries of origin or neighbouring states for some time. But, whilst European political establishments seek to use yet another crisis to demand yet more money from hard—pressed British taxpayers, we say no. There is more than enough money within the EU budget as is. If we stopped wasting this money on non-essential projects and actually channelled these hard-earned funds to lifesaving projects, we might see the public regaining faith in foreign aid. The spending of GBP 500 million on more than 100 publications and 1 000 videos, as well as cartoons, colouring books and other educational material is an example of wasteful spending and arrogance. Instead of promoting our supposed values through propaganda, the EU would be well advised to lead through example by immediately ceasing to spend this money in this way and redirecting it towards measures aimed at solving the refugee crisis.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Madam President, Commissioner, Minister, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. A special meeting of European interior ministers was held on Monday to raise awareness among European Union Member States of the refugee crisis. This is insufficient and insufficient in view of the greatest crisis facing the European Union. Equally inadequate are the Commission's measures, which do not help to deal with the crisis in a sustainable way. There is no real protection of the EU's external borders. The Frontex border agency has too few resources and a mandate that is too narrow. The European Union's relocation programme, with 160 000 relocations, is not very effective: 3500 places have so far been offered in the countries. Even for the funds we are discussing today – which I very much welcome – it is not yet clear how much, when and what will be given. This is an untenable situation: the stabilisation of the hotspots is far too late, and we have been reminded for a year by the UNHCR, by the World Food Programme, that there is an urgent lack of money. As we speak now, thousands of people are waiting to enter the border of my country, Austria. More than 400,000 people have been smuggled in since August. This is an untenable state of affairs for the citizens, but also for the EU. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI). Madam President, in the context of tackling the problem a resulting from the crisis in Syria and the causes of migration and travel to Africa, the Member States of the European Union will be obliged to pay more than EUR 500 million. But we are making a terrible mistake if we think that with this money we will solve the problem. Migrants and refugees will continue to come to Europe in waves, the need to finance them will continue to exist and the peoples of Europe, and in particular the long-suffering Greek people, will continue to suffer from the exterminating austerity measures imposed to finance illegal immigrants. In order to deal partially with the problem, we must try to challenge the causes which caused it. The money should also be given to the countries of origin of migrants, so that they can grow economically and their governments do not allow migration to Europe.  Hot Spots should be held in countries of origin and not in countries of entry, and finally Turkey should be forced to stop sending thousands of refugees to Greece and Europe.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: - Madam President, the European Parliament has been advocating a comprehensive approach to the refugee crisis and the migrant wave from the beginning, and in this context we welcomed the establishment of a special fund for Africa, along the lines of the already existing Fund for Syria. If we expect effective talks and agreements at the La Valetta summit, including more effective ways to readmission of migrants who are not entitled to asylum.  Then it is also clear that on our part we must show responsibility and seriousness when financing the fund for Africa. This means that Member States are now expected to participate, after the European Commission allocated €1.8 billion or rather realised these funds, mainly from unused european development fund funds. In addition to calling on Member States to finance the fund, I think it is important to mention here the issue of the effectiveness of The European Development Cooperation Policy.  The European Commission is expected to provide as precise information and measurable data as possible on the fund's objectives on the expected impacts. However, the issue of efficiency must not become an alibi so that Member States do not do what is right and necessary, which is to fund funds for Africa and Syria.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: Madam President, we are faced with an exceptional situation - I believe that we have not finished repeating this formula of the President of the Commission - in the face of a moral and historical responsibility which obliges us to find solutions to match the situation. Among them, the Commission has chosen to create the "Madad Fund" to respond to the Syrian humanitarian crisis and Parliament supports it.  Yet we have two problems with these trust funds. The first relates to the unfulfilled financial promises of the Member States.  The second is that the ceilings in section 4 of the budget are too low and that there is no more money for external action. This obliges the Commission to create instruments outside the EU budget, thus depriving its expenditure of genuine democratic control. The Union's budget and therefore the Union's action are stifling because they are corseted in a multi-year financial framework that is too narrow and inadequate. Not only will this crisis continue, but we will continue to face other crises. If we are to be credible again, there is an urgent need to confront the fiscal reality and to initiate a review of the multi-year financial framework.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, we have said this before in this Chamber that Greece cannot afford other refugees and illegal immigrants. The Aegean islands have been flooded by the thousands of poor refugees in Syria. And what does the European Union do? It gives crumbs to deal with the refugee crisis in impoverished Greece. At the same time, the European Union is threatening Turkey instead of threatening it with measures if it does not stop the commercial circuits operating uncontrollably, transporting thousands of refugees and illegal immigrants to the Aegean.  First of all, hot spots must be created in Turkey and other third countries outside the European Union. Secondly, to abolish Dublin III and to apply the clause on the distribution of refugees and illegal immigrants at European Union level, depending on the GDP, population and area of each country. Thirdly, to give development aid to the countries of Africa to stop illegal immigration from there. Finally, to intensifie efforts to resolve the Syrian crisis peacefully.

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: – Madam President, this year 1.3 million migrants – both asylum seekers and migrants – came to Europe. Next year, there will be an estimated 3 million. The EU solution is to provide a trust fund of a couple of billion euros to try and solve the African problem as they see it – an African problem that was caused by supporting regime change in Libya and Syria; an African problem that is caused by tariffs that compete harshly against African businesses; and an African problem that supports those governments that terrorise their own people. The EU is no friend of Africa. The EU is no friend of its African people. The EU is no friend of its continent’s potential for being an economic power, as the EU’s proto—colonial policies are indeed driving down the ability of that continent to survive. This damages Africa’s ability to feed its own nations through issues such as 7.5% tariffs on roasted coffee to protect the coffee-roasting industry of Germany. As the Nigerian authoress, Chimamanda Adichie, once said: Africans do not need limp gifts of fish. They need sturdy fishing rods and fair access to the pond to survive.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: Madam President, Mr Schmit, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the establishment of the Africa Trust Fund remains relatively innovative, but it should be remembered every time there have been 11 European development funds that preceded it. These programs have failed to anticipate and prevent the crisis we are experiencing today. So let's not stop asking ourselves why? I will emphasize three fundamental aspects: yes to intelligent financing, yes to anticipation and yes to result. First, the need for sufficient funding, but above all thoughtful and intelligent. Caution must be exercised. Let us make this fund a true multi-donor fund with the participation of our public and private donors and think together about how to give this fund a truly global scale. Second: anticipation. These funds must enable us to build the capacity of these countries, beyond the urgency, in order to better anticipate future crises. In this regard, what is the added value of these funds compared to the old development funds? How is the objectives consistent? Third: the results. If we are to increase the effectiveness of aid, perhaps it is time to say that one of the possibilities would be to limit our priorities to better target them. There is a need to strengthen the mutual obligations of donors and partner countries to achieve results by defining performance indicators and systematically referring to them. Finally, let's put into practice the principle of giving more to receive more.  Finally, the efforts of The Member States to participate in the fund must be strengthened and commitments must be kept, but we cannot ask our African partners in Valletta to do more if our actions do not reflect our words within the tools we create ourselves. It is time to redouble our efforts, while learning from the past, migration can no longer remain a grey area of cooperation between the Union and Africa. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: David COBURN
text: blue-card question. – Do you not agree with me that the European Union is absolutely, flagrantly, useless with money? We have had 20 years of the accounts not being submitted properly or signed off. Surely it is the worst possible agency in the world to distribute funds to Africa or to any of these camps on the Syrian—Turkish border. Would it not be better if the nation states of Europe – for example, Great Britain or France – gave the money directly or set up these camps themselves? What is the point of giving it to the European Union? Let us cut out the middleman; let us give it directly to those camps. Do you agree with me?

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: "blue card" answer. Madam President, thank you for the question. I have two answers. First, I think we have not understood the great lesson of this crisis. If, many years before, we had acted together as a Union, this crisis would not have had the dimension we are facing today. So, clearly, no, I do not agree with the approach that is chosen.  Secondly, it is enough to look at the figures which show how some indicators have improved thanks to european Union funding. We have less poverty, fewer malnourished children, women are better cared for in health care. For that reason, we should continue. Yes, it is not easy, but we have to continue because, in a few years, we are getting results. Whether we like it or not, the Union is strong and has more clout than a single state.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: – Madam President, I can only share the intention in the objectives that led to the creating of these funds.  We have more and more crises that last longer, we are increasingly in need, more displaced, but we do not have greater funding according to these needs. That funding is becoming less predictable and therefore we are not able to serve the people who need it.  Therefore, welcome these funds if they can provide more coordination, if they can provide more forecasts in funding and if they can provide more efficiency in management. But we cannot deceive ourselves or deceive others: most of these funds come from other funds that were already intended for equivalent actions.  In addition, the Commission has responded; but if we look at the list of Member States' contributions – I will not say which ones – in many cases do not correspond at all to the values of the European Union, which they advocate to care for the people who need it. Therefore, we need to make these funds additional and not simply substitutes for other efforts. If we are honest in preaching that we have to care for people fleeing hunger and war, we have to be responsible by putting the means for our preaching to become a reality.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Of course, the aid programme for Syria is to be welcomed. Hopefully, this will ensure the food supply of the refugee camps in the region. Several EU countries have cut their contributions to the UNHCR in recent years, despite strong warnings of a refugee crisis. Our German Federal Government and also the EU have ignored the problem. Now we are trying to persuade Turkey to secure the EU's external borders, and they are generously providing money. For years, Turkey has made a step backwards in democratisation, in freedom of the press, in human rights, et cetera. Now Mr Juncker has even promised Turkey the resumption of accession negotiations. What is going on with Mr Juncker? Isn't he talking to Donald Tusk? Mr Tusk recently called on the European Parliament in Strasbourg to protect Europe's external borders. Europe must get its own problems under control. Traditional tasks of each state, such as border protection, must not be sacrificed to Merkel's current hippie culture or spun off to autocratic regimes such as Turkey.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE). Madam President, I believe that no one doubts and disagrees that there must be support and solidarity on the refugee issue. No one in this Chamber, I believe, feels that we should not stand in solidarity and I believe that the European Union, the Member States, the European citizens themselves are the only ones who have stood in solidarity on the refugee issue. And the refugee issue I think is not just a matter for the European Union. It's an international issue. It is not only the European Union that can show sensitivity and solidarity and all the other countries that are indifferent. At the moment, the European Union cannot do its utmost to find resources to support the refugee crisis and not to create an International Refugee Support Fund.  It is an international issue that concerns both the United Nations and all countries. It is not possible that what the Arab countries are talking about is known for their huge investment funds and that they do not have a single euro or a petrodollar to support the crisis appeal as well. I therefore think that the European Union is wrong when many say that it has not done what it should have done. It could have been better. However, the only one that has taken action on the refugee issue is the European Union itself. I find it unacceptable, and I am not saying this either out of prejudice or for any other reason, that countries such as Turkey, instead of doing the obvious thing about refugees, as other Mediterranean and European countries are doing, are trying to take advantage of it. He's putting refugees in front of him to win in return. Not to mention the suspicious and destructive role it played in the instability in the region and the creation of the refugee problem. (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a blue card, in accordance with Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: blue-card question. – I am grateful that you support the concept that this is not simply a European Union issue, but a global issue. I have been campaigning for some time for the United Nations to come together. Would you support the argument that the United Nations has been gravely inadequate in this problem by relying solely on the European Union instead of calling for an international convention to deal with it on an international scale?

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), "blue card" answer. Of course I agree. It is not only that the European Union has given samples and taken excellence in terms of solidarity. We are a Union of solidarity, and that is why we support the European Union. You are absolutely right that it is the United Nations that must take initiatives but also other countries, which are silent at the moment and are not at the heart of the discussions, have had to contribute at least financially. Great powers from the American continent, from the Arab countries, from Russia and other countries cannot contribute and expect everything from the European Union, from the European Commission, from the European Parliament.  That is why I appeal and propose to the President that we address other organisations in order to deal sensitively with the refugee issue, and if they do not deal with it, they should be exposed and the European Union should not be exposed to an issue on which it has done everything.

name: Richard HOWITT
text: – Madam President, I was proud to be at the Valletta Summit earlier today and pleased to welcome the launch of the new EU trust fund for Africa there. I am very happy to be involved in this debate tonight, back in Brussels, to welcome the trust fund for Syria. I would like to thank the budget authorities for their cooperation on this, and I am pleased that Parliament boosted the amount in our own vote on 14 October. Today, at the EU summit and in this Parliament, I make clear, on behalf of the Socialist and Democrat Group, that genuine new money must be pledged. This trust fund cannot be a cover simply for reassigning existing funds. If it is an instrument which will genuinely attract additional international donations, then it will be welcome. To British Eurosceptics, who have simply tried to use this – and every debate – to criticise Europe, it is true that the initial Member State contributions have come from Italy and Germany and not my own country, Great Britain, but there are many of us in Britain who do believe that coordinated help amongst international donors can improve aid for those who receive it. That should be our objective. Let us remember that, while thousands of refugees have come to Europe, there are millions in the states neighbouring Syria. There is a shocking humanitarian shortfall. But it is right that we plan beyond immediate humanitarian relief, that we help refugees to gain livelihoods to integrate in their new societies, to assist host communities to receive them and to maintain cohesion in countries which are themselves fragile. The refugee crisis has been beset by short—term thinking. This trust fund is about planning for the long term, creating a better future... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. People for whom the risk of flight is less than the hope of peace and a better life at home set out. Both trust funds are a straw of hope for these people. I therefore believe that the Member States are negligent and negligent in their carelessness and with their promises. Promising 2.3 billion and paying 120 million is shameful and speaks for itself. I therefore call for a halt to the repayment of the 9.4 billion! From this money, the outstanding amounts must be paid for and necessary investments in growth and employment, in border security and in the fight against causes for the flight are paid for. This is the only way forward if the Member States do not seem to know what they are doing.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: PPE). Madam President, Madam Vice-President of the European Commission, Mrs Georgieva, the Greeks who welcome refugees to Lesvos and Kos and see children drown are asking, at the same time, what the European Union is doing about all this. The answer is that the European Union does a lot, but it happens in life that we are responsible not only for what we do, but also for what we do not do.  And indeed here the funding of trusts, funds for Syria and Africa, is dramatically delayed. And the question is: is the timing of the Member States' voluntary contribution binding? Is that enough money? No, it's the answer. When will they be paid? No one has answered so far. How will this funding be increased? Will it be taken into account that EUR 9.4 billion of additional resources are being given to the Member States to finance such actions as well? And thirdly, and more seriously, how do we as the European Union monitor the implementation of agreements with third countries financed from our own resources? Starting with Turkey getting three billion euros based on pre-accession aid. How do we do that? We must act, act now, because otherwise Euroscepticism will flourish on the despair that refugees bring to our soil.

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: – Madam President, the budget of the European Union is part of the solution to overcoming the refugee crisis. We have shown this with the fast adoption of draft amending budget 7 earlier this year – but draft amending budgets are not the best way to tackle such crises and unexpected developments. What we need to do is to properly define political priorities when we prepare the budget for next year and to properly finance them. Otherwise, the EU will again be in a position in which it is unprepared and unable to respond to a crisis, as we were throughout the summer. This also needs to be made clear to the Member States throughout the negotiations which we are now having on next year’s budget. Commissioner, Minister, we count on you making and passing this message to Member States, along the lines of what my colleague, Mr Karas, also described earlier. These two funds are, of course, important, because only by improving the situation on the ground in the countries of origin will we ever managed to exit and to terminate this permanent crisis management in which we find ourselves on the refugee crisis.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I would like to point out on this subject that, undoubtedly, Europe simply has to help. And I even think that Europe must not be afraid to intervene. The creation of two trust funds for Syria and the Countries of North Africa is really late. We have to remember that these people have been experiencing civil war for five years. And if anyone thinks that these people are really going to get killed or they're going to be in conditions of camp that are totally undignified, that don't give any future to their children, then it's clear they won't. I – and certainly none of my colleagues – would not have been living in such conditions, would have risen and gone. That is why it is important that Europe assists. Of course, I welcome the creation of these two trusts, but I just have to sigh that they were simply late.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Madam President, I warmly support the launch of the first ever EU Regional Trust Fund in Response to the Syrian Crisis and the Emergency Trust Fund for stability in addressing the root causes of irregular migration and displaced persons in Africa. Member States are expected to match EU funding for the Madad Fund (EUR 5 million) and the Trust Fund for Africa (EUR 1.8 billion) with voluntary contributions. At the same time, given the fact that some African countries with autocratic leaderships might not use this money properly, we have to keep an eye on the expenditure of this money, which could disappear very quickly through corruption. We know that this has happened before. These countries have to respect some conditions and these must not become again a way to blackmail the European Union. Ladies and gentlemen, it is important that Member States are politically committed to ensuring sufficient funding for these funds in their ongoing negotiations on the 2016 EU budget.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Madam President, the trust funds for Syria and Africa are I believe based on nobility and good intentions, but unfortunately will not contribute to better crisis management in these areas. This is a measure that is an expression of the Power of the European Union to contribute more effectively to the final resolution of the crisis in Syria and Africa. I'm afraid these measures towards third countries are counterproductive, whereas Europe itself doesn't know what it wants. After the initial invitation for refugees and migrants to come to Europe, which was evidently against the wishes of most of our citizens, today barbed wire and walls are flying within this Community among neighbours, partners and friends. What exactly is Europe's policy towards migrants? Why don't we make a deal first? Without a clear message to migrants that Europe can and wants to receive only those life-threatening by war destruction, above all women and children, these funds will, I fear, be a simple waste of taxpayers' money.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Madam President, the world is changing dramatically before our eyes. Relations in the world community are practically different every day. I see what we're discussing today as one firefighting measure that's late, but of course it's still welcome.  However, I would like to call on the Commission to launch a completely new initiative, a long-term, strategic and new initiative, in which I agree to include the United Nations, should include all those of our partners who live very well in trade and in business with the European Union, with our economy, our member states.  There are very many countries in the world that do very little to solve this problem that Europe is facing the most. Therefore, I think it is very important that the European Commission launches a new global world initiative, because this is just a firefighting resolution of the situation in Syria and some African countries.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: – Mr President, while ignoring the underlying humanitarian problems that deserve an answer, we must condemn this European Union which it destroys with one hand and is now trying to remedy the evil it has created with small crumbs. The European Union is complicit in all this barbarism. It is complicit in the destruction of sovereign countries such as Libya, Iraq or Syria. His hands are stained with blood by the deaths of thousands of innocent people, as well as by the wave of refugees who continue to flee the war, now facing the cynicism of the European institutions.  There are no values to justify these crimes and history will condemn the leaders who have tied the European Union and its countries to this slaughter.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: – Madam President, if migration is a problem, we should perhaps look at history. Homo sapiens emerged from Kenya and consequently conquered the whole of our planet. So this is not a big issue. I think Mrs Georgieva is doing the best she can do in order to facilitate a solution to the current problem. But we are not going to solve the problem by pouring more money into boiling hotspots. We have to think Europe, including in terms of defence and security. That is why I would like to stress, once more, that we need a common security, defence and foreign policy.

name: Kristalina Georgieva
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, two general points. Firstly, this is a global crisis and it requires a global response. We in the European Union are 20% of the world economy but 50% or more of development and humanitarian aid. We are doing our part, and it is important that everybody who has the means to contribute should do so. More wealth means more responsibility, and I share the comments that have been made that we need to call for mobilisation so we can help people and help people help themselves. My second general observation is that, in the same way that the financial and economic crisis has pointed out to us that we have work to do in terms of building the institutions and capabilities to deal collectively with this crisis, the refugee crisis is also exposing some of the deficiencies of the European Union in terms of collective action. I hope that we will see proposals ranging from border control, common defence and security, to rethinking Dublin but, most importantly, more coordinated and coherent medium- to long-term engagement with the countries that need our assistance to continue to build their own capacity to cope with their development challenges. It goes without saying that the best way to deal with the humanitarian crisis is not to have it in the first place. In other words, we have to invest more in conflict prevention, conflict resolution and disaster risk reduction – in things that help fewer people to be affected in the future by what, inevitably, climate change is going to cause – more disasters – and what, unfortunately, violent extremism is producing – more conflicts and more severe dramas. This goes without saying. I do not think that the European Union has been perfect, but yes, we are more engaged and we are contributing more than many others around us. I would like to make some specific comments. It has been pointed out, and rightly so, that we have to reach out to other key development partners, and we are doing so. I myself was in the United States last week to meet with the World Bank, the IMF and the US authorities. The US is our most important partner and the most aligned in terms of how we approach this kind of crisis, and we need to expand beyond an immediate urgent response to creating fiscal capacity for countries to have a buffer against crises, to get the development community more aligned in how we deal with fragility. I am very pleased to see the IMF building a much stronger capacity to address fragility in the world, and rightly so. There has been a very clear call that this money should not be a fragmented little island, and that is my fault, as I should have started by saying we are placing this 2.3 billion in the context of what is now 10 billion from the Commission to address the refugee crisis inside and also outside. The specificity of these trust funds is that they are a new way for us to better organise and deploy our resources in a more agile manner, but it does not diminish accountability, and we are of course going to have the reporting to, and engagement with, the European Parliament. I hope this will be more substantive, because it would be a well thought-out, longer-term programme. There was a question on whether this money is only revamping what already exists in our budget. The answer is that a big chunk of it is fresh money. We have taken a billion from the EDF reserve. This is money that is now added specifically to deal with this crisis. We have also found and relocated funds from lower-priority activities to what we believe is right now our top priority, and I think this is right to be done. We have been criticised, and unfortunately those who made this criticism were here to speak but not to listen – if you ask a question it is a good thing to actually wait for the answer. We have a very good track record in the European Union in development programmes, and in particular in humanitarian aid. The UK Government has ranked us – my former service that is, and I am very proud for the people there – as a top performer for a good reason, because we have eyes and ears on the ground and we are very connected to what the priorities are. We have been deploying our resources to aid people in Syria. The point was made that we only help the neighbourhood but not inside Syria. That is not correct. Half of our humanitarian aid goes inside Syria and about half of that goes to rebel-controlled areas. No, we are not going to disclose with whom we work there, because that would put people at risk – but we have a very strong presence there. We are one of the very few funders that have never given up on the most affected parts of Syria where bombs fall and people are living in tragic circumstances. The point was made a couple of times that we are wasteful and that our accounts have not been signed off for 20 years in a row. Wrong. Our accounts have been signed off for eight years in a row; the last signing came yesterday. We should not mix up errors, which are undesirable but are what they are, with waste or fraud, which they are not. Errors such as people incorrectly filing documents on how money is being used are errors, not fraud. I think we have to be clear that yes, we are facing an enormous challenge. This is hugely important for Europe’s own standing, and we will face this much more effectively working together. I hope we will see that these trust funds – which are, by the way, a new platform for action – will gain more traction and that we will see more contributions from our Member States and, I would also say, from others. There have been some encouraging signals, for example from the US, that they may now join us in the Syria Trust Fund; whether directly or through parallel financing remains to be seen. Finally, I want to thank Parliament very much for engaging in this topic, for its call for more joined-up action and for Member States to join us. I will finish with special thanks to Luxembourg, and to Minister Schmit. If only all were like you!

name: Nicolas SCHMIT
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Madam President, I do not have much to add to what the Vice-President has just said.
