I believe that we are in absolute urgency and that we must now effectively mobilize the resources we need. It is true that some Member States may not have reacted sufficiently yet and that not all commitments have yet been met. I will send a strong message from Parliament that the commitments are absolutely respected and kept.  It must also be said openly that there are no two absolutely separate entities: there is not the Union on one side with its budget and the Member States on the other. What we do, we do as the European Union. While some contributions come from the EU budget, and therefore from the Member States, and other resources come from the Member States, they must be put together. I believe what you are saying now about the trust fund, which must be opened as well.  I think you have put your finger on a crucial point, as have others among you: this issue concerns Europe first, because it takes place in its neighbourhood, and strikes us because people come to Europe. But in reality, this issue is not just about Europe, it is an international crisis. It is therefore quite clear that if we are to act, we must also engage the entire international community and in particular a number of States which have a strong interest in us's proper control of this crisis. The second point is of course the longest term. I think that is the whole issue of development. It is, perhaps, a matter of rethinking our development policies a little too because we cannot conclude that we are a success. Do we have to look at where the money is going? How effectively do we spend it? How can we engage the countries in question - to the extent that we can engage them because, as has been raised, we are sometimes in situations where there is no state, there is not a beginning of the rule of law, etc.? So there is also a major problem, because when we talk about Eritrea, for example, we know very well that there is a regime somewhere that scares people away, young people because ultimately they are forced to spend their lives in an army that they reject. So I think that is a difficult point to resolve and, of course, long-term action must be taken. I conclude from this extremely rich debate that we must give a clear message, that the only solution to control these problems is a solution of solidarity, there are no others. It is not by focusing on one or the other, by carrying out an action separate from the global action that we will achieve results. It is this conclusion that I draw from your Parliament's speeches.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The debate is over. Declarations in Iras (Article 162)

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. – The Commission has set up two trust funds as part of the package of measures taken to address the refugee crisis: the EU Regional Trust Fund in response to the Syrian crisis ('Madad Fund') and the Emergency Trust Fund for Stability and for the Treatment of The Root Causes of Irregular Migration and movements of displaced persons in Africa. Through them, the EU intensifies its response to current challenges, as a complementary tool to existing development cooperation in the region to help Africa's most fragile and vulnerable countries. Funding from the EU budget for both funds amounts to EUR 500 million for the Madad Fund and EUR 1800 million for the Trust Fund for Africa. While Member States have committed themselves to making voluntary contributions to achieve the amount equivalent to EU funding, to date that contribution amounts to only EUR 78.2 million. That is why, from Parliament, we call on States to fulfil their heads of state and government commitments at the September and October and November summits.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. – In my opinion, the key to solving the refugee and migration crisis is to deal with the problems that arise at or as close as possible to where they arise. This points in the direction that the European Union has promised a total of EUR 5.6 billion in financial assistance for humanitarian purposes in recent weeks, as well as the Africa and Syria funds, half of which (EUR 2.8 billion) will be allocated to the EU budget and the other half would be made up of eu28 pledges. As of 30 October 2015, eur 2.23 billion was still missing from the EU28 contribution of EUR 2.8 billion, which was promised by the Heads of State or Government at a summit. In addition to money, human and technical assistance is well below what is needed.  Due to the general cash constrictions, the fulfilment of the eu budget offer does not seem to be an easy thing to do either, but a recent Commission statement shows in black and white that the situation is even more worrying with the 50% contribution of the Member States. I therefore consider it extremely important that the Member States speed up the payment of their contributions to the Fund, because delays every day encourage new groups of migrants to travel.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. – The Commission has set up two trust funds as part of the package of measures taken to address the refugee crisis: the EU Regional Trust Fund in response to the Syrian crisis ('Madad Fund') and the Emergency Trust Fund for Stability and for the Treatment of The Root Causes of Irregular Migration and movements of displaced persons in Africa. Through them, the EU intensifies its response to current challenges, as a complementary tool to existing development cooperation in the region to help Africa's most fragile and vulnerable countries. Funding from the EU budget for both funds amounts to EUR 500 million for the Madad Fund and EUR 1800 million for the Trust Fund for Africa. While Member States have committed themselves to making voluntary contributions to achieve the amount equivalent to EU funding, to date that contribution amounts to only EUR 78.2 million. That is why, from Parliament, we call on States to fulfil their heads of state and government commitments at the September and October and November summits.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. – The Valletta Summit taking place today is essentially a stepping stone towards a better-managed and more effective international migratory policy. Immediate effective measures are not enough to adequately deal with this phenomenon. We need long-term solutions to encourage economic growth and the creation of more job opportunities for regions in Africa and the Middle East which are currently facing a mass exodus of people. The creation of two new trust funds is such an essential step for all. Europe is ready to invest in these regions, but in turn we must ensure that we have adequate safeguards in place to make sure that the people who need these funds are the ones who are benefiting from them. I call for these funds to be manned by reputable international organisations to ensure that projects are completed and create jobs for people in the region.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. – In 2015, Europe faced the worst migratory pressure in recent history. The scale and characteristics of the problem require a common European solution so that we can take global action against the root causes of migration. In recent weeks, the European Union has pledged a total of EUR 5.6 billion in financial assistance for humanitarian purposes, as well as to the Africa and Syria funds, half of which (EUR 2.8 billion) will be allocated to the EU budget and the other half would be made up of eu28 pledges. Hungary in line with its commitment to help the most vulnerable communities in their homes, it has pledged a €3.4 million amount of aid to community funds in addition to its other commitments. This amount is similar to the contribution of countries in our region with similar capacity.  We support our country's efforts to protect Europe's borders and to deal with conflicts that reinforce the wave of immigration on their site, i.e. where they were created. Only by working together globally and euly can we effectively address the root causes of migration.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. – In general, I support the idea of financially supporting development projects for countries enveloped by conflict, poverty and poverty. Improving living standards in these countries may deter the wave of economic immigrants coming to Europe. This is what the European Commission hopes to achieve with new trust funds earmarked for Syria and Africa. The problem is that for decades the European Union has been supporting developing countries, but the result is an ever-increasing number of illegal immigrants. Rather, it means that by pouring even more money, the problems will not be solved, especially as far as Syria is concerned. Before any financial means are intended, the problem of Islamic State must be resolved once and for all and peace must be established in the country.  As for the trust funds themselves, I believe that they should be aimed at establishing cooperation with countries of origin and transit, ensuring the effective implementation of readmission treaties, building the capacity of those countries in order to be able to cooperate in the fight against migrant traffickers and, last but not least, refugee camps must be supported. The situation in them is constantly deteriorating and that is what makes people flee from there to the European Union.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: in writing. – The PPE has always advocated a holistic approach to migration. The crisis remains serious and the solution to end it is complex by nature. Together with managing the migratory flows and protecting our external borders, we must tackle the root causes of migration. The number of Africans trying to reach Europe over the Mediterranean is just the tip of an iceberg compared to the number of displaced people in Africa. According to the UN refugee agency UNHCR, crises in countries like Somalia, Congo, Nigeria, South Sudan and the Central African Republic have forced 15 million people out of their homes.  Therefore I welcome the initiative of creating the two trust funds which through humanitarian and development aid should bring back stability, support resilience in Syria and Africa, and help refugees return to their homes. Setting up these trust funds is a positive action, and we must make sure that the money will be used in the most efficient way. The support to refugees must be given as close as possible to the country of origin and special attention must be given to children, who are the main victims, deprived of a safe environment, schooling and often even food.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. – The Commission has set up two trust funds as part of the package of measures taken to address the refugee crisis: the EU Regional Trust Fund in response to the Syrian crisis ('Madad Fund') and the Emergency Trust Fund for Stability and for the Treatment of The Root Causes of Irregular Migration and movements of displaced persons in Africa. Through them, the EU intensifies its response to current challenges, as a complementary tool to existing development cooperation in the region to help Africa's most fragile and vulnerable countries. Funding from the EU budget for both funds amounts to EUR 500 million for the Madad Fund and EUR 1800 million for the Trust Fund for Africa. While Member States have committed themselves to making voluntary contributions to achieve the amount equivalent to EU funding, to date that contribution amounts to only EUR 78.2 million. That is why, from Parliament, we call on States to fulfil their heads of state and government commitments at the September and October and November summits.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: in writing. Since the crisis broke out in Syria five years ago, there have been around 12.2 million refugees. But Syria is not the only country from which millions of people are fleeing, and war is not the only reason for migration. The two trust funds for Syria and Africa will face many challenges: extreme poverty, institutional weakness, lack of infrastructure, environmental stress.  It is everyone's responsibility to help those societies that are unable to support their citizens. Because to stop the exodus there is no need to build new walls and barriers: we need to invest in programmes that create job opportunities. We need to invest in training and in micro and small businesses. It is essential that the Member States make their contribution, but even more important is the proper management of these trust funds, so that the money is not once again dispersed into inefficiencies and corruption.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: Writing. – With the concept of funding funds for Syria and Africa, the European Union is taking another step towards a Community solution. From previous initiatives based on community and Member State solidarity, Hungary has tried to pull himself out, instead the government has surrounded the country and developed a refugee policy based on accelerated procedures rejecting asylum applications on a number of points and, in effect, a total disregard for EU core values. The European Commission recently sent a letter expressing its concerns and questions about Hungarian legislation and undermining EU core values, but since then the government has only done so by rejecting the proposal for a quota system to be used as a common solution by a parliamentary decision. It is worrying that while the Government is communicating the use of EU funds as its own success, often in a desperately corrupt way, it is using populist rhetoric to desecrate the Union in dealing with the refugee crisis. So far, the Hungarian Government has shown little sign of cooperation, which is also an EU core value. Despite the fact that the Prime Minister has repeatedly said that he does not consider the idea of a financial contribution to be devilish – in the case of Turkey he himself proposed it – it is only with fear that the current initiative will not be swept off the table on principle.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. – Trust funds focused on managing the Syrian crisis and serving stability in Africa are instruments by which the European Union can take concrete and effective action in resolving the migration crisis and the tragic situation in North Africa. These funds will enable the implementation of vital programmes that can enable people to stay by supporting better living conditions in the countries concerned. Member States should understand that by investing in funds for stability in Syria and Africa, they are contributing to eliminating the root causes of the migrant crisis.  It is not enough to have populist political talk about our humanitarian duty to take in whom and when, or to protect our daily lives from the masses of immigrants. Concrete steps are needed, and these two funds provide a tangible solution. This will save lives from the dangerous journey and pre-conflict within our own borders. I therefore urge the Member States to reach deep into their pockets and make these funds budgetaryly operational as soon as possible. He wins lives, he buys time... therefore, by stalling, we cut the tree just below us.

name: Andrey NOVAKOV
text: in writing. – The European budget is an investment engine for the EU, but also an instrument to support third countries. In both cases, performance orientation, clear priorities and measurable results are needed. Trust funds for Syria and Africa are one of the instruments of support to third countries. The two funds now have $2.3 billion in assets. from the budget. The European Commission expects Member States to contribute an equivalent amount to the Funds. These instruments come with their shortcomings, such as the voluntary principle of contributions, as well as the lack of a time frame for transactions. Insufficient clarity around the expected results is also a serious problem.  Bulgaria approved 100,000 to be transferred to the Syria Fund, but a clear vision is needed to invest these funds in order to achieve the desired result. For the financing of both funds, it is necessary to use the flexibility of the EU budget, not a fresh resource. The draft amending budget No 8/2015 exempts a resource to be returned to Member States under the Own Resources Decision and Regulation 1150/2000 for its implementation. Member States should decide the size of their contribution to both funds on the basis of confidence earned, as well as a clear picture of priorities and expected results.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. – There must be a consistent response to the EU's migration crisis, both in the countries from which migration starts and in Europe, where we are already dealing with the consequences, but where winter is approaching, bringing more and more new problems. A number of countries have already contributed to the financing of activities to manage the EU migration crisis, and it is important that all other countries actually deliver on their financial commitments. It is pleased to say that Estonia contributes EUR 150 000 to the EU's African Trust. Estonia also contributes 150,000 euros to the MADAD fund set up to respond to the Syrian crisis.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. - The migration crisis is turning into a structural, protracted and complex problem in which political instability and uncertainty in Europe manifests itself. The creation of trust funds for Syria and Africa aims to address the cause of destabilisation and ensure greater coordination and a more integrated approach to overcoming the migrant crisis.  The figures show that only one in 10 refugees immig to Europe, while the rest go to Africa, so the logical focus is on African countries affected by migration.  Member States are urged to solidarity and provide funding. In the context of the economic and financial crisis in Europe, it is necessary to highlight to our citizens the importance of funds created to address the root cause of the migration crisis.  It is also important that the European Commission finalises the necessary procedures which are preconditions for providing funding for the two trust funds for Syria and Africa, in the context of this week's Valleti conference, where the next steps should be concreted. Funding is not the only assistance needed, but it is a prerequisite for a holistic approach to all aspects of stability in a spirit of solidarity and shared responsibility.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: Writing. – The European Union must, of course, keep its word and contribute to the funds for dealing with the crisis in Syria and Africa with the promised amounts. At the same time, it is necessary to talk about the fact that these amounts should indeed be used by the States to eliminate the causes of emigration, and that there should indeed be a noticeable change in the areas in which they are affected. It is important that resources support the development of the economy, contribute to basic care for the local population, improve food security, and better governance and increased security. The reluctance of the Member States is understandable, since the costs of the migration crisis are not yet foreseeable and, in these circumstances, the use of the development aid offered could be crucial.  On the other hand, it is also clear that, whatever the impact of the resources of these funds, the standard of living of the African states concerned will not be close to that of western European countries, and therefore a reduction in immigration requires the protection of EU borders.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. – For my part, I can support the Commission's proposal to establish two separate support funds for Syria and the African countries concerned because of the burden of migration. It should, of course, be appreciated that this is about the inclusion of resources outside the approved budgetary framework, which the Member States are offering to support these areas in addition to their other efforts under the Development Fund and other Community budget headings. At the same time, I consider it a priority that those fleeing war-torn Syria, as well as those arriving in Europe from certain African countries under prolonged migratory pressure, are currently the most serious political and economic challenges facing the European Union, the primary solution of which must be sought in the issuing countries.  I believe that this is also in the European interest, and these two funds can make a meaningful contribution to creating the necessary conditions. I hope that the serious situation and the support of the EP will encourage individual Member States to replenish the two funds as soon as possible, while, once again, I regret that my own country's government has been so little cooperative in jointly managing the refugee crisis in the EU.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Writing. – I consider these two funds to be very important, especially as assistance in resolving the migration crisis. Of course, their amounts are not small, but their direction is essential for the EU. If we can use this money to help stabilise both regions, i think this funding will be used much more effectively than on some of the EU's internal policies. Member States should therefore urgently provide appropriate funding for the activities covered by these funds. Their contribution will certainly be several times more valuable in the future.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The next item is the debate on the oral question referred to the Commission by Iratxe García Pérez on behalf of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality on the objectives of the previous Daphne programmes in the context of the new Rights, Equality and Citizenship Programme (O-000100/2015 - 2015/2827(RSP) - B8-1104/2015)

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: Author. – Madam President, before we start talking about this issue which brings us to the plenary session of the European Parliament at this time of night, I have commented with some colleagues, who are going to speak in this debate, that we consider that it is no coincidence that the debates on equality between men and women are always the last on the agenda of the different plenaries. We are therefore possibly moving this issue to the Bureau of Parliament to conduct a study and see how many times the last debates in the House have had as their object issues relating to equality between men and women. For us, for those of us here, it is not something that lasts, it is an absolute priority of the European institutions. And I'm going on to ask the question about the Daphne programme to combat gender-based violence. I wanted to start by giving some statistical data. In March 2014, the European Union Agency for Fundamental Rights produced a report on gender-based violence with truly chilling data: 33% of European women, according to a survey conducted, had been victims of physical, sexual violence, labour violence of different types throughout their lives. 33% of women! It is estimated that nine million European women had been victims of violence. This data became an alarm and tell us the need to act on this matter.  I'm going to give you more data. In what we have been in Spain, in spain, in my country, 44 women have been killed victims of sexist violence. And I can tell the figures because a law we have in our country, a comprehensive law on gender-based violence, makes it possible for real data on the situation, which at European level does not happen. Today in Europe we do not have approved criteria to be able to know how magnitude we are talking about when referring to a reality that we know to be a social scourge and on which it is necessary, it is essential and urgent to act.  Today we talked about the Daphne program. The overall objective of the Daphne programme is to prevent and combat all forms of violence, whether they occur in the private or public spheres. It also aims to achieve a high level of health protection, well-being, cohesion, and is a programme open to NGOs, public institutions, associations. It was created in 1997 as an initiative to promote the action of non-governmental organizations and establish better cooperation.  The European Commission decided to include the Daphne programme as part of the general Rights, Equality and Citizenship programme for the period 2014-2020. At that time, when this decision was taken, this Parliament, civil organisations, women's organisations spoke out against it, because it was essential for us that there was a specific European programme to combat gender-based violence, because the visualization of this reality is essential in order to raise the consciences of those of us who have the obligation and responsibility to act in this area.  Finally it could not remain as a specific program and remained in the Rights, Equality and Citizenship program. This programme aims to prevent and combat all forms of violence against minors, young people and women, as well as violence against other risk groups.  The financial endowment for the implementation of this programme, in this period 2014-2020, amounts to EUR 439 million; 43% of the funds are for Group 2, which is the fight against violence against children, young people and women. And we want to debate here and we want to ask the European Commission how these objectives will be pursued in the context of the new Rights, Equality and Citizenship programme, and we also want clarification on the amount of specific funding for gender-based violence fighting and prevention.  Since we are unable to maintain a specific programme and it has become widespread in a comprehensive programme, we want to know what the European Commission's intentions are about what specific funding will be in this area, what programmes will be able to be financed in cooperation with the Member States, with social organisations, with civil society, because we are talking about an urgency , so it is necessary that, from the Member States and from the European Commission, we are working to end, as I say, the greatest social scourge that Europe has at the moment.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Thank you very much for the Member's comment and question. He spoke so quickly to the end that the translators could barely translate. I also understand your concern, your criticism, that you may have wanted to bring the oral question forward in the list of items on the agenda. But if you look at the items on the agenda, you will certainly see that they were just as important.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, yes, the statistical figures are shocking. The latest figures which were delivered by the Fundamental Rights Agency and from other surveys really show that there is a huge instance of violence against women – and the numbers are not decreasing. We are fully aware of the need for better collection of data to address this problem properly and also the need for effective campaigning against violence against women. Another of the means which we traditionally use is funding grassroots activities and supporting Member States’ activities. There is continuity: we have funded activities contributing to fighting violence against women under the Daphne Programme, and we continue to do so also within the 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework, under the Rights, Equality and Citizenship Programme. It is our priority, and the objective must remain highly visible. This is why we have kept referring to ‘Daphne’ activities in the Annual Work programmes of the Rights, Equality and Citizenship Programme for 2014 and 2015. We want to make clear that, although the name of the programme from which the relevant funding is made has changed, the objective of fighting violence against women remains high on the agenda. This is also the reason why relevant calls for proposals published on the DG Justice website always contain a specific reference to the Daphne objective, both in their title and in their text. A filtering mechanism has been set up which allows searching per programme and per priority. This means it is possible for interested NGOs to have an overview on one page of all upcoming, open and closed Daphne calls. A reference to Daphne is also included on the website presenting the Rights, Equality and Citizenship Programme. We follow the same approach in all communication activities relating to funding opportunities under the Rights, Equality and Citizenship Programme. In particular, in order to raise awareness about the funding possibilities under the new programme, reference to Daphne is always made when the Commission holds information events. The Commission has so far organised eight such information events in cooperation with Member States. The Commission also participated in several meetings of stakeholders, where we were invited to present the funding opportunities under the new programmes. In their relations with Member States and in the relevant conferences, the Commission representatives will continue to refer to Daphne funding and to highlight its essential role in combating violence against women. Before going into the details of the specific amounts to be spent and the actions to be funded, I would like to stress that clarity and transparency – allowing Parliament and citizens to scrutinise the use made of public funding – are a must. In this respect, DG Justice publishes the award decision of each of its calls for proposals and the summaries of the projects selected for funding, including amounts and partners involved, on the website. In addition, a first monitoring report on the programme’s implementation for the budgetary year 2014 will be transmitted to Parliament and the Council at the beginning of 2016. It will contain information on the use of funds per specific objective, thus also including Daphne and gender equality. Now to the details. The whole amount reserved for the Daphne specific objective in the 2015 Annual Work Programme is EUR 14 million. The main part of it will be spent on concrete, tangible projects, awarded through five different calls for proposals. I insist that they must make a real difference to the lives of women and children in the EU. The first of these calls is already under evaluation. With an amount of EUR 3 million, it targets women and girls and addresses sexual harassment and sexual violence against women and girls. Two other calls, for a total amount of EUR 3.4 million, will specifically target children: one on the elimination of corporal punishment, to be launched in November, and one dedicated to support the already existing European hotlines for missing children under the phone number 116, which is currently open. In this case, the aim is to support the integration of hotlines into child protection systems rather than have them as stand-alone services, and to put in place structures and measures to ensure their sustainability after the end of the Union funding. The fourth call aims at supporting victims. Also to be published in November, it will tap funds from both the Rights, Equality and Citizenship Programme under the Daphne objective, and from the Justice Programme. EUR 3 million will stem from the Rights, Equality and Citizenship Programme, plus EUR 2 million from the Justice Programme, amounting to EUR 5 million in total. This call will address, in a comprehensive way, victims of violence and crime and will contribute to the implementation of the Victims’ Directive. The deadline for Member States to transpose the Directive is 16 November this year – in a few days. The funding will help women and children who are victims of violence to benefit from the rights deriving from the Directive, such as the right to specialised support services. A fifth call for a total amount of EUR 3 million will encourage multi-agency and multi-disciplinary cooperation to respond to violence against women and/or children, and encourage victims and witnesses to report incidents of violence. In addition, about EUR 1.1 million of the 2015 budget will be spent on supporting European organisations and networks that work to combat violence against women and children. About EUR 370 000 will be spent on procurement activities, for example for carrying out a necessary study on migrants’ attitudes towards female genital mutilation. The same general approach applies to the specific objective of the promotion of equality between women and men. I want policies with a tangible impact and a focus on implementing existing legislation. The whole amount reserved for this specific objective in the 2015 Annual Work Programme is around EUR 7 million. Under the 2015 Annual Work Programme, a call for an amount of EUR 3.4 million will be launched in the coming months to finance projects presenting innovative answers to educational and occupational labour-market segregation. The aim is to promote good practices on gender roles and to overcome gender stereotypes in education and training and in the workplace. Finally, for 2016, nearly EUR 1 million has been reserved to support the work of the European Women’s Lobby as well as around EUR 1 million funding for gender equality-related research. Let me also add from my side the comment that for me also the timing for the discussions on gender topics is rather problematic because they are held every time very late at night. It also gives me the impression that this topic is a secondary-level one.

name: Teresa JIMÉNEZ-BECERRIL BARRIO
text: PPE Group. – Madam President, that we live in an area of freedom, security and justice has been and is one of the main objectives of the European Union, and the new Programme on Rights, Equality and Citizenship will be the instrument under which the Daphne programme, created to combat violence against women and children, will be financed. That is why, and on behalf of those of us who devote all our efforts to combating violence, I ask the Commission to inform us of the funds to be devoted to this fight.  The numbers are alarming: sexist violence does not mean countries, so this battle must all be united. Women are harassed, raped, killed, both in northern and southern Europe.  Spain is a benchmark in the fight against gender-based violence and, despite all our efforts, we do not always manage to save these innocent women who are so often murdered in front of their children. Recently, in my country, the figure of the child has also been introduced as a victim, and adolescent awareness campaigns have been increased.  I feel a deep helplessness in the face of these deaths because one, one victim is too much for me. That is why I carried out the European Order for the Protection of Victims to stop aggressors in any country in Europe. We need greater protection and education measures.  Hopefully one day we will not have to be here asking the Commission to allocate funds to eradicate violence against women. That day we will have won the battle not only of security, but also of equality and freedom, but as long as we continue to give our voice to all women who are afraid and that is why they are silent.

name: Clare MOODY
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, an MEP’s life is a varied one. Today I have worked on artists’ rights, the Aviation Safety Agency, and vacuum cleaner efficiency tests, among other things. All of those were interesting and important, but while I was working on those issues, behind closed front doors across Europe, women and children were living in fear in their own homes. That is why, of all the things I have done today, the outcome of this debate goes straight to my heart. Since its launch in 1997, the Daphne Programme has helped fund some powerful causes. One such organisation which has received support is Women’s Aid, a national charity that is dedicated to ending domestic abuse. It is based in my region but works tirelessly throughout the UK to keep women and children safe and provide support to victims. My colleague Iratxe should be praised for raising this debate, even if it is taking place at this hour. We must have clarity on how the Daphne Programme will continue to work. It is through this clarity that we can have accountability – accountability on what we are doing to prevent and combat domestic violence. We must be accountable to those organisations like Women’s Aid, but most of all we must be accountable to those women who, as we debate in this chamber, are seeking ways to protect their children.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: for the ECR Group. – Thanks to the mediated case of the now former Member and Vice-Chairman of the Human Rights Committee of the National Council of the Slovak Republic, Vladimír Jánoš, the topic of violence against women also resonates in Slovak society. Mr Jánoš, who is accused of torturing his wife, is being prosecuted at large. And although more than half a year has passed since the charges were filed, the case has gone nowhere. Similarly, almost nothing has changed in the area of protection and assistance to abused women who do not attract media attention. Although government leaders had strong talk of taking effective action after the case was made public, it remained on promises and cosmetic adjustments. Free legal aid for women is still inaccessible, victims of violence do not stop complaining about insensitive and unprofessional practices by the police, prosecution and courts, there is no state funding system for crisis centres for abused women. As a result, victims of violence have no confidence in institutions, have nowhere to go from the rapist, suffer in silence. And why am I talking about all this? I am talking about this because it is the non-profit organisations supported by the European Daphne programme that are often the only straw they can catch for abused women. It is these organisations that provide psychological assistance to women, accompany them to the doctor, to the police, to help them find safe housing. These are these organisations which, to the limits of their capabilities, will, at least from time to time, train part of the experts. Daphne is an extremely important program. Every single euro matters, and I therefore appeal to you, Commissioner, to do everything possible to ensure that there is sufficient resources so that they are distributed as best and easily as possible among those who can do their job properly.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, I hope that, in this last debate, you will be as patient and tolerant in the management of times as it has been in the previous ones, where you have really given us a lot of room to listen.  I would like to thank Mrs Jourová for being here with us, not because it is late, which is not a problem for those of us here, because the important thing has no time; what is important is what this treatment means, the attitude it shows as to what is a priority.  I do not think anyone doubts that the Daphne programme has been a success since its launch in 1997 or that the Commission needs to provide concrete solutions and be more concise in explaining the improvements made in terms of transparency and dissemination of results. But it seems to me that one of the key issues on which we must influence is that many of these funds – on which Mrs Jourová has already explained to us in great detail how they will be implemented, how they will be allocated in parts – must be used to raise awareness among young people: the growth of violence against adolescents must be a priority because it is increasing and really alarming. I would also like to recall and say again that we will not tire of asking the Commission, without further resignation, to sign and ratify the Istanbul Convention. As I am informed, the Commission has recently produced a study confirming that this is a simple and feasible process. I therefore ask this Parliament today to be no longer aware of the specific date on which the European Union is going to sign and ratify the Istanbul Convention.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: gue/NGL Group. – Madam President, we have always considered that it was a colossal mistake to add the DAFNE programme to a wider programme, removing the specificity of this objective and, above all, by removing the allocation of own resources which can only be used for this purpose, therefore own resources for the fight against violence against women. It is clear that this strategy is part of a conservative approach to the issue, which tries to hide that discrimination against women is a structural injustice of our societies and that it tries to remove from the struggle of women the centrality that, for example, this programme gave.  The Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality itself, when discussing the regulation of the current Multiannual Financial Framework in its opinion, of which I was rapporteur, called on the Commission and the Council to take into account the issue of gender equality as a specific objective in the Law and Citizenship programme, as well as to maintain the DAFNE programme as an independent subheading of this programme. This position has been completely ignored.

name: Margot PARKER
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, I do not think anyone could argue that providing more help for victims and support services is a bad thing. The question in this debate is asking about the accountability and transparency of the funding of projects under this EU programme. In the UK, we have no doubt that the EU is completely unaccountable and undemocratic and squanders taxpayers’ money. If we did not pay GBP 55 million a day to the EU, we could do so much more to support and protect the victims of violence. We would then be able to hold the politicians accountable for their policies, every five years. Not so with the EU Commission. The final point I would like to make is that because of EU free movement laws, we are not even allowed to do a criminal background check on people coming to our countries who have a history of violence. Also, this open-door immigration policy provides the perfect environment for traffickers to exploit and abuse women and children.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, the Daphne programme is at first sight a sympathetic programme. Created in 1997, it has the merit of seeking to combat violence against women and children. Of course, it is necessary to lead this fight not only against domestic violence, but also against excisions, a barbaric rite imported alas!, in Europe for a few decades. However, we must be vigilant. A 2014 report reveals that the Commission has financed transnational projects to the tune of EUR 9 million. That is a lot of money, and it is not certain that it has always been used to protect women and children. The Bastos report of 5 January 2012 stresses the need to improve the transparency of programmes and the effectiveness of grants. In other words, a lot of money was distributed lightly, and NGOs spent it on operating costs. A Belgian NGO, for example, has received almost 400,000 euros for - I quote - "to get an overview of how to deal with the phenomenon of missing children". This did not allow a single family to find their child. It's expensive paid for a simple overview. The Daphne programme also has the disadvantage of trying to combat stereotypes. However, I am afraid that this is an attempt to promote gender theory. I strongly condemn this theory of gender. For my part, I prefer to remain faithful to biblical anthropology, of which a symposium recalled the news just a year ago at the Vatican. Men and women are different but equal. They must accept their complementarity, which is for them a factor of fulfillment and mutual fulfilment.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: – Madam President, Madam Commissioner, the Daphne programme was set up to help tackle violence against women, children and young people. Certainly with all victims of violence I deeply sympathize and I think we can always do more and better to help them. Of course, it is important to monitor the objectives of previous Daphne programmes in the context of the new programme.  However, it is also important to monitor how projects are implemented and the entire work of the organisations behind these projects. In fact, in recent months we have unfortunately faced grave accusations that some organisations whose projects were funded through the Daphne programme are involved in serious illegal and unethical activities that constitute the exact opposite of the objectives with which Daphne was founded. Given the scandal that accompanies America's Planned Parenthood, it is important to know exactly which European Planned Parenthood projects are funded by the European Commission to make sure that these projects really contribute to the right goal. It is important that we are absolutely certain that under the guise of protecting women and preventing violence against women, serious human rights violations and illegal acts do not occur.

name: Maria NOICHL
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. You have mentioned several times in this Chamber that the issue of violence against women is important to you. You have again stressed today that you are very concerned about the Daphne programme or the follow-up programmes. I would like to share with you another thought: every programme, however good, needs to be embedded in a strategy. Commissioner, I say this very strongly to you today: we are waiting for a strategy for gender equality in the EU! As rapporteur, I have heard in many places that the Commission may not want to put forward a strategy, that there should be no real action plans. Commissioner, if you take it seriously – and I would also like to address the whole Commission – if the Commission takes seriously that the issue of violence against women is an important issue in Europe and that equality is also an important issue in Europe, then we need a strategy for gender equality. A Daphne program or daphne continuation program is part of it, but a subprogram can never replace a strategy.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Madam President, Europe needs its mark and actions against gender-based violence, because this scourge has cost the lives, in Spain alone, of 44 women in ten months, has generated 40 orphans and three murders of minors, used by their parents to punish their mothers with the utmost cruelty.  This is true terrorism that requires a strong response and a comprehensive response. In the subconscious of many Europeans, the values and stereotypes that, taken to the extreme, animate it still persist. They are on billboards, in textbooks, in the narrative of the everyday, in the sharing of institutional and private responsibilities; create inequality and the most serious consequence of it: sexist violence. That is why the institutional, social and civic effort against it must remain, Commissioner, visible, transparent and didactic.  It is a bad time to launch against the European brand that fights sexist violence a lead arrow. Domination, disdain, and contempt led to the eternal condemnation of nympha Daphne and continue to kill thousands of women every year. That is why we need greater involvement, which we miss, of the whole Commission, including President Juncker.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: – Madam President: Elizabeth, 65, struck yesterday in the head to death at the hands of her partner. Unfortunately, one more example, among thousands, of the violence that women suffer within the European Union.  Their austerity policies are increasing levels of violence, especially in one of the most despicable manifestations, such as sexist violence. Diluting the Daphne programme, created to protect women and minors from violence, by mixing it with two previous programmes on a wide range of issues means downplaying importance, visibility and attention to a problem that must be in the status of a state affair.  The European Union can and must do better because it has a responsibility to build a Europe that cares about its citizens and protects its women from sexist violence. Those who do not take the necessary measures to defend women from such violence that murders them are responsible, by default, for these murders.

name: Romana TOMC
text: – As my predecessors have said, the Daphne programme aims to contribute to the protection of children, young people and women and to combat all forms of violence. It wants to achieve a high level of protection of health, welfare and social cohesion for these groups. In the past, this programme has played a very important role in implementing the objectives of protecting women from violence, and it would be right to maintain this programme. However, as the other interlocutors say, we must ensure that funds from this programme are spent transparently. We cannot allow an untransparent implementation to fall into a shadow of doubt on this good programme. Therefore, Honourable Commissioner, please ensure that this programme is indeed implemented in such a way that it achieves its objectives. Good luck with his execution.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I will in no way downplay the subject in the sense that violence against men is also being permeate or that there should be a minor name change. I consider this to be really serious, because violence against women is a fact, and we should all join the call for prevention. And I would like to ask the Commissioner – her speech was quite exhausting – but she did raise two questions for me. Firstly, how are this programme and the Commission's efforts, all five calls, coordinated with national authorities? And whether the challenge or those challenges are somehow targeted at countries that have a higher level of problem with this phenomenon than some others. Because the statistics on violence against women are really very different according to the Member States. So these are my two questions.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Madam President, the Daphne programme represents a key tool to end violence against women. I truly believe that the new programme of Fundamental Rights, Equality and Citizenship should maintain Daphne as a stand-alone programme to support women’s rights organisations in the field. However, clarifications are needed on the amount of funding, the allocation for different target groups and the visibility of actions to combat violence against women, especially the process of selection of projects and actions. The Commission should take action in order to ensure the visibility of Daphne-related objectives and to raise their awareness of the funding possibilities under the new programme on Fundamental Rights, Equality and Citizenship, taking into account the need to maintain the profile of the former Daphne programme. I welcome the recognition of the promotion of equality between women and men and the advancement of gender mainstreaming as a specific objective in the Rights, Equality and Citizenship programme.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, human rights violations are common in Europe, and even more strongly there is the violation of women's rights and gender inequality. The Daphne programme has enabled many problems of gender inequality to be solved. However, the European Commission must take multiple immediate measures to safeguard women's rights and gender equality.  In my country, Greece, it is memorial policy and austerity has irreparably affected women, as the unemployment rate of women in the first quarter of 2015 stood at 30.6% compared to 23.5% of men, confirming that memorial policies increase gender inequalities. At the same time, women are paid at least 16% lower salaries than men and with pensions 39% lower than men. These inequalities between the sexes must be stopped immediately, including through the Daphne programme.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Madam Commissioner, I would like to highlight two programmes, which I personally participated in when I was istrian prefect, which proved to be very effective when it comes to domestic violence against women.  The first program is a secure phone where victims of violence could answer and be immediately admitted for interview, and after that the organization of a network of safe houses where women could come alone or with children, if they had children, and in this case get concrete help from cities in Istria and Istria County, and a long, months-long assistance.   Such concrete projects are important, such concrete NGOs that care about these victims of violence must be directly assisted. And the last thing, I also want to warn about the victims of the war that was on the territory of the former Yugoslavia. There are many more women who are suffering, please help those organizations that care for them as well.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: – Madam President, in my country, in Galicia, so far this year, six sexist criminals have murdered María Isabel, Beatriz, Divina, Silvina, Concepción and María José. We ask ourselves: how long? We are also wondering, Commissioner, what is failing to keep this situation going.  We believe that the first thing that fails is the administrations. There is still too much tolerance for machismo; there's still too much complicity. Also these days, in my country, the press echoes institutional public positions that are harassing women.  We also believe, Commissioner, that this is not the time to implement cuts, that all means are few; specific budget measures are needed to end femicide; that these measures should be declared priority and urgent.  I call on the Commission and the Council not to be complicit in the murders with their policies of austerity and cuts.

name: Iliana IOTOVA
text: Madam President, the success of the Daphne programme in the fight against violence against women and children is well established. It therefore seems to me essential that its integration into the Law, Equality and Citizenship programme does not reduce its visibility and ensure the transparency of its funding and related projects. This programme is crucial in supporting associations working on the front lines in preventing such violence and helping victims. I would therefore like to stress three points: first, facilitating access to Daphne, especially for small NGOs, whether in terms of information, language or red tape; secondly, a fair geographical distribution of projects, particularly with regard to the new Member States; third, to ensure that the results of the various projects covered by Daphne are clearly communicated and visible. This is particularly essential for better coordination between European, national and local levels.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I wish to thank Members very much for this discussion and for once again bringing up this topic here. I will now try to summarise several key issues and also to respond to some concrete questions. As I said before, this must be a smart combination of enforcement of existing legislation. Some of you mentioned the application of the European Legal Order, which is a typical case. Also, the Victims Directive, which will be in force in all Member States on 16 November. Speaking of enforcement, I have in mind especially enforcement at the level of the activity of police and procurement, because we are speaking here about criminal activity, which must be punished but also published, and which must be responded to from the side of society. We see increased violence against women, but also other forms of intolerance in Europe, which is now a very nervous and unstable society. So we are seeing these increasing numbers in the Member States where there is higher intolerance from the side of wider society. It leads to the need for better use of funding for efficient campaigns, better training of people working in the field and very-well—targeted support of grassroots organisations and NGOs which do our work in the Member States on the ground and who also work with the victims. One of the big problems is that we are still missing data which is caused also by the fact that victims do not report because they still feel ashamed, as though they are the ones who have done wrong. This is also something which we have to change. As for the funding, I fully understand all Members who speak about the need to better evaluate efficiency and value for money. We are now evaluating previous projects and, as I said, we will submit the report at the beginning of 2016. I can only promise Members that I will be very strict and will look at projects which have already been funded from the point of view of tangible results and whether these have been achieved or not, because I am afraid that, in general, in funding we use again and again standard kinds of projects which in many cases have proved not to be efficient. We should go for more innovative ways and projects which are better targeted towards tangible results. We do not have enough money for combating violence against women, but that is a never-ending story, and we will always be missing money for important priorities because we have too many priorities to finance at the same time. Also, when speaking about legislation, we are not preparing any legislation for the whole of Europe. Next year we are planning, as the European Union, to accede to the Istanbul Convention, which I will also confirm here in plenary on 25 November, when we have this topic again in plenary. We plan to do it and we see this as a big step forward in the legislative field of combating violence. I was asked by Ms Noichl about the strategy. Yes, we are now finalising the document, which we are calling the Strategic Engagement of the European Union for the Years 2016 to 2019. This strategy will be submitted to the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality (FEMM) in December, and there, Members will see that the priority of combating violence against women is very highly prioritised. You are right, and only when we work on the wider strategy do we see the wider context of this phenomenon. We see, for instance, very clearly that there is a very close correlation between the economic vulnerability of women and violence. There are some other clear links which we have to look at when planning the proper actions in gender policy. So this strategy is now being finalised and, again, combating violence is one of four main priorities. In answer to Mr Polčák’s questions: yes, we of course cooperate with the relevant bodies, and not only with NGOs but with governmental bodies – with the relevant ministries – and we try to plan together with them the funding so that it is in good synergy. On the second question, there is no Member State package. There are no envelopes correlating with the appearance of the phenomenon of violence against women. I must say that this is based on the principle that we are trying to campaign and to inform more strongly in the Member States where this problem is more serious and where the tolerance of violence is higher, but then it is up to Member States and up to the relevant organisations to come for the money, so this is how it stands. I would like to thank Parliament again for talking about violence. We will come back to this topic later in November and, as I said before, I am ready to put the issue into the wider context of the gender policy which we are planning for the next three years.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: I, too, thank the Commissioner for her reply. I agree with the importance of efficiency gains and the importance of tangible results. It is important precisely for the sake of the victims that we do this and how much we can do it, and that is our responsibility, Commissioner. The debate is over. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. – The fight against gender-based violence is the most widespread violation of human rights in Europe and the rest of the world, and affects all strata of society. The overall objective of the Daphne programme is to prevent and combat all forms of violence, whether they occur in the public or private sphere, affecting children, young people and women, including sexual exploitation and human trafficking, through preventive measures and the offer of support and protection to victims and risk groups. Funded projects have been a real success in popularity and effectiveness. The Commission decided, despite the opposition of Parliament and civil society, to include Daphne in the new Rights, Equality and Citizenship programme 2014-2020. It is essential that the name 'Daphne' be maintained under that programme to ensure the visibility of anti-violence objectives and to achieve greater dissemination of funding opportunities. It is also important that the Commission ensures the transparency of information on the actions selected to receive funding and their contribution to the achievement of the objectives set out.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. – As White Ribbon Day approaches, the commemoration of The Day of Violence against Women, we must once again call on the Commission to ensure that the Daphne programme is implemented and that adequate funding is ensured. Daphne is designed to prevent all forms of violence against children, young people and women, as well as to prevent and protect victims of violence against other groups of violence, in particular those at risk of domestic violence. Various forms of violence are being experienced throughout the European Union, and its consequences for the physical and psychological health of the victims, as well as for society as a whole, are extremely severe. Addressing this problem and protecting victims requires strong political will and concerted action based on daphne methods and results. Action to combat violence against women contributes to promoting equality between women and men. Daphne has been a very successful programme since its inception in 1997, popular with stakeholders (government and academic institutions and non-governmental organisations (NGOs) and the projects funded are effective, so it is important to continue to link the Daphne name to the specific objective of preventing and combating violence against children, young people and women, so that daphne remains as visible as possible. So how does the Commission plan to achieve the objectives of the previous Daphne programmes through the new Rights, Equality and Citizenship Programme? How does the Commission plan to ensure adequate funding for the prevention of violence and, at the same time, support for victims of violence?

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. It is a fact that the Daphne programmes play a key role in combating violence against women in the EU. The available data require us not to lower our attention. 35% of all women are victims of domestic and/or sexual violence by their partner or strangers. The consequences are very serious and the numbers vary according to the country and the culture to which they belong. In Italy, almost 7 million women between the age of 16 and 70 would be victims of physical and sexual abuse, or 31.9%. The regions of the Mezzogiorno almost always have values lower than the national figure, although we must consider the different factors that contribute to the willingness of women to respond and to their awareness of the crime suffered. It is therefore likely that the underestimation of the phenomenon is particularly important for the southern regions. It is therefore important to continue along this path, and indeed the Commission is called upon to make greater efforts to promote and disseminate results so that the organisations concerned can fight against violence against women.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. – Violence against women is a violation of human rights and a form of gender discrimination. Estimates of the extent of this phenomenon are alarming. Violence has a major impact on victims and leads to significant costs. Although common trends in combating violence are observed, the approaches adopted differ from one Member State to another. The European Parliament's many contributions are aimed at strengthening the Union's policy in this area. Parliament has repeatedly called for an EU strategy to combat violence against women, including a binding instrument. I believe that the main objective of the new Daphne programme is to prevent and combat any forms of violence that take place in public or in private against children, young people and women, as well as to protect victims and groups at risk. It complements existing programmes in the Member States and builds on the policies and objectives already defined in previous Daphne programmes.

name: Filiz HYUSMENOVA
text: alde), in writing. – Dear Mr President, I believe that supporting and promoting projects aimed at raising awareness, prevention and combating violence against children, young people and women is of the utmost importance, so ensuring adequate funding for such projects must be a priority. In this regard, I believe that regardless of whether the name of the Daphne programmes will be maintained, their profile must be maintained as regards the possibilities for carrying out such projects. The new Rights, Equality and Citizenship programme must ensure the continuation of the specific objectives of the previous Daphne programmes by providing adequate funding to prevent and combat all forms of violence, taking into account the specificities of violence against women and girls.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. Gender-based violence in all its facets reaches more than nine million women, but the Commission does not seem aware of the seriousness of the situation. We are still waiting for the future gender policy strategy (2016-2019), but the signs that come to us are not good.  The Daphne programme on gender-based violence has been diluted in the multi-year framework of rights and citizenship, detracting from visibility and relevance to an essential programme, while there are doubts about its budgetary envelope. I am concerned, of course, about funding uncertainties , as my colleagues have pointed out – but this invisibilization is no less serious because, increasingly, it seems as if gender-based violence and the murders of women have acquired a certain air of inevitability, an element of trivialisation.  We must combat this situation with active mobilization and education, because the social condemnation of violence is one of the most effective measures to denounce these facts. That is the ideological and cultural battle that we must undertake.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. We think it is particularly appropriate to put this oral question to the European Commission on the transition from the Daphne programme to the 'Rights, Equality and Citizenship' programme. This Parliament has repeatedly spoken out in favour of the pursuit of gender equality and it is clear that no project can be effective unless it is supported by adequate funding. In this respect, it is very appropriate for the Commission to specify which share – both in terms of funding and, more generally, in terms of attention – of this new programme will be devoted to supporting gender equality and the fight against violence against women. It is important, not least in order to ensure transparency towards the citizens, that the commitments made in our declarations are matched by concrete actions that demonstrate the effective presence of gender equality among the priorities of this European legislature.

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: Writing. – Reducing domestic violence is a notoriously complex and lengthy process, and the Daphne programme, which supports organisations fighting violence against women, children and young people, plays a major role in this. It is essential that it continues in the profile and financial support of the programme. There are currently nearly two million women in Hungary who are once in a relationship with a partner who has used severe psychological violence, nearly 800,000 women have been physically assaulted in their lifetime and nearly 300,000 have been sexually assaulted. There are currently more than 200,000 women in a relationship in which their partner is a victim of physical and/or sexual violence. The children of these women are also direct or indirect victims of violence.  Every week in Hungary, at least one woman is murdered by her husband or ex-husband, partner or ex-partner, friend or ex-boyfriend. In the light of the staggering numbers and the hungarian government's do-nothings over the past five years, it is essential that the EU act more decisively against violence against women, children and young people. The various regulations of the 28 Member States ensure unequal protection for those in need against different forms of violence. Improving the current framework and joint action against domestic violence would make a major contribution to the protection of women, children and young people and their equal rights in the EU, and would be an important step towards a community based on common values and the protection of human rights.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Item on the agenda: One-minute speeches (Article 163 of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Daniel BUDA
text: – Madam President, Romania has been marked by a terrible tragedy these days, namely a strong fire that has caused the deaths of 50 people, and dozens more are in serious condition. Member States must be responsible and do everything to ensure that such tragedies do not happen again in any other place. At the same time, we had a welcome resignation from a government that, by far, could have performed much better. I am pleased, however, that there is a nomination for the office of Prime Minister, in the person of Dacian Cioloş, who, for five years, managed the common agricultural policy from the position of Commissioner. The absorption of European funds must be his main priority. The money allocated to Romania must be spent responsibly and efficiently so that they do not end up anywhere else. I am absolutely convinced that his experience at European level will enable him to manage the interests of Romania and the European Union in a time of profound challenges, given the migrant crisis and beyond.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: – Madam President, the Neuromuscular Centre Midlands (NMC) provides specialist physiotherapy to patients with muscular dystrophy – patients who have told me that this treatment is almost the only thing that helps them bear this terrible disease. It is not offered anywhere else in the West Midlands. The cost is negligible. Treating a single fall injury would cost more than specialised physiotherapy for a dozen patients for a year. So, on 22 July, I wrote from this Parliament to the Coventry and Rugby CCG and the Warwickshire North CCG, asking why they are not providing funding to the NMC, even though it is treating patients from their areas. Neither replied. So, on 2 October this year, I wrote personally to their two chairs, Dr Adrian Canale-Parola and Dr Heather Gorringe. Neither still has bothered to reply. Yet so many sufferers have told me that this treatment is the only thing that helps, and the cost is negligible. Why will these faceless bureaucracies not pay for the treatment their people are using?

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab 97 years ago, on November 11, 1918, Poland regained its independence. This happened after 123 years of bloody partitions – tributes to Polish blood shed on numerous battlefields. I pay tribute to the heroes of the struggle for Polish independence, the builders of the Second Republic, the victims of World War II, the soldiers who were hatched, the victims of communist terror, President Lech Kaczynski and other victims of the Smolensk disaster. Honor their memory.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: – Madam President, recently the Guardian published a report alleging that some migrant workers are being abused in the Irish fishing industry and that some are being trafficked. The extent of these practices has not been determined. I have called on the Irish authorities to immediately increase the number of unannounced on-the-spot inspection checks on trawlers. This will help to protect the workers. It will also help to deter further abuse and show the many honest and decent trawler owners that they are not facing competition from low-cost illegal operators. While in no way minimising the Irish situation, there is evidence of similar practices elsewhere. Commissioner Vella has called on the Irish authorities to put their house in order but, equally, the Commissioner has a responsibility to ensure that all EU countries fully comply with EU law to prevent trafficking and ensure the rights of migrant workers. Action is needed in Ireland, but it is also needed elsewhere in the EU.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: – Madam President, once again the European Commission has tried to interfere in decisions which must be taken in a sovereign and unconditioned manner.  During the government's training process in Portugal, which followed the elections of 4 October, Commissioner Dombrovskis threatened to punish my country with sanctions for not delivering the 2016 state budget proposal. More recently, it referred to Portugal again, anticipating a catastrophe, if Portugal does not follow the course until today and which, by chance, was a course that led to the impoverishment and destruction of the rights of the Portuguese people.  Commissioner Oettinger presented the European Of The Year Award from the Association of Newspaper and Magazine Editors of Germany to the 11 million Portuguese, justifying it because Portugal applied the troika programme well and managed to find, according to him, the way to more employment. He also said that the prize was also a request for the 11 million such so that they could maintain stability.  These interventions are a disgrace, an attack on the sovereignty and democratic regime of the countries.

name: Ernest MARAGALL
text: – Madam President, a ghost travels through Europe, a ghost called democracy. The European Union has a problem of coherence and respect for its own democratic principles, especially today in the field of economic governance, with the euro area and Greece as more visible examples. But let's talk about three illustrations that are very different from each other, but which also affect the idea and reality of Europe.  Firstly, this afternoon, in the vote on electoral law, we deny proportionality, we do not dare to talk about the 'European list', we say 'transnational list', and we pass the real decision on to the states. Even at the headquarters of the democratic representation of the 500 million Europeans, we are not able to act as such: we resign. Secondly, the action plan proposed by the Union to Turkey. We close our eyes to the null and void respect of the rule of law and freedom of expression and set out to compensate it with a service of containment and vigilance.  Thirdly, the case of the State against Catalonia. Here we have a contrary abuse: the anti-democracy law was used. The reason for state is alleged against the democratic will of the majority in a Parliament as legitimate as this and, indeed, very explicitly pro-European.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: – Madam President, in the early 20th century and throughout the 20th century, large quantities of asbestos were used throughout Europe, resulting in health damage so severe that it is estimated that up to 500 000 people could die from this respiratory disease caused by asbestos by 2030. The use of asbestos in the Union has been prohibited since 1 January 2005, but this is not a complete solution as it remains present in buildings and it would therefore be necessary to establish a European asbestos removal fund to help remove asbestos from public and private buildings. The other problem is the compensation for those who have suffered damage to health, because states, including, where appropriate, Hungary do not accept claims that have fallen ill in the state-owned asbestos plant in restitution cases, and a court-level solution must be sought.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: - Madam President, I would like to address the progress report on the enlargement process presented by Commissioner Hahn at the Foreign Affairs Committee yesterday.  I believe that the New Approach of the European Commission in evaluating the progress of each of the countries involved in the enlargement process is one good step forward, as in this way this report is a kind of guide to reforms, and the four-year medium-term strategy gives a clear picture to the efforts of individual governments to prioritise areas, in particular the judiciary, the fight against corruption, organised crime, public procurement and, most importantly, , meeting economic and financial criteria. In particular, I would like to stress the necessity of strong support from the European Union to Bosnia and Herzegovina. Twenty years after the Dayton Peace Agreement, we must extend our hand to the New Approach of the European Union to this country and ensure the equality of all three constituent peoples in Bosnia and Herzegovina.

name: Iliana IOTOVA
text: S&D). – Madam President, at this late hour, a meeting of European and African leaders on the issue of the refugee crisis and migration is taking place in La Valletta.  What will be the outcome of this meeting we are yet to see. Unfortunately, Europe went almost empty-handed. Yesterday, the European Commission made the first report on the implementation of emergency measures to deal with the crisis. There's nothing special to boast about. Of all the hotspots, only one works. So far, only 147 people out of 160,000 have been relocated.  The Western Balkans meeting failed. There is a tendency to selfishly lock Member States into national policies rather than European policies. The return of borders between the Schengen States and the coming up of new fences is proof. There is a danger that the migrant crisis will also trigger a political crisis in the Union with unpredictable consequences. We insist on strict monitoring of the European Commission to implement the measures adopted by the European Parliament.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: – Madam President, I would like to take this opportunity to celebrate the results of last weekend’s election in Myanmar/Burma. As the news continues to come through, it is now certain that the NLD, led by Aung San Suu Kyi, will sweep the board. I had the pleasure of meeting this amazing lady a couple of years ago when I visited Myanmar as part of this Parliament’s ASEAN delegation. It remains one of the highlights of my political career to have been welcomed by her into her now famous elegant home with its lush tropical gardens. Indications are that the military dictatorship is going quietly, conceding defeat. Let us hope that this continues to be the case. We so often hear stories of violence and oppression in this Chamber; it is interesting to hear that this transition may happen without violence. Given Burma’s recent history, this is remarkable. There are clearly many challenges ahead, including the continuing presence of the military in the parliament and the dreadful plight of ethnic and religious minorities such as the Rohingya, but I would like to take this moment to congratulate Aung San Suu Kyi.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
