text: – Madam President, tonight, the regional government of Catalonia has declared itself in absentia in front of the Constitutional Court and has decided to sabotage democracy and act directly against the fundamental rights of more than half of Catalans and against most Spaniards.  In the last legislature, that regional government began to implement an illegal secession strategy with respect to the rest of the Spanish nation. It affects the sovereignty of all of us – the Spaniards – and substantially affects the rule of law and democracy. At the heart of Europe is the flight forward of our nation's most corrupt political class and, to hide the operation, they behave like populists who play to take advantage of the noble identity sentiments of many good people. It is unusual a case that looks practically like a coup d'eer to democracy in Catalonia, without weapons and by chapters.  The European Union must know, and must explore, how to support the fundamental rights to democracy of so many Affected European Spaniards.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: – Madam President, the EU is failing in its targets to reduce poverty and social exclusion, and nowhere is this more apparent than in my own country, Ireland. Thanks to their austerity policies, the poverty rate in Ireland has doubled since 2008, and the most tragic manifestation of this is the housing and homelessness crisis. The number of homeless families in Dublin shot up by 106% in the 12 months to September, and there are nearly 2 300 people in emergency accommodation in my city, the majority of whom are children. There are now 5 000 citizens in temporary shelter across the state. Government policies have directly caused this crisis. They have slashed social housing budgets and instead opted for policies that favour private landlords – hardly surprising when 24 of them are landlords themselves. They have allowed rents to spiral, provided inadequate rent supplements, cut mortgage interest supplements and made it easier for banks to repossess. The Irish Government urgently needs to change course, and it must build social housing, tackle spiralling rent costs and rent uncertainty, and act to stop forced evictions.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for On 6 November, it was 40 years since 350,000 Moroccans marched across the border into Western Sahara. While the media was watching the march, the army started the invasion a few miles away. This was the beginning of a long-standing armed conflict between Morocco and Western Sahara.  In 1991, a ceasefire between the Polisario Front and Morocco was agreed and the referendum was promised until January 1992. The fact that it has not happened is not due to the Sharians. For 40 years now Morocco has occupied Western Sahara. No country has recognised their right to the country. Since 1991, the Sharians have been fighting for self-determination by non-violence.  But the signal that we are sending to them is that non-violence does not pay off and that international law does not have to be followed. It is time now that europe rewards non-violence, and that we stand up for the right of the Shari to actually have their promised independence, that we stand up for international law. We're not going to punish the Shari, we're going to reward them.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: – Madam President, let me remind you that the refugee crisis is not over, on the contrary, there are possibilities for its reincarnation in other parts of Europe. We already have about one and a half million IDP in Ukraine, internal refugees, and any economic or military upheaval can open the floodgates to a wave of refugees from the east to abroad. Today, Semyon Semyonchenko, a member of the Ukrainian parliament and founder of the Donbas volunteer battalion, informed me that in recent days, north of Donetsk, separatist forces have launched a heavy-arms offensive against Ukrainian forces. The Ukrainian military confirmed the information and said it was returning its withdrawn heavy equipment to its original positions. Semyonchenko has called the Minsk agreements ineffective, and I ask, ladies and gentlemen: Are the Minsk agreements dead? Isn't it time to replace them with the concept of strong military support for Ukraine? This is the way to stop another refugee wave.

name: Paul BRANNEN
text: – Madam President, ‘nightmare’: that was the word used by a senior politician from Northern Ireland to describe the consequences of the United Kingdom leaving the European Union. Why nightmare? Three main reasons: First, exit from the EU would undermine 17 years of peace in a region that previously suffered decades of violence, civil strife and political failure. Second, the nature of the border between the United Kingdom and the Republic of Ireland would fundamentally change. Instead of it being a porous border between two fellow EU Member States, it would become a hard border, raising a whole host of questions regarding customs control, trade tariff and freedom of movement. Third, the loss of key funding structures for farmers, business and community regeneration programmes would have a devastating impact on a region where incomes are 20% lower than the EU average. To conclude, leaving the EU would not be cost-free. I put it to the Eurosceptics: would the end of the peace process in Northern Ireland, the building of a border fence and an increase in poverty be a price worth paying for a little England?

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Madam President, I welcome the Commission's decision which calls into question the contract for the construction of the Plomin 3 thermal power plant in Istria, and this contract is incompatible with the European legislation. I also welcome the fact that the Commission has decided to help build an LNG terminal on the island of Krk, as this is of course an excellent energy project.  However, it should be noted that the two projects are very close. 25 km difference is really nothing and it is unnecessary to have a coal-fired Plomin 3 thermal power plant, on the other hand to it an LNG terminal on lng gas. I call on the Commission to combine the two projects, to create a real energy center for European needs in the northern part of the Adriatic and thus take advantage of the synergy of these two projects.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: – Madam President, the ECB, the European Central Bank, is now the most powerful institution in the European Union and at the same time the most obscure and the least scrutinised. Its operation, based on a so-called technical mission, apolitical or neutral, represents a huge hoax for the peoples of Europe. It was recently learned that the members of its Executive Council met happily with representatives of the major financial groups on the eve of key monetary policy decisions, such as interest rates or asset purchase operations.  As far as monetary policy is in question, it is also important to question it. With negative interest rates, favourable exchange rates, low crude oil prices and all this showered with an almost unlimited injection of liquidity, the total of which already accounts for half of the eurozone's GDP, how can we explain the complete stagnation of our economies?  For our part, we do not feed any illusions about this model. Europe is in a structural crisis and will only emerge from it with a profound rupture of this capitalist model which is unable to respond to the problems of society.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: – Madam President, I have to say to my colleagues: unfortunately I cannot meet you very soon, because my national air carrier has gone into bankruptcy because of a Commission decision on the grounds of illegal state aid. I want to challenge the Commission. The decision has been taken wrongly, because the periphery must be encouraged to come to Brussels and not punished for coming to Brussels. But there is also the other side of the coin, namely that we are promoting people who are responsible for that bankruptcy to European jobs. The former Prime Minister of Estonia, Mr Andrus Ansip, is now a Commissioner for the digital market, and the former Minister of Economic Affairs, Mr Parts, is going to be appointed by the Estonian Government to be an auditor for Europe. I wish we would vote against all those kinds of decisions.

name: László TŐKÉS
text: – Madam President, the fall of the post-communist government led by Victor Ponta is a great blessing for Romania. However, the people of the street are also calling for an end to the "murderous corruption" of which the young people who have been injured and romanian society itself have fallen victim. Together with corruption, the Romanian political class should be free once and for all from xenophobe anti-Hungarianism inherited from the Ceaușescu dictatorship. Romania needs more than a change of government: a real regime change. In a short period of time, the country could become a parade area for migration from the Middle East or even ukraine. However, only a stable democratic government can effectively combat the looming migration crisis. As a Schengen member state free from corruption, Romania, together with Hungary, could play its part effectively in protecting the EU's external borders.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: – Madam President, first of all, I would like to thank the European Parliament for commemorating, following the request made, the victims of the tragic event in Bucharest. This once again illustrates the solidarity that Europe shows in difficult times. Another example of solidarity to be taken into account is that of European doctors and nurses, who came to Romania to support local medical teams, but also that of countries that have taken the wounded to treat them. It is a symbol of the fact that, in times of need, Europeans stand together and manage to unite to protect the lives of their citizens. I take this opportunity to once again welcome the medical community in Romania and Europe for their joint efforts to save those who have suffered as a result of this tragic event. In this respect, I believe that an important direction in building a common future at European level is the creation of a common health policy that allows the treatment of all European patients, regardless of the country, because, after all, the most important thing is to save as many lives as possible

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: – Madam President, the situation of work in Europe cannot be separated from the absence of a strong public sector, which is a guarantee of distributive justice and democratic control of production.  This underdevelopment of the public, which particularly affects States such as Spain, is based on two pillars. The first is the European obsession with deficits, instrumentalised in implementing the harsh neoliberal measures. The second is structural tax avoidance, favoured by the governments themselves and the Commission through the opacity of tax agreements and tax competition between States. We look closely at the Commission's new proposals on corporate taxation. We like to work towards harmonizing corporation tax and linking it to the real economy, but we lack confidence, political confidence.  The European institutions are complicit in the multinationals in their circumvention strategy, as evidenced by the false closure of luxLeaks' investigative committee. Therefore, we must end this situation now.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: – Yesterday, Lithuanian milk producers and consumers submitted to me a petition of more than half a thousand people and obliged to refer it to the European Parliament. It contains proposals to start regulating the milk market in difficulty following the abolition of the milk quota system, as well as helping to avoid future crises. Lithuanian dairy producers also insist on not forgetting the losses caused by the Russian embargo and creating a unified system of compensation for them. Equally important is the requirement to support, to promote cooperation between milk producers. I call on colleagues and representatives of other institutions not to remain indifferent to the dairy sector and to act more quickly in order to make effective decisions.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I would like to comment on the demands made by the British Prime Minister this week, which, in my opinion, attack the fundamental principles of the EU. For me, as a citizen of the Czech Republic with our historical experience, restricting freedom of movement is unacceptable, even if it should only affect part of the Member States, and perhaps even because of it. After all, freedom of movement is one of the pillars on which the European Union and its foundations are founded. Without these pillars, I do not think it is possible to imagine the continued existence of the Union as such. But Cameron's demand to limit welfare benefits for members of other member states also lacks economic justification. Statistics and data are available according to which UK citizens use the social systems of other Member States to a greater extent than citizens of other Member States use the British social system. I do not understand this requirement very much either, and I hope that this is not an ultimatum, but indeed a rational and normal debate.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Madam President, I take the opportunity of having representatives of the Commission here to remind the Commission and the European Council that their main goal, task and aim is to maintain the European Union’s stability and the European Union States’ stability underpinning everything. I say this to you because of the situation with the tide of migrants that is continuing to come to Europe. The European Union proved not to have the necessary tools and institutions to respond to such a crisis. The system of crisis management is very poor and inefficient at the level of the European Union, and this has to be improved. The European Union proved one thing: that soft power is not enough. The European Union needs also to build security and defence structures, to have real hard power in the future to face all these challenges and threats to its security and defence.

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: – Madam President, before yesterday, 9 November, the Parliament of Catalonia adopted by an absolute majority a declaration initiating the construction of the Catalan Republic. It is the mandate given to democratically elected Deputies in the recent Catalan elections.  The Spanish state has offered no alternative and has repeatedly refused to allow a referendum on Catalonia's independence. Three days after that declaration, State agencies have put in place prohibition and punitive mechanisms, i.e. exclusively repression.  It is difficult to understand that the Spanish Government and political forces have not had the democratic capacity to initiate some kind of dialogue or rapprochement to address the majority desire of the citizens of Catalonia.  Democracy in Catalonia will go its way, despite sanctions and repression, because the democratic will of peoples always come first. We have reiterated this many times in this House.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in Italy, every year, SVIMEZ, the Association for the Development of the Mezzogiorno, assesses growth figures. Well, the picture is quite alarming: in 2015 the South had growth more than 40% lower than the average of the Convergence regions of Europe. Absolute poverty in Italy has more than doubled and more than half a million jobs have been lost in the South. The report also highlighted the substantial cessation of industry investment, which was reduced by 59% from 2008 to 2014. Every year, in conjunction with the publication of the report, the newspapers dedicate whole pages to it for a few days, but then everything goes into oblivious. These figures, on the other hand, require an extraordinary effort by states and local governments to seize all the opportunities offered by the European Union, starting from the resources of the European Fund for Strategic Investments. I hope that the EIB will join this change of pace, in synergy with the Juncker plan, the 2014-2020 operational programmes and public-private partnerships, in order to stimulate the confidence of local entrepreneurs and administrators and the creation of the right operational network, all enabling factors to make investments.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: We're going to move on to voting.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against the renewal of the EU ISA2 programme: ‘Interoperability solutions for European public administrations, businesses and citizens’. While we recognise the potential benefits of interoperability, we see this expensive EU programme as primarily designed to ‘Europeanise’ public administration, and to prise it away from national control, rather than as an efficiency measure.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 With a view to the development of an increasingly cohesive Union, given the EU's aim and motive, the presentation of a programme that helps to harmonise as well as modernise public administrations can only be welcomed. The ISA2 programme fully realises the concept of union between Member States, creating an interoperability system at national and European level. The possibility of creating a system that guarantees benefits not only to European and national administrations, identified as direct beneficiaries of this programme, but above all to citizens, as indirect recipients, certainly cannot leave Parliament indifferent. Simplifying procedures, adapting and dispositioning common fees, sharing suggestions and ideas within Europe to improve the system have always been the EU's ambition and objective. In view of these reasons, I voted in favour of the isa2 programme, mainly because of the possible establishment of a common administrative system that is distinguished by its considerable social impact.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is an initiative aimed at improving European citizens' access to public services and their rights. This report proposes a programme on interoperability solutions for public administrations in the EU; these solutions at European level are aimed at being compatible among the 28 Member States. This reduces compatibility costs and facilitates mobility and access to public services for citizens switching Member States within the EU. In addition, this report points to the need to combat the digital divide, as well as to ensure SME access to such solutions. Electronic interoperability represents an opportunity to improve the functioning of the public sector by increasing the services it can provide to citizens. For all this, I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly oppose the renewal of the ‘Interoperability solutions for European public administrations, businesses and citizens’ programme. While I recognise the potential benefits of interoperability, I see this expensive EU programme as primarily designed to ‘Europeanise’ public administration and to prise it away from national control, rather than as an efficiency measure. The current programme has a budget of EUR 164 million for the period 2010-2015. The financial envelope for implementation of the new ISA program for the period 1 January 2016 to 31 December 2020 is EUR 130 928 000.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal establishing a European Programme for Interoperability Solutions for Public Administrations, Enterprises and Citizens (ISA 2). This is done to take account of the apparent development of technology, the new needs of administrations and civil society and the new potential of cloud computing. The interoperability of institutions and businesses increases the quality of public services and allows for greater competitiveness of businesses and greater citizens' satisfaction. It is a major ally of europe's strategy for growth and jobs. It also contributes to the creation of a digital single market and to the achievement of an ambitious, globally leading and socially inclusive Digital Agenda for Europe. I support the proposals to create a common semantic system that connects public administrations with each other and with other sectors. It is important to create a repository of solutions and standards for the direct use or involvement of administrations in new projects and to create a one-stop shop for best practice. It is also necessary to protect the privacy and security of data and to simplify administrative procedures.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: Writing. \u2012 The report is about the establishment of a programme of interoperability solutions (ISA2) available to European public administrations, businesses and citizens. As such, it is a continuation of the ISA programme, which gives public services in EU countries the opportunity to easily access each other's databases and to digitise basic information only once. The ISA programme was for 2010-2015 and ISA2 for 2016-2020, and EUR 131 million was approved for this purpose. Interoperability means access to each other's databases, systems that work together for data access and processing.  As an example of the content of the programme, Directive 2012/17/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council provides for mutual access to the central registers, commercial registers and business registers of the Member States through a central platform in the field of company law. By linking business registers, the information contained there is available beyond national borders, allowing business data to be accessed at EU level by both businesses and citizens, which enhances legal certainty in the business environment in the Union. On this basis, I supported the adoption of this report.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I supported this report, which supports the strengthening of interoperability for public administrations, businesses and individuals in Europe, in line with the Commission's efforts since 1995 to promote the exchange of data between administrations. Interoperability can enhance the quality of public services as well as the competitiveness of businesses and service to individuals.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report on interoperability solutions as a means of modernising the public sector because of their importance following the agreement with the Council. Interoperability increasingly promotes the potential quality of public services and creates a context of greater competitiveness for businesses and greater satisfaction for citizens. It is also the achievement of the digital market. Moreover, harnessing the potential of the Decision in question implies a greater emphasis on the economic and social appropriation of the programme.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I am in favour of promoting and developing the principle of interoperability as good practice to improve the efficiency of public administrations and the exchange of information between them and the European institutions. Noting that electronic communication is a strategic sector of fundamental importance for all stakeholders, I voted in favour of the text.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. By this agreement, Parliament supports the implementation of the ISA2 programme, which is necessary to provide technological solutions that facilitate interoperability in both cross-border and cross-sector electronic communications, in areas such as e-government, health, billing or public competitions. This programme is intended to enable the modernisation of public administrations and further progress in the implementation of transnational services in Europe. For this purpose it will have an endowment of 130 million euros in the period 2016-2020. Thanks to input from Parliament, interoperability efforts between the different levels – local, national, European – of public administrations, as well as with different EU agencies, have been strengthened and regional and local administrations included among the beneficiaries of structural funds for the development of interoperable solutions. Moreover, as the Spanish Socialists demand, Parliament has succeeded in introducing the principle of combating digital exclusion, so that the development of interoperable public services will take into account both the most disadvantaged and the least populated areas in order to combat the digital divide.  For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it expresses Parliament's position on modernising public interactions in the future. Parliament generally welcomed the Commission's proposal establishing a European Programme for Interoperability Solutions for Public Administrations, Businesses and Citizens (ISA 2). However, he pointed out that the preparation for the new phase of this programme must take into account the apparent development of technology, the new needs of administrations and civil society and the new possibilities of cloud computing. The inclusion of enterprises and citizens in the list of target users in ISA 2 is an important sign of progress and the Commission must therefore identify the criteria to be used for the implementation and evaluation of the programme, not only from a supply perspective but, above all, from a demand perspective, i.e. in terms of public sector modernisation capacity, in order to meet the needs of civil society more effectively and effectively. Interoperability increases the potential quality of public services and allows for greater competitiveness of businesses and greater satisfaction for citizens. He is therefore a powerful ally of Europe's strategy for growth and jobs.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 Member States' commitment is key to the rapidly developing of an interoperable e-society in the UNION and for public administrations to participate in encouraging the use of online procedures. Furthermore, in order to create a more efficient, simpler and more user-friendly e-administration, some adjustments to European administrations may be necessary, in addition to the support provided by the Member States. Efficient online public services are key to strengthening business and citizens' confidence in digital services. It is therefore important that the policy on interoperability and its possible uses is coordinated at Union level in the most efficient and flexible way possible for the end-user.  In order to avoid fragmentation of the interoperability environment in the Union, a common union-wide understanding of interoperability and a comprehensive approach to interoperable solutions should be promoted. The report points in this direction and I therefore voted in favour of its adoption.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 The modernisation of European public administrations and the increase in their interoperability are an important step towards the completion of the digital single market and the effective implementation of the Europe 2020 strategy.  Support for today's vote continues in the direction of enabling citizens, but also other realities, such as those of small and medium-sized enterprises, to fully benefit from the potential offered by interoperable electronic services and the consequent reduction in administrative burdens and costs. It should be remembered that the increased efficiency of public administrations has a direct impact on the economic environment and is therefore essential to promote competitiveness, growth and employment.  In line with this, the priorities of the decision taken today are along these lines. The establishment of the ISA2 programme for the period 2016-2020 aims to remove obstacles to interoperability through the development and promotion of a global approach at Union level. The actions designed to achieve this objective are aimed at facilitating cross-border or cross-sectoral electronic interaction between European public administrations and between them, on the one hand, and businesses and citizens, on the other. Finally, we must remember that more efficient online public services increase public and business confidence not only in digital services but also in institutions.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 Interoperability serves to make the services that the public administration (PA) offers to citizens more efficient and effective, which is why it cannot be applied to obsolete systems. Interoperability – which must be promoted in conjunction with free and open source software – is not just a means of saving on programme licensing: it is, together with the spread of free and open source software, an important tool for raising quality standards of safety, response speed, system interconnection and accessibility. The union's new programme must not be a simple continuation of the previous IDA, IDABC and ISA, but an improvement in them, due to the progress made in the ICT sector and the deepening of cross-border cooperation between PAs.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 One of the European Union's intense concerns was to facilitate cooperation and communication between Member States' institutions, a concern that has materialised in a number of programmes, one of which is the Data Exchange Between Administrations Programme, which aims both to exchange data between Member States' administrations and between administrations and EU institutions (IDA), launched since 1995. With the evolution of technology and the increase in civil society expectations, the Interoperability Solutions Programme for European Public Administrations (ISA, followed by the ISA 2) programme has been initiated, which focuses on the needs and dynamics of businesses and citizens precisely so that administrations respond effectively and promptly to the needs of citizens. The Programme on Interoperability Solutions for European Public Administrations ISA 2 is the prerequisite for the modernisation of public administrations in Europe, increasing the quality of public services, creating a competitive environment for businesses and, at the same time, improving the quality of life of the population, which is why I have expressed myself in favour of the Report on interoperability solutions as a means of modernising the public sector.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour. Since 1995, with the Programme for The Exchange of Data between Administrations (IDA), the Commission, together with the Member States, has promoted solutions that allow the exchange of data in administrative contexts and between ADMINISTRATIONS and THE EU institutions. ISA2 (Union programme on interoperability solutions and common frameworks for European public administrations, businesses and citizens) will be in force from 2016 to 2020, with a budget of EUR 131 000 000.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. Public administrations in the various Member States must communicate with each other quickly and effectively in order to improve the functioning of the internal market. The freedom to work and settle in another Member State implies close collaboration between the country of origin and the reception of European citizens. In addition, it is important to set up electronic platforms for public administrations. They will then be better able to transfer information from one Member State to another. A worker, student or company based in another Member State will then be able to benefit from an optimal service tailored to their specific needs.  I voted in favour of this text.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on interoperability as a means of modernising European public administrations, businesses and citizens. As indicated in the report, the Union's strategic objective must be to establish support programmes for structural investments that guarantee the interoperability of the systems and technologies used to ensure better quality of public services, while creating an environment of greater competitiveness for businesses and, consequently, greater satisfaction of citizens' needs. In order to achieve these objectives, Europe must step up its efforts to unlock the potential of data completely and definitively. It is essential to make digital public procurement effective, removing the many obstacles to the lack of standardisation and interoperability of telematic platforms.  Through these actions, the Union will therefore be able to improve the effectiveness, efficiency and cost-effectiveness of the services offered to businesses and citizens.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on the ISA2 programme which aims to improve interoperability in online communication between the public administrations of Member States. It aims to develop a more effective, simplified and user-friendly administration at state, regional and local levels of public administration. It recognises the right of states, businesses and citizens not to use these solutions. The report also seeks to ensure a high level of user privacy and data protection, and includes references to technological neutrality and net neutrality.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against the renewal of the EU ISA2 programme: ‘Interoperability solutions for European public administrations, businesses and citizens’. While we recognise the potential benefits of interoperability, we see this expensive EU programme as primarily designed to ‘Europeanise’ public administration, and to prise it away from national control, rather than as an efficiency measure.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I believe that this programme will be effective in improving the existing European cross-border and cross-sector interoperability solutions and in developing new ones as a means of modernising the public sector. When agreeing to this report the aim was to make full use of the available technologies and together these measures will have a positive impact on the work of public administrations, businesses and citizens.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The aim of the ISA2 programme is to help modernise public administrations so that they can provide interoperable digital services at national and European level. The M5S delegation has tabled amendments, included in the compromises by the rapporteur, to promote the full exploitation of the potential of e-democracy for European citizens and to ensure the widest and most inclusive participation in the programme, giving priority to those who have never received funding before.  I fully agree with the idea of increasing the efficiency of public administrations for citizens and businesses and having been favourably accepted in our amendments, and I voted in favour of this report.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the proposed programme on interoperability solutions for European public administration as I find it essential to promote the digitalisation of public administration. It is one of the key features of the overall digital agenda to be developed throughout the EU. The Czech Republic has a poor record in this area and some serious effort must be made in order to modernise national public administration. The funds provided through the new ISA2 instrument could be a very useful contribution to the government’s initiatives in this field.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. \u2012 The success and completion of the internal market is also based on freedom of movement, which allows European citizens to work within the Union and businesses to operate throughout Europe. For this reason, the ability of users to interact electronically with the administrations of the Member States, as well as the interaction between public administrations in the different countries of the Union, which must be put in a position to exchange information and cooperate to ensure efficient cross-border public services, must be strengthened. As early as the mid-1990s, the European Commission launched several programmes to facilitate the process of modernising public administrations: e-health, as well as invoicing and electronic public procurement, are concrete examples of interoperability. The European Commission's proposal to establish, for the period 2016-2020, the ISA 2 (Interoperability solutions for European public administrations) programme will give continuity to the previous programme and will effectively and efficiently facilitate cross-border electronic interaction between European public administrations and between them and businesses and citizens. The programme has been and will be an important and concrete tool for the realisation of the digital single market and the 'Digital Agenda' light-up initiative. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 Concerns the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a programme on interoperability solutions for European public administrations, businesses and citizens of Europe (ISA2). This is a welcome continuation and improvement of older programmes. In agreement with the ITRE and IMCO Committees, the LIBE Committee will be solely responsible for the parameters relating to data protection and fundamental rights. We support the report positively, because interoperability is a means of modernising the public sector.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I have decided to vote in favour of this measure. The motion for a resolution, which welcomes the dictates of the Commission's ISA2 programme, complements the initiatives that contribute to the modernisation of European public administrations.  Interoperability is increasingly strengthening the potential quality of public services, creating an environment of greater competitiveness for businesses and greater satisfaction of citizens' needs, thus proving to be a valuable ally of the European strategy for growth and jobs.  The EP suggests giving greater emphasis to the economic and social ownership of the programme. In particular, it proposes to develop a one-stop shop for the exchange of good practice, to pay attention to the protection of privacy, to simplify procedures and to encourage cooperative solutions involving public administrations in different Member States and also sectors other than the public sector. Finally, the EP stresses the need to calibrate the assessment of the success of the programme on the basis of the impacts and satisfaction of the needs of citizens and businesses.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal because I believe it can improve the system compared to the current situation. In particular, the inclusion of businesses and citizens among the recipients of the ISA 2 programme marks significant progress and prompts the Commission to determine the criteria for implementation and evaluation to be applied. I personally find it very interesting that this decision involves the ability to modernise the public sector by adapting it more effectively and efficiently to the needs of civil society. The ISA 2 programme is fully integrated with other initiatives that contribute to the modernisation of European public administrations, and the rapporteur fully agrees with me that, in addition to the others, three main points are of fundamental importance: the development of common semantics linking public administrations with each other, the creation of a directory of solutions and standards and the protection of privacy and security.

name: David COBURN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against the renewal of the EU ISA2 programme: ‘Interoperability solutions for European public administrations, businesses and citizens’. While we recognise the potential benefits of interoperability, we see this expensive EU programme as primarily designed to ‘Europeanise’ public administration, and to prise it away from national control, rather than as an efficiency measure.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 Since the launch of the Data Exchange Programme between Administrations in 1995, the European Commission has been promoting solutions with Member States to enable data exchange in the context of their administrations and their administrations with the EU institutions. The introduction of businesses and citizens as recipients of the programme on interoperability solutions for European public administrations, businesses and citizens (ISA2) is an important sign of developments that will contribute to the modernisation of the public sector, providing more effective and efficient responses to the needs of civil society. I therefore support the development of the one-stop shop of good practice (Joinup platform) and i consider it essential to safeguard privacy and security from the perspective of administrations, businesses and citizens. I support this report by Mr Zorrinho, as the ISA2 programme is interconnecting with other initiatives that contribute to the modernisation of public administrations in Europe and is a contribution to the completion of the Digital Single Market and the implementation of an ambitious European Digital Agenda.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome this report, as it aims to renew the existing programme on interoperability between public administration, businesses and citizens, through the modernisation of technological instruments.  The interoperability of public administrations strengthens the potential amount of public services by creating a more competitive environment for businesses, ensuring benefits for European citizens and the consolidation of the digital single market.  In particular, I believe that this programme can help to bridge the digital divide between member states' public administrations and to facilitate the exchange of information through enhanced cross-border cooperation, while protecting the protection of personal data. In addition, the creation of new common public services will bring significant benefits in terms of efficiency and cost reduction through the strengthening of operational processes and technological infrastructure.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 The aim of the ISA2 programme, which follows on from the first ISA programme, is to help modernise public administrations so that they can provide interoperable digital services at national and European level. ISA2 marks the beginning of a new phase that allows efficient and effective interaction with citizens and businesses and allows the exchange of data between the various administrative contexts and between the administrations of the European Union. The report provides, among other points: development of a common semantics linking public administrations with each other and with other sectors (common frameworks); creation of a register of solutions and standards that can be used directly by administrations or integrated into new projects; development of a one-stop shop for the exchange of good practice (Joinup platform); protection of privacy and security from the point of view of administrations, businesses and citizens; simplification of procedures and potential extension of the scope of the programme; encouraging the development of cooperative solutions involving administrations in two or more Member States and assessing the success of the programme on the basis of impacts and meeting the needs of citizens and businesses. In a globalised world, I can only vote in favour.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is an initiative aimed at improving European citizens' access to public services and their rights. This report proposes a programme on interoperability solutions for public administrations in the EU; these solutions at European level are aimed at being compatible among the 28 Member States. This reduces compatibility costs and facilitates mobility and access to public services for citizens switching Member States within the EU. In addition, this report points to the need to combat the digital divide, as well as to ensure SME access to such solutions. Electronic interoperability represents an opportunity to improve the functioning of the public sector by increasing the services it can provide to citizens. For all this, I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal as it further improves the previous ISA system, which was effective in its implementation and helped achieve interoperability between Member States in the field of public administration. ISA2 seeks to establish a decision for the period 2016-2020 and focuses on improving, operating and reusing existing cross border and cross sector interoperability solutions. As the shadow rapporteur for the S&D Group in the LIBE Committee on this file, alongside my colleagues I also ensured that a clause which refers to data protection safeguards and stronger guarantees for people’s data was included in this legislative proposal. Through this inclusion, Parliament has guaranteed better safeguards for European Citizen’s data.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ I am supportive of the overall aim of securing improvements in interoperability to reduce the problems involved in online transactions across borders and sectors in the EU. However, I am very concerned that there was no accompanying impact assessment with the initial proposal, and therefore we need to ensure that the recommendations from the interim evaluation of ISA1 are implemented in ISA2 in order to improve its overall effectiveness. Impact assessments should be automatic when the Commission proposes legislation. While significant improvements were made to the text from both the Council and Parliament, I believe that ISA2 is still lacking a clear objective and failed to learn sufficient lessons from the first programme, hence my decision to abstain on this report.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that interoperability in data protection and closer cross-border cooperation must highlight a substantial potential to improve the efficiency of public services in the Member States which, if fully exploited, could contribute to the achievement of the objectives of the European Semester. I support the rapporteur's position and therefore believe that it is important to introduce specific references to the Union acquis on data protection, because the European Commission's current proposal does not sufficiently address this issue.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This legislative report proposes to modernise the public sector by adopting the European Union's new 2016-2020 programme on interoperability solutions for public administrations, businesses and individuals in Europe.  In particular, this report aims to harness the potential of new technologies, in order to ensure better cross-border coordination between European public administration services and the faster formulation of solutions for citizens and small and medium-sized enterprises. Supporting these objectives, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. Since 1995, with the launch of the Programme for the Exchange of Data between Administrations (IDA), the Commission has promoted solutions enabling the exchange of data between EU administrations and institutions. Interoperability strengthens the quality of public services, creating an environment of greater meeting of citizens' needs and greater competitiveness for businesses in line with the European Strategy for Growth and Jobs. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the ISA 2 programme contributes to the modernisation of European public administrations and the creation of a digital single market, taking into account technological advances as well as the new needs of administrations and civil society.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I strongly support the modernisation of the interoperability solution for public administrations, businesses and citizens. The ISA2 programme is an effective and necessary successor to ISA and will deliver the necessary changes to a more digitised environment. This is a necessary step if we are to fully integrate the new technologies at our disposal to further improve communication solutions and interoperability between public administrations, to make it more consistent. This modernisation is also of particular importance for small and medium-sized enterprises and micro-enterprises, which make up a significant part of our economy, and neither they nor citizens should suffer from the burden of excessive bureaucracy and incompatibility of different systems.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 We are voting in favour, because the modernisation and upgrading of the services offered by the Public Administration to citizens and businesses will contribute to the development that our country so badly needs, as well as reduce the bureaucracy that is a big problem in our country long before the economic crisis. In addition, the articles referring to the publication of public contracts will help to combat corruption. Unique objection, the possible involvement of private companies in the management of personal data that should be avoided.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 The first reading agreement between the EP and the Council provided a reassuring solution to all the disputes contained in the Parliamentary position that I supported. The text provides a good basis for overcoming electronic barriers between member states' administrations, ensuring cross-border interoperability, taking advantage of the opportunities offered by new technologies, creating an open and flexible environment for new challenges and opportunities, and – delivering solutions for small and medium-sized enterprises. For these reasons, in line with the direction of the European People's Party, I voted in favour of the adoption of the text in the First Reading Agreement.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission has established a programme on interoperability solutions for public administrations, businesses and European citizens (ISA2), which allow the exchange of data in the context of its administrations and these with the EU institutions. The decision taken and with which I agree, in addition to following the path taken, opens a new cycle that takes into account technological developments, the new needs of administrations and civil society and the new opportunities of cloud computing. Interoperability increasingly fosters the potential quality of public services and creates a context of greater competitiveness for businesses and greater satisfaction for citizens, is a contribution to the completion of the Digital Single Market and to the implementation of an ambitious, leading European Digital Agenda on a global and socially inclusive scale. The programme enters into force on 1 January 2016 and mobilises funding of EUR 131 million for a five-year period.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Interoperability gradually improves the potential quality of public services and creates an environment that allows for greater competitiveness of businesses and greater satisfaction of citizens. It is therefore a strong ally of the European strategy for growth and jobs. I therefore welcome the efforts of the European Commission, which is seeking that the new ISA2 programme reflects the technical progress made, the new needs of public administrations and civil society, but also the new opportunities brought about by the development of cloud computing. In future, the European Commission must better inform civil society about the benefits of ISA2, because several surveys show that citizens know very little about the predecessors of this programme.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of interoperability solutions as a means of modernising the public sector, because the modernisation and upgrading of the services offered by the Public Administration to citizens and businesses will contribute to the development that my country so badly needs, as well as to reduce the bureaucracy that is a major problem in my country, long before the economic crisis. In addition, the articles referring to the publication of public contracts will help to combat corruption. Unique objection, the possible involvement of private companies in the management of personal data that should be avoided.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ ISA is the latest programme in a long line of Commission programmes that support the interconnection, digitisation and collaboration of public administrations since the 1990s. The current programme, ISA, will end this year and has supported the development of eGovernment solutions that are today operational in public administrations across the EU. The new programme, ISA, will build on the success of its predecessor. It will ensure seamless electronic cross-border or cross-sector interaction between European public administrations in areas such as government, health, invoicing and procurement. ISA² will support the development of interoperable digital solutions which will be available to all interested public administrations on European, national and regional level, free of charge. This will lead to a harmonised interoperability landscape in Europe, saving time and costs, and contribute to the modernisation of European public administrations and to the creation of a digital single market. I welcome the introduction in the programme of new priorities such as greater involvement of citizens and businesses, additional safeguards concerning data protection, a stronger emphasis on the reuse and sharing of references and solutions, enhanced cooperation between Member States to fight the digital divide, develop creation of user communities and exchange of good practice.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the agreement on the EP and Council decision establishing a programme on interoperability solutions between public administrations as a tool for modernising the public sector because I believe it is important to promote efficient public services for European citizens through the use of new information technologies. Interoperability in public administrations across borders delivers great results in the fight against crime, environmental, tax, corporate and customs law, cross-border health services, management of European funds and public procurement, and I therefore consider a programme on the interoperability of European public administrations managed by the Commission to be fundamental, ensuring uniformity and convergence between the different Member States. I welcome the launch of the ISA 2 programme, which has been extended to SMEs and citizens, end users of public services.  The EU must promote digital public administrations, which use new technologies to cross-border communication of information and data for efficient and quality services.  I therefore support the call for a platform for the sharing of good practices and innovative solutions and I support all actions aimed at creating interoperability solutions that can be directly used by administrations. However, the sharing of data must take place in compliance with the right to privacy and EU legislation on the protection of personal data.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the report on interoperability solutions as a means of modernising the public sector, as I believe it is important to develop the administration and the entire public sector in the EU Member States quickly and citizen-friendly. Digitalisation and the concept of smart governance play a major role here. THE EU Member States can learn a lot from each other and grow together.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. Increased interoperability between public authorities and the public sector offers many opportunities for citizens. For example, in the event of illness, the scope of necessary documents can be significantly reduced. Through the funding period decided today, we are making a decisive contribution to the continuation of this development.

name: Juan Carlos GIRAUTA VIDAL
text: In writing. This new programme, ISA2, will ensure better interoperability of online administrative services across Europe, with solutions made available to administrations, whether national or local. It will contribute to the modernisation of public services and the realisation of the European digital market and will enable citizens and businesses to benefit from a better quality of online services across Europe, in accordance with the current regulations on private data. That is why I supported this report.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this agreement because, although the text of the European Parliament's report was diluted during negotiations with the Council, the main points are mainly mentioned in the recitals, or there is a reference to existing legislation: the issue of net neutrality (rec. 32 and reference to the TSM proposal) or data protection (art. 16 Rec. 43). We also consider that the modernization of the increasingly interconnected public sector is essential to live up to the demands of individuals, accustomed to the continuous modernization in the private sector.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Report on the Interoperability of solutions for European public administration, businesses and citizens as it supports the interconnection, digitisation and collaboration of public administrations in Europe.  The current interoperability programme will end this year and has supported the development of eGovernment solutions across the EU. Having this programme in place will ensure seamless electronic cross-border or cross-sector interaction between European public administrations in areas such as government, health, invoicing and procurement.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report. The ISA programme is a programme designed to help Member States offer interoperable digital services. It will be endowed with 131 million euros from 2016 to 2020. The ISA programme has supported, for example, actions on electronic signature creation and verification tools, cross-border online health systems and open source software to support the European Citizens' Initiative, so it is an indispensable European tool!

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a programme on interoperability solutions for European public administrations, businesses and citizens (ISA2) Interoperability as a means for modernising the public sector. This continues the approach pursued to date, exemplified most obviously in the ISA programme – still in force – on interoperability solutions for European public administrations, while also marking the start of a new phase in which technological advances, the new needs of administrations and civil society, and the new opportunities offered by cloud computing will have to be taken into account. Interoperability is increasingly enhancing the potential quality of public services and creating an environment in which businesses can become more competitive and citizens can obtain greater satisfaction. It allows European growth and better job strategy.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 The ISA programme ends on 31 December 2015 and is replaced by the ISA2 framework programme for the period 2016-2020. ISA2 aims to develop a comprehensive approach to interoperability, to promote effective and effective electronic communication between European administrations and bodies and between businesses and citizens across borders and sectors, and to explore, create and operate interoperability solutions to support the implementation of UNION policies and activities. Examples of enhanced interoperability between Member States are the Visa Information System, the second generation schengen information system, the European fingerprint identification system and the European e-Justice portal. Coordination at European level also plays an important role in the sharing and dissemination of best practices. As a member of the Hungarian delegation to the People's Party, I supported the new isa2 framework programme in line with the PP proposal.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I was happy to support this proposal. As the current ISA programme ends this year, ISA2 aims to help Member States modernise their administrations and provide interoperable digital services at national and European level to ensure efficient and effective cross-border interaction for citizens, businesses and European public administrations. The holistic approach employed in the report will provide added value for citizens and SMEs by avoiding overlaps and encouraging exchange of best practices to continuously improve services while respecting privacy and data protection rights.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report, as it increasingly enhances the potential quality of public services and creates an environment in which businesses can become more competitive and citizens can obtain greater satisfaction. This will help public administrations in Europe to modernise and stand out in order to improve economic competiveness or the quality of people’s lives. It is therefore a powerful ally of the European Growth and Jobs Strategy, which is vital for the future of the Union.

name: Roger HELMER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against the renewal of the EU ISA2 programme: ‘Interoperability solutions for European public administrations, businesses and citizens’. While we recognise the potential benefits of interoperability, we see this expensive EU programme as primarily designed to ‘Europeanise’ public administration, and to prise it away from national control, rather than as an efficiency measure.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Writing. The creation of the Digital Services Interoperability Programme (ISA2) is to be welcomed. The main purpose of the programme is to improve interoperability between European public administrations and citizens or businesses. By enabling cross-border and cross-sectoral interaction of European public services, the EU is moving in the right direction. There is no doubt that European public administrations should lead the digital revolution by example. The Digital Single Market is one of the flagships of the European Commission and ISA2 is an important milestone. There is no doubt that this initiative deserves strong support.

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: In writing. The ISA programme is a programme offering interoperability solutions for public administrations, businesses and individuals in Europe. As it expires, a new programme is to be proposed for the period 2016-2020, the ISA 2 programme. In other words, this programme proposed by the European Commission facilitates electronic collaboration between public administrations, particularly in the context of cross-border cooperation, and other actors in order to reduce administrative procedures deemed to be long, costly and sometimes counterproductive. Supporting all initiatives to improve the daily lives and quality of life of citizens, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Ian HUDGHTON
text: in writing. ‒ As digital systems become ever more important in all our lives, it is appropriate that we seek interoperability solutions across Europe’s public administrations. This report rightly underlines that regional and local as well as national administrations are responsible for many services. It also highlights the importance of security and privacy. I accordingly voted in favour.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because the ISA2 is the latest in a long line of Commission programmes that support the interconnection, digitisation and collaboration of public administrations. Moreover, it will ensure seamless electronic cross-border or cross-sector interaction between European public administrations in areas such as government, health, invoicing and procurement. I hope that the ISA2 programme will build on the success of its predecessor and will lead to a harmonised interoperability landscape, saving time and costs.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a decision by Parliament and the Council to establish a programme of interoperable solutions for European public administrations, entrepreneurs and citizens (ISA2). Interoperability as a means of modernising the public sector, as this contributes effectively and effectively to the needs of the public sector and encourages the creation of a Digital Single Market.  This also contributes to the quality of life of European citizens and strengthens the European growth and job creation strategy, but it is necessary to take into account respect for privacy and ensuring security. The digitisation of European public administration is of particular importance in order to reduce costs and save time and strengthen internal and external competitiveness in favour of the progress of the European economy.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. The proposal negotiated in the trialogue is balanced and in many respects reflects Parliament's position without intervening in the competences of the Member States. Parliament has been particularly committed to data protection, net neutrality and a balanced financing and audit model, which has been largely adopted. That is why I am voting in favour of the proposal.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report. ISA2 is the latest in a series of programmes that have been supporting the interconnection, digitisation and collaboration of public administrations since the 1990s. This agreement will ensure that ISA2 will be ready to kick in by the time the current ISA programme expires at the end of 2015. I welcome the introduction of new priorities such as greater involvement of citizens, additional data-protection safeguards and enhanced cooperation between Member States to overcome the digital divide and develop the creation of user communities and exchanges of good practice.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Writing. The creation of the Digital Services Interoperability Programme (ISA2) is to be welcomed. The main purpose of the programme is to improve interoperability between European public administrations and citizens or businesses. By enabling cross-border and cross-sectoral interaction of European public services, the EU is moving in the right direction. There is no doubt that European public administrations should lead the digital revolution by example. The Digital Single Market is one of the flagships of the European Commission and ISA2 is an important milestone. There is no doubt that this initiative deserves strong support.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ In general, the rapporteur supported the Commission proposal. In his opinion, this programme should be as a part of ambitious and socially inclusive European digital agenda. He also believes that more emphasis should be put on the demand side while modernising the public sector, in order to respond more effectively and efficiently to civil society’s needs. GUE tabled several amendments, mainly focused on avoidance of digital divide, guaranteeing the data protection and benefits of the programme to citizens. Most of them were included in the text of the final report. This is why I voted in favour.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I refused to take part in this vote because I consider it unacceptable to have scheduled it on 11 November, in violation of the respect due to our forefathers who died for our freedom. If I had voted, I would have voted against this text because it recklessly encourages the exchange of computer data between administrations. Espionage by the American secret services (among others) will be facilitated.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is an initiative aimed at improving European citizens' access to public services and their rights. This report proposes a programme on interoperability solutions for public administrations in the EU; these solutions at European level are aimed at being compatible among the 28 Member States. This reduces compatibility costs and facilitates mobility and access to public services for citizens switching Member States within the EU. In addition, this report points to the need to combat the digital divide, as well as to ensure SME access to such solutions. Electronic interoperability represents an opportunity to improve the functioning of the public sector by increasing the services it can provide to citizens. For all this, I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Writing. The creation of the Digital Services Interoperability Programme (ISA2) is to be welcomed. The main purpose of the programme is to improve interoperability between European public administrations and citizens or businesses. By enabling cross-border and cross-sectoral interaction of European public services, the EU is moving in the right direction. There is no doubt that European public administrations should lead the digital revolution by example. The Digital Single Market is one of the flagships of the European Commission and ISA2 is an important milestone. There is no doubt that this initiative deserves strong support.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 Although I see the potential benefits of interoperability, I see this legislation as an expensive EU programme to "europeanise" public administration and take it out of national control, not as a tool for streamlining it. That is why I voted against it.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The Commission has been committed to interoperable solutions since 1995 with a view to facilitating data sharing between the EU institutions and public administrations and cooperation between various organisations on mutually beneficial and agreed common objectives. This goal is still pursued today through the ISA programme, which is currently in force, and marks the beginning of a phase in which technological progress affects the work of public administrations and civil society.  The Commission's proposal for the ISA2 programme represents a significant step towards modernising the public sector in order to bring it closer to the needs of civil society as efficiently and effectively as possible. It would enable public administration to connect with other sectors, protect data and privacy of administrations, businesses and citizens, simplify procedures, establish solutions that administrations will be able to directly use and measure the performance of programmes. Interoperable solutions are no longer a goal but a means of achieving greater efficiency, as there is a clear user requirement to do so. I supported representative Carlos Zarrinh's report, because interoperable solutions are a prerequisite for better public service and creating an environment in which companies are more competitive and citizens are deprived of administrative burdens. Member States should continue to modernise their administrations, improve business processes and ICT infrastructure.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Mamikins (S&D), in writing. \u2012 Further consistent multi-sector modernisation is necessary for the successful optimisation and development of the European Union's activities. On the other hand, given the multi-layered and complex structure of our Community governance, as well as the impact of various factors and actors on its mundane functioning, the exchange of high-quality information between public administrations, businesses and citizens, thereby contributing to the improvement of their interoperability, is very important and should therefore be continuously encouraged. Developing methods of strategic and tactical challenge solutions, establishing a repository of common standards, ensuring privacy and security in the areas of information exchange and further application, simplifying procedures and reducing the degree of risk-cutting, encouraging more active interinstitutional cooperation and, above all, targeting all these principles to meet the needs of European Union citizens, these principles must be based on a programme of interoperability solutions for European public administrations, businesses and citizens. It is hoped that the ISA2 programme will continue to work effectively for its predecessors and further contribute to the promotion of inter-institutional and other exchanges of information and cooperation in the EU Member States, which, among other things, could also act as a factor in increasing the confidence of EU citizens in relation to their administrations.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union without internal borders and the development of electronic communications and the digital society also require effective electronic cross-border and over-departmental interaction between European public administrations and the interaction of these authorities with citizens and businesses. This naturally increases the demands for open access to, rapid processing and reuse of data. The aim of the interoperability project is to improve, accelerate and streamline the provision of public services to citizens and entrepreneurs and to promote seamless cross-border and cross-sectoral synergies between public administrations. In accordance with the principle of subsidiarity, this problem must be tackled as a matter of priority and uniformly by eu bodies and institutions. I support this project, saying that privacy and security must be preserved in its resolution and implementation from the point of view of public administrations, businesses and citizens.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a programme on interoperability solutions for European public administrations, businesses and citizens (ISA2), interoperability as a means of modernising the public sector, because the report is complete and documented.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a programme on interoperability solutions for European public administrations, businesses and citizens. The proposal provides for the establishment of a programme on interoperability solutions for European public administrations, businesses and citizens.  The ISA 2 programme contributes to the modernisation of European public administrations by strengthening competitiveness for businesses. It is therefore an important contribution to the realisation of the digital single market and to the implementation of an ambitious, global and socially inclusive European digital agenda.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we voted on a draft decision establishing an interoperability programme for European public administrations, businesses and citizens (ISAs). In particular, interoperability should help to remove obstacles to the exercise of the rights of EU citizens. This is closely linked to the objective of introducing e-government, which should make communication with public authorities easier and easier for citizens. At the same time, however, it is necessary to draw attention to the risks associated with this, such as the possibility of hacking the network, i.e. how to ensure the protection of personal data, often insufficient coverage, with regard to the elderly, who are already struggling to learn how to move and handle digital means, and therefore the phenomenon of the potential emergence of new excluded groups of the population should also be combated. The ISA2 programme should also contribute to achieving these objectives. I consider the report to be balanced when it also draws attention to possible risks, which is why I voted in favour in the final vote.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. Interoperability increasingly promotes the potential quality of public services and creates an environment with more competition between businesses and greater satisfaction among citizens. I therefore support this report.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. As early as 1995, the European Union set up programmes to promote trans-European exchange networks through which Member State administrations could exchange data with other administrations or directly with EU institutions. This included maximizing the interoperability of the minitel network at the time.  This programme was resumed in 1999 to establish cooperation over the internet. The report before us today aims to extend this system to businesses and citizens. It proposes the development of more effective online administration, at the national, regional and local level of public administration, as well as cross-border or cross-sectoral electronic interaction. Although it has no interest and is probably used for bad generalized surveillance, I vote for this text.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this resolution as it is essential that we update and improve the ways that data is exchanged between administrations and EU institutions. The implementation of these interoperability solutions is a key component of the digital single market.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. This report strengthens efforts to improve interoperability between jurisdictions. In the digital age in an increasingly united Europe, it is essential for administrations to make interaction between administrations, businesses and individuals efficient, both at national and European level. Beyond lower costs, interoperability will enhance the quality of the service offered and thus energize our company. The ISA 2 programme thus proposes a series of measures that will enable us to better meet an important challenge facing all of our Member States.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on interoperability solutions for European public administration, businesses and citizens (ISA2), which aims to harmonise the interoperability landscape in Europe, saving time and costs for citizens and business, and contributing to the modernisation of European public administrations and to the creation of a digital single market. The proposal will support the interconnection and digitisation of public administrations and collaboration between them, and will ensure unified electronic cross-border or cross-sector interaction between European public administrations in areas such as government, health, invoicing and procurement. I also strongly welcome the introduction in the programme of new priorities such as greater involvement of citizens and businesses and enhanced cooperation between Member States to overcome the digital divide, and to develop the creation of user communities and exchanges of good practice.

name: Sorin MOISĂ
text: in writing. ‒ An efficient public administration is key to a successful citizen-state relationship.
