The EU’s aim is to enable the free movement of its citizens, goods and services, and therefore it is important not to burden this movement with unnecessary bureaucracy. If national public administrations could function more like a network, thus collaborating and sharing information, it could save everyone time and money. This piece of legislation puts in place a programme to facilitate digital cross-border and cross-sector information exchange between our public administrations, thus enhancing this network functionality. Such an initiative can only increase the quality of the services provided by public administrations in the EU and therefore it has my full support.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 Since 1995, the inter-administrative data exchange programme has been used for the exchange of data within public administrations and between public administrations and eu institutions. The Commission has now proposed a decision by Parliament and the Council to launch a programme that would open up the possibility for businesses and citizens. The report highlights the strengthening of the service character of public administration, in particular the need for civil society data. I supported the adoption of the proposal.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 Interoperability solutions for public administrations, businesses and citizens are an essential tool for the exchange of data between administrations and the European Commission. With technological developments, it is necessary to modernise the public sector in a more effective and efficient response to the needs of citizens and businesses.    I voted in favour of this proposal because I believe it has contributed to achieving the Digital Single Market and implementing the European Digital Agenda.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the european Parliament and Council's proposed decision setting out a programme for interoperability solutions for public administrations, businesses and individuals in Europe (ISA2) - Interoperability as a means of modernising the public sector.  Indeed, it incorporates all the concerns of the EPP Group, including how to overcome electronic barriers between Member States, ensure cross-border interoperability between the European public administration and, beyond that, fully exploit the opportunities offered by new technologies and remain open and flexible in order to integrate new challenges and new areas. It also aims to facilitate solutions that meet the needs of SMEs.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome the Commission's proposal establishing a programme on interoperability solutions for European public administrations, businesses and citizens. Since its launch in 1995, the Commission, together with the Member States, has always promoted solutions that allow the exchange of data between the administrations and institutions of the European Union.  We are therefore in favour of maintaining this approach, which is still in force, on interoperability solutions for European public administrations, but we believe that, at the same time, new strategies must be adopted that take into account technological advances, the new needs of administrations and civil society, as well as the new opportunities offered by cloud computing.  The inclusion of businesses and citizens among the target groups of the ISA 2 programme is also a significant step forward, especially from a demand-oriented perspective, i.e. the ability to modernise the public sector by adapting it more effectively and efficiently to the needs of civil society. It will be necessary to strengthen the potential quality of public services more and more, creating an environment of greater competitiveness for businesses and greater satisfaction of citizens' needs. It is certainly a valuable ally of the European strategy for growth and jobs.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The report by Mr Beazley on be it is a good one. Zorrinho welcomes the Commission's proposal establishing a programme on interoperability solutions for European public administrations, businesses and citizens. This decision maintains the approach adopted so far but at the same time marks the beginning of a new phase, which must take into account technological advances, the new needs of administrations and civil society as well as the new opportunities offered by cloud computing. Interoperability will increasingly strengthen the potential quality of public services, creating an environment of greater competitiveness for businesses and greater satisfaction of citizens' needs, a valuable ally of the European strategy for growth and jobs.  As I believe it is an important contribution to the realisation of the digital single market and to the implementation of an ambitious European digital agenda, I voted in favour of this report.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 Taking advantage of interoperability within the EU will make a major contribution to overcoming the digital barriers that still exist in the business, administrative and public sectors between Member States. The interoperability solutions programme not only ensures effective sharing of data, experience and best practices between Member States, but can also bring about many quality changes in the long term. It clearly contributes to the cohesion of the European Union, the strengthening of the internal market and, last but not least, provides an opportunity to overcome new challenges. Good and close cooperation is the basis for the sustainability of our competitiveness.  Cross-border access to information also means large savings, which is a major advantage for end-users, i.e. small and medium-sized enterprises and EU citizens. However, we must not forget that a number of interoperability solutions include the processing of personal data, so compliance with EU data protection standards is inevitable, in any case.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ The programme on interoperability solutions for European public administrations, businesses and citizens was launched in 1995. I have voted for this report that will help public administrations in Europe to modernise in order to address overall economic competitiveness and people’s quality of life.

name: Dan NICA
text: in writing. \u2012 ISA 2 is the Commission's latest programme supporting the interconnection, digitisation and collaboration of public administrations. The current programme will end this year and has supported the development of eGovernment solutions that are today operational in public administrations across the Union. The new ISA 2 programme will ensure cross-border or cross-sectoral electronic interaction between European public administrations in areas such as governance, health, billing and public procurement. ISA 2 will support the development of interoperable digital solutions available to all interested public administrations at European, national and regional level, free of charge. This will help modernise European public administrations and create a digital single market. The new ISA 2 programme is expected to operate in 2016-2020, with a budget of around EUR 131 million. As the S&D ITRE coordinator, I welcome the introduction of new priorities in the programme such as greater involvement of citizens and businesses, additional guarantees on data protection, a strong focus on reuse and exchange of references and solutions , enhanced cooperation between Member States to fight the digital divide and to develop the creation of user communities and the exchange of best practices.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the Commission's proposal establishing an interoperability programme for European public administrations, businesses and citizens (ISA2). I appreciate that the ISA2 programme represents a significant shift in its focus on businesses and citizens in order to modernise the public sector to respond more effectively to the needs of the public. At the same time, it represents an essential contribution to the creation of the Digital Single Market, in particular its socially inclusive components. Increasing interoperability means improving the quality of public services, which can benefit both businesses and citizens.

name: Andrey NOVAKOV
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 ISA2 is a programme that the European Union needs to overcome electronic barriers between Member States. The programme is expected to start work in January 2016 and will aim to support the development of operational digital solutions that will be made available to public administrations in Europe. The main beneficiaries will be administrations at national, regional and local level in EU countries. They will use digital systems to ensure compatibility of their IT systems and to provide electronic services that will allow easier application and implementation of cross-border projects and programmes, exchange of experience, etc. Work on the EC proposal in the European Parliament was divided between the ITRE, IMCO and LIBE committees. I hope and believe that, in addition to reducing red tape, this programme will also be a step forward towards a common european funding procurement portal, a more effective and transparent work of the European Union. It will also support citizens and businesses. At the same time, the actual product of the programme must meet the real needs of the administration in order to provide technical assistance and the maximum effect of the use of European taxpayers' funds.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that cooperation between the various Member States is important in the context of the general modernisation of public administration in the EU and the Community. The continuation of the modernisation of public authorities in the future will also be important. Better governance must be promoted and cross-border and cross-sectoral interaction between administrations can bring people closer to the citizens in individual areas. Another positive effect would be cost savings, increased efficiency, transparency and greater quality of public sector services.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. A programme of interoperability solutions will be created for European public administrations, businesses and citizens, which will increasingly improve the quality of public services and create an environment where businesses can increase their competitiveness and citizens' satisfaction increases. Digital solutions will be developed that can be used by the public sector, businesses and also citizens.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with the report on monitoring the implementation of ISA2, as well as on its evaluation provisions. Greater efforts should be made to modernise the public sector, make it more efficient and transparent and improve public services. In particular, it is important to ensure close cross-border and cross-sectoral interoperability and to improve people's access to digital services in the public sector. This programme will ensure a more efficient provision of interoperable digital services. In addition, closer cooperation between public administrations will be facilitated and public confidence in public administrations will be increased. This programme will help to promote productivity, competitiveness and growth. It should be noted that the European Parliament must play a greater role in the implementation and evaluation process in order to promote good governance and contribute more effectively to the implementation of the Digital Agenda for Europe.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against the renewal of the EU ‘Interoperability solutions for European public administrations, businesses and citizens’ (ISA2) programme. While we recognise the potential benefits of interoperability, we see this expensive EU programme as being designed primarily to ‘Europeanise’ public administration and prise it away from national control, rather than being an efficiency measure.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 As not only an MEP but also an Italian politician and entrepreneur, on the basis of my experience I have gained awareness of the importance of a constant and productive dialogue between the different sectors of public administration, both internally and with the private sector. This must be done not only at European level, but also between bodies of different levels in order to improve the governance and quality of citizens' representation and the needs of businesses; On several occasions, in the form of an amendment to the dossiers of my fellow Members, I have supported this cause. I therefore welcome and welcome the changes made in this regard to the draft report that has just been debated in this House and I am voting in favour of it.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – EGovernment is an important element of the future development of United Europe. Not only does it save us money and time, but it also brings with it greater transparency. I supported ISA2 because for the first time the programme defines not only public administrations at European, national, regional and local level, but also citizens and businesses in Europe as beneficiaries. In the amendments to the text, we focused on better access to public information for companies and especially SMEs, which are the biggest victims of cumbersomeness and outdated administrations. For business, this also means opening up easier access to new markets.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ I support the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a decision by the European Parliament and the Council to establish a programme of interoperable solutions for European public administrations, entrepreneurs and citizens. It is necessary to remove electronic barriers between all Member States in order to take advantage of all the opportunities given to us by new technologies. The electronic public administration not only greatly reduces the time and cost of individual procedures, but adapts to the increasing demands of end-users. Due to the increasing mobility of citizens within the EU, rapid flow and exchange of information must be ensured. Fast and efficient public administration is an important service for small and medium-sized enterprises and entrepreneurs. Reducing administrative barriers and providing rapid services will make it easier for entrepreneurs to create new jobs.  Unfortunately, in some EU member states, including Croatia, public administration still cannot adequately respond to the demands of its beneficiaries, resulting in a loss of trust in public administration and the absence of new investments and jobs. For all of the above, in particular taking into account the free flow of people and goods and the need for entrepreneurs to obtain documents and evidence necessary to carry out their work in different Member States, it is clear that the interoperability of modern electronic public administration cannot be realised at Member State level, but a single legislative framework is needed.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. The aim of the establishment of the programme is to modernise the public sector and facilitate the needs of citizens. The proposed program focuses on citizens' needs, privacy, security and a high level of data protection, simplification of administration and availability of data by traditional and electronic means.  Activities that serve to achieve the objectives are the establishment of common semantics to connect the public sector with other sectors, to improve open standards, in particular those relating to data transfer security, data processing and storage, and the development of privacy and security mechanisms. It is certainly important to establish a common repository of usable solutions and standards that would be available for public sector or eventual upcoming projects. The proposal also covers social, economic and other aspects of interoperability in order to connect European public administration with citizens with quality.  In addition, it covers the development of a more effective and simpler e-administration at national and regional level. It focuses in particular on ensuring a common understanding and validation of interoperability. Consequently, I agree with colleague Carlos Zorrinh's proposal for a programme of interoperable solutions for European public administrations, entrepreneurs and citizens.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider interoperability necessary to make the most of the social and economic possibilities of information and communication technologies, and as a result, only with sufficient interoperability will we be able to achieve the objectives of the European Digital Agenda. That is why the EU will introduce a new ISA interoperability solution programme for 2016-2020, building on the previous programme, which expires at the end of this year. The EU has already done much in terms of interoperability, but there is still a lot of work to be done to achieve the ideal state of digital connectivity between organisations, public administrations and citizens. Lack of interoperability often constitutes an obstacle to the deployment of digital services between end-users and to the creation of points of single contact for businesses and citizens. Maximum interoperability between European institutions and public administrations is essential for the completion of the Digital Single Market, which will enable citizens to fully benefit from interoperable electronic services, including e-government or eHealth. I believe that interoperability is one of the policies that we can most effectively manage at European level. This requires a common concept of interoperability and a holy solution. For citizens and businesses, better interoperability will mean, above all, more efficient, simplified and user-friendly e-governance.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 ISA 2 is the new programme that allows the exchange of data within administrative contexts and between public administrations and European institutions. This program includes an improvement in the previous IDA, IDABC and ISA tools. This new instrument, which will have to take account of technological advances, will contribute to the modernisation of the public sector by adapting it more effectively and efficiently to the needs of civil society. Interoperability solutions, through the creation of greater competitiveness for businesses, will be a valuable ally of the European strategy for growth and jobs.  I welcome the Commission's proposal because I believe that ISA 2 can make an important contribution to the realisation of the digital single market and to the implementation of an ambitious European digital agenda.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 This Decision establishes a programme for interoperability solutions for European public administrations, businesses and citizens (the "ISA2 programme") for the period 2016-2020, following the end of the successful ISA programme. The main objective of the ISA2 programme is to facilitate effective and effective electronic cross-border or cross-sectoral interactions between European public administrations on the one hand and Between European public administrations and businesses and citizens on the other. Modernising European public administrations and increasing their interoperability is important in order to enable European citizens to make full use of interoperable e-services. Such modernisation will contribute to a digital transformation that will make public services more transparent, efficient and user-friendly. The digital transformation of cross-border services is the next step towards a digital single market. The cost of the ISA2 programme is estimated at EUR 131 million. That is why I supported the resolutions.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the interoperability report. I consider its development to be important. For the European institutions in particular, interoperability is something that we must support. We must develop efforts to modernise public administration at all levels, and I consider the ISA programme to be a good example of this effort.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against the renewal of the EU ‘Interoperability solutions for European public administrations, businesses and citizens’ (ISA2) programme. While we recognise the potential benefits of interoperability, we see this expensive EU programme as being designed primarily to ‘Europeanise’ public administration and prise it away from national control, rather than being an efficiency measure.

name: Dominique RIQUET
text: In writing. Data exchanges between Member States, administrations, businesses and citizens should not be left behind by the digital single market. Interoperability solutions for public administrations should lead to standards and semantics common to all administrations, with the aim of promoting data exchange. The expected benefits are significant, whether it is improving the efficiency of public services or strengthening the competitiveness of businesses in the Union. I therefore voted for this report, which represents as many opportunities for our European citizens as for our businesses.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. With the ISA programme coming to an end on 31 December 2015, a new EU programme on interoperability solutions for public administrations, businesses and individuals in Europe was needed. The decision, which I supported, proposes here to establish, for the period 2016-2020, a programme on interoperability solutions for public administrations, businesses and individuals in Europe (the "ISA2 programme").  Its specific objectives are to perfect, exploit and reuse existing cross-border or cross-sector interoperability solutions; Develop, exploit and reuse new cross-border or cross-sector interoperability solutions; assess the ICT implications of proposed or adopted EU legislation and identify areas where new legislation could promote interoperability; Create a European Interoperability Reference Architecture (ARIE) as a tool to develop and evaluate interoperability solutions; Create an instrument to facilitate the reuse of existing interoperability solutions and identify areas where such solutions are still lacking; assess and promote existing common specifications and standards and develop new ones and establish a mechanism to measure and quantify the benefits of interoperability solutions.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. The interoperability of intra-EU public-citizens-business administrations maximises the economic, even social, potential of Information and Communication Technologies and it is to that extent that this report is a relevant step towards the creation of a programme on interoperability solutions for European public administrations, businesses and citizens under the European Digital Agenda. The Programme for Interoperability Solutions for European Public Administrations (ISAs) has proved to be key in the coherent development and implementation of global and sectoral strategies to avoid electronic barriers in the Union and to improve efficient and effective cross-border or cross-sectoral electronic interaction between European public administrations and between businesses and citizens. With the end of the ISA programme at the end of this year, it is necessary to establish a new EU programme for 2016-2020, which promotes the reduction of cross-border costs, barriers and administrative burdens, deepens the internal market and freedom of movement in the EU. To that extent, I agree overall with the objectives set out in this report and endorse the need to provide for an increase in financial appropriations for interoperability solutions between EU public administrations that is consistent with the current multiannual financial framework 2014-2020.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. A new European programme on interoperability solutions for public administrations, businesses and individuals in Europe is needed as the current ISA programme will be completed on 31 December 2015.  I supported this report on the new programme, entitled 'ISA2', which will propose interoperability solutions for the period 2016-2020. It is intended to help Member States offer digital services and will continue to support action on electronic signature creation and verification tools, cross-border online health systems and open source software to support the European Citizens' Initiative.  The text also highlights the cross-border or cross-sector dimension of interoperability.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on interoperability as a means of modernising European public administrations as I believe it is necessary to strengthen the quality of public services.  The ISA2 programme aims to develop common semantics that connect public administrations with each other and with other sectors and to enable all European citizens and businesses to benefit from interoperable electronic services. The report also makes improvements in terms of protecting privacy and security.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this agreement because, although the text of the European Parliament's report was diluted during negotiations with the Council, the main points are mainly mentioned in the recitals, or there is a reference to existing legislation: the issue of net neutrality (rec. 32 and reference to the TSM proposal) or data protection (art. 16 Rec. 43). We also consider that the modernization of the increasingly interconnected public sector is essential to live up to the demands of individuals, accustomed to the continuous modernization in the private sector.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The report voted on today welcomes the proposal to establish the new EUR 131 million ISA2 (interoperability solutions for European public administrations) programme, which will help modernise European public administrations and provide interoperable digital services.  Building on the success of its ISA predecessor, the ISA2 programme will support the development of digital solutions that will ensure cross-border or cross-sectoral electronic interaction between European public administrations, businesses and citizens. A harmonised European interoperability scenario calls for a higher level of competitiveness for European companies and greater satisfaction of citizens' needs. Through the use of ISA2 solutions, administrations will be able to ensure interaction between the different IT systems responsible for the provision of electronic services, saving time and costs and contributing to the creation of the digital single market. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this because I am opposed to further Europeanisation of public administration. This bill also releases significant additional spending whilst taxpayers are being asked to accept cuts in front-line services.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the introduction in the programme of new priorities which will introduce a greater involvement of citizens and businesses. I also welcome the additional safeguards which concern data protection, a stronger emphasis on the reuse and sharing of references and solutions, and enhanced cooperation between Member States in order to address the digital divide.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. – When voting on the European Parliament's legislative resolution on the proposal to establish an interoperability solution programme for European public administrations, businesses and citizens (ISA2), I voted in favour of adopting the present proposal. ISA2 represents the continuation and adjustment of previous Union programmes in this field. It is important that we continue to modernise European public administration. Ins upsising the interoperability system is also necessary to implement the effective and effective implementation of existing common EU policies.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ Interoperability is undoubtedly a key success factor in the areas of customs, taxation and excise duties and the operation of trans-European ICT systems covering all Member States. Furthermore, Member States and the Commission have committed to develop strategies for JOINTLY managed IT systems that work together in all customs-related areas.  Interoperability in terms of data protection and better cross-border cooperation should reveal a significant potential to achieve better efficiency for Member States' public services. By introducing electronic public procurement, procurement procedures themselves would be more efficient and transparent, meaning large budget savings and a level playing field, especially for new and existing SMEs. For these reasons, I supported the proposal for a decision establishing an interoperable solutions programme for European public administrations, entrepreneurs and citizens.  It not only enables sustainable interconnection between public administrations and these administrations and other sectors, thereby strengthening the Union economy's capacity for competition globally, but also creating an environment in which companies become more competitive, making such a solution a strong ally of the European growth and employment strategy.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the motion for a resolution because interoperability as a means of modernising the public sector is very important. The modernisation of public administration must continue, with particular emphasis on e-services such as eGovernment, eHealth, e-invoicing and e-public procurement. The consequent ensuring interoperability between these services will lead to more and better digital services for citizens and businesses across Europe, as well as cost savings and efficiency, transparency and quality in the public sector. The interoperability of eGovernment requires not only systemic compatibility (M2M solutions), but also the capacity of state administration to work in close cooperation with information systems, as well as informing the public about the possibilities offered by such systems. Staffing must therefore also be taken into account in ISA2, both in terms of digital and language skills.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. \u2012 The report represents a continuation of the ISA programme, which provides interoperability solutions for European public administrations. This programme is still being used, but it also opens a new cycle that cannot ignore technical developments, new needs of administrations and civil society, and new opportunities in the field of cloud computing.  Interoperability increasingly promotes the potential quality of public services and creates an environment that enables businesses to be more competitive and more satisfied with citizens. The new programme thus brings more focus to businesses and citizens, makes a significant contribution to the digital market strategy, captures the results of increased cooperation and synergies with important initiatives by the European Commission, etc.  The ISA2 programme contributes to the modernisation of public administrations in Europe and increases their potential in terms of positive differentiation, both in the area of global competitiveness of the economy and in the quality of life of the population. It also contributes to the creation of the Digital Single Market and to the implementation of the ambitious Digital Agenda for Europe, which is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Renato SORU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the legislative resolution by which Parliament approved the fourth interoperability programme called ISA2, which for 20 years has been offering support for the development of tools and services in the e-government sector, with a view to developing solutions for the modernisation of public administrations to digital evolution.  Indeed, the aim of the programme is to develop interoperable solutions for a more effective, simplified and accessible digital administration at all levels through a common framework of cooperation and exchange between administrations and dialogue with citizens and businesses, ensuring high levels of protection and efficient use of resources.  I agree with the rapporteur's approach, which has insisted on the social and economic dimension of interoperability, so that the provision of public services takes place in such a way as to prevent the digital divide, solutions are developed inclusively through a community of users and suppliers and there are as many synergies as possible with other European Union initiatives.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Writing. The creation of the Digital Services Interoperability Programme (ISA2) is to be welcomed. The main purpose of the programme is to improve interoperability between European public administrations and citizens or businesses. By enabling cross-border and cross-sectoral interaction of European public services, the EU is moving in the right direction. There is no doubt that European public administrations should lead the digital revolution by example. The Digital Single Market is one of the flagships of the European Commission and ISA2 is an important milestone. There is no doubt that this initiative deserves strong support.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: Writing. \u2012 I was happy to support the Commission's proposal to introduce an interoperability programme for European public administrations, businesses and citizens (ISA2). This programme, building on the current very successful ISA1 programme, is a major step forward, mainly because it is now targeting businesses and citizens. Considerable space is thus given to the real needs of the public. In today's Europe, more and more citizens are working and doing business across the EU and thus urgently need to communicate with public authorities. Unfortunately, they very often encounter electronic administrative barriers that prevent them from using public services effectively and, as a result, the smooth functioning of the EU internal market. The interoperability programme will contribute to improving public services within the EU. It will lead to the proper implementation of various EU policies, for example in the area of public procurement, health, tax. It will ensure greater competitiveness and help to implement the European digital agenda, all while benefiting businesses and citizens.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ I supported this report because the public sector plays an important role in the economy as a regulator and provider. A public sector that is efficient and productive can be a powerful driver of economic growth by supporting and managing in the private sector. With many Members facing the challenge of securing a financial construction to boost growth, competitiveness and employment, there is a strong case for improving efficiency, better governance and faster action and more pronounced user participation in the public sector.  I also believe that in order to allow for more efficient interaction with citizens and entrepreneurs, Member States must modernise their administrations and provide interoperable digital services at national and European level. I believe that this programme will facilitate cooperation between Member States and the Commission and mapping and analysis of the overall interoperability environment in Europe.  I also believe that it will enable the promotion and support of a holistic approach in the collection, assessment, development, establishment, industrialisation, action, improvement and maintenance of interoperable solutions, including solutions facilitating the reuse and exchange of data, in support of cross-border and cross-sectoral interaction between European public administrations, entrepreneurs and citizens.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ The report on a programme on interoperability solutions as a means of modernising the public sector is the latest proposal since the 1990s supporting the interconnection and digitisation of public administrations and collaboration between them. I welcome the introduction in the programme of new priorities which will ensure greater involvement of citizens and businesses. Furthermore, I support the additional data-protection safeguards, a stronger emphasis on the re-use and sharing of references and solutions, and enhanced cooperation between Member States in order to address the digital divide.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ The public sector plays an important role in the economy as a regulator, provider and employer. At a time when governments face the challenge of ensuring financial consolidation while boosting growth, competitiveness and jobs, there is a strong justification for improving efficiency, better governance, faster action and more pronounced user participation in the public sector.  Interoperability between administrations is a key factor enabling the efficient provision of digital services, while the exchange and reuse of existing interoperable solutions could reduce costs multiplying. The new programme should focus on end-users; security, respect for privacy and a high level of data protection; standard data protection and data protection when designing; administrative simplification and modernisation; access to services by traditional and electronic means. I support the proposal for a decision by the European Parliament and the Council to establish an interoperable solutions programme for European public administrations, entrepreneurs and citizens (ISA2), as I believe that an efficient and productive public sector can be a powerful driver of economic growth.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal and welcome the efforts to streamline interaction between public administrations of individual EU countries, as well as between public administrations and businesses and citizens.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a programme for interoperability solutions for European public administrations, businesses and citizens. I support the establishment of an interoperable e-society in the European Union and the participation of public administrations in promoting the use of online procedures.  More efficient online public services will strengthen business and citizens' confidence in digital services. Interoperability solutions will modernise public administration in the EU, the quality of public services and improve the competitive environment for businesses.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 It is our firm position that the public sector should be modernised by promoting reforms that work for the benefit of the needs and interests of society. There are many positive references in the legislative text, such as the need to modernise public administration using new technologies, to ensure the protection of personal data during the information exchange process, to take into account the negative effects on SMEs in order to ensure more favourable conditions for them, to ensure the public character of the Internet, to simplify procedures in order to reduce the administrative burden on citizens, to combat social exclusion and to promote gender equality. However, as mentioned, the establishment of the interoperability programme should contribute to the implementation of the initiatives developed under the Europe 2020 strategy as well as the digital agenda, policies on which we have often expressed our disagreements. The proposal to exchange information is also problematic as it is not clear where it will stop.  However, we voted in favour of the text because of the positive reports, but also the need to reform the public sector in order to enhance the quality of services in order to better serve people.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The modernisation and upgrading of the services offered by the Public Administration to citizens and businesses will contribute to the development that our country so badly needs, as well as reduce the bureaucracy that is a big problem in our country long before the economic crisis. In addition, the articles referring to the publication of public contracts will help to combat corruption. Unique objection, the possible involvement of private companies in the management of personal data that should be avoided.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The dismantling of so-called e-borders is a process that has been going on for several years and now has tangible results, for example in the functioning of the European institutions. Programmes (IDA, IDABC and ISA) have been put in place which have made a significant contribution to the electronic exchange of information between the European institutions. I supported this report because I think it is important to close the gaps in the digital field, not just physical, at all levels; for the public sector, businesses and citizens.  I agree with the report that interoperability offers serious opportunities in terms of data protection and closer cross-border cooperation, and that taking responsibility for these opportunities can bring significant growth and efficiency benefits. I believe that this can also contribute to achieving the objectives of the European Semester. Isa2 (2016-2020), which will replace the so-called ISA programme, which runs out on 31 December 2015, takes into account the conclusions of the impact assessments carried out in recent years and I hope that digital interoperability will be developed in a measurable way with a tool based on some EUR 131 million.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 In the 21st century, it is crucial to take action to improve the use of existing as well as new cross-border and interoperable solutions for public administration, not only because of the increasing digitisation process in the current world, but also because such solutions bring significant savings and facilitation for both offices and citizens. At the end of this year, the ISA Programme, which was implemented between 2010 and 2015 and supported the introduction of interoperable solutions for public administrations, businesses and citizens in the European Union, ceases to apply. As a result, a new programme, called THE ISA2 Programme, has become necessary.  The European Parliament's legislative resolution properly outlines methods that will lead to better interoperability of the public sector, such as facilitating small and medium-sized enterprises, taking full advantage of the opportunities offered by new technologies or overcoming electronic barriers between Member States. I therefore decided to support this resolution by vote.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 In a European Union, the public administration serves the European citizen at all levels. In view of the right of our citizens to travel freely within the Union and to reside in any Member State, public administration services must also maintain their effectiveness and meet the needs of European citizens. In this respect, a number of programmes on interoperability solutions for European public administration have been launched, and the report we voted on today focuses on ISA2, a welcome continuation of the IDA, IDABC and ISA programmes. Today, eGovernment is public administration, but the digital gaps we are seeing still make it difficult to exploit the full potential of making public services more efficient. Cross-border electronic barriers are yet another reason for the Union to be fragmented and hinder the creation of common services in the interests of European citizens. The key element in this context is interoperability in terms of data protection and cross-border cooperation, the contribution of which to the successful implementation of policies is essential. The ISA2 programme brings us closer to the objective of modernising public administration and adapting it to a highly mobile, informed and digital society.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the european Parliament and Council's proposed decision setting out a programme on interoperability solutions for public administrations, businesses and individuals in Europe (ISA 2) because it is a continuation of efforts in this area, including the ISA programme (interoperability solutions for European public administrations) still in force , but at the same time opens a new cycle that cannot fail to take into account technological developments, the new needs of administrations and civil society, and the new opportunities offered by cloud computing.  ISA 2 will complete the Digital Single Market and contribute to the implementation of an ambitious European digital strategy through its leading role at the global level.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on interoperability solutions for European public administrations, businesses and citizens (ISA2): interoperability as a means of modernising the public sector. E—goverment solutions are becoming more and more important, or rather necessary. Digital solutions in public administration can bring significant savings, make public administration easier and faster and ensure seamless electronic cross-border or cross-sector interaction between public administrations, businesses and citizens. Therefore I support the ISA2 programme – the follow-up programme to ISA, which ran from 2010-2015. ISA2 is expected to start on 1 January 2016, and to run until 31 December 2020. The new EUR 131 million programme will support the development of interoperable digital solutions, which will be available to all interested public administrations in Europe.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒I voted for the report, as it also establishes a programme of interoperable solutions for European public administrations, entrepreneurs and citizens, as I believe that this delivers better efficiency of Member States' public services through overcoming electronic cross-border barriers and cross-sectoral cooperation between the European public, businesses and citizens.  I take particularly useful the requirement to introduce electronic public procurement with a view to increasing the efficiency and transparency of public procurement procedures, which would ultimately lead to large savings in the budget and a level playing field, including new and existing SMEs.  In particular, I support the one-stop shop's best practices proposal so that users can get the information they need more easily and efficiently. I believe that it will be extremely useful to regularly measure success according to the impacts and satisfaction of businesses and the needs of citizens to ensure the effectiveness of this program and that, in the event that the results do not meet the set criteria, the program of interoperable solutions could be changed or improved.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. The report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing an interoperability solutions programme for European public administrations, businesses and citizens (ISA2) – interoperability as a means of modernising the public sector – was supported as I believe that this document brings about the continuation of the ISA programme, which brings about modernisation of public administrations in Europe.  This will increase their potential in the area of global competitiveness, the economy and also in the area of quality of life of the population.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this agreement because, although the text of the European Parliament's report was diluted during negotiations with the Council, the main points are mainly mentioned in the recitals, or there is a reference to existing legislation: the issue of net neutrality (rec. 32 and reference to the TSM proposal) or data protection (art. 16 Rec. 43). We also consider that the modernization of the increasingly interconnected public sector is essential to live up to the demands of individuals, accustomed to the continuous modernization in the private sector.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Writing. The creation of the Digital Services Interoperability Programme (ISA2) is to be welcomed. The main purpose of the programme is to improve interoperability between European public administrations and citizens or businesses. By enabling cross-border and cross-sectoral interaction of European public services, the EU is moving in the right direction. There is no doubt that European public administrations should lead the digital revolution by example. The Digital Single Market is one of the flagships of the European Commission and ISA2 is an important milestone. There is no doubt that this initiative deserves strong support.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly support interoperability in the EU in all possible fields. Interoperability is a fundamental element of the Connecting Europe Facility (CEF) in order to complete the single market in the railways sector, for example removing regulatory and physical barriers. But Interoperability is also essential in the public administrations and digital world. Common solutions, promotion of good practices, technological neutrality and adaptability should be a key priority. Principles of security, privacy and protection of personal data should always be applied. In this respect, net neutrality is of the uttermost importance to ensure that there is no discrimination between internet services and competition is fully guaranteed.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposal provides for the launch of the Interoperability Solutions Programme (ISA2) available to European public administrations, businesses and citizens, a long-awaited continuation and further development of previous programmes (IDA, IDABC, ISA). In addition, the principle of data protection by design is added to the general principles on the basis of which the actions of the ISA2 programme are implemented. This ensures that data protection requirements are taken into account at the development stage for interoperability solutions involving the processing of personal data. I voted in favour of the final proposal.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this agreement because, although the text of the European Parliament's report was diluted during negotiations with the Council, the main points are mainly mentioned in the recitals, or there is a reference to existing legislation: the issue of net neutrality (rec. 32 and reference to the TSM proposal) or data protection (art. 16 Rec. 43). We also consider that the modernization of the increasingly interconnected public sector is essential to live up to the demands of individuals, accustomed to the continuous modernization in the private sector.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a programme on interoperability solutions for European public administrations, businesses and citizens as a means of modernising the public sector. I believe it is important to promote solutions enabling data to be exchanged in administration contexts and between administrations and EU institutions. The aim of the ISA2 programme is to make sure that the Commission, when determining the implementation and assessment criteria to be applied, does not confine itself to an exclusively supply-side perspective, but, on the contrary, will have to emphasise the demand-side perspective – that is to say, the ability to modernise the public sector to make it respond more effectively and efficiently to civil society’s needs. I also believe that interoperability within local, national and European public administrations facilitates the achievement of the goals set out by the European Parliament in its resolution of 29 March 2012 on the ‘EU Citizenship Report 2010: Dismantling the obstacles to EU citizens’ rights’.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. We are talking about a report on the proposal for a Decision of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a programme on interoperability solutions for european public administrations, businesses and citizens (ISA2). In this way, it is intended to continue the efforts of the ISA programme, supporting cooperation between public administrations in the service of Community acts and policies on the basis of an effective and efficient use of information technologies for the establishment of cross-border public services, and helping to remove barriers to cross-border interactions in the context of lack of interoperability and common solutions. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in favour of that report.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is an initiative aimed at improving European citizens' access to public services and their rights. This report proposes a programme on interoperability solutions for public administrations in the EU; these solutions at European level are aimed at being compatible among the 28 Member States. This reduces compatibility costs and facilitates mobility and access to public services for citizens switching Member States within the EU. In addition, this report points to the need to combat the digital divide, as well as to ensure SME access to such solutions. Electronic interoperability represents an opportunity to improve the functioning of the public sector by increasing the services it can provide to citizens. For all this, I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this proposal because the new programme allows cross-border and cross-sector interaction between European public administrations. The new ISA2 programme will ultimately lead to a harmonised interoperability landscape within Europe, which will ultimately result in cost and time savings. Moreover, this proposal will contribute to the creation of a digital single market within the European Union. I also welcome the fact that the new ISA2 programme is now also aimed at businesses and citizens and not just on public services. As a result, the Commission will have to respond more to the needs of civil society in the development of this programme or, to put it another way, to take into account the demand side and not just the supply side.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 Since 1995, the European Commission has been promoting interoperability solutions for European public administrations, businesses and citizens with Member States, and mechanisms that allow the exchange of data in the context of their administrations and their son with the EU institutions. We follow all measures aimed at modernising the various public administration services and, in particular, those that go to dematerialize part of the documentation. However, access to and universality of these services should be safeguarded by combating any type of exclusion, particularly in relation to those who are struggling with new technologies and the Internet.  On the other hand, we believe that these advances cannot under any circumstances question the existence of proximity services, particularly in socially, economically and demographically depressed regions.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. Interoperability increasingly promotes the potential quality of public services and creates an environment with more competition between businesses and greater satisfaction among citizens. I therefore support this report.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I did not agree with parliament's position on the establishment of a programme on interoperability solutions for European public administrations, as adopted by Parliament in its legislative resolution of 11 November 2015. The main focus of this programme is on the efficient cross-border and cross-sectoral interaction between public administration on the one hand and citizens and businesses on the other. It is trying to enable the public administration to keep up with the rapid pace of IT developments. The aim is to make the administration more modern and equipped for digital transformation. The cost is EUR 131 million.  This form of administrative reform is exactly what the EU suffers from: administration must be thought of by the citizen. Efficient and citizen-oriented administration must start at local level. And that is where the competences must lie. The EU, as the most remote institution, symbolises the opposite, tramples on the idea of subsidiarity and simulates proximity to the citizens through expensive programmes.  As always in the EU, the approach is noble, the reality is different.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of Interoperability solutions for European public administration, businesses and citizens – new ISA Programme. Given that the current ISA Programme will expire in less than two months, since it is valid only until the end of the year 2015, there is a need for establishing the new, improved programme. First of all, the project focuses on overcoming electronic barriers between Member States through promoting existing common specification, but on the other hand focuses on developing the new common standards. This seems to be a crucial issue considering the era we live in. Moreover, what also attracted my attention is the fact that the new programme considers creating an instrument to facilitate the re-use of existing interoperability solutions and identifying those areas in which such solutions are still missing. The proposal’s objectives are very promising and, if achieved, will prove to be a decisive step towards the improvement of the activities of the whole European Union.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which was adopted by the committee responsible, taking into account the opinion of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, in which I participate as an alternate member. This initiative brings multiple benefits to Europe's societies, enhancing the digital single market, the quality of life of citizens and the competitiveness of national economies.

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: in writing. The report on interoperability solutions as a means of modernising the public sector is absolutely necessary. This new package will allow an interoperability solutions programme to be established for public administrations, businesses and European citizens. There is no doubt that improving existing cross-border and transectoral interoperability solutions is necessary. The EU must develop and operate new interoperability solutions and be able to analyse and evaluate future solutions at European level. This is good news for businesses, especially SMEs. So is it for the public administration; interoperability is a means of modernizing the public sector. Finally, and more importantly, it is good news for European citizens.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 This report deals with the programme of interoperability solutions for European public administrations, businesses and citizens - ISA2 - and aims to continue the Data Exchange Programme between administrations - IDA - launched in 1995 with the aim of promoting solutions with Member States that enable the exchange of data in the context of their administrations and their administrations with the EU institutions. The document, in essence, is an important sign of developments with a view to modernising and interoperability of the public sector so that more effective and efficient responses are given to current needs, in particular in terms of new technologies and cloud computing. Despite this important step in updating and adapting the programme, it is stressed that measures should be taken to protect data protection and, therefore, that IT resources, among others, remain in the exclusive area of public administrations. Furthermore, that the necessary advances in this field do not call into question other measures and other means of supporting the provision of public services to people throughout the territory of the Member States and should be in complementarity. We voted for it.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Today's vote has shown that the majority of the European Parliament prefers to stay among themselves rather than compete in democratic competition. Today we have seen long-established MPs disregard a high court ruling by Germany, which in 2014 ensured that millions of voters could feel involved in the formation of political will. Millions of citizens will no longer vote, and the ever-expanding political disaffection will increase. Colleague Jo Leinen of the SPD warned against the destabilisation of the parliament by splinter parties. Only seven members of various small parties came to the European Parliament from Germany as a result of the abolition of the undemocratic blocking clause. With 751 Members, the seven Members are unlikely to be destabilising or even restricting Parliament's ability to act. In any case, my party – the NPD – will take all necessary legal action against the abolition of democratic standards.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I voted against the report, I will vote against these reforms. I wanted to remind you that in Germany before World War I there were different voting systems in each country. When Adolf Hitler came to power, he immediately unify all systems, because this is the old method of the European Union – to follow in the footsteps of his spiritual master Adolf Hitler: "everything is to be unified". More besides, I think that the European Union should be destroyed.

name: Max ANDERSSON
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for There is discontent in this House that Members are elected from their own Member States, from their own parties, which have their own election manifestos and that they represent their own voters. Instead, it wants MEPs to be elected on European election manifestos and to submit them to the largely artificial EU parties.  This proposal for a European electoral law contains several proposals that go in this direction. The proposal for transnational lists, the proposal that the eu parties' electoral symbols should appear both on ballot papers and on electoral material. What is at stake is shifting power from the Member States to the EU parties. It is about increasing the distance between voters and elected representatives. And that would undermine democracy.  I have voted against this proposal and I hope that the Council will ensure that these bad proposals do not become a reality.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: – Madam President, I have rejected the proposal for electoral reform in the European Union. To me, it is enough to quote from the explanatory memorandum that the referring party resents the fact that the division of seats in the European Parliament is not decided in a European election, but in the 28 national elections for national seats. It should be acknowledged that, however many would like, we have not yet reached the United States of Europe, there are still nation states, not just provinces. This proposal itself runs forward to where we hope we will never get to. Here he is talking about a common unified EU electoral organisation. He wants to create a common constituency with a candidate for the presidency of political families at the top of his lists. How many seats they will receive, we do not know, so it is quite clear that this is a proposal made in the same way that we have already managed to take down nation states. Let's hope it doesn't work.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I will comment on the reform of the right to vote, but I just want to point out that I was also registered on the previous point concerning the future of air transport, and i was overtaken there without being allowed to comment. I would like to say that, with regard to the right to vote, I supported the report by Mrs Hübner and Mr Leinen, because I believe that time has already evolved since the original act, since the 1970s. I disagreed with some of the provisions of the report, whether it was about gender equality, but about the regular rotation. I think that is a rather strange view of the principle of equality. But there were a number of good points, whether it was the drop in the right to vote to the age of sixteen or, for example, the internet vote. So that's about the voting rights reform.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP is opposed to the very existence of, and to UK participation in, a so-called European Parliament. It is therefore against any proposal designed to consolidate the power and position of that entity. There are proposals for legislation contained in the report and UKIP always votes against legislation, all of which has the effect of draining sovereign power away from the UK. In addition there are specific proposals on the conduct of elections, which are designed to federalise the whole European election process and to produce the illusion of a bogus EU demos, and which are unacceptable.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 The main purpose of the electoral law is to indicate the principles and rules necessary for the election of the European Parliament. The council's last decision to this effect was in 1976. That is why it is essential, as well as necessary, to carry out an analysis and a possible adaptation of parliament's election procedures as a result of the evolution of the Union itself. The possibility of relying on rules that reflect today's social structure is, in fact, fundamental to respect for the rights of European citizens themselves. Ensuring greater transparency in procedures certainly brings the citizen closer to politics and avoids the practice of abstention, restoring confidence in the system of choice.  Although in some respects the report presented meets the above requirements in a welcome way, I have none the same time decided to abstain from voting in view of the role and role of the creation of European political parties. In view of the value and traditional importance of national parties in relation to their relationship with the citizens, abstaining from voting is intended to represent a possibility of constructively changing the proposed reform.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is a reform which will contribute, inter alia, to strengthening the democratic dimension of European elections, giving greater legitimacy to the work of the European Parliament and ensuring greater electoral equality for citizens. In particular, I welcome the adoption of political groups, at least twelve weeks before the European elections, formal candidates for the presidency of the Commission and for all countries to set a minimum vote threshold (between 3% and 5%) to obtain parliamentary representation.  I also welcome the approval of the following measures: - creation of ballots with greater visibility of the name and logo of European parties; - creation of a European constituency with lists headed by the candidate appointed by each political family for the post of President of the Commission; - study of the harmonisation of the minimum age for voting at the age of 16; - possibility to allow voting by mail, email and online. Finally, I regret that the use of instruments such as zipper lists or other equivalent methods to ensure gender equality has been rejected.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted against this report because there are several points on which I cannot in any way agree. The report does not provide for the possibility of the President of the European Commission being democratically elected by direct suffrage among European citizens. I refuse to give the current way of elying the President of the Commission after the adoption of the Lisbon Treaty democratic status, as set out in the report. In addition, I am also against the existence of a European constituency where 26 MEPs are directly chosen to be presented by lists of European parties. Nor am I in favour of forcing national parties to include the European party logo on the ballot. This should be left to the election of each national party. That is why I did not vote in favour of the own-initiative report.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the reform of electoral law in the EU for a number of reasons. I believe the introduction of constituency and Member State thresholds to be undemocratic: it clearly disadvantages smaller parties, regional parties and independents. As citizens identify primarily with local, national parties, the inclusion and participation of European political groupings in election campaigns would add an unnecessary and potentially confusing dimension to those campaigns. I also believe that elections are the competency of established national authorities, and that no attempt should be made to create, or move towards the creation of, a single European electoral authority. Whilst the report contained some progressive elements, in relation to female representation and extending the franchise, these failed to mitigate its worst excesses, forcing me to oppose it.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ This report entails significant intrusion into the operation of elections within the Member States. It is not for the European Union to tell Member States how to run their democratic elections.  Much of this report I would oppose even if it were suggested by my national Parliament itself, because it tells political parties that they should choose candidates based upon gender. I fundamentally disagree; candidates should be chosen based upon merit.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal aimed at reforming the European elections. The debate on e-voting takes place not only in Lithuania, but also throughout the European Union. I supported the amendments that will allow EU citizens to elect the European Parliament even more effectively by allowing electronic voting to be allowed. I believe that this would improve the conditions for expressing our political will to the citizens of Lithuania in the future.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I supported this Parliament's resolution, which generally aims to increase the attractiveness of European elections. In particular, it proposes to improve the visibility of European political parties by indicating their names and logos on ballot papers as well as on electoral media and during election broadcasts. It also proposes to set a common deadline of 12 weeks before the European elections for the nomination of leading candidates by European political parties in order to allow them to present their electoral programmes and to organise political debates between the candidates.  The resolution also reiterates the need for better representation of women in European elections and to encourage the vote of European citizens residing in another EU country.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: in writing. Through the reform of European electoral law, we had a unique possibility for European elections to be more than just an assessment of national policy, to bring an institution like the European Parliament closer to citizens and for parliamentarians, their representatives, to be under the scrutiny of the people. Despite including some improvements, such as parity lists or transnational lists to encourage citizen participation, in most issues progress has been timid. The result has been an uns ambitious text. Moreover, the establishment of a mandatory electoral threshold only places barriers to representative democracy as it does not take into account the particularities of each State. This law is a clear example that doing things fast does not mean doing them better.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I am grateful for the work done in the report by the rapporteurs and shadow rapporteurs, but I have had to vote against that report as there has been no possibility of setting any thresholds for European elections. My party, being a regional party, has to show up in coalition with others in order to get representation in the House; if electoral constituencies existed, we would have obtained two Deputies. There is currently no threshold in the Spanish State for these elections and therefore I cannot vote in favour of them being included.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 Creating a single pan-European constituency of 25 seats by entrusting the European Union with the task of being the only electoral authority responsible for voting is madness. In concrete terms, it means, among other things, preventing democratic control of a very large constituency. For these reasons, I voted against the proposal.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is a reform which will contribute, inter alia, to strengthening the democratic dimension of European elections, giving greater legitimacy to the work of the European Parliament and ensuring greater electoral equality for citizens. In particular, I welcome the adoption of political groups, at least twelve weeks before the European elections, formal candidates for the presidency of the Commission and for all countries to set a minimum vote threshold (between 3% and 5%) to obtain parliamentary representation.  I also welcome the approval of the following measures: - creation of ballots with greater visibility of the name and logo of European parties; - creation of a European constituency with lists headed by the candidate appointed by each political family for the post of President of the Commission; - study of the harmonisation of the minimum age for voting at the age of 16; - possibility to allow voting by mail, email and online. Finally, I regret that the use of instruments such as zipper lists or other equivalent methods to ensure gender equality has been rejected.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report amending the electoral law of the European Union. The possibility of establishing a uniform electoral procedure based on direct universal suffrage has been enshrined in the Treaties since 1957. The reform of the European parliamentary electoral procedure should aim at strengthening the democratic and cross-border dimension of elections to the European Parliament, the democratic legitimacy of the European Union's decision-making process and the concept of EU citizenship, and improving the functioning of the European Parliament and the governance of the EU. The reform of EU electoral law also aims to increase the legitimacy of the European Parliament's activities, to ensure greater respect for the principles of electoral equality and equal opportunities, to increase the effectiveness of the electoral system for the European Parliament and to bring MEPs closer to the electorate, especially the youngest of them. In addition, the effective harmonisation of the european parliamentary electoral procedure in all Member States could better encourage all citizens of the European Union to exercise their right to participate in the democratic life of the EU on an equal basis, while strengthening the political dimension of European integration.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 Although the Treaty of Lisbon allows the European Parliament to determine the procedure for its own election, changing electoral procedures remains, in many respects, a competence of the Member States. This report indirectly foreshadows constitutional amendments with a number of proposals, which may quasi-in violation of the principle of subsidiarity, and I therefore did not support the Hübner-Leinen report.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this proposal because the reform of european electoral law is an important step towards adapting the 1976 Electoral Act to the current situation and at making the democratic mechanism in Europe more effective.  Since the Union outlines only a few general guiding principles in this regard, the differences between the various national legislations on electoral procedures have long weakened the concept of European citizenship, the concept of electoral equality and, above all, the role of active citizenship within the Union. A move towards greater uniformity and harmonisation at European level is therefore not only desirable, but necessary.  With the adoption of this own-initiative report, the European Parliament aims to increase the visibility of European political parties, thanks in particular to the desire to emphasise their affiliation more clearly than national ones, making the European elections more transparent. The inclusion of thresholds in the larger countries will also make it possible to avoid the creation of micro-training and therefore excessive fragmentation. The decision to set a common deadline for the submission of electoral lists will make it possible to carry out more effective election campaigns and the setting of a single deadline, valid for all Member States, for the closure of polling stations will make the election result less effective.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the reform of electoral law in the EU for a number of reasons. I believe the introduction of constituency and Member State thresholds to be undemocratic: it clearly disadvantages smaller parties, regional parties and independents. As citizens identify primarily with local, national parties, the inclusion and participation of European political groupings in election campaigns would add an unnecessary and potentially confusing dimension to those campaigns. I also believe that elections are the competency of established national authorities, and that no attempt should be made to create, or move towards the creation of, a single European electoral authority. Whilst the report contained some progressive elements, in relation to female representation and extending the franchise, these failed to mitigate its worst excesses, forcing me to oppose it.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that many of the proposals it contains represent substantial progress towards the adoption of an EU electoral law.  The implementation of a European electoral law would make a decisive contribution to increasing interest in and importance of the European elections. I would, however, like to express my disappointment at the failure to approve the 'zip lists' that I have proposed, which would have led to a decisive advance towards gender equality in the European elections. I think it is very serious that the Europe of 2015 is not yet ready to accept such a basic principle.

name: Renata BRIANO
