text: in writing. \u2012 Although the European elections renew the same Parliament, which is the Representative Assembly of the European people, it is the national laws governing the election, referring only to a few basic principles enshrined in EU legislation: for this reason, the methods of election, the thresholds for blocking and the allocation of preferences vary widely from state to state, de facto undermining the homogeneity of the renewal of the parliamentary assembly.  Over the years, since 1976, attempts have been made ten times to improve European electoral law, but the Council has always vetoed it. Although the improvements proposed in the agreed text are modest, the effort to make the elections 'more European' and more homogeneous is to be welcomed. In particular, gender balance, the introduction of transnational lists and the increased visibility of European political parties are useful tools to overcome the mistaken habit of experiencing the European elections as a 'poll' within the national political forces or as a 'vote of feelings' and instead understand their nature as a fundamental continental democratic exercise capable of setting the political and economic course for the whole Union. For the first time, we have the opportunity to build a European electoral law: let us not waste it.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The political representation of mandates in the European Parliament is not determined by a single European election, but by the 28 national elections in the 28 Member States of the European Union of the national mandate quotas. Even if the harmonisation of electoral rules is not an end in itself, European citizens must exercise their right to vote under comparable conditions, respecting democratic principles. The first direct elections to the European Parliament (EP) took place in 1979, and the provisions governing European elections have evolved, but not as substantially as the EP would have liked. However, the Maastricht Treaty gave the EP the right to approve the Council's decision on the uniform procedure, which gives European citizens the right to vote and run in the Member State of residence, whatever that may be. I was in favour of the legislative initiative on the reform of the European Union's electoral legislation, because it reflects the objective of strengthening the democratic dimension of European elections, strengthens EU citizenship, leads to the better functioning of the European Parliament, but also to the governance of the Union.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Main aims of this proposal to reform EU electoral law: - to formalise the appointment by European political parties of their candidates for the post of President of the Commission. This practice, used in 2014, is in clear violation of the Treaties and was deliberately designed to deceive voters into believing that they could directly elect the President of the Commission; - one day to establish a pan-European constituency of 25 seats, with the relevant EU electoral authority. It will be impossible to ensure effective democratic control over a college of this size; - make the thresholds mandatory (between 3 and 5%). There is a surplus for a very strong vote against.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is a reform which will contribute, inter alia, to strengthening the democratic dimension of European elections, giving greater legitimacy to the work of the European Parliament and ensuring greater electoral equality for citizens. In particular, I welcome the adoption of political groups, at least twelve weeks before the European elections, formal candidates for the presidency of the Commission and for all countries to set a minimum vote threshold (between 3% and 5%) to obtain parliamentary representation.  I also welcome the approval of the following measures: - creation of ballots with greater visibility of the name and logo of European parties; - creation of a European constituency with lists headed by the candidate appointed by each political family for the post of President of the Commission; - study of the harmonisation of the minimum age for voting at the age of 16; - possibility to allow voting by mail, email and online. Finally, I regret that the use of instruments such as zipper lists or other equivalent methods to ensure gender equality has been rejected.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. I voted in favour of reforming the electoral law in the Union. It is indeed important to adapt European electoral legislation to the current challenges and challenges. We need to build a coherent set of rules so that the European elections are more visible and transparent. In this text, it is recalled that MEPs vote individually and personally, which is a particularly important concept.  Member States must set an electoral threshold to avoid too much fragmentation of the European Parliament that would impinge on the effectiveness of the decision-making process. Member States must also ensure gender parity on the electoral rolls.

name: Enrique CALVET CHAMBON
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it includes among its main amendments the introduction of a mandatory threshold in European elections for countries with a single constituency (that type of constituency exists in Spain).  The introduction of a mandatory threshold makes it impossible for certain political parties or platforms to be represented in the European Parliament and to combat equal voting of citizens. Those who support this option say it will prevent fragmentation in the Euro-Camera and the arrival of Eurosceptics. In my opinion, these fears must be quelled by conveying to our citizens pride in the project we are defending. During the processing of this report, amendments have been tabled which collide head-on with my view of representation in the Eurochamber. In the same way that I criticise the introduction of a mandatory threshold limiting the representation of the citizen will, I criticise my own group for trying to introduce a nuance that favours fragmenting regional parties; the proposal has been to reduce the mandatory threshold required, in order to promote its representation over others at national level.  This only takes us away from the construction of a Europe of citizens.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 After careful consideration and discussion in this House, I voted in favour of the report on the reform of the Eu ropean Union's electoral law, considering, in the final analysis, the proposals made by the rapporteurs at the bottom of the report to be valid.  As well as appropriate, the efforts made to ensure the best possible aggregation of political forces in order to form a real 'European political conscience' are to be welcomed, as the process of democratic representation in Europe is still in formation and requires balanced parliamentary representations consistent with internal constitutional systems and for strengthening the stability of government, while avoiding fragmentation.  If Parliament's regulatory function is strengthened, and if more political awareness has been built up with the formation of European political parties, there are many open issues on which this reform produces an important development. I support the proposals to harmonise the minimum age for the active and passive electorate, to introduce mandatory thresholds recognised by the Constitutions as a legitimate means of operation, to introduce the right to vote for citizens outside the EU, and to introduce transparent procedures for the selection of candidates. I see them as real progress which increases the democratic dimension of the European elections.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the reform of electoral law in the EU for a number of reasons. I believe the introduction of constituency and Member State thresholds to be undemocratic: it clearly disadvantages smaller parties, regional parties and independents. As citizens identify primarily with local, national parties, the inclusion and participation of European political groupings in election campaigns would add an unnecessary and potentially confusing dimension to those campaigns. I also believe that elections are the competency of established national authorities, and that no attempt should be made to create, or move towards the creation of, a single European electoral authority. Whilst the report contained some progressive elements, in relation to female representation and extending the franchise, these failed to mitigate its worst excesses, forcing me to oppose it.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP is opposed to the very existence of, and to UK participation in, a so-called European Parliament. It is therefore against any proposal designed to consolidate the power and position of that entity. There are proposals for legislation contained in the report and UKIP always votes against legislation, all of which has the effect of draining sovereign power away from the UK. In addition there are specific proposals on the conduct of elections, which are designed to federalise the whole European election process and to produce the illusion of a bogus EU demos, and which are unacceptable.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I agree with this report mostly because it aims to bring the European Parliament closer to the voters. It also outlines provisions which will improve the functioning of the European Parliament as well as the visibility of European parties.

name: Daniel CASPARY
text: Writing. I am speaking on the part of the German CDU/CSU MEPs: for us, the adoption of this report is an important step forward, because it contains many amendments to the electoral act, which we warmly welcome. These include, in particular, rules that increase the perception of this election, facilitate participation in it and keep Parliament fit for work.  The aim was also to take this step with the broadest possible majority. That has been achieved. Democracy also involves recognising and recognising that there are actors in the House who associate with the right to vote objectives that are not ours or which we currently consider to be unrealistic. In particular, our scepticism applies to the trans-European constituencies for the leading candidates, to whom we only voted in favour of the Hübner/Leinen report as a whole in the interests of a broad majority.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The report is the first step in the revision of European electoral law, which dates back to 1976. The proposal contains many elements of improvement, including measures aimed at harmonising electoral times and deadlines in the various States, the possibility of introducing electronic voting, the possibility of voting for those who are temporarily abroad (soldiers and workers in general) and elements of greater transparency for those taking part in the electoral competition.  However, the report also contains some critical aspects, in particular the call for the introduction of a European constituency and a reference to the role of European parties as promoters of a European political conscience. I have therefore chosen to abstain.

name: Jean-Marie CAVADA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report by Danuta H-bner and Jo Leinen on the reform of the European Union's electoral law. This text aims to remedy the growing disaffection of European citizens for the European elections and to promote the emergence of a European public space.  At a time when national withdrawal is all too often observable in the Union, I welcome the adoption of an amendment by my political family to create a European constituency. Similarly, I was in favour of introducing a minimum electoral threshold requirement and improving the procedures for appointing the leading candidates for the presidency of the European Commission, guaranteeing a certain democratic representation (prompt to avoid, among other things, the over-representation of infrequent political parties) and a better legibility of the European political offer. On the other hand, I did not support the recommendation to harmonize the right to vote at 16, since the full awareness of European citizenship and what it commits, in my opinion, comes later, nor that in favour of electronic voting, because I consider that physical movement to the polling station is a citizen's act to be preserved.

name: Lorenzo CESA
text: in writing. \u2012 The role of the European Parliament has gradually changed since the 1979 elections and its powers have increased considerably. Today, Parliament is co-legislator with the Council in most areas of the Union's activities, especially after the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, which made MEMBERS of the European Parliament directly representatives of the citizens of the Union rather than representatives of the people. That is why we need a reform of Parliament's electoral procedure that increases the democratic and supranational dimension of the European elections, so that they are no longer just the sum of national elections and that European political parties acquire the role of real political parties, and are not the sum of national parties. In this way, Parliament itself will gain more legitimacy by getting closer to the voters. It is important that harmonisation concerns a number of rules, including the affixing of logos and names of European parties to the ballot papers, as a sign of belonging to the same political family.  I welcome the fact that the italian text adopted has accepted the linguistic clarifications which distinguish the terms necessary for the establishment of electoral lists from the lists of voters entitled to vote.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the proposed EU electoral law reform because I believe there has been a continuous need to update the current electoral legislation. I would like to highlight measures concerning the possibilities of electronic voting via the internet. I am convinced that, in the 21st century, we have to be able to make use of our supreme democratic right by all acceptable means, including the electronic vote. This measure can, furthermore, help to attract young people to vote. There are, however, several issues in the reform proposal that I could not support. They relate to the obligation to present the so-called zipped lists. I could also not agree with the recommendation to harmonise the minimum age of voters at 16 years.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 It is an important step in modernising European electoral legislation which, above all, member states must adopt and implement. The motion for a resolution approaches and modernises important issues such as ensuring equal representation of men and women, the right to vote for all citizens wherever they are, the representation of all EU citizens by members of the European Parliament, the setting of electronic and online voting, and the implementation of transparent and democratic procedures, etc.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report. Since 1976, EU citizens have been able to vote for their representatives in the European Parliament by direct universal suffrage. However, the election procedures vary from state to state, thus being contrary to the objective of creating a common Europe where elected representatives act as "representatives of the citizens of the Union" (Article 14(2) TEU).  Article 223(1) TFEI gives the EP the opportunity to reform the 1976 European Elections Act by making proposals on which the Council will be called upon to give its opinion. The EP has proposed strengthening the visibility of European political parties, introducing a common deadline of 12 weeks before the national election round, introducing a mandatory threshold for the allocation of seats, introducing a common 12-week deadline for the appointment of european political party leaders, introducing gender equality and introducing the possibility of electronic voting , via the Internet or by mail order. Finally, the GROUP of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats has called for the Council to set up a joint constituency in which the lists are headed by candidates from all political families for the office of President of the European Commission.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal to reform eu electoral law. The Treaty of Rome of 1957 already provided for the possibility of establishing a uniform electoral procedure based on direct universal suffrage, and I think it is necessary to strengthen the transnational dimension of the European elections, given that at the moment elections are based on national issues and therefore European political parties cannot sufficiently carry out their constitutional mandate and contribute 'to forming a European political conscience and expressing the will of the citizens of the Union'.  The rapporteurs examined a large number of potential reform measures that would enhance the democratic dimension of the European elections by improving the functioning of the European Parliament and the governance of the European Union, all through the strengthening of the visibility of European political parties, the introduction of the right to vote for all EU citizens residing outside the EU and the introduction of the possibility of electronic voting , among the many measures that I agree with.

name: David COBURN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP is opposed to the very existence of, and to UK participation in, a so-called European Parliament. It is therefore against any proposal designed to consolidate the power and position of that entity. There are proposals for legislation contained in the report and UKIP always votes against legislation, all of which has the effect of draining sovereign power away from the UK. In addition there are specific proposals on the conduct of elections, which are designed to federalise the whole European election process and to produce the illusion of a bogus EU demos, and which are unacceptable.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 The deepening of European democracy that has been done over the last decades has in the election by universal suffrage of the European Parliament one of its major expressions and causes.  Although the possibility has been established since 1957, it was only with the so-called "Electoral Act" of 1976 that the universal election was put into practice. In 2002 was made the first - and so far unique - reform.  Over the years, Parliament has gradually reflected its increased democratic legitimacy through an increase in powers, and today it is co-legislator - with the Council of Ministers - on almost all matters.  We remain with 28 national elections to the European Parliament, but we need to bring Europeans closer to the only institution that directly represents them. To do so, many factors compete, including a better electoral law. I therefore support the eu electoral law reform report overall, although I disagree with some points that deserve further reflection, such as the immediate creation of a European constituency and the right to vote at the age of 16.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 In the run-up to the next European elections in 2019, Parliament and the Council are engaged in the preparation of the reform of the electoral law, which aims to increase the democratic dimension and legitimacy and strengthen the Decision-making process of the European Union.   The European elections are currently largely governed by national legislation and the procedures for nominating candidates vary widely in the different Member States. European citizens must be able to exercise their right to vote under similar conditions while respecting democratic principles. It is therefore appropriate to introduce transparency requirements and democratic standards into national electoral procedures, in order to ensure good governance at European level and to increase the electorate's confidence in the EU institutions.  I welcome the report on the reform proposal because it presents some effective measures to enhance the democratic dimension of the European elections, such as strengthening the visibility of European political parties during election campaigns, introducing a uniform threshold that aims to reduce party fragmentation within Parliament, strengthening the online electronic voting system and facilitating access to voting for European citizens residing in third countries. The reform will thus also consolidate the political dimension of European integration.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 The report is the first step in the revision of the so-called European electoral law. The report amends a 1976 act. The main aspects are: harmonisation of the time in the various Member States with regard to the electoral deadlines (presentation of lists, first projections, closure of polling stations – the latter is fixed definitively at 9 p.m. on the last day of the election session, which maintains the national specificity with regard to the choice of day(s) of the week); voting rights for citizens living outside the EU for work; electronic voting at the discretion of the Member States (this measure is an aid for disabled people, soldiers on missions and workers abroad who are not forced to return/are unable to vote); reinforced transparency measures for parties participating in the electoral competition; the possibility of affixing the logo of the European reference family next to the logo of the national parties, both on the ballot papers and on the electoral material; the establishment of a European Electoral Authority to improve the exchange of information in the run-up to the elections.  However, I am abstaining on the inclusion of certain amendments, including in relation to a single European constituency alongside those already present.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted against this report because there are several points on which I cannot in any way agree. The report does not provide for the possibility of the President of the European Commission being democratically elected by direct suffrage among European citizens. I refuse to give the current way of elying the President of the Commission after the adoption of the Lisbon Treaty democratic status, as set out in the report. In addition, I am also against the existence of a European constituency where 26 MEPs are directly chosen to be presented by lists of European parties. Nor am I in favour of forcing national parties to include the European party logo on the ballot. This should be left to the election of each national party. That is why I did not vote in favour of the own-initiative report.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on the reform of electoral legislation in the European Union contains proposals with which I can agree, in particular as to the easier participation of EU citizens in elections. Such is the proposal to promote the proper representation of citizens belonging to ethnic and linguistic minorities in European elections to the Member States. At the same time, the report on the reform of electoral legislation may indirectly foreshadow constitutional amendments in the Member States with a number of proposals, which may be in violation of the principle of subsidiarity. Although the Treaty of Lisbon allows the European Parliament to determine the procedure for its own election, changing electoral procedures remains in many respects a competence of the Member States. For these reasons, I abstained from voting on this report.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I support the overall aim of making European elections more transparent, visible, fair and democratic. I am in favour of this resolution as it emphasises that political parties need to select their lists democratically and transparently; that ballot papers may give equal visibility to the national parties and European political parties; that EU citizens living or working outside the EU should be able to vote in these elections; and that Member States may consider ways to harmonise voting at age 16.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this attempt to subvert national electoral systems and traditions. It is very important for Member States to be able to retain their own voting traditions as they see fit. In the UK our traditional voting day is Thursday, and I therefore do not support calls for the Election Day to be unified across the EU. Furthermore I also do not want to see important decisions such as voting age set centrally by the EU, and I see no benefit in the proposed creation of a European Electoral Authority. While the amendments to the voting threshold do not specifically affect the UK, I do not agree with solving an issue specific to one country via European legislation. I also cannot support the notion that the Lisbon Treaty provides Parliament with the right to choose the president of the European Commission, given that it represents an erosion of Member State prerogatives and will further politicise the Commission. I also disagree with the assertion in the report that greater harmonisation will ‘strengthen the political dimension of European integration’.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the reform of Parliament's electoral procedure must aim to strengthen the democratic and transnational dimension of European elections and the democratic legitimacy of the decision-making process within the Union, to give consistency to the concept of Union citizenship, to increase the legitimacy of the work of the European Parliament and to strengthen the principles of electoral equality and equal opportunities, to increase the effectiveness of the system applied in the conduct of European elections and to bring Members of the European Parliament closer to their constituents , especially the youngest of them. I support the idea that the list of candidates for elections to the European Parliament should ensure gender equality.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This initiative report makes a number of recommendations to the Council, which will have to vote unanimously on a possible reform of the European electoral system. These amendments will then be forwarded to the Member States for ratification by the relevant national bodies, according to their constitutional rules.  This report aims to strengthen the democratic dimension of the European elections, by improving the visibility of Parliament's work and the effectiveness of the organisation of the European elections. In particular, the report provides for the introduction of electronic voting, via the internet or by mail to facilitate access to the ballot boxes. Together with my colleagues from the French EPP delegation, I also supported an amendment in favour of parity lists providing for a gender balance, as already exists in France. Supporting the objectives of this report, I voted in favour.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 Although the Treaty of Lisbon allows the European Parliament to determine the procedure for its own election, changing electoral procedures remains, in many respects, a competence of the Member States. This report indirectly foreshadows constitutional amendments with a number of proposals, which may be a quasi-violation of the principle of subsidiarity, and I therefore did not support the Hübner-Leinen report.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report on the reform of the electoral law of the European Union. I believe that the recommendations made in the report interfere with the sovereign right of member states to determine the rules for holding elections themselves. I believe that the idea that the minimum voting age should be 16 years, for example, is also not applicable to all EU Member States. I do not agree with the imposition of common rules for the whole EU. I believe that each country should have the freedom to determine its own election legislation, and I do not believe that, for example, the introduction of the same voting time would contribute to the fight against electoral fraud and vote manipulation seen in some Member States.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 This plan promotes the existing lack of democracy that exists in the EU. At the same time, the promotion of electoral measures is not to have a proper functioning in Parliament, but to silence the up-and-coming national political parties that oppose the EU. Although there are some positive elements in this plan regarding the organisational part of the elections to the European Parliament, most of the report is devoted to downplaying the role of national parties and promoting professional EU politicians who will no longer be accountable to the citizens of the Member States.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 Although the Treaty of Lisbon allows the European Parliament to determine the procedure for its own election, changing electoral procedures remains, in many respects, a competence of the Member States. This report indirectly foreshadows constitutional amendments with a number of proposals, which may be a quasi-violation of the principle of subsidiarity, and I therefore did not support the Hübner-Leinen report.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: Written. \u2012 The rules surrounding the European elections need to be better updated and coordinated between different EU countries. I therefore voted in favour of this report in the final vote. However, the text contained some proposals, such as a common EUROPEAN constituency, which I did not support, as I believe that would make the European elections even more complicated.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal envisaged provides for the introduction by Member States of electronic voting and by mail in European elections and the establishment of a mandatory limit of 3% to 5% for the allocation of mandates. According to the reform of the Electoral Act 1976, Member States must allow voting by electronic means and on the Internet in elections to the European Parliament. Voting by mail should also be allowed in the European elections. This amendment aims to increase participation and facilitate the voting of all citizens, especially persons with reduced mobility and persons working or residing abroad. The current European electoral legislation allows the european elections to be set for a non-compulsory limit of up to 5% of the votes cast. In the smaller Member States and Member States that have subdivided their territory into constituencies, although there is no limit, the de facto limit remains above 3%.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The appointment of leading candidates for President of the European Commission to the head of European political parties in the 2014 European elections can be seen as a step in the right direction. Turnout in the only direct elections among all the institutions was extremely low to embarrassing in most Member States, reaching only 13% in Slovakia. The citizens have given us a clear signal that they have lost interest in the functioning of the European institutions and that they do not understand many of the actions of the European authorities and do not consider them to be right. I therefore welcome the changes to be made through the reform of the European Union's electoral law, which should bring about an increase in participation in European Parliament elections and also raise awareness among the populations of the Member States of the functioning of the European Union.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Electoral law is a matter for a sovereign nation state, not this chamber. It is a mistake to detach the electoral process from the national context in favour of further artificial measures aimed at creating European demos. Controlling and imposing the electoral process on nations will bring no more democracy. On the contrary, they have distanced citizens from their representatives. The amendment to create a pan-European constituency, in which dozens of Members would be elected, is particularly damaging, and this election would translate into a decision on the election of the President of the European Commission. That is why I voted against the report by the 'grand coalition' of Chadians and Socialists. The daily functioning of the European Parliament gives a clear picture of what vision of 'democracy' european peoples want to impose on the two largest political blocs. I am convinced that the provisions of the report will be opposed by the Member States.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 This plan promotes the existing lack of democracy in the EU. At the same time, the promotion of electoral measures is not to have a proper functioning in Parliament but to silence the up-and-coming national political parties that oppose the EU. Although there are some positive elements with regard to the organisational part of the elections to the European Parliament, most of the report is devoted to downplaying the role of national parties and promoting professional EU politicians who will no longer be accountable to the citizens of the Member States. For these reasons I am voting against the report on the revision of European Union electoral legislation.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The electoral law is one of our main instruments to show our democratic characteristics and processes. The reform of the electoral law is therefore a very important action that needs to be taken and will enable us to improve the democratic procedure and to have more transparent, visible, fair and democratic elections. I support the set of recommendation proposed by the rapporteur, such as a common date to finalise the lists and appoint top candidates, ballot papers to give equal visibility to the national parties and European political parties, and election thresholds to be set between 3%-5% in single constituencies that comprise more than 26 seats. I welcome the proposal of establishing the European Election Authority and the suggestion to consider ways to harmonise voting at age 16. Using zipped lists or other ‘equivalent’ methods is also a step in the right direction of more gender balance.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is a reform which will contribute, inter alia, to strengthening the democratic dimension of European elections, giving greater legitimacy to the work of the European Parliament and ensuring greater electoral equality for citizens. In particular, I welcome the adoption of political groups, at least twelve weeks before the European elections, formal candidates for the presidency of the Commission and for all countries to set a minimum vote threshold (between 3% and 5%) to obtain parliamentary representation.  I also welcome the approval of the following measures: - creation of ballots with greater visibility of the name and logo of European parties; - creation of a European constituency with lists headed by the candidate appointed by each political family for the post of President of the Commission; - study of the harmonisation of the minimum age for voting at the age of 16; - possibility to allow voting by mail, email and online. Finally, I regret that the use of instruments such as zipper lists or other equivalent methods to ensure gender equality has been rejected.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is a reform which will contribute, inter alia, to strengthening the democratic dimension of European elections, giving greater legitimacy to the work of the European Parliament and ensuring greater electoral equality for citizens. In particular, I welcome the adoption of political groups, at least twelve weeks before the European elections, formal candidates for the presidency of the Commission and for all countries to set a minimum vote threshold (between 3% and 5%) to obtain parliamentary representation.  I also welcome the approval of the following measures: - creation of ballots with greater visibility of the name and logo of European parties; - creation of a European constituency with lists headed by the candidate appointed by each political family for the post of President of the Commission; - study of the harmonisation of the minimum age for voting at the age of 16; - possibility to allow voting by mail, email and online. Finally, I regret that the use of instruments such as zipper lists or other equivalent methods to ensure gender equality has been rejected.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP resolution on the reform of eu electoral law because I believe it is important to have a European electoral law before the 2019 elections, in order to increase the transnational and democratic dimension of the European elections, implement the concept of UNION citizenship and promote the direct representation of citizens in the EP. The EP has called for an electoral law that promotes the visibility of European political parties in the national context, that introduces a threshold for barriers in single constituencies and constituencies with more than 26 seats, that guarantees both pluralism and the functioning of Parliament, that allows, through electronic voting and by correspondence, the participation of citizens resident in third countries and strengthens the link between the European elections and the appointment of the President of the Commission by explicitly indicating the the leaders.  I believe that the reference to the principle of gender equality and the participation of women in institutional life is a victory, and I support the call for Member States to present gender-balanced electoral lists. I regret, however, the failure to refer to the obligation to make closed lists representative of gender equality in the Member States. I very much hope that the Council will agree to implement this proposal.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted against the report on the reform of the EU's electoral law today. This report is neither, as Jo Leinen mantra-like, a mantra-like gain for the attractiveness and transparency of the European elections, nor is it a decided thing, as a Herbert Reul claims on the evening of the vote against better knowledge. The SPD, CDU and CSU have abused the efforts pushed for years – especially by their liberal ex-colleague Andrew Duff – to reform the EU's electoral law sensibly. They are simply trying to overturn the judgments of the German Federal Constitutional Court on the blocking clause on the European back door. They are right to do so – and the right to vote is a ribbon that is as cheap as it is suitably red. This behaviour is national party politics of the most evil kind. The result is a proposal on EU electoral reform as a meaningless smorgasbord with a democratic guarantee of chaos. And an embarrassing vote result: only 315 out of 604 – a majority of 13 deputies, 90 percent from the house factions of the CDU, CSU and EPP. And even in their own groups, the ranks were not closed. Anyone who sells this – like linen and reul – as a victory on such an incisive theme, lives with Pippi Longstocking in Taka-Tuka-Land. But not in the democratic reality of Europe.

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Today's vote on the report on the reform of the Electoral Law of the European Union is an important step towards increasing the democratic dimension of the European elections, strengthening the citizenship of the Union and the effectiveness of the work of the European Parliament. Although the possibility of creating a single electoral procedure based on direct universal suffrage was already taken into account in the 1957 Treaty of Rome, elections to the European Parliament are still largely based on national principles. Campaigns in their home political arenas do not represent the real visions and interests represented by the European Parliament. I agree with the rapporteurs that the inclusion of the names and logos of European political parties on ballot papers and election posters will affect their recognition. Nevertheless, it is important to increase the democratic dimension of the European elections and the turnout, which in Poland did not exceed 24% in 2014. In this context, they are pleased with the proposals to implement the right to vote in European elections for all Citizens of the Union living outside the Union, as well as the possibility of electronic voting, online and by post. In addition, the introduction of a common deadline of twelve weeks before election day for the drawing up of lists at national level and for the designation of the main candidates by European political parties will streamline and harmonise procedures. It is also a great success to record an increase in the presence of women on the electoral lists. I therefore welcome the outcome of today's vote.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. By aligning the different rules of the Member States, regional differences are more relativised. At the same time, the forthcoming reform will make it easier to participate in the elections. For this purpose, further participation opportunities, such as postal voting or voting via the Internet, will be established in the future. Parliament's draft also proposed the introduction of a percentage threshold of between 3 and 5%. This is a further step in the right direction and prevents individual splinter groups from forming due to the lack of barriers to entry in Parliament.

name: Juan Carlos GIRAUTA VIDAL
text: in writing. The European elections are of particular importance because they make the European citizen part of the European construction process, allowing him to choose the representatives he considers best suited to shape european policies from which he will later be a beneficiary.  So far, however, more than a European election, they have been a sum of national elections. It was therefore time to vote in favour of the uniformity of the rules governing this election. Particularly necessary has seemed to me to set thresholds to prevent the presence in the European Parliament of Members who represent only the interest of very small communities. It is precisely the European project that departs from the particular interests of defending common interests.  However, due to the presence of zipper lists and positive quotas, I have had to vote against this Resolution. I am in favour of achieving greater and more balanced representation of women in political life, but I believe in the principle of merit and not discrimination, even if it is positive.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted against the report on reform of EU electoral law. In principle, we consider it necessary to reform legislation which stresses the need for EU parties to modernise and to make proposals, for example on candidates, which are accompanied by the necessary principles of transparency. We believe that the report and some proposals for amendments, focusing on transparency, primaries, gender equality, the possibility of using zipper lists, are the first steps needed for EU modernisation, access to the European Parliament and for it to be truly representative of the society ahead. However, we believe that the necessary plurality of this Parliament must be a red line and that threshold proposals can force us to vote against it, as they undermine the basis on which the electoral system and the EU itself are up.

name: Beata GOSIEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted against the report on electoral reform in the European Union because it breaks the principle of proportionality by interfering with the sphere of competence of the Member States. There is no need to harmonise the rules on European political parties, voting age or the opening time of polling stations. I regret that the European Parliament has adopted a report which seeks to introduce a uniform procedure in the Member States in the hands of the Fundamental Principles of the Treaties.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report, which examines ways to make European elections more transparent, visible, fair, and democratic.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: In writing. On Wednesday 11 November, I voted in favour of the report on the reform of the European Union's electoral law. The European Parliament, on the basis of Article 223 of the FUE Treaty, can indeed formulate proposals in favour of amending the European electoral law on which the Council unanimously decides. For example, MEPs want candidates for the presidency of a committee to stand as the front-line candidates in Parliament elections but also want mandatory thresholds for the allocation of seats in the European Parliament and the possibility for any European living abroad to vote in these elections.  With regard to the question of a common constituency and the question of raising the legal voting age to 16, I preferred to vote against it.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is a reform which will contribute, inter alia, to strengthening the democratic dimension of European elections, giving greater legitimacy to the work of the European Parliament and ensuring greater electoral equality for citizens. In particular, I welcome the adoption of political groups, at least twelve weeks before the European elections, formal candidates for the presidency of the Commission and for all countries to set a minimum vote threshold (between 3% and 5%) to obtain parliamentary representation.  I also welcome the approval of the following measures: - creation of ballots with greater visibility of the name and logo of European parties; - creation of a European constituency with lists headed by the candidate appointed by each political family for the post of President of the Commission; - study of the harmonisation of the minimum age for voting at the age of 16; - possibility to allow voting by mail, email and online. Finally, I regret that the use of instruments such as zipper lists or other equivalent methods to ensure gender equality has been rejected.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that the reform of Parliament’s electoral procedure should aim to enhance the democratic and transnational dimension of the European elections and the democratic legitimacy of the Union decision-making process. We need to improve the functioning of the European Parliament and the governance of the Union, make the work of the European Parliament more legitimate, and bring Members of the European Parliament closer to their voters, especially young people.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: Written. Fundamentally, we Social Democrats believe that it is natural to have a European electoral law regulating the European elections and that this should be updated when necessary. The proposal presented to plenary contained several good elements, such as requirements for gender-balanced candidate lists and better coordination between Member States.  When drafting an electoral law, it is important not to move too fast and to ensure that electoral systems are interlinked, in order to ensure that voters recognise themselves in the process. Unfortunately, the text before the plenary contained a series of proposals that were too detailed and far-reaching, which risked confusing the electorate and not respecting the democratic traditions of the Member States. We could not support these proposals in the vote.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is a reform which will contribute, inter alia, to strengthening the democratic dimension of European elections, giving greater legitimacy to the work of the European Parliament and ensuring greater electoral equality for citizens. In particular, I welcome the adoption of political groups, at least twelve weeks before the European elections, formal candidates for the presidency of the Commission and for all countries to set a minimum vote threshold (between 3% and 5%) to obtain parliamentary representation. Finally, I regret that the use of instruments such as zipper lists or other equivalent methods to ensure gender equality has been rejected.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 Although the Treaty of Lisbon allows the European Parliament to determine the procedure for its own election, changing electoral procedures remains, in many respects, a competence of the Member States. Several of the report's proposals indirectly foresee constitutional amendments, thus in violation of the principle of subsidiarity. For these reasons, I did not support the Hübner-Leinen report.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I did not support this report, as I do not support the idea of obligatory thresholds which can exclude smaller parties and independents – even if this does not impact on my home country – and nor do I support the concept of an additional European list. I also voted against provisions for zipped lists, not because I do not believe in gender equality but rather because of the specific measure cited. There were some good proposals in this report, which I did support and was pleased to see succeed, such as the proposal to give equal visibility to the names and logos of national parties and their affiliated European parties on ballot papers and the proposal to harmonise the voting age at 16 to further enhance democratic participation in EU elections. I hope that these will be taken up by the Council.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report, as I agree in principal with many of the articles. I abstained on Amendment 23 as it was grouped with a number of other amendments. However, I do agree with extending voting rights in EU elections to Irish citizens outside of Ireland.

name: Roger HELMER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP is opposed to the very existence of, and to UK participation in, a so-called European Parliament. It is therefore against any proposal designed to consolidate the power and position of that entity. There are proposals for legislation contained in the report and UKIP always votes against legislation, all of which has the effect of draining sovereign power away from the UK. In addition there are specific proposals on the conduct of elections, which are designed to federalise the whole European election process and to produce the illusion of a bogus EU demos, and which are unacceptable.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Writing. The EU's electoral reform initiative is an attempt to intervene deeply in the electoral law of the Member States. Key elements include, in particular, the introduction of a 3-5% clause to make it more difficult for smaller parties to enter the European Parliament, the lowering of the voting age to 16 and the zipperprocedure for the filling of electoral lists, which is intended to force a quota for women for all parties and countries. Given the peculiarities of the Electoral Systems of the Member States and because small countries are excluded from the reforms, we have to note that a significant part of this initiative has been tailored to Germany. The European electoral system penalises the people of the large countries because their votes are worth less. A 3% quota for Germany can potentially exclude millions of people from political participation in the European Parliament, while the population of smaller states is represented at far lower numbers. That is why this quota system is not acceptable. Nor is the enforced quota system for men and women acceptable. Even if the zipper procedure has failed, a quota is to be introduced. The political participation of women is significantly lower than that of men and very unequal among the parties. They should continue to be able to select the best candidates. I have therefore rejected the electoral initiative.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. \u2012 Although the Treaty of Lisbon allows the European Parliament to determine the procedure for its own election, changing electoral procedures remains, in many respects, a competence of the Member States. With several proposals in this report, it may even indirectly require constitutional amendments. This would violate the principle of subsidiarity, so I did not support the Hübner-Leinen report.

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: In writing. I share the rapporteurs' conviction that the electoral law must be reformed in order to increase the visibility of MEPs and the knowledge of this election, which is largely sullied or ignored by European citizens. On the other hand, I am convinced that the conduct of these elections must be as close as possible to national electoral practices. For example, I do not believe that lowering the voting age to 16 is an expectation of citizens. This rule exists only in Austria. Why impose it on the rest of Europe when it is by no means the culture of other countries? Let us not forget that the right to vote is accompanied by duties and legal and criminal responsibility. This is not a cosmetic change but a much deeper upheaval that results from such a decision. With regard to the other proposals, I am also of the opinion that all initiatives that contribute to publicity among elected officials and the political groups to which they belong are moving in the right direction.

name: Ian HUDGHTON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the notion of transnational lists for elections to this Parliament, and also against the proposed single European constituency. The EU is currently going through a number of parallel crises of a nature never seen before in its history. Whilst, as part of the efforts to overcome these crises, it is necessary for the EU institutions and this House to reengage with the citizens, the recommendations contained in this report, if enacted, will do the opposite. Democracy must come from the grassroots up, not the other way round. Attempts to replace parties of mass membership with European political constructs seem, in my view, destined to fail. Mandatory thresholds will result in diminishing diversity. And the continued attempts by the large political groups in the House to gain for themselves a permanent stranglehold on power will only lead to further disengagement with the citizens we are elected to represent. I therefore voted against this report in the final vote.

name: Filiz HYUSMENOVA
text: alde), in writing. \u2012 I support the report on electoral law reform in the EU, as I find it particularly significant that Member States should take measures to promote adequate representation of ethnic, linguistic and other minorities in european elections. It is also highly relevant to Bulgaria. According to the Bulgarian electoral code, the election campaign is conducted only in Bulgarian, and the violation of this provision leads to the imposition of administrative sanctions. Under the Treaties, every European citizen residing in Bulgaria has the right to be a candidate for a member of the European Parliament. However, this cannot actually happen – because he has been taken away from speaking to his constituents in a language other than Bulgarian, and because this hinders the right of voters to make their informed choices. I believe that the formation of a European political consciousness and the expression of the will of all Citizens of the Union require that this situation be changed.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I applaud the rapporteurs for proposing solid updates to the procedures for electing the European Parliament. Firstly, it is of tantamount importance that parties participating in elections offer gender equality and transparency in selecting candidates. Also, the introduction of a common and comprehensive organisational plan for elections rises to the spirit of European ideals.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. I voted for a report on the reform of the European Union's electoral law, because I believe that European democracy needs to be revived, citizens, especially young people, and encourage the public to think about current European issues. I believe that reform of the electoral process is needed, because we are witnessing a deducies in the European elections. Some of the objectives of this reform, which would be implemented before the 2019 elections, are certainly to increase the democratic and transnational dimension of european elections and the democratic legitimacy of the EU-wide decision-making process, to strengthen the concept of Union citizenship and equality of suffrage across the EU, and to improve the functioning of the EP and the governance of the Union.  Greater transparency of european elections would be achieved by better highlighting the names and logos of European and regional political parties, on the ballot papers and in all media materials during the campaign. The reforms also relate to the timely drafting of election list holders and programme presentations, the introduction of equal end times for elections and the limitation of campaign costs in order to contribute to a more open and transparent process that empowers democratic legitimacy.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is a reform which will contribute, inter alia, to strengthening the democratic dimension of European elections, giving greater legitimacy to the work of the European Parliament and ensuring greater electoral equality for citizens. Finally, I regret that the use of instruments such as zipper lists or other equivalent methods to ensure gender equality has been rejected.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. While the proposed standardisation of some deadlines, such as the introduction of electoral lists or the demand for an equal election day in all countries, is worthy of support, I am opposed to the Europeanisation of the EU election as envisaged here: national candidates will be replaced by EU candidates, EU-wide constituencies will be set up, and THE EU parties will be on the EU's lists as sending parties. This proposal is completely misguided and will not increase citizens' interest in the elections and the EU in general. I therefore reject it.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Writing. The EU's electoral reform initiative is an attempt to intervene deeply in the electoral law of the Member States. Key elements include the introduction of a 3-5 per cent clause to make it more difficult for smaller parties to enter the European Parliament, the lowering of the voting age to 16, and the zippering procedure for filling electoral lists, which is intended to force a quota for women for all parties and countries. I have therefore rejected the electoral initiative.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ Yet again, Parliament is trying to draft suggestions for changing the existing law for the election of its Members, and to give guidelines to Member States in order to obtain changes in their national laws accordingly. I submitted an abstention vote because, although there are certain positive issues, many others need to be addressed in a more concrete way. One example is the nomination of lead candidates for the office of President of the Commission as practised by some European political parties in the 2014 European elections – an arbitrary procedure not provided for in the Treaties, as the President of the Commission is elected not directly but indirectly by Parliament.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I refused to take part in this vote because I consider it unacceptable to have scheduled it on 11 November, in violation of the respect due to our forefathers who died for our freedom. If I had voted, I would have voted against this text because it is an outrageous attempt to disconnect the European elections from nations by exalting 'European citizenship' and by strengthening the role of European political parties during the election campaign. One can guess what the next step will be: it will be to prohibit national political parties from submitting lists. Transparent goal: get rid of the FN!

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is a reform which will contribute, inter alia, to strengthening the democratic dimension of European elections, giving greater legitimacy to the work of the European Parliament and ensuring greater electoral equality for citizens. In particular, I welcome the adoption of political groups, at least twelve weeks before the European elections, formal candidates for the presidency of the Commission and for all countries to set a minimum vote threshold (between 3% and 5%) to obtain parliamentary representation. Finally, I regret that the use of instruments such as zipper lists or other equivalent methods to ensure gender equality has been rejected.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted against this report because there are several points on which I cannot in any way agree. I refuse to give the current way of elying the President of the European Commission after the adoption of the Lisbon Treaty democratic status, as set out in the report. I am also against the existence of a European constituency where MEPs are directly chosen by lists of European parties. Nor am I in favour of forcing national parties to include the European party logo on the ballot: this must be left to the election of each national party. That is why I did not vote in favour of the own-initiative report.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Writing. The EU's electoral reform initiative is an attempt to intervene deeply in the electoral law of the Member States. Key elements include, in particular, the introduction of a 3-5% clause to make it more difficult for smaller parties to enter the European Parliament, the lowering of the voting age to 16 and the zipperprocedure for the filling of electoral lists, which is intended to force a quota for women for all parties and countries. The political participation of women is significantly lower than that of men and very unequal among the parties. They should continue to be able to select the best candidates. I have therefore rejected the electoral initiative.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against this gruesome initiative, which aims to reform the electoral system in the Euro elections, but also to reform national elections. The desperation of Eurocrats and MEPs is mirrored in the proposals in point 2: 'proposes to increase the visibility of European political parties by placeing their names and logos on ballot papers' and – incredibly – 'recommends that names and logos also be featured on the electoral broadcast of radio and television'! The right solution, of course, is to withdraw all public money from the Eurogroups. To do this, the European Parliament proposes a single euro constituency (!) (PN 63), uniform deadlines for submitting candidates (paragraph 9), single election day (paragraph 24), reduction of the voting age to 16 years (when children under the influence of subjects such as Education for Europe do not ask Eurosceptic questions) (paragraph 15), a minimum of 3% electoral clause (paragraph 7), the European Electoral Office (paragraph 22) and "encourages Member States to take measures to promote adequate ethnic representation, and other minorities in European elections" (paragraph 21). Something so desperate and flagrantly anti-democratic is not seen even in the European Union.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Although the 1957 Treaty of Rome provides for the possibility of developing a uniform electoral process, elections to the European Parliament are still determined by national law.  I supported a report by Hübner and MEP Leinen on the reform of the EU electoral law, an initiative launched by the European Parliament. Reform is needed to base the electoral system on the same rules for all Member States, which would help better promote the right of European citizens to participate equally in democratic life.  It is important to make the work of the European Parliament more legitimate and efficient, to bring the work of members they themselves to represent their interests directly. The proposed reforms should, inter alia, result in strengthening the demographic and transnational dimension of elections, electoral equality, ensuring gender equality, introducing voting rights for Europeans living outside the EU and increasing the efficiency of the overall system for conducting European elections.

name: Svetoslav Hristov MALINOV
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 Today, the European Parliament has taken advantage of one of its rare opportunities for the right of initiative and proposed reform of the provisions for the election of its members. One of the main proposals is the introduction of electronic voting in european elections. What's next? In order for the proposals voted in plenary to enter into force, they must obtain unanimous approval from the Council and the Member States in accordance with their constitutional requirements. We are yet to see whether Member States will adopt these measures and whether they will allow their citizens to vote electronically in the 2019 European elections. I hope with a common effort to stop the declining turnout and make it easier for all citizens to vote from abroad. I therefore support the reform of European electoral legislation.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Mamikins (S&D), in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament is the only institution of the European Union elected by regular democratic and direct elections by EU citizens and, on the basis of the laws of individual Member States, by third-country nationals (or nationals of other Member States) on the basis of the duration of their stay within their territory. Given the important role this power institute plays in community governance, and the fact that it has long been time to adapt its elections to today's real ones, I support this motion for a resolution. In my country, for almost a quarter of a century, there is a rather specific category of population that has no right to vote in municipal, parliamentary or European elections. It is about so-called non-citizens or, as they are still called, 'aliens'. Based on statistics available at the beginning of 2015, there are currently just over 262 thousand people in Latvia – 12.15% of the total population of the country. 262 thousand people – many of whom have lived in Latvia since the end of the Second World War or who were born here in the last 70 years, worked, paid taxes, built the local economy and actively participated in a wide range of areas of life – cannot vote in any elections at all. Among our neighbours (Estonia), where a category of non-citizens was established since the early 1990s, they can at least vote in local elections. In my country, our non-citizens cannot even do it.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposal builds on the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU. The Treaty gives the EP the right to start a reform of its electoral procedure. The aim is to develop a single procedure or procedure based on principles common to all Member States. More uniform and transparent rules are proposed for campaigning, the conduct of elections, the possibility of electronic voting and other measures that will streamline the management and conduct of elections, while strengthening the democratic character of elections, increasing the electoral equality of EU citizens and thus strengthening citizenship.  These proposals must be decided unanimously by the Council.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the revision of the European Union electoral law, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 27/10/2015, and because it is not complete and documented.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we voted on a motion for a resolution on the reform of electoral legislation. It is a sad fact that turnout in European elections continues to decline. The news that the largest political factions are nominating a candidate for President of the European Commission has done nothing about it, with some politicians promising to make elections to the European Parliament more attractive. The resolution we are voting on today includes proposals with which I cannot identify, in particular the introduction of a single European candidate, where the whole eu would serve as one constituency. Of course, this reform would significantly damage small parties from small Member States whose chances of being elected would be virtually zero. Similarly, I cannot agree with other proposals that, for example, introduce a single EU-wide electoral day, a single deadline for the submission of lists, as well as the so-called European Electoral Commission. The adoption of these proposals would entail disproportionate interference with the constitutional traditions of the Member States or would directly require amendments to the constitutions of the Member States. That is why I voted against the motion for a resolution in the final vote.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. It seems reasonable to standardise Election Day, as does an approximation of deadlines. However, it appears that the report has the intention of 'nationalisation' of the EU. We want a union of sovereign nation states, which is why I cannot vote in favour of this report.

name: David McALLISTER
text: Writing. In European electoral law, there is an urgent need to enshrine a binding minimum hurdle to the European elections. In Germany, for example, a 0.5% share of the vote is already leading to a seat in the European Parliament. Seven seats in micro-parties from Germany , as after the 2014 election – exceed the entire Luxembourg contingent, which is six seats. The further fragmentation of the European Parliament by the increase in the number of national parties represented in it runs counter to the principle of effective representation of the peoples of the Member States. While 170 parties were already represented in the European Parliament in July 2009, there are now 204 parties. Eight new parties were added from Germany alone in 2014. In the interests of the European Parliament's ability to act, a Europe-wide blocking clause of 3 to 5% should therefore be introduced. I would like to emphasise that I am sceptical about transnational lists. In the vote, I voted in favour of them only so as not to jeopardise the compromise reached on the blocking clause.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. This report pursues the positive objective of harmonising the methods of electing MEPs in the various countries of the European Union to ensure the equality of citizens. However, it enshrines this reform in an undemocratic over-national development of the European Union.  Even though the European Constitution has been rejected, the report speaks of the "constitutional mandate" of Parliament and MEPs. For such a constitution to exist, it would still have to be granted by the citizens themselves, for example through a constituent assembly. The report also touts a "citizenship of the Union" that does not really exist.  And finally, he claims that Parliament now has as much power as the Council, which is absolutely false, as evidenced for example by Parliament's increasing impotence in budgetary matters.  I vote against it to disagree with the overall undemocratic framework of this discussion.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this report as it is important that Parliament continues to strive to advance the democratic credentials of the European Union. These measures are intended to address the democratic deficit and increase participation by the Union’s citizens.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: Written. – The organisation of European elections is still organised in a very different way in the Member States. Although the principles for this have been laid down in European legislation, the procedure and practical organisation are largely determined by the Member States. That is why the European Parliament has adopted a legislative initiative with recommendations to harmonise European elections, to make it less national, and to involve citizens more intensively in the conduct of these elections. In order to reinforce the recognition of the European project, it is recommended that, in addition to the European 'national' lists, a federal European constituency should be introduced. In this way, all citizens, wherever they live, can express their preference for their candidate for President of the European Commission. I also support the idea of harmonising the distribution of seats and the voting age, launching the campaign simultaneously in all countries and ensuring that European elections take place everywhere on the same day. The equal representation of men and women on the list or the possibility of giving voting rights to citizens living abroad, principles which I introduced at the time as Minister of Institutional Reform in Belgium are now included in european electoral law.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the European Parliament report on the reform of the electoral law. In my opinion, the report provides valuable recommendations that will lead to more transparent, visible, fair and democratic European elections. We need improvement to the European electoral law in order to bring the European Parliament closer to its citizens. Having said that, however, I also acknowledge that the electoral law needs fully to respect the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality, and that it should be seen in relation to the national context, cultures and traditions of each and every country. I welcome the recommendation to lower the voting age to 16 years.

name: Sorin MOISĂ
text: in writing. ‒ It is the rules of electoral competition that shape the political system, and our system needs to be improved. As the recently passed proposal mentions, there is a need to enhance the democratic and transnational dimension of our Union. For this reason, I supported the proposal aiming to harmonise the rules that govern European parliamentary elections. I believe the reform would raise citizens’ interest in the voting process, help bring more European issues onto electoral agendas and hopefully also help to establish a link between the European political parties and the citizens they represent.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 MEPs act not as representatives of their Member States but as representatives of citizens of the Union. However, the various political ideas and interests represented in the European Parliament are not presented to the electorate before the European elections. Election campaigns are primarily carried out on the national political battlefield, so EU citizens do not know the actual policies that their vote can result in. For many voters, even the relationship between their national parties and their European political families is unclear. Elections are the main means of democratic participation, but because of the outdated system governing European elections, EU citizens are unable to participate in European political debates. The current degree of heterogeneity of national electoral rules runs counter to the idea of CITIZENSHIP of the European Union and the principle of equality. Citizens of the Union, irrespective of their nationality, should be able to exercise their right to vote under similar conditions which respect democratic principles. The report of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs proposes that the European Parliament initiate the reform of the European Electoral Act in order to bridge the gap between the European institutions and the electorate segregated by nation, and to ensure equal treatment for all EU citizens. I fully agree with the report and therefore supported it unreservedly.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 We need greater participation of citizens in european elections so that the work of the European Parliament is even more legitimate and the effectiveness of our decisions is strengthened. If the aim is to involve more and more citizens in political decisions at European level, it is essential to consider harmonising the minimum age of voters to 16, as is already the case, for example, in Austria. There are many young people who are studying or interning in other countries of the European Union, as well as many citizens working in Member States other than their country; i therefore think it is increasingly important to introduce electronic voting as a fundamental means of promoting and facilitating greater participation in the electoral act. It should also be stressed that the European Parliament advocates the adoption of open and transparent procedures for the selection of candidates with a view to strengthening the democratic legitimacy of representatives at European level. In today's resolution, the choice of a common day for the 28 Member States for the election to the European Parliament is also defended, that the polls close at the same time (8pm in Portugal) and a common deadline for the finalisation of the electoral roll (8 weeks).

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the reform of the European Union's electoral law. This text formulates proposals to adapt this law drafted in 1976, in order to increase the democratic dimension of the European elections and to increase voter participation.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 We are voting in favour of this report, which proposes a progressive standardisation of the various national laws for the election of the European Parliament.  The measure, which has become necessary in order to ensure that the European elections are more transparent, fair and democratic, could give greater visibility in a European way to elections to the European Parliament and reduce the gap in democratic legitimacy of the European Union institutions. Among the precise and specific points that the rapporteurs propose, the ones that prompted us most to vote in favour are: a common date for finalising the lists and appointing the leaders; ballot papers that give equal visibility to European national parties and political parties; encouragement to give more media space to European political parties; thresholds of between 3% and 5% for individual constituencies; gender equality in the composition of lists. In addition, in the long term, it is hoped to create a European Elections Authority, to standardise the age for the active electorate at 16 and to ensure that elections are held on the same days throughout Europe.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 Through this resolution, the European Parliament is finally able to standardise an electoral procedure that until yesterday was dominated by national electoral regulations. The very fact that the political distribution of seats is determined not by a single election, but by 28 national elections, is in stark contrast to the very nature of the European Parliament, the only and genuine European collegiate body. European citizens should be able to exercise their right to vote in accordance with democratic principles, irrespective of national citizenship.
