I voted in favour of this reform in order to strengthen the democratic dimension of the European elections, strengthen the citizenship of the Union and improve the functioning of Parliament, making its work even more legitimate and effective.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 This report was very time. The willingness to participate in EP elections is on a downward trend. The situation is perhaps the worst in my country, Slovakia, where only 13 % of eligible voters cast their ballots in the last elections. All this shows how far Brussels is from its citizens, how they do not feel about EU policy for their own cause. The range of causality could be explored at length, because, for example, on many occasions, Member States try to label the EU as the cause of all the bad things on the domestic policy platform, but still, I think a good electoral regulation can help the formula a lot.  There is no doubt that the introduction of electronic voting can make great progress, for example. In our accelerated world, this journey forward, we will waste time if it is not introduced as soon as possible. I think it is equally important to improve the visibility of EU policy among citizens. We could achieve much greater results if European parties and politicians became more well known. I trust that the proposals proposed in this report will soon be put into practice from paper form.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ The proposals by Parliament to reform the electoral law of the European Union bring important changes that will stimulate political debate across Europe. Firstly, the report brings more visibility to the European parties, given that national parties will need to indicate clearly their affiliation to the European ones on the ballot papers and on posters and other campaign materials. The report also creates a clear link between the elections and the future European Commission because it states that the nominations for Commission President will be announced by all European political parties prior to the elections. I voted for this report because it also seeks to increase the participation rate at European elections by suggesting the introduction of electronic and internet voting options as well as postal voting.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the reform of electoral law in the EU for a number of reasons. I believe the introduction of constituency and Member State thresholds to be undemocratic: it clearly disadvantages smaller parties, regional parties and independents. As citizens identify primarily with local, national parties, the inclusion and participation of European political groupings in election campaigns would add an unnecessary and potentially confusing dimension to those campaigns. I also believe that elections are the competency of established national authorities, and that no attempt should be made to create, or move towards the creation of, a single European electoral authority. Whilst the report contained some progressive elements, in relation to female representation and extending the franchise, these failed to mitigate its worst excesses, forcing me to oppose it.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the reform of European Union electoral legislation, motivated by the aim of making the electoral system more transparent and 'European' to the EP. The Council will now be on the move, but it is good that it has been given impetus, for example, in the form of a requirement to ensure gender equality in the form of lists of candidates and to allow the introduction of electronic and internet and mailing votes, which would facilitate voting, in particular for those Union citizens who have reduced mobility or live abroad.

name: Andrey NOVAKOV
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 In order to change EU legislation, it is necessary to approve the proposals, firstly, by the Council by unanimity and, secondly, by the Member States, in accordance with their respective constitutional provisions. It's a slow and difficult process, but sometimes the cause is such that it's worth fighting for. In the proposal voted on in the European Parliament, the new rules require the election of the EP to be held with officially approved leading candidates for President of the Commission. These candidates shall participate in the EP elections and be formally nominated within 12 weeks of the vote. Also, all EU citizens living abroad should be able to vote online or by post.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. In principle, I would like to see a reform of the electoral law, but I voted against this report because I have a very sceptical opinion on some points. An example of this would be the introduction of electronic voting. The risk of fraud and manipulation in this case would simply be too high.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. \u2012 We must preserve Europe as a community of nations and free and independent states. It cannot be allowed to be deleted. The sovereign rights of the Member States must not be violated. Elections must be held in good faith and honor, without restricting the independence and independence of states. I do not support the eu's centralism and the principles of federalism. The proposal for a single constituency in all EU countries is therefore unacceptable. The European Union must find the courage to change so that its institutions truly represent the interests of national citizens. Democracy should not be just an empty word with completely different content: it should indeed be the power of the people. We therefore need to restore democratic control and public confidence. The implementation of the principles of equal opportunities for equal elections and political parties must be ensured.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Proposals to change the legislation of the European elections seek to promote even more decisively the aggressive policy of capital at the expense of the peoples, to strengthen the "European parties" and to put greater obstacles in the expression of the popular will.  The definition of a "common constituency" with single ballots of European political parties, the simultaneous designation of heads of candidates for the Presidency of the Commission and the indication of the names of the Euro-parties on the respective ballots of the national parties attempt to legitimise the EU in the conscience of the peoples. To restore the non-existent prestige and influence of European political parties, the European Parliament itself, as EU tools for manipulating labour-popular consciences. At the same time, the proposal to set a minimum electoral threshold for the election of MEPs from 3% to 5% seeks to exclude political forces opposed to the EU and its unpopular policy, first and foremost Communist Parties. The proposal for a postal and electronic vote for even non-EU residents is also dangerous.  The aspirations of urban political forces to integrate popular reactions, and with such methods, must fall into limbo. The working people have an interest in condemning the EU and its parties, rejecting the proposed changes aimed at blackmailing and enssing in popular forces.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP is opposed to the very existence of, and to UK participation in, a so-called European Parliament. It is therefore against any proposal designed to consolidate the power and position of that entity. There are proposals for legislation contained in the report and UKIP always votes against legislation, all of which has the effect of draining sovereign power away from the UK. In addition there are specific proposals on the conduct of elections, which are designed to federalise the whole European election process and to produce the illusion of a bogus EU demos, and which are unacceptable.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Although the European Parliament is, in the European institutional system, the only institution democratically elected by European citizens, some data note that the problem of the democratic deficit is present and needs to be resolved (for example, during the last European elections held in 2014, turnout was 42.61%, a percentage that I hope will rise during the next elections). Electoral participation must be encouraged, which is why I am in favour of reforming the Eu ropean Union's electoral law and of a system that clearly and transparently informs our citizens.  I say that I am voting in favour.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – As a politician working for a Europe of young and digital technologies, I supported the proposal to reform the 1976 Act on the Election of Representatives in the European Parliament. Modernising the 1976 rules for the digital age is a necessity. Europe has the chance to be a leader in the digital world and this can only happen to proactive and socially responsible citizens.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒Amending the European Union election law proposes measures that could contribute to strengthening the role and efficiency of the European Parliament institution itself, strengthening democracy, increasing citizens' legal security and strengthening the European Union itself. For all the above reasons, I support these reforms. I think it is very important to make available and bring information closer to the citizens they are voting for, while ensuring their right to choose the party that is in their best interests.  The reform does not have a great impact on Croatia, but these changes can make the electoral system more efficient and accessible for citizens, and I supported this proposal because I think it certainly supports the realization of what is in the best interests of citizens. I am in favour of preventing double voting, in terms of setting up specific supervisory bodies, to ensure fair and transparent elections are held.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The 1976 ACT on the Election of MEPs for the first time allowed for immediate general elections in the EU. The rules it prescribes are outdated in many parts today. The election campaign is conducted in national political arenas, making it difficult for European citizens to make an informed decision on the real consequences of their vote. The appointment of the main candidates by European political parties as President of the Commission in the last European elections was a step forward.  The reform of legislation seeks to achieve a greater degree of harmonisation in electoral rules to ensure the principle of equality. All European citizens should be able to exercise their active and passive voting rights under comparable conditions. Art. 14. The EU Treaty establishing the principle of progressive proportionality in determining the number of Members per Member State has significantly contributed to preserving a shared sense of belonging to the European project between all Member States, and should therefore be respected consistently.  Placing the names and logos of European political parties on the ballot paper, alongside the names of national parties and candidates for President of the Commission, will certainly increase the visibility of European political parties in front of voters across Europe. I therefore support the report of my colleague Hübner and colleague Leinen, which is an important step towards harmonising European electoral legislation.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: Writing. \u2012 Declining turnout at a time when The European Parliament's decision-making is reflected in people's daily lives confirms the large communication gap between the EU apparatus and its people and a number of changes therefore need to be made. It is difficult for EU citizens to navigate the organisation of parliamentary political groups, it is not easy to understand that it is belonging to a particular political group that influences the ability of an individual Member to promote his or her views. For this reason, I consider it a step in the right direction if the national ballot paper already clearly shows the national political party's affiliation to its equivalent at European level. I regret that not all progressive proposals have been adopted, in particular measures to ensure gender balance on the lists of candidates. On the basis of the practical experience of working in the European Parliament, I am also behind the proposal to enshrine a minimum threshold for elections, which has not yet existed in some Member States and has led to fragmentation, on the other hand, with regard to equality of chance, there must also be an upper limit. I consider the setting of a Europe-wide threshold for the choice of between 3% and 5% to be fully adequate. I strongly support the introduction of electronic choice. At present, I consider this an absolute necessity and I believe that with this step we will support the introduction of electronic elections also in elections at national or regional level.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 Article 223(1) TFEU gives the European Parliament the prerogative to initiate a reform of the legislative act relating to the European elections by making proposals on which the Council of the EU is called upon to decide unanimously. Given that the citizens of the Union must be able to exercise their right to vote under similar conditions, in accordance with democratic principles and regardless of where they come from, elections to the European Parliament are still significantly dominated by national electoral regulations. In addition, election campaigns remain too focused on national issues. In this report, Parliament, through proposals to reform the current electoral law, intends to strengthen the citizenship of the Union, improve the effectiveness of the conduct of the European elections and ensure greater visibility of supranational political parties at European level. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The report provides for the harmonisation of m.in. on the visibility of European political parties, the introduction of a mandatory electoral threshold of 3-5%; the introduction of the provision that elections end in all Member States at the same time, i.e. at 21.00, the harmonisation of the minimum age of voters to be at least 16 years of age, ensuring gender equality on the electoral lists for the European Parliament. This report clearly seeks to introduce a uniform electoral procedure in the Member States, as expressly stated in its content, and interferes with the sphere of member states, which must be assessed as a breach of the principle of proportionality. I therefore could not support this report.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Writing. \u2012 I could not support the proposal to reform the right to vote for elections to the European Parliament. For example, I actively voted against the proposal for the European Parliament to recommend the introduction of a system where men and women would have to take regular turns on the list. I am, of course, in support of greater representation of women in politics, but such quotas are no solution. Nor have I voted in support of the various declarations aimed at introducing one Pan-European constituency. In my opinion, MEPs should have the closest possible connection with their constituents, and one constituency would lead not only to the opposite, but also to the emergence of two categories of MEPs – pan-European super-Members and then the other. Although I liked the proposal in support of electronic voting, overall, I think the negatives outweigh the positives in the proposal, which is why I did not vote for it.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP is opposed to the very existence of, and to UK participation in, a so-called European Parliament. It is therefore against any proposal designed to consolidate the power and position of that entity. There are proposals for legislation contained in the report and UKIP always votes against legislation, all of which has the effect of draining sovereign power away from the UK. In addition there are specific proposals on the conduct of elections, which are designed to federalise the whole European election process and to produce the illusion of a bogus EU demos, and which are unacceptable.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. The turnout in the May 2014 European elections was the lowest in history, at least since the first direct universal suffrage election of MEPs in 1979. This means that the democratic legitimacy of the Union's decision-making process is undermined and that a comprehensive reform of the electoral law, towards greater transparency and direct democracy, must be considered quickly.  This is precisely the purpose of the report, which I supported because it contains many proposals that it is essential to see completed before the next election in May 2019: respect for gender parity in the constitution of the lists; Introducing the right of EU citizens, including those residing or working in a third country, to vote in European elections; authorisation of postal voting, electronic voting and internet voting; support for the establishment of European electoral lists. This means that all citizens could directly elect the President of the European Commission. In the Council, which will have to decide unanimously, to take up the ambitious proposals for reform of the Union's electoral law voted tonight by the European Parliament.

name: Dominique RIQUET
text: In writing. The continued growth in abstention rates since the introduction of direct universal suffrage in 1979 demonstrates the growing disinterest of citizens in the European parliamentary elections. That is why I voted in favour of the report on the reform of the electoral law aimed at reversing this trend.  Among the measures proposed are the introduction of internet voting to encourage citizens and in particular the new generation to make their voices heard, as well as the granting of the opportunity to vote to European citizens living abroad.  The report also proposes to harmonize the modalities of elections across member states, to increase their legibility. Thus, electoral lists should be drawn up 12 weeks before the elections. Finally, to improve the functioning of Parliament, thresholds for the allocation of seats will be put in place in the largest countries, with the aim of avoiding the fragmentation of political groups that interfered with the work within the institution.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution which proposes to reform the European electoral act of 1976.  What do we want with these various reforms? We want to improve the democratic and transnational dimension of the European elections and how they are organised. We want to strengthen the concept of European citizenship as well as electoral equality. We want to promote equal representation of men and women in this House. We want to improve the visibility of European political parties.  To do this, we demand that the European elections be held with candidates at the top of the list for the presidency of the European Commission. In practical terms, this means that Europeans will vote directly to elect the President of the European Commission. We also call on the Council to create a common European electoral district, in which the lists would be led by the number one candidate of each European party.  We must create a real European political space, whose election of this House will be heart-beating. It is now up to the Council and the Member States to unanimously adopt these proposals so that they can be seen.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. As a convinced federalist, I supported the amendments of the Green Group which proposed that 25 MEPs be elected in a constituency made up of the whole of the European Union, from pan-European lists and that, at the next European election, each voter could express a vote for the pan-European list in addition to his vote for the national or regional list. Unfortunately, these amendments were ultimately not voted on.  I also, of course, voted in favour of the amendments that ensure gender equality and a gender rotation in the lists of candidates for the European Parliament elections in future European elections.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. Elections are the main instrument of democratic participation and, in this sense, I consider positive, inter alia, the solutions for introducing the right to vote in European elections for all Union citizens residing outside the EU and the possibility of electronic voting, via the Internet or by mail, as a means of promoting greater electoral participation and fairness of citizens, strengthening the concept of Union citizenship and improving the functioning of the European Parliament and the governance of the institutions. The amendments contained in the proposed amendment to the 1976 Electoral Act contain controversial aspects, such as the introduction of a mandatory minimum limit between 3% and 5% for the allocation of mandates, harmonisation for 16 years of minimum voting age, the introduction of alternating lists (in gender) in ballot papers and the creation of a transnational list. Generally speaking, I consider the solutions presented to be positive. However, I did not follow up on the proposal to harmonise the minimum voting age for 16 years, because I considered it more important to preserve the traditions of each Member State (principle of subsidiarity), nor to create a common constituency which is not based on a subsequent Council decision.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the reform of the European Union electoral law dating back to 1976. On the basis of Article 223 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, it is up to the European Parliament to formulate proposals to amend and update the European electoral law; the proposals are then forwarded to the Council, which must rule unanimously.  The proposals in this report aim in particular to mobilise and involve citizens more in the European elections, since the turnout in the last elections was only 42.61%.  The aim is therefore to encourage and facilitate participation in the European elections, particularly for young people, this text proposes electronic, online and postal voting systems in all Member States, while avoiding double voting.  In the end, the central issue of this text, which I support, is to strengthen the European dimension of elections and citizenship.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the reform of the European Union's electoral law as it aims to increase the democratic and supranational dimension of the European elections and gives greater legitimacy to the work of the European Parliament. The main objective of the report is to standardise the electoral procedure, which is still different between the various Member States of the European Union today. The report introduces an obligation on political parties to observe democratic procedures and transparency in the selection of their candidates for the European elections. In addition, the reform provides for the strengthening of the visibility of European political parties, the introduction of a mandatory threshold for the allocation of seats, the introduction of the possibility of electronic voting, via the Internet or by correspondence, and the setting of a common deadline of twelve weeks before election day for the establishment of lists at national level.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted against the report on reform of EU electoral law. In principle, we consider it necessary to reform legislation which stresses the need for EU parties to modernise and to make proposals, for example on candidates, which are accompanied by the necessary principles of transparency. We believe that the report and some proposals for amendments, focusing on transparency, primaries, gender equality, the possibility of using zipper lists, are the first steps needed for EU modernisation, access to the European Parliament and for it to be truly representative of the society ahead. However, we believe that the necessary plurality of this Parliament must be a red line and that threshold proposals can force us to vote against it, as they undermine the basis on which the electoral system and the EU itself are up.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this as I do not see the EU having any authority over national elections in Member States. There are many proposals contained in this document which I am concerned will override the democratic institutions of Member States.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Hübner/Leinen report on electoral law reform for the European elections because its proposals generally represent a significant advance in the functioning of European democracy and a strengthening of the democratic legitimacy of the Union's institutions. In particular, the visibility of European political parties on ballot papers and campaign materials greatly favours transparency, so that citizens know who they vote for. On the other hand, further harmonisation of electoral rules, now largely regulated by different national laws, promotes the unity of the electoral act, voter participation and equality between European citizens. While I have reservations about the proposal to create a common European constituency on the basis of a transnational list, a complex issue that would require further maturity, my final vote in favour took into account that this proposal is part of the overall, very positive compromise reached between various political groups in the European Parliament and that its implementation is still dependent on a unanimous decision by the Council.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider the principle of subsidiarity to be one of the key principles of the EU, and in the motion for a European Parliament resolution on the reform of the European Union electoral law, I saw the significant strengthening of the identification of a candidate through European political parties as a very problematic proposal precisely in terms of defending the principle of subsidiarity. This is an artificial effort to suppress national political parties that are clearly more important in the consciousness of the EU's population than European political parties with which people do not identify. I also considered the re-enforcement of the gender agenda to be totally inadequate in the present proposal. I do not consider it appropriate for it to be part of electoral reform. For these reasons, I voted against the adoption of the resolution tabled.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ Recent years have seen a decline in voter turnout in European elections, especially among young people, while citizens' disinterest in European affairs poses a threat to the future of Europe. A comprehensive agreement on the electoral process has not yet been reached, which would be uniform for all Member States.  For example, the deadlines for finalising voter lists before european elections vary considerably between Member States, which can make it more difficult to exchange voter information among them (which seeks to prevent double voting) or even disable it. A genuine harmonisation of the European Parliament election process in all Member States could help to better promote the right of all European citizens to participate equally in the democratic life of the Union, while strengthening the political dimension of European integration.  The aim of this reform of the electoral process is to increase the democratic and transnational dimension of european elections and the democratic legitimacy of the decision-making process in the Union, to strengthen the concept of Union citizenship, to improve the functioning of the European Parliament and the governance of the Union, to increase the legitimacy of the work of the European Parliament, to strengthen the principle of equality of suffrage and equal opportunities, to improve the efficiency of the system for conducting European elections and to bring MEPs closer to voters, especially the youngest ones.  Because of this, and also because it is a proposal that would contribute to the revival of European democracy, I supported the reform of eu electoral law.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 In view of the fact that participation in European elections is steadily declining and elections represent the highest level of democracy, where voters are free to decide who to support and who they elect as their representatives in the European Parliament, it is necessary to think about a possible reform of the EU electoral law. Although I do not agree that young people from the age of 16 should have the right to vote, I supported many of the proposals because the EP elections have great differences within the various Member States. There are no uniform deadlines for the submission of candidates, there are no uniform thresholds for electability, there is a different form of involvement in the campaigns of individual political parties ... In some Member States MEPs may have more elected posts, in others this is incompatible. As the next elections will be in 2019, in the meantime, the electoral procedure needs to be reformed in a timely manner in order to increase the democratic and transnational dimension of EP elections and the democratic legitimacy of the decision-making process in the EU, to strengthen the notion of Union citizenship, to improve the functioning of the EP and to manage the EU by making the work of the European institutions more effective.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution on the reform of electoral legislation, although I hope that, for example, there will be no lowering of the age limit for voters. I consider it important that the laws of the Member States make it possible to vote for all those who wish to take part in elections to the European Parliament. I also consider it important that elections be organised as effectively as possible. The resolution called on The Member States to introduce correspondence elections to be agreed on one day of elections, to ensure gender equality on lists, and also to allow Member States to amend their electoral laws so that there can be no choice in two States in the case of dual citizenship. However, I voted against the recommendation to reduce the age of the electorate to 16. I do not consider it appropriate to recommends harmonisation to The Member States in such a specific area, as the maturity of the electorate is a very important condition for responsible decision-making, and I think that everything has its time. The lackluster majority that decided on the recommendation points to the problem of such a change.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. \u2012 The purpose of the reform of the electoral process is to increase the democratic and transnational dimension of the European elections and the democratic legitimacy of the decision-making process in the Union, to strengthen the concept of Citizenship of the Union, to improve the functioning of the EP and the governance of the European Union, to strengthen the legitimacy of the EP's work, to strengthen the principles of equal voting rights and equal opportunities, to improve the effectiveness of the european elections and to bring the EP closer to its voters, especially the youngest.  The report contains proposals to make European political groups more visible, to harmonise certain deadlines, to assume a mandatory 3% and 5% threshold in the European electoral system, introduces a process of main candidates for President of the Commission, adds the possibility of elections by post, changes the procedure for implementing the election act, sets the gender rule and represents minorities.  However, I do not think that all these proposals are adequate solutions for an unspecified electoral system. As an example, I can cite the setting of a mandatory 3% and 5% threshold, which would be very harmful to smaller parties and a provision on gender equality, which is inappropriately regulated as a result of the non-application of the list system.  I also believe that the provision governing the subject-matter of the transnational journals is too weakly formulated. For the sake of the above, I voted against the adoption of the report on electoral law reform in plenary.

name: Renato SORU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft reform of the Eu ropean Electoral Law aimed at making the European elections more visible and attractive to European citizens.  The legislative act which currently lays down common provisions on European elections dates back to 1976, when the role of the European Parliament was profoundly different from the present one: as a consultative assembly it has become co-legislator in almost all matters within the competence of the Union. However, the European elections in the 28 Member States remain national elections, on national issues and personalities and not on European issues. The 2014 elections marked progress from this point of view, introducing the figure of the leader of each European party, who made visible to citizens the person indicated by their political forces as President of the European Commission.  The reform voted on today codifies this proposal and adds others aimed at strengthening the European dimension of election campaigns, such as the presence of european party symbols on the ballot paper, precise deadlines for the submission of lists, gender equality on the lists, the introduction of electronic and postal voting and the possibility of creating transnational constituencies to facilitate the voting of citizens residing in another country.

name: Bart STAES
text: Written. 'I voted against the majority of my group on a number of occasions in this vote on the legislative initiative report on a uniform electoral system for the election of MEPs. I disagree on the need to use transnational or pan-European lists to increase europe's sense of purpose in this type of election. I don't know of any federal system where transnational lists exist. Elected representatives represent their constituency in a Parliament. Even in the US, the election of the president does not exclude the states. Pan-European lists are the dream of an elite that believes that it will instill more Europe in the population. They are the toy of people who behave like primus inter pares in Parliament. They provide "show democracy." They are a far-from-my-bedshow and in no way close the gap between the EU and the citizen. This gap can only be closed by stronger policies, genuine behaviour and authentic action, and by tackling the problems of our time decisively and convincingly. Fumbling with the electoral system does not provide a solution to this. For me, this conviction is stronger than loyalty to my party's electoral programme.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Writing. The EU's electoral reform initiative is an attempt to intervene deeply in the electoral law of the Member States. Key elements include, in particular, the introduction of a 3-5% clause to make it more difficult for smaller parties to enter the European Parliament, the lowering of the voting age to 16 and the zipperprocedure for the filling of electoral lists, which is intended to force a quota for women for all parties and countries. Given the peculiarities of the Electoral Systems of the Member States and because small countries are excluded from the reforms, we have to note that a significant part of this initiative has been tailored to Germany. The European electoral system penalises the people of the large countries because their votes are worth less. A 3% quota for Germany can potentially exclude millions of people from political participation in the European Parliament, while the population of smaller states is represented at far lower numbers. That is why this quota system is not acceptable. Nor is the enforced quota system for men and women acceptable. Even if the zipper procedure has failed, a quota is to be introduced. The political participation of women is significantly lower than that of men and very unequal among the parties. They should continue to be able to select the best candidates. I have therefore rejected the electoral initiative.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 In this change I see the possibility of increasing the legitimacy of elected representatives. It also gives the possibility to vote for EU citizens outside its territory, as well as to use the electronic form of choice.

name: Jutta STEINRUCK
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the draft law because it will allow us to better prepare for the next European elections in 2019 and make it easier for citizens to participate. The new European electoral law is intended to enshrine the leading candidates for the office of President of the Commission. We want to ensure that this progress towards more European democracy from the 2014 European elections can no longer be reversed. In addition, the establishment of electoral lists in all EU Member States should be carried out in accordance with transparent procedures and should be completed no later than 12 weeks before the election in order to guarantee sufficient time for the substantive debate in the election campaign. I hope that the Council will adopt this proposal swiftly.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on the reform of European Union electoral legislation attempts to unify certain electoral rules in the context of elections to the European Parliament. Harmonisation of Elections to the European Parliament in all Member States could strengthen the political dimension of European integration and harmonise electoral conditions in all Member States. I remember the EP elections in which I ran, but I could not vote because I was on a foreign trip in Kiev at the time and the election to the embassies is not possible for citizens of the Czech Republic in the european elections. It is this reform that should eliminate this electoral inequality. I supported the proposal as a whole, but took the liberty of disagreeing with the introduction of mandatory gender quotas on the list of individual Member States. I consider this step unnecessary in the sense that, while I respect equality between a man and a woman, this equality cannot be used for the purpose of force-highlighting women on the list. I am equally glad that the PPE rejected the proposal to harmonise the minimum age for eligibility to vote at 16. This step interferes with the institutes of nation states and it would be very difficult to agree europe-wide on this point. Despite this, however, there are a lot of contentious points that will have to be agreed by nation states.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ I supported this report because it aims to reform the EU electoral law, before the 2019 elections to better reflect the true European character of the EP and bridge the gap between its voters. I support the introduction of voting rights in European elections for all Union citizens living outside the EU.  Furthermore, I think it would be useful for Member States to introduce electronic and online voting as well as postal voting, provided that all measures necessary to ensure the reliability of the results, voting secrecy and data protection are also adopted. I believe that a comprehensive harmonisation of some elements such as the closure of polling stations and communication on projections of election results, a common deadline for proposing candidates of the main parties, a mandatory threshold for the distribution of some seats, and a common deadline for establishing electoral lists at national level are needed.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ The proposal for reform of the electoral law of the European Union suggests many positive changes to the procedures for electing the European Parliament – the nomination of candidates for the Presidency of the Commission, gender-balanced lists, a vote for 16-year-olds and improved possibilities for voting abroad. However, I voted against the final report as I do not support proposals to introduce a Europe-wide constituency and a common European election day. Many aspects of the report still need thorough consideration and further evaluation.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ The European Parliament's Committee on Constitutional Rights adopted a report on the reform of the European Union's electoral law concerning electoral rights in the European Union. This report proposes an electoral rights reform that should be implemented by 2019 with a view to introducing change.  The most important among them are the right to electoral equality and raising it to the highest possible level, promoting basic representative rights, as well as making parliament's work as legitimate and efficient as possible. It also proposes changes in universal suffrage relating to the direct election of MEMBERS for the European Parliament, most notably: gender equality on electoral lists, the introduction of online voting and post office, and the setting of a 12-week deadline before election day, in which the electoral roll must be submitted. I support this report, because I think it brings new and positive changes in the electoral rights of citizens of the European Union. Not only will the entire electoral process be more transparent, but it will be simplified and voter-friendly.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the proposal as it significantly and, moreover, unnecessarily interferes with the competences of EU Member States.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \ U2012 I voted in favour of the report on the reform of the Electoral Law of the European Union. The report aims to strengthen the democratic dimension of the European elections, to improve the visibility of work and the success of the organisation of elections to the European Parliament.  In recent years, we have faced a decline in citizens' support and confidence in the institutions of the European Union, and I therefore support any activity that goes towards building trust.  Many years have passed since the last amendment of electoral law, and in that time, there have been many changes both in the european Union as a whole and in the european Parliament. Elections to the European Parliament must be given a European note and should not be seen as a confrontation on national topics.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report concerns changes to the electoral law for the European elections, which also requires unanimous agreement at Council level. We voted against the report because it contains a number of elements which influence the way elections are organised and held in the Member States, which refers to a restriction of the sovereign rights of the Member States. Such reform amendments need very careful consultation. At the same time, the report promotes the role of European parties and the election of MePs of the Territory, a position which degrades the role of national parties and promotes the depoliticisation of elections and the concealment of the essential problems faced by peoples in their countries. In conclusion, the attempt to harmonise the rules for holding the European elections overlooks a number of specificities that exist in each Member State.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The promotion of new electoral laws must contribute to the consolidation of democracy, proportionality and subsidiarity, as mandated by EU national laws and operating principles, in the context of participatoryness and popular sovereignty.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the reform of electoral law in the European Union, which rightly underlined that there are a number of differences in the electoral procedure of the Member States in the European Parliament, which prevents EU citizens from exercising their electoral rights under the same conditions. As highlighted in the report, harmonisation in these areas would indeed promote the political dimension of European integration.  The report raised a number of points, such as strengthening the role of European political parties in order to raise European political awareness, unifying the nomination process for candidates running for parliament, or prohibiting early publication of election results, which would not only increase the efficiency of the european election system, but would also enhance the democratic legitimacy of the EU decision-making process. I also support the timing of the implementation of the reform, which falls well before the European elections in 2019.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Almost 40 years after the establishment of the legal framework for elections to the European Parliament, it was necessary to make some changes that go with the times and entail a significant increase in Parliament's powers. The proposed changes, such as the designation by individual European political parties of their candidates for the post of President of the European Commission or the inclusion of party names and graphic signs on the ballot papers, will significantly increase the visibility of European political parties, which will lead to the European Parliament's rapprochement with the citizens of the European Union. Part of the issue, m.in. harmonising the minimum age for voters and setting it at 16 years should not, in my opinion, be included in the final text of the report, but the document as a whole is going in the right direction, which is why I decided to vote in favour of it.

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: in writing. \u2012 This change in electoral law in the EU was necessary in order to grant the right to vote to all citizens, regardless of their country of residence. Thus, by electronic, online or mail-in voting, all citizens living abroad will be able to vote in the elections to the European Parliament. In addition, the European affiliation of national parties to European parties must also be clearly mentioned on the ballot papers. I support this change, as it will bring clarity to European elections: elections will be democratic and transparent. Finally, we will have an adaptation and a uniformisation of the European electoral process to the new political and social context.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. ‒ The elections to the European Parliament are governed to a great extent by national rules. As a result, election campaigns are often dominated by national topics and led by national political actors. Reforming the electoral law will make elections to the European Parliament more European, in both form and substance, by promoting electoral equality between EU citizens across the EU and improving Parliament’s functioning and the EU’s governance. The current report represents Parliament’s aim of obtaining such an EU‐wide electoral procedure. The provisions in the report ask for a common deadline of 12 weeks before the vote for the establishment of electoral lists, and nomination of lead candidates; gender balance on electoral lists; higher visibility of national parties’ affiliation to European political parties on ballot papers; and a minimum threshold of between 3 and 5%. While I support the reform of the law, I believe it must exclude any attempts to introduce transnational lists. Electing Members on transitional lists means these Members have no concrete constituencies. That raises concerns as to the democratic accountability of these Members towards their voters. Yet I voted for the report, as I believe that reforming the law will lead to more transparent, visible and democratic elections.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the reform of the European Union's electoral law. The latter proposes that Parliament decide to reform its electoral procedure early enough before the 2019 elections in order to strengthen the democratic character of the elections, the representative dimension of Parliament by further balancing the composition of the elections, to promote European citizenship and to improve the efficiency of the way European elections are organised.  The report also recommends that Member States consider harmonising the minimum age of voters to 16 in order to ensure greater equality for EU citizens in elections.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on the reform of European electoral law. If the proposals adopted by Parliament receive the support of the Council, this will be an important step for the future of EU democracy. In the future, a joint constituency would be established in order to allow the direct election of candidates, presented by European political parties, for the function of President of the Commission. The proposals would also further harmonise the organisation and voting conditions of the European elections in the Member States.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted against a report aimed at introducing a single electoral procedure in all Member States, as I believe that most of the proposed measures to achieve this objective encroach on member states' rights and thus violate the principle of subsidiarity. This suggests increasing the visibility of european political parties' names and logos on ballot papers, as well as on materials used in European election campaigns. Namely, while this supposedly aims to further inform voters, I think it might confuse them, as a larger ballot would probably have to be drafted that would be even more imprecisive.  I believe that the proposal to equalize the minimum age for voters to 16 is also a violation of the principle of subsidiarity. In addition, setting a common minimum deadline of 12 weeks before Election Day to draw up electoral lists at national level, explaining that candidates and voters across the Union would have equal time to prepare and think before voting, did not take into account that this would mean an extension of the election campaign during which voters could get enough and which could result in increased abstinence.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the report on the motion for a resolution on the reform of the European Union's electoral law, as the electoral process will be reformed before the next elections in 2019. This will increase the democratic and transnational dimension of the European elections, as well as strengthen the concept of Citizenship of the Union and the concept of equal voting rights.  The visibility of European political parties will certainly be better. The novelty introduced by the resolution is also the integrity of elections by sensibly limiting campaign costs and encouraging Member States to use electronic, online and mail-based voting.  This will improve voter turnout and will also enable people with reduced mobility and others living or working in another EU Member State to take part in the elections.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted against the report on reform of EU electoral law. In principle, we consider it necessary to reform legislation which stresses the need for EU parties to modernise and to make proposals, for example on candidates, which are accompanied by the necessary principles of transparency. We believe that the report and some proposals for amendments, focusing on transparency, primaries, gender equality, the possibility of using zipper lists, are the first steps needed for EU modernisation, access to the European Parliament and for it to be truly representative of the society ahead. However, we believe that the necessary plurality of this Parliament must be a red line and that threshold proposals can force us to vote against it, as they undermine the basis on which the electoral system and the EU itself are up.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Writing. The EU's electoral reform initiative is an attempt to intervene deeply in the electoral law of the Member States. Key elements include, in particular, the introduction of a 3-5% clause to make it more difficult for smaller parties to enter the European Parliament, the lowering of the voting age to 16 and the zipperprocedure for the filling of electoral lists, which is intended to force a quota for women for all parties and countries. Given the peculiarities of the Electoral Systems of the Member States and because small countries are excluded from the reforms, we have to note that a significant part of this initiative has been tailored to Germany. The European electoral system penalises the people of the large countries because their votes are worth less. A 3% quota for Germany can potentially exclude millions of people from political participation in the European Parliament, while the population of smaller states is represented at far lower numbers. That is why this quota system is not acceptable. Nor is the enforced quota system for men and women acceptable. Even if the zipper procedure has failed, a quota is to be introduced. The political participation of women is significantly lower than that of men and very unequal among the parties. They should continue to be able to select the best candidates. I have therefore rejected the electoral initiative.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted with regret against this resolution. I am completely in favour of a greater degree of Europeanisation of the European elections, but for me it is unacceptable that with the new rules, regional parties like mine can become excluded from the European Parliament due to high thresholds. If this is the way to go, the motto of the EU should become ‘united in uniformity’.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 Although the Treaty of Rome foreseen as early as 1957 the possibility of developing a uniform electoral procedure based on universal suffrage, elections to the European Parliament are still primarily governed by national electoral rules. The division of seats in the European Parliament is not decided in a European election, but in the 28 national elections for national seats. This is in stark contrast to the role of the European Parliament as a genuine European body and as an equal co-legislator in the institutional system of the European Union.  In addition to strengthening the European dimension of the European elections, the current degree of heterogeneity of national electoral rules runs counter to the idea of Citizenship of the European Union and the principle of equality. While harmonisation is not an end in itself, EU citizens, regardless of their nationality, should be able to exercise their right to vote under similar conditions which respect democratic principles. In order to bridge the gap between the European institutions and the electorate segregated by nation and to ensure equal treatment for all EU citizens, the European Parliament is determined to initiate the reform of the European Electoral Act, taking advantage of its rights under Article 223(1) TSI. I voted in favour of the final proposal.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted against the report on reform of EU electoral law. In principle, we consider it necessary to reform legislation which stresses the need for EU parties to modernise and to make proposals, for example on candidates, which are accompanied by the necessary principles of transparency. We believe that the report and some proposals for amendments, focusing on transparency, primaries, gender equality, the possibility of using zipper lists, are the first steps needed for EU modernisation, access to the European Parliament and for it to be truly representative of the society ahead. However, we believe that the necessary plurality of this Parliament must be a red line and that threshold proposals can force us to vote against it, as they undermine the basis on which the electoral system and the EU itself are up.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on the reform of the electoral law of the European Union. Voting in democratic elections is one of the most important rights in a democracy. Currently, the rules governing European elections are set out by national legislations, meaning that there are major differences among Members States. I hope that the provisions outlined in this resolution will increase citizens’ interest in participating in this important element of European decision-making. The resolution seeks to make voting more accessible for EU citizens living abroad through online voting systems. Online and postal-voting systems too should therefore be made available in all EU Member States. I also acknowledge that the minimum age for eligibility to stand as a candidate across the 28 Member States varies between 18 and 25, and the minimum age for eligibility to vote ranges from 16 to 18, due to the divergent constitutional and electoral traditions in Member States. I believe that harmonisation of the voting age and of the minimum age for candidates at EU level would be highly desirable as a means of providing Union citizens with real voting equality, and would ensure that any type of discrimination is avoided.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is a reform which will contribute, inter alia, to strengthening the democratic dimension of European elections, giving greater legitimacy to the work of the European Parliament and ensuring greater electoral equality for citizens. In particular, I welcome the adoption of political groups, at least twelve weeks before the European elections, formal candidates for the presidency of the Commission and for all countries to set a minimum vote threshold (between 3% and 5%) to obtain parliamentary representation.  I also welcome the approval of the following measures: - creation of ballots with greater visibility of the name and logo of European parties; - creation of a European constituency with lists headed by the candidate appointed by each political family for the post of President of the Commission; - study of the harmonisation of the minimum age for voting at the age of 16; - possibility to allow voting by mail, email and online. Finally, I regret that the use of instruments such as zipper lists or other equivalent methods to ensure gender equality has been rejected.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. I voted against this report because there are several points on which I cannot in any way agree. The report does not provide for the possibility of the President of the European Commission being democratically elected by direct suffrage among European citizens. I refuse to give the current way of elying the President of the Commission after the adoption of the Lisbon Treaty democratic status, as set out in the report. In addition, I am also against the existence of a European constituency where 26 MEPs are directly chosen to be presented by lists of European parties. Nor am I in favour of forcing national parties to include the European party logo on the ballot. This should be left to the election of each national party. That is why I did not vote in favour of the own-initiative report.

name: Anneleen VAN BOSSUYT
text: Written. 'The N-VA delegation is voting against this report on the revision of the EU Electoral Act because we are in favour of an EU based on subsidiarity. This must also be reflected in the way in which the European Parliament is elected. The visibility of trusted national party names and logos and of national candidates contributes to greater voter engagement and turnout and to an electoral system that safeguards the principles of equal suffrage and equal opportunities for political parties rather than the electoral and campaign system proposed in this report that traditional European political parties seek to modulate to their advantage. The first experience of the Spitzen candidates in 2014 led not to a more transparent formation of the European Commission, but to political haggling in which the "grand coalition" of Christian Democrats, Socialists and Liberals – to save the predicament of their own weak candidate in the juncker commission hearings – put all its controversial candidate commissioners in one big bag and thus took the European Parliament hostage.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. I voted in favour of the reform of the European Electoral Act. After all, this is not a far-from-my-bedshow. Exactly on 11 November, 101 years after the Great War, we voted for a more European election to the European Parliament. In this way, we want to bring Parliament, and by extension the whole of the European Union, closer to the citizen and give equal opportunities to men and women. The fact that EU citizens outside Europe will now be involved in the elections by being able to vote via the Internet, which is what I call progress. I therefore fully support this initiative, which makes the European elections more democratic, more federal and European. In this way, I believe that we are also contributing to a better European awareness among citizens.

name: Paavo VÄYRYNEN
text: Written. \u2012 The vote on the reform of the European Union's electoral law dealt extensively with the European elections and what kind of reforms should be carried out. The aim of the proposal was to harmonise electoral methods and make the elections as transparent as possible. These objectives of principle are to be supported.  In many respects, the motion interfered with detailed electoral acts which are part of the decision-making powers of the Member States. The proposal dealt with in relative detail, among other things, the methods by which the parties in the Member States should choose the candidates for the European elections and how the European party should appear during the elections. The presentation of the elections and procedures were strongly addressed in the proposal.  The motion also proposed a common constituency throughout the EU, which would lead to some MEPs being elected outside national quotas. Solutions were also proposed for postal and remote voting that are difficult to fit into Finnish practices. The common threshold for voting was also a motion that I could not accept.    Overall, the performance was poor. It sought to develop the Union in a supranational direction and to weaken the decision-making powers of the Member States. It is clear that there must be common frameworks in the European elections, but we must act within these already existing rules. There is no need to build new electoral acts that bypass nation states' own electoral procedures. It is important that we improve existing procedures rather than constantly creating new ones.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. On 11th November the European Parliament adopted its proposal to revise the electoral law for the European elections. The Council will decide unanimously The least that can be said is that the European Parliament has not taken this opportunity to reform the process of the European elections in an attempt to at least partially fill the democratic deficit of the European Union. The great innovation of reform is the institution of transnational lists that will favour European parties at the expense of political diversity. Despite his declarations in favour of bringing the institution closer together with the citizens, the proposals allowing better representation of small political parties with low or non-existent thresholds, most measures in favour of gender equality, or the right to vote from the age of 16, have all been rejected. The European Parliament is missing a real opportunity to reform the European electoral law, and to promote the creation of a real European public space. And after that, we will continue to be surprised at how little people have in the way of the European elections.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This reform of the electoral law represents another manifestation of pure hypocrisy. The EU proclaims democracy but continues to shield all its instruments and mechanisms for imposing its policy and single neoliberal thinking on citizens and national states. So it was in referendums, so it is in economic governance and so it is at THE LEVEL of the ECB that it continues to determine what states should or should not do under penalty of cutting back on access to credit. If there were any doubts, look at the case of Greece. Waving at European parties or with measures to standardise electoral practices in each Member State does not disguise this reality.  We no longer follow this attempt to federalize the election process of the European Parliament and reject the attempt to impose criteria that are related to the practice and experience of each national State. Nor do we recognise any legitimacy of the EU to lecture democracy anywhere.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. It seems reasonable to standardise Election Day, as does an approximation of deadlines. However, it appears that the report has the intention of 'nationalisation' of the EU. We want a union of sovereign nation states, which is why I cannot vote in favour of this report.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I reject Parliament's resolution of 11 November 2015 on the reform of EU electoral law. The two major groups – the European Christian Democrats and Social Democrats – are collaborating to prevent competition. Together, they are voting for an EU electoral reform that is only important for Spain and Germany. The Federal Constitutional Court had argued that european law did not provide for a mandatory percentage hurdle and therefore rejected the 3 percent hurdle passed by the Bundestag for Germany as illegal. Now the SPD and CDU are forcing Germany to reintroduce a 3 percent hurdle by changing THE EU's electoral law. The argument of the Federal Constitutional Court is deliberately removed from the ground. The major parties get what they have always wanted: the exclusion of unwelcome competition. In addition, a few more items and mandates – at the expense of the party offer. The FDP and Sonneborn really do not disturb anyone, but the 3 percent hurdle hinders small parties. Political diversity of opinion threatens to be lost.  I consider this decision by the SPD and CDU to be shabby and made out of pure self-interest. The CO-founder of the EU, Robert Schuman, once said: "Democracy is worth as much as those who speak on its behalf." In terms of this change in the electoral law proposed with the common voice of the Christian and Social Democrats on behalf of the European Parliament, THE EU's democracy is no longer worth much.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the electoral law of the European Union. The report aims to introduce several direct changes to the Electoral Act 1976. Those changes are the harmonised ideas created in order to strengthen the democratic dimension of the European elections and to reinforce the functioning of the European Parliament, as well as the governance of the whole European Union. I find this report to be a fresh perspective and it is rather an interesting proposition which comprises several new, innovative factors. Firstly, it covers the idea of improving the visibility of European political parties by placing their names and logos on the ballot papers, which is a simple strategy that may in fact prove to be very effective. Moreover, it tries to introduce an obligatory threshold for the allocation of seats in single-constituency Member States and constituencies which comprise more than 26 seats, ranging between 3% and 5% for Member States using the list system.  I believe that the provisions of the report will enhance the electoral equality of European citizens, which is one of our fundamental values.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 This report, which I supported, aims to modernise electoral systems, strengthening democracy and the representativeness of the process by proposing that the competent Member States converge on a framework with more common characteristics.

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: in writing. In fact, I agree with the reform of EU electoral law, as I believe that it has very positive consequences for the whole of the European Union. On the one hand, it aims to enhance the participation of the citizens of the European Union in decision-making and to facilitate the means by which the vote can be expressed. It also helps all Europeans to have a greater understanding of the functioning of the European institutions and are therefore more attracted to voting. On the other hand, it seeks to give greater popularity to European parties in each Member State, and to create a level playing field among the various participants in the European elections. In this way, I believe that the integration and consistency of the EU is greatly encouraged.  However, I do not agree with the reduction of the minimum voting age to 16 years, as I consider it to be a measure contrary to the Spanish Constitution and the definition of 'age majority', with all the responsibilities that this entails.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported this report because I believe that it is necessary that elections to the European Parliament should not be purely national in nature, but should at least have basic common rules. In my opinion, this will lead to an improvement in the common European political consciousness. However, in this report, I could not vote in favour of the proposal, which calls for regular rotation of men and women on the lists. Candidates are made up according to the abilities of individual politicians, not their gender, and this should remain the case in the future.

name: Roberts ZĪLE
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support parliament's position by voting against in the vote on the reform of the Electoral Law of the European Union. I believe that this joint report by the Group of european socialists and the People's Party, which also includes the idea of creating a single constituency, is an attempt to develop European federalisation, which is in a strong contradiction with both my views and that of my European Parliament's ECR political group and the National Alliance. Despite the fact that these proposed amendments will undermine the independence of the Countries of the European Union, they would at the same time make it more difficult to hold elections. The report offers the electoral register list to be completed at the latest eight weeks before election day. This is in consistent with the policy pursued by the Latvian CVK, which is more welcoming to the electorate, bringing the time to the election day when the voter is still allowed to change the intended constituency. The offer to lower the age threshold of voters to 16 years is hasty and not sufficiently debated, and a few months ago the Saeima of the Republic of Latvia has already rejected the proposal to introduce voting rights from 16 years in municipal elections. I believe that the proposal to form another European institution - the EU's 'Central Electoral Commission'- is also financially useless.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the motion for a resolution on the reform of the European Union electoral law. Elections to the European Parliament and their legislation vary from one Member State to another in the European Union, and despite the gradual convergence of systems, there are differences between Member States regarding thresholds, different election days or the minimum age of the electorate. Although I agree that the Electoral Act of 1976 requires certain changes relating to technological progress, as well as to the attempt to bring elections to the European Parliament closer to the electorate, thereby increasing their interest in these elections, the proposal contained many provisions that I could not support. In my opinion, there is no need for a uniform electoral procedure throughout the European Union. I believe that decisions such as election time or deadlines for drawing up electoral lists should be left to the Member States. I also do not agree with the reduction of the minimum age of voters to 16 years, which in Slovakia, for example, would be an exception to electoral rules to other elected bodies.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 Under the bonnet of increasing transparency, increasing democracy, strengthening the concept of 'European citizenship' and harmonising the process of elections for the EP, what is proposed in this report is the deepening of federalism. The report advocates the inclusion of the names and logos of European political parties in the ballot papers and the use of them in posters and other material used in election campaigns for the EP; encouraging member states to facilitate the participation of European political parties in election campaigns; the creation of an EU constituency (25 Members); the creation of a European electoral authority. It also proposes that 'national' parties 'democratically' elect their candidates for ep elections, which means the imposition of ways parties function. The report argues that MEPs have become representatives of 'EU citizens'. All these positions aim at deepening federalism, removing the sovereignty of the Member States and standardising the thinking of MEPs who, in this respect, must no longer be representatives of the peoples who elect them, but be subordinated to the logic of the EU, as well as the parties to which they belong. It's an attack on democracy. We voted against it.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, thank you for giving the word on the previous point. I consider it important to explain my vote. I also supported the proposed resolution in view of the fact that over several years European airlines have lost more than 20 000 jobs. And I think that is a significant lift that we should be feeling in air transport. In my opinion, the increase in competitiveness in the aviation sector needs to be addressed, as the report suggests. But it also, and I liked it very much, mentions, for example, the removal of unnecessary burdens, not in security measures, but in those unnecessary administrative measures, where there are also several proposed measures. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report and I am very thank you for giving me the opportunity to explain why.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this resolution because it is wishing to interfere in the function of the Member Countries when determining the competitiveness of the industry. The resolution is also calling for the Commission to have an input into the efficient running of the airports when the UK has one of the most efficient airport operations in the world. Furthermore, the resolution is looking at increasing the responsibilities of EASA when there is no necessity for this; the CAA has already had some regulatory responsibilities passed to EASA and further responsibilities must not be taken away.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted against this Resolution because it raises a privatization agenda and offers no solutions to the main problems facing the sector. With an exclusive focus on the competitiveness and internationalisation of the sector, this Resolution continues with the impetus for the development of the single European area, which entails liberalisation and privatization of the functioning of different national airspaces. Privatization of air services only creates problems for users, public coffers and even safety standards. Despite this, the Commission continues its neoliberal agenda, which only envisages the competitiveness and internationalisation of the sector. Nor does this Resolution address the most serious problems of social dumping and declining security standards in the sector. That is why I have decided to vote against this Resolution.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ As I have been elected on a mandate of opposition to the European Union, I believe that further harmonisation in this field would be contrary to the wishes of my electorate. I note that the aviation industry is a growing sector which has attracted highly skilled and motivated professionals. However, the provisions on employment should be a matter for the Member States themselves to determine in order to balance workers’ rights with economic productivity according to their own needs.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to reform the European aviation sector. The European aviation sector generates EUR 5 million in aid. jobs and EUR 365 billion 2.4%, european GDP. The liberalisation of this sector has led to an increase in the number of airlines, more new routes, increased competition and increased air travel and increased travel by more people. At the same time, air pollution has increased and airports are overcrowded. The European Commission is due to present an aviation package by the end of 2015 to boost the competitiveness of the European aviation industry. I agree that the main objectives should be the growth of a more sustainable and competitive European aviation industry, the strengthening of european airlines, airports and aeronautics, ensuring a level playing field on the global market and a long-term strategy for the European aviation sector.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution to set out the Priorities of the European Parliament on the future Aviation Package to be presented by the European Commission. Among its priorities, Parliament explicitly recognises the importance of regional airports within the Union and to ensure cohesion within European regions. It calls on the Commission and member states to present a long-term strategic plan on the issues and opportunities of regional airports in the context of the European Union. This is obviously extremely important with regard to the development of Charleroi Brussels South Airport, which is obviously - by its dynamism and remarkable results - an essential tool for the socio-economic redeployment of my region, for its image and for the creation of jobs.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: in writing. The resolution we have just adopted is the European Parliament's contribution to the aviation sector package which the European Commission will present before the end of the year. This package will be essential to create the conditions that make this sector one of the most competitive and sustainable, while improving the regulations that guarantee the highest level of security of our airspace, for which we call for the definitive implementation of the so-called Single European Sky. The text also points to the clear linkage of working conditions in the aviation sector with flight safety. We therefore require the Commission to end harmful business practices such as false freelancers, 'zero-hours' contracts or pay-to-fly programmes (contracts in which in-experience pilots pay to purchase flight hours).  In short, we voted in favour of a resolution dealing equally with regulatory needs to improve competitiveness but also the social and labour standards of the sector.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I am in favour of discussing the often very unfavourable contractual conditions imposed by some European airlines on their employees.
