I am very much in favour of improving aviation legislation in order to facilitate the development of regional airports and to support the competitiveness of European airlines exposed to increasingly fierce competition from third countries. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the text.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. U2012 The loss of competitiveness of certain European airlines against third-country carriers receiving subsidies and competing in unefiable conditions requires measures to allow EU companies and airports to compete: by introducing reciprocity clauses, demanding greater control by States, eliminating unfair trade practices and abuse of some of the gaps in European law or signing agreements with third countries to regulate access to control of companies. In addition, the conditions of workers in the sector are deteriorating, which can also have an impact on aviation safety. It is important that workers in this sector remain highly qualified professionals whose working conditions cannot be subsequently impaired. Clarity must be required in the definitions of the place of establishment of the company and its workers as certain airlines are being abused as is the case with some low-cost carriers. As requested by this Resolution, these questions must be included in the aviation package which the Commission will adopt in December, so I voted in favour of it.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this resolution because it is being advocated by Parliament on the aviation package that the Commission plans to present by 2015 and aims to identify and address the challenges facing the EU aviation sector. Parliament therefore believes that the aviation package should lead to much-needed growth in a more sustainable and competitive European aviation industry, strengthen European airlines, airports and the aeronautics industry, ensure a level playing field on the global market, and considers that it should set out a long-term strategy for the European aviation sector. Parliament also stressed that the aeronautics industry makes a significant contribution to the EU's growth and jobs and is closely linked to competitiveness in the EU aviation sector (e.g. a positive export balance, cleaner technologies for European aircraft, the development of the SESAR programme, the creation of the Single European Sky, the maintenance chain). It generates around EUR 100 billion in aid. Parliament has called for an active aviation policy aimed at supporting and developing the aeronautics industry.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission will present its future aviation package in December, which will, among other things, update civil aviation standards, revise the mandate of the European Aviation Safety Agency and are expected to include eu-wide regulation of drones. In order to maintain the sector's competitiveness and maintain the current level of security, updating existing rules is essential. This has already been indicated several times by the European Parliament and, after long negotiations, it has also adopted its own resolution. The 3 major factions (EPP, S&D and ALDE) managed to reach an agreement and adopt a text that reflects the position of the People's Party and is also in line with Hungarian interests, so I voted in favour of the adoption of the motion for a resolution.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 Aviation accounts for a significant part of the European Union's economy, where some 5.1 million workers with wealth production of 2.4% of GDP are employed.  The motion for a resolution on aviation that we have voted on today, and which I supported, highlights the central issues for the development of this strategic sector. European aviation is a engine of growth, in terms of productivity and employment, and it is good that this report emphasises the importance of the sustainable development of this sector through the involvement of all the actors involved (airlines, international and regional airports) but also through research and innovation in the European aviation industry. The challenge of increasing international competition in this sector represents an opportunity full of potential that the European Union must seize in order to be able to increase its competitiveness on global markets.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 Since 2012, European airlines have faced a number of competitiveness challenges, with the need to reduce 20,000 jobs within companies. These institutions had a considerable contribution to the European Union's GDP of more than 2.4% in 2012, creating 2.6 million jobs. The aviation industry makes a remarkable contribution to growth and employment, generating important turnovers. However, at present, this industry requires active policies to support and develop the aviation field, especially in view of the legal and financial regulations that have increased the burden borne by the aviation sector, which are related to the limitation of operating hours, the level of national taxes and charges, but also the extension of passenger rights. Specific measures are needed to support the aviation industry, a level playing field, as well as an improvement in the competitiveness of the sector and a strengthening of financial transparency. I was in favour of the Report on the future package of measures in the field of aviation, as a long-term strategy for the aviation sector is needed to bring measures to boost the sector and optimise the competitiveness of the sector.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution is positive. I voted in favour. There are many issues in the dispute, and the report adopted in the Committee on Transport seems to touch on them all.  Among the most important issues touched on is the competitiveness of European airlines, which compete for a global market with third-country airlines that are subsidised by their respective states (while in Europe there are rules that restrict "State aid" more). It deals with the jobs lost in the numerous company crises and the unfavourable contractual conditions that certain companies apply to their employees, taking advantage of the less stringent Member States' rules even for workers who work alone or mainly in countries by regulations that ensure greater protection of their interests.  It is clear that our delegation, while being very critical of the European Commission, understands very well that the issue of aviation cannot be regulated only at Member State level. In this respect, the demands for improved aviation standards must be agreed not only at European level, but also at world level.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. We need a new set of legislative measures to adapt the European aviation sector to the new challenges it is currently facing. It is true that the airline industry is having some difficulty adjusting to ever-increasing international competition. Yet this sector has a high potential for innovation and growth.  We need to give this sector a new impetus to fully free up its competitiveness capacity. It is particularly important to combat unfair competition. To do so, the international bodies provided for this purpose would need to be more vigilant in order to establish a fair global competition in the aviation sector.  I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the motion for a resolution on the future aviation package.  I believe that, with the presentation of the package, the Commission should give a strong impetus to increasing the sustainability of the European aviation sector and improving its competitiveness. The Commission's package will therefore have to include solutions aimed at combating CO2 emissions, the ecological development of airports and new business models, such as the issuance of integrated tickets. With regard to the competitiveness of the sector, I hope that the Commission will put in place measures to strengthen the structure of European airlines and to encourage Member States to improve the infrastructure of EU airports, thus enabling the sector to compete internationally under favourable conditions. The report we voted on reflected these elements and I therefore voted in favour of it.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ We have voted against this resolution because it is wishing to interfere in the function of the Member Countries when determining the competitiveness of the industry. The resolution is also calling for the Commission to have an input in the efficient running of the airports when the UK has one of the most efficient airport operations in the world.  Furthermore, the resolution is looking at increasing the responsibilities of EASA when there is no necessity for this; the CAA has already had some regulatory responsibilities passed to EASA and further responsibilities must not be taken away.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of these resolutions because they aim to improve the competitiveness of European air companies within the wider global aviation market and innovation. I believe that the two elements are interlinked. We are in need of a long-term aviation strategy and the measures outlined in the resolutions will help us achieve this. The resolutions also seek to eliminate unfair practices and prevent, for example, unfair pricing.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission has announced the release of a new aviation legislative package with the aim of strengthening the competitiveness of the European aviation sector, with reference to both passenger mobility and freight transport and, more generally, to all commercial and non-aviation-related activities. The political groups have tabled a motion for a resolution on the future aviation package. The EPP, S&D and ALDE have tabled a joint resolution. The one presented by the EFDD Group emphasises the need to focus on aspects related to the safety of aircraft and passengers, to implement the sustainability of air transport, focusing on both new technologies and new fuels, in order to reduce the impact on the environment, reducing waste and investing in technological innovation. I voted against the text that has been adopted in plenary, namely the text presented by the PPE, S&D and ALDE.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. \u2012 The European aviation system is a vitally important sector that is now facing a global challenge, undermined in its leadership by increasingly competitive emerging markets. We must ensure that this leadership is maintained.  In 2013, 842 million Europeans travelled within Europe, with a series of positive effects on the world of work and in the economic field. Forecasts for air traffic in Europe in the coming years see a significant increase in passenger and freight numbers: Eurocontrol expects average annual business volume growth of 2.2%. In the light of these figures, it is clear that aviation plays a crucial role in the economic growth of our Union. In order for this favourable situation to continue, the sector needs reforms that will further strengthen its competitiveness and productivity. But innovating the transport sector does not just mean dealing with means, infrastructure and profits: it means ensuring that passengers can travel in the safest and most environmentally friendly way, and it means guaranteeing workers in the sector reliable contracts that respect their rights. That is what we want to achieve. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support positively the European Parliament's resolution on the future air transport package. We believe that the air transport package due to be presented at the end of this year should develop the European aviation sector, while respecting the EU's commitments and environmental objectives.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I chose to vote in favour of the measure. The legislative package on aviation, which the Commission is expected to present by the end of 2015, should provide much-needed impetus for the relaunch of the European aviation sector.  The report calls on the Commission to take account of certain critical issues in the context of a comprehensive approach to regulating safety, the environment and performance. The comments relate primarily to measures to strengthen the competitiveness of EU carriers and airports. To this end, it is necessary to eliminate national and EU burdens and to negotiate as soon as possible agreements that promote transparency of funding, protection against unfair competition and equal treatment. It also calls for air safety to be strengthened through a 'risk-based' approach, by prescribing the use of the most modern satellite traffic surveillance technologies and best practices for managing safety on board the aircraft. Thirdly, a comprehensive systemic approach to all aviation sectors is recommended through close cooperation between the Commission, air navigation service providers, air carriers and airports. Finally, the EP calls for the role and budget of the EASA to be strengthened.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution because, given that airlines operate in a rapidly changing sector and provide many jobs, I believe that we must encourage their development and innovation. Furthermore, I am convinced that the negotiation of comprehensive aviation agreements with the EU's main trading partners, the strengthening and harmonisation of the safety chain by attracting and retaining competent and highly qualified personnel and the full implementation of the SESAR programme, which requires close cooperation with the Commission, are the cornerstones of an innovation and development package necessary to ensure greater security for eu citizens. Finally, I agree with the rapporteur, who is calling for greater efforts in the Council to approve the proposal for a regulation on the allocation of slots, so as to increase the efficiency of airports and ensure the orderly operation of air transport in Europe, in a context in which traffic is expected to double between now and 2030.

name: David COBURN
text: in writing. ‒ We have voted against this resolution because it is wishing to interfere in the function of the Member Countries when determining the competitiveness of the industry. The resolution is also calling for the Commission to have an input in the efficient running of the airports when the UK has one of the most efficient airport operations in the world.  Furthermore, the resolution is looking at increasing the responsibilities of EASA when there is no necessity for this; the CAA has already had some regulatory responsibilities passed to EASA and further responsibilities must not be taken away.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. The air transport sector represents a huge market at European level, representing a considerable value in European GDP and accounting for a large number of jobs. As the European Commission intends to present by the end of 2015 an aviation package to identify and address the challenges facing the EU aviation sector, it is important to stress that the measures taken should ensure, on the one hand, the sustainability and competitiveness of the sector (threatened with competition both in the internal and external markets) and , on the other hand, to ensure high safety, labour and environmental standards. I share the concern that this new package is consistent with passenger rights legislation in order to create a clear and easily understood body of legislation for both consumers and air carriers.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the European Parliament resolution on the future aviation package because I believe that it can be an effective instrument for relaunching the European aviation sector, making it possible to improve its competitiveness and define a long-term strategy.  I am convinced that proactive policies are needed to strengthen the capacity and connectivity of EU airports, which, unfortunately, have suffered a loss of competitiveness compared to non-European airports. In this respect, I believe that we need to revise Regulation (EC) No 868/2004, through which it will be possible to remove all the obstacles it provides for in order to make it an effective instrument to safeguard fair competition in the EU's external relations and its competitive position. I maintain that the negotiation of global aviation agreements with the EU's main trading partners is a strategic objective, and that is why I believe it is appropriate to open these negotiations in order to promote global regulation in order to have fair competitiveness rules. Furthermore, I believe it is of fundamental importance to ensure that EASA continues to have a competitive budget, which will ensure the use of flexible and effective instruments to compete on a global scale.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission has announced the release of a new aviation legislative package with the aim of strengthening the competitiveness of the European aviation sector, with reference to both passenger mobility and freight transport and, more generally, to all commercial and non-aviation-related activities.  Our report stresses in particular the need to focus on aspects relating to aircraft and passenger safety, to implement the sustainability of air transport, focusing on both new technologies and new fuels, in order to reduce the impact on the environment. The importance of investing in innovation, with reference to drones, digitization and the use of control and monitoring systems based on GPS technologies, is highlighted. In many cases, action must be taken to create conditions of fair competition. All too often, European funds invested in the modernisation and construction of new airport infrastructure are squandered, as also pointed out in a report by the Court of Auditors.  I am therefore voting in favour of safer and more environmentally sustainable transport.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted against this Resolution because it raises a privatization agenda and offers no solutions to the main problems facing the sector. With an exclusive focus on the competitiveness and internationalisation of the sector, this Resolution continues with the impetus for the development of the single European area, which entails liberalisation and privatization of the functioning of different national airspaces. Privatization of air services only creates problems for users, public coffers and even safety standards. Despite this, the Commission continues its neoliberal agenda, which only envisages the competitiveness and internationalisation of the sector. Nor does this Resolution address the most serious problems of social dumping and declining security standards in the sector. That is why I have decided to vote against this Resolution.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission intends to submit an aviation package by the end of 2015 to identify and address the challenges facing the EU aviation sector. The European Parliament's motion for a resolution adopted today, which I voted in favour of, makes recommendations that could improve the draft legislation in preparation. It therefore calls, inter alia, on the Commission to take into account and include in the package the essential aspects contained in Parliament's resolutions adopted at first reading on Single European Sky 2+ (SES2+) and the European Aviation Safety Agency (EASA) and in parliament's resolution of 2 July 2013 on the European Union's foreign policy on aviation. The motion adopted calls for the introduction of proactive policies to support and develop the aeronautical industry, for a proactive policy to ensure a level playing field and for Member States to improve their national infrastructure so that their airlines can compete on more favourable terms.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ As the European Commission is soon adopting an important aviation package, this EP resolution is entitled to underline the priority of EP in this sector. I support the resolution as it asks the Commission to act strongly in both aspects from a competition point of view to ensure a playing level field and, on the social aspect, to ensure fair competition and strongly fight against social dumping.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that small and regional airports in the Union are important and have a significant role to play in ensuring cohesion between EU regions, and I believe that both the Commission and the Member States must present a long-term EU strategic plan to address the challenges and opportunities of EU regional airports, given that regional cohesion must be part of the Union's strategy for growth and employment.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This resolution sets out the European Parliament's position for the publication of the European Commission's new Aviation Package on 2 December. Supporting the airline industry is essential, given that the sector is expected to grow by 5% per year until 2030 globally. In view of the many current challenges, such as the security objective, the loss of competitiveness or the increase in the number of passengers, European legislation needs to be modernised.  Several priorities need to be put forward, namely to strengthen the competitiveness of European airlines in a context of fierce international competition, while taking into account the interests of the three main players (airlines, airports and aviation industries), and to maintain high safety standards, in order to guarantee passenger protection.  Considering that aviation is a strategic economic sector in the European Union, which employs more than 5 million people and contributes 2.4% of GDP (365 billion euros), I supported this report.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission intends to present an aviation package by the end of 2015 to identify the sector's challenges, promoting its competitiveness and defining a long-term strategy to strengthen airlines and airports. In view of the intensification of traffic flows estimated for 2030 and the competitive pressures to which European airports are exposed, I believe that we must ask the Council for a further effort to approve the proposal for a regulation on the allocation of airport slots as soon as possible.  I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution because I believe it is essential to promote the implementation of the Single European Sky, to make strategic use of foreign investment in the aviation sector and to take advantage of the positive impact of this package for the tourism industry as well.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission will present its future aviation package in December, which will, among other things, update civil aviation standards, revise the mandate of the European Aviation Safety Agency and are expected to include eu-wide regulation of drones. In order to maintain the sector's competitiveness and maintain the current level of security, updating existing rules is essential. This has already been indicated several times by the European Parliament and, after long negotiations, it has also adopted its own resolution. The 3 major factions (EPP, S&D and ALDE) managed to reach an agreement and adopt a text that reflects the position of the People's Party and is also in line with Hungarian interests, so I was able to vote in favour of the adoption of the motion for a resolution.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 It is expected that the 'Aviation Package', to be announced by the Commission at the end of 2015, will identify problems in the sector and propose measures to address the challenges facing the European aviation sector. It is also assumed that future measures will improve competitiveness in both the internal and external markets, ensuring a greater level playing field and ensuring a long-term strategy for europe's aviation industry. Unfortunately, the proposals made in the EFA, S&D and ALDE joint resolution will be detrimental to the growth and competitiveness of the European aviation sector. That's why I decided to abstain.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The aviation sector is an important factor in the economic development of the European Union. It should be respected at a competitive level, with environmentally friendly technologies and rules, with an increased level of security measures.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission will present its future aviation package in December, which will, among other things, update civil aviation standards, review the mandate of the European Aviation Safety Agency and are expected to include eu-wide regulation of drones. In order to maintain the sector's competitiveness and maintain the current level of security, updating existing rules is essential. This has already been indicated several times by the European Parliament and, after long negotiations, it has also adopted its own resolution. The three major factions, EPP, S&D and ALDE, managed to reach an agreement and adopt a text that reflects the position of the People's Party and is also in line with Hungarian interests, so I was able to vote in favour of the adoption of the motion for a resolution.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 In Europe, the economy of the air transport sector contributed directly to 2.6 million jobs and accounted for more than 2.4 % of EU GDP and in 2014 849.4 million passengers were transported by air in the EU, an increase of 4.4 % compared to 2013 and 16.9 % compared to 2009. However, the environment around companies areas is accelerated change, which has already led to the elimination of more than 20,000 jobs.  Against this backdrop, the presentation of an aviation package aimed at identifying and responding to the challenges facing the EU aviation sector is of utmost importance, even in order to strengthen its sustainability and competitiveness, consolidate European airlines, airports and the aviation industry, ensure a level playing field on the world market and define a long-term strategy for the European aviation sector.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Following the recent terrorist attacks on trains in Europe, it is clear that the European Union must constantly work to increase and guarantee security for the populations of individual Member States in various forms of transport. The aviation industry is an important employer with an important impact on the development and growth of the European economy. Around 10 million flights a year take place over Europe. About half a million people are employed in the area. The new measures under the aviation package are intended to improve the functioning and protection of the single aviation market in Europe. This market could eventually be extended to some other countries. It is also important, when liberalising, to genuinely guarantee the quality of existing consumer rights for passengers. This applies, for example, to financial compensation for significant flight delays or lost or damaged luggage. However, efforts to increase security cannot lead to even greater harassment of passengers at airports.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the reports on the future air transport package as a whole. The aviation sector is an important factor in the economic development of the European Union. It should be respected at a competitive level with environmentally friendly technologies and rules, with an increased level of security measures.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly support the future Aviation Package, as it will provide a boost for a more sustainable European aviation industry, improve the competitiveness of the sector, strengthen European airlines, airports and the aeronautic industry, ensure a level playing field in the global market and set out a long-term strategy for Europe’s aviation sector. The Commission should take into account and support innovation in the fields of air traffic management, airport security, digitalisation and multimodal solutions. It is very important that the package supports global environmental solutions such as a global market-based measure to address CO2 emissions from international aviation. European airports are facing significant competitive pressures; therefore, the Commission should take these developments into consideration in implementing the Airport Charges Directive. Moreover, the package should include a long-term EU strategic plan to address the challenges and opportunities for regional airports within the EU. Finally, I endorse the call to strengthen the role of the EASA on the international scene and to ensure its official recognition within ICAO, in order to establish a single EU voice that will ensure a higher level of safety for EU citizens worldwide while safeguarding the competitiveness and exports of the EU aviation industry.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP resolution on the future aviation package because I believe that, in view of the Commission's legislative proposal, which is expected by the end of 2015, it is appropriate to identify the many challenges that particularly affect European airlines and airports, both large and regional. The latter, in particular, play a very important role in the development of the territories, and the peripheral ones specifically. The aviation sector is booming, so it is crucial to implement existing Single European Sky legislation efficiently, taking into account the needs of civil and commercial users.  I therefore believe that the competitiveness and liberalisation of the aviation sector cannot be separated from the airlines' respect for workers' rights, standards and social standards. In the aviation sector, social dumping is very present, because many airlines use temporary workers, false self-employed workers, precarious contracts to the detriment of workers' rights in order to increase competitiveness. The safety of air space and airlines must necessarily be combined with the safety of conditions in the workplace, the necessary vocational training of staff and collective bargaining.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the resolution on a future aviation package, as I very much welcome the approach and thematic focus. The following aspects are important to me: Europe's aviation must be competitive in international competition – but without throwing overboard important demands and high targets. Europe's aviation must, above all, be consumer-friendly – there are still many places here. Europe's aviation must protect citizens and the environment – that is, take into account local residents – for example through bans on after-flight flights, consideration for flora and fauna, and fair taxation of emissions. Ultimately, Europe's aviation must also guarantee a high level of safety – here European airlines should be among the world leaders and encourage innovation.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. The aviation industry is a mainstay of the international competitiveness of the European economy. It is precisely here that many jobs are created directly and indirectly. Serious future concepts are therefore needed to ensure the long-term competitiveness of the sector.

name: Juan Carlos GIRAUTA VIDAL
text: in writing. ‒ In view of the adoption by the European Commission of an aviation package in December, I supported today this resolution which underlines the need to support the competitiveness of the European airlines, airports and the aeronautic industry to better face international competition in the sector. The resolution also encourages innovation, for instance in the fields of digitalisation, to improve air traffic management and to ensure the security of passengers.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. On 2 December last, the Commission presented a set of documents called aviation package aimed at defining the future strategy of the EU aviation sector. This Joint Resolution of the PPE, S&D and ALDE Groups follows this line and emphasizes, as a matter of priority, strengthening the competitiveness of the sector, with little mention of the social aspects. In these circumstances, such competitiveness against third countries could be achieved through dumping. In an attempt to avoid this possibility, if the amendments tabled by the GUE/NGL Group, which reject privatizations and point to the need to preserve and strengthen the sector's jobs and working conditions, as well as the protection of workers and users in cases of airline failure, had been accepted in this vote, we would have voted in favour of the Resolution. But since they were rejected, we voted against.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this vote on the aviation sector in the EU as the sector is facing strong competition from outside countries. Both airline companies and airports are facing an uncertain future. Airline companies are facing competition from some state-owned airlines while European airports are struggling to compete with new airports in the third countries which are competing to become major hubs in the aviation world.  In light of these difficulties, it is important to examine issues of competition to ensure a playing level field for the sector but it is equally important to closely strongly fight instances of social dumping and precarious contracts.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text. Aviation is a very important economic sector in the European Union, contributing almost 2.4% of GDP and representing hundreds of thousands of jobs! But to ensure aviation safety, face global competition and meet the challenge of increasing passenger numbers, EU legislation should be updated and more responsibilities could be entrusted to the European Aviation Safety Agency. We must defend the competitiveness of our aviation sector!  In addition, I believe that Member States should speed up the implementation of the Single European Sky provisions.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for the resolution on the future Aviation Package because I believe it should provide a much needed boost for the European aviation industry, improve the competitiveness of the sector, lead to a level playing field and set out a long-term strategy for Europe’s aviation industry. The resolution emphasises that the aeronautics industry is a major contributor to EU growth and jobs and is closely linked to competitiveness in the EU aviation sector, generating a turnover of around EUR 100 billion per year and sustaining some 500 000 direct jobs.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission will present its future aviation package in December, which will, among other things, update civil aviation standards, review the mandate of the European Aviation Safety Agency and are expected to include eu-wide regulation of drones. In order to maintain the sector's competitiveness and maintain the current level of security, updating existing rules is essential. The European Parliament has indicated this several times. The resolution adopted reflects the position of the People's Party and is also in line with Hungarian interests, which is why I voted in favour of the adoption of the motion for a resolution.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I was pleased to support this resolution on a future Aviation Package which dealt with competitiveness in the wider global dimension, safety and working conditions within the industry. In particular, I strongly supported the reiteration that, to encourage this growing sector, EU regulatory provisions on employment and working conditions, standards and practices – including collective bargaining practices – must be maintained.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I was in support of this resolution, as the aviation industry is a growing sector that has attracted and provided highly skilled and motivated professionals. In this case, in order to continue this trend, the current EU regulatory provisions on employment and working conditions should be maintained. In 2012 the European air transport economy directly supported 2.6 million jobs and contributed more than 2.4% of EU GDP. It is a vital sector for the EU economy.

name: Roger HELMER
text: in writing. ‒ We have voted against this resolution because it is wishing to interfere in the function of the Member Countries when determining the competitiveness of the industry. The resolution is also calling for the Commission to have an input in the efficient running of the airports when the UK has one of the most efficient airport operations in the world.  Furthermore, the resolution is looking at increasing the responsibilities of EASA when there is no necessity for this; the CAA has already had some regulatory responsibilities passed to EASA and further responsibilities must not be taken away.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission will present the new aviation package in December. This will, among other things, update civil aviation standards, revise the mandate of the European Aviation Safety Agency and are expected to include EU-wide regulation of drones. In order to maintain the sector's competitiveness and maintain the current level of security, it is essential to renew the current rules. This has already been indicated several times by the European Parliament and, after long negotiations, it has also adopted its own resolution. The 3 major factions (EPP, S&D and ALDE) have reached an agreement and adopted a text that reflects the position of the People's Party and is also in line with Hungarian interests. I was therefore able to vote in favour of the adoption of the motion for a resolution.

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: In writing. In France, we know the importance of the aviation sector because it is a job-creating and highly strategic sector. In the European Union, aviation employs more than 5 million people and contributes 2.4% of European GDP alone. It is also a sector threatened by strong competition, as evidenced by the current crisis in Air France. This resolution is timely. It is indeed imperative that Europe prepares the future of this sector and adapts its legislation in this direction.  Otherwise, the jewels of the aviation industry are in danger of disappearing and the jobs that go with it. At the same time, ensuring the viability of the aviation sector means ensuring the stability of European economies and the ability of the European Union to be a major economic player in the world. That is why I have decided to support this resolution.

name: Ian HUDGHTON
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution calls for the full integration of airports into the European transport system, and I welcome that call. It should be remembered, however, that this does not just mean connecting large cities to hubs such as Heathrow, Frankfurt and Amsterdam. Air transport provides a priceless lifeline from many Scottish highland and island communities to places such as Aberdeen, Inverness and Glasgow.  In developing European integration, we should aim to be linking small communities to the rest of the world in as few transits as possible. This means encouraging routes from places like the Scottish cities to multiple international destinations.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I applaud the aeronautics industry for being a central generator of growth, stability and jobs within the European Union, having more than EUR 100 billion turnover per year and supporting 500 000 direct jobs. I would also like to note the issue of protection against unfair pricing practices in the air transport sector, which should be addressed urgently by the European Commission. Finally, I believe that the Aviation Package provides great incentive for a more structured, fair and competitive European aviation industry.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's aviation resolution, as the aviation industry is one of the biggest drivers of employment and growth in the Union, directly affecting the overall European economy. It is essential that the Commission's package of measures focuses on creating a competitive European aviation industry. In this context, it is necessary to address the burdens that exist at European and national level so that the real competitiveness of this sector can be strengthened, and further growth and progress through innovation and new technologies should be encouraged.  However, social provisions and the provision of the necessary protection and the security aspect are vital. I believe, therefore, that a skilled and highly trained workforce and a high level of security in European airspace are a prerequisite for the competitiveness and export of the EU aviation industry. In addition, investments in regional airports and the progress of drone systems that must also be included in the new package of measures are essential.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. A strengthened and competitive European aviation industry – not only in production but also in the operation of aircraft fleets – ultimately has a positive impact on passengers and the economy as a whole. The competitive pressure on the Gulf airlines is to be increased, and in some areas eASA needs to be strengthened under the law of competence. Despite all the sensible and correct proposals to strengthen the aviation industry, I am abstaining because EASA is to be given the status of a common aviation authority, which is unrealistic without ICAO recognition.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution as it calls for measures to boost the EU aviation sector and fight unfair competition while upholding high safety and social standards.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ The joint motion for a resolution by the EPP, S&D and ALDE contains a very weak social agenda in the aviation sector. That is why I voted against. On the other hand, the resolution by GUE/NGL underlines the need to preserve and reinforce jobs and working conditions, pinning down the concept of a ‘principal place of business’, and calls on the Commission to strengthen the protection of workers and consumers in the event of bankruptcy of an air carrier.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I refused to take part in this vote because I consider it unacceptable to have scheduled it on 11 November, in violation of the respect due to our forefathers who died for our freedom. If I had voted, I would have abstained because this text certainly tries to protect the European aviation sector from unfair competition from Gulf airlines, but on the other hand it organises the application of the 'single European sky' that I am fighting.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted against this Resolution because it raises a liberalisation agenda and offers no solutions to the main problems facing the sector. This Resolution continues with the impetus for the development of the single European area, which entails liberalisation and privatisation of the functioning of the different national airspaces. Privatization of air services only creates problems for users, public coffers and even safety standards. Despite this, the Commission continues with its neoliberal agenda. Nor does this Resolution address the most serious problems of social dumping and declining labour standards in the sector. That is why I have decided to vote against this Resolution.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Data shows that in 2012 the aviation industry created 2.6 million jobs, and in the period up to 2020, a positive impact on GDP of EUR 419 billion is expected. The air transport system thus generates benefits, not only in the air industry, but also beyond. Also, the production of aviation hardware and software in Europe meets the world's highest innovation standards. While the EU has developed a regulatory framework for the European aviation market, the current situation is not satisfactory. The role and resources of the European Aviation Safety Agency need to be further strengthened, the sustainability of the provision of aviation services should be ensured, with a particular focus on digitalisation as a priority of aviation strategy and the aim of creating new jobs. In order to create a single aviation market, it is necessary to ensure the full implementation of EU legislation in the Member States and to establish global standards through international relations. I supported the European Parliament's resolution on the future aviation package, due to its importance for Europe's economic growth and competitiveness, faster and safer connectivity and mobility of people, goods and services, and the fact that a single European sky is a necessary prerequisite for the sustainable competitiveness of the European aviation sector.

name: Curzio MALTESE
text: in writing. \u2012 Airline lobbies thank the European Parliament after today's vote on the aviation package. A large group of Members has, in fact, prevented a vote from being taken on an amendment on the protection of workers and consumers in the event of the bankruptcy of an airline.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union's aviation sector, like such sectors in any other part of the world, is currently going through massive changes that have not been in place for decades. They take place due to increased competition, workers' rights, safety factors, economic difficulties, unstable resource and fuel prices, as well as a number of other reasons. On the basis of the European Commission's "Aviation Package" plan, which is expected to be adopted by the end of this year, active efforts are needed, which would place particular emphasis on the implementation of further incentives to increase the competitiveness of the EU aviation sector compared to other global airlines and associated sectors. Given the importance of aviation, not only in the EU economy, but also in social life and other sectors, the adoption of this package is undeniably very necessary. More than that, it would certainly be worth not only promoting the competitiveness of our aviation sector, but also its reform and increasing adaptation to today's real ones, namely, among other things, more effective protection of the consumer rights of its services and an incentive for general security, both on board aircraft, at airports and in other associated facilities.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the joint motion for a resolution on aviation because it is not complete and substantiated, and for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 11/11/2015.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the motion for a resolution on the aviation package. This package is strongly needed to make the European aviation sector more sustainable and competitive, to strengthen European airlines, airports and the aviation industry, to ensure a level playing field on the global market and to define a long-term strategy for the European aviation sector.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: Writing. \u2012 Although air transport, as an important sector of the economies of the EU Member States and the Union as a whole, undoubtedly needs a vision for further development, I could not support the 'air package' presented by Parliament. Behind my abstaining from voting are a few unfulfilled expectations that I have put into the document that we have tried to reflect in our own version of the document for GUE/NGL. Although the economic contribution of air transport and its considerable importance for employment and the preference for highly skilled professions are emphasised on several occasions, I lack a greater emphasis on social aspects. It should not even be an effort to break down existing legal norms in this regard or to move some into supranational competences! I also lack a hardening against social dumping and inequalities in working conditions, which, together with the enormous pressure on the workload of workers, co-creates an environment that threatens aviation safety. I also did not support the 'aviation package' because of the contentious proclamations on the need to reduce unfair competition for European air transport by third-country companies. Knowing that the EU does not have the real strength to meet such plans, I consider these points of the document to be toothless and populist. Last but not least, I am not even in support of the proposed 'one vote' of the EU in ICAO (International Civil Aviation Organisation) – it is impossible to deprive Member States of their representation, which is common for the whole aviation world.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. A strengthened and, above all, more competitive EU aviation industry (whose main competitors are the state-subsidised airlines of the Gulf States) is of enormous importance and ultimately has a positive impact on passengers and the European economy.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The joint resolution of the right and the socio-liberals takes up the initiative of the European Commission 'single sky'. According to the usual mantras, the aim is to "improve the competitiveness of the aviation sector" in Europe, i.e. to accelerate its liberalisation in order to over-exploit people. To this end, the resolution calls on the Commission to "remove the burdens on European airlines at national and EU level".  Finally, the resolution ignores all ecological prospects and, on the eve of COP 21, stresses that "the aviation sector is recognised as a growing sector" and is enthusiastic about the forecast of doubling traffic in 2030.  Astonished by the erism of this document, I vote against this text which threatens aviation employees, passenger safety and the environment.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as it stresses that, in order for the European aviation industry to remain competitive, we must support innovation in a number of areas that affect the sector. The resolution highlights air traffic management, remotely piloted aircraft, alternative fuels and research in aircraft and engine designs. The resolution also focuses on the need to ensure and maintain high standards of safety in European aviation and take into account the findings of the recent EASA Task Force report.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. I welcome the adoption by the European Parliament of a resolution on aviation. The European aviation sector faces many challenges including increased passenger flows, competition, passenger rights, aviation safety and CO2 emissions.  In the run-up to the Commission's next legislative proposal, it was essential that Parliament voted again on this subject. Among other things, it stresses the need to pay more attention to the competitiveness of European airlines and airports in a context of increased competition in the global market. I am pleased that the adopted text also refers to working conditions in the aviation sector and calls on the Commission to provide social provisions in this regard. Finally, on the safety side, I welcome the emphasis on passenger safety and in particular on the development of technology to track, via satellite, every aircraft in flight.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the European Parliament Resolution on the future of the European Aviation Package. The Resolution underlines the top priorities of the European Parliament in the aviation sector and should contribute to the important aviation package that the European Commission is expected to adopt at the beginning of December. The aviation sector and airline companies are facing strong competition from third countries, therefore the Commission needs to act strongly to ensure a playing level field and fair competition for European companies.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 On the subject, the PPE, Verts/ALE, ALDE, EFDD, ECR, GUE/NGL and S&D Groups tabled motions for resolutions, of which PPE, ALDE and S&D reached an agreement and drafted a joint compromise motion. I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this joint resolution on the future Aviation package, which tells the Commission its recommendations in the context of the future legislative proposal in the field of aviation. I support this text which recommends supporting and developing this sector which makes a considerable contribution to growth and employment. In 2014, almost 850 million people used air transport in the EU, an increase of 4.4% over 2013 and 16.9% over 2009. The aviation industry generates a turnover of around 100 billion euros per year and directly employs 500,000 people.  The report calls on the Commission to take steps to improve the competitiveness of this sector, by promoting innovations in air traffic management, aircraft and engine design, and fuel. It also calls for increased security in European airspace, where traffic is expected to double by 2030.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 Given the importance of the sector, which contributed 2.4% of Europe's GDP in 2012 and directly employed 2.6 million people, we welcome the joint resolution on aviation. Despite the increase in passengers, which in 2014 recorded a growth of 16.9% compared to 2009, airlines have made and/or planned staff cuts totalling twenty thousand jobs since 2012.  We therefore call for the European Parliament's position to remain the importance of the sector as a factor for internal growth and industrial innovation. We call for a proactive policy by the European Commission to ensure fair competition in the air travel market, with particular reference to competition from third countries with looser legislation on subsidies and state aid. Concerned about the introduction of new practices and contractual conditions, potentially damaging to the safety of travellers, we hope for the adoption of greater social guarantees and more timely medical assessments for pilots. Recalling that the aviation sector is not regulated by the World Trade Organisation, we call for a multilateral agreement, within the framework of the International Civil Aviation Organisation, to enact common rules that require a reduction in emissions. The sector is responsible for 13% of European CO2 emissions.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The aviation package should provide the necessary impetus to make the European aviation sector more sustainable and competitive by strengthening European airlines, airports and the aviation industry. In this way, we will be able to ensure a level playing field on the global market and define a long-term strategy for the European aviation sector.  Aviation supports 5.1 million jobs and contributes € 365 billion, or 2.4% of Europe's GDP. Despite the current economic crisis, long-term global air transport is set to grow by about 5% annually until 2030. The EU's common aviation policy also aims to make Europe the safest airspace in the world. I therefore welcome this resolution.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 The popularity and worldwide role of air transport in passenger and freight traffic is now untreated. Europe must also face this fact, and therefore, like other transport sectors, we must also aim to develop and expand air transport. A well-functioning air infrastructure can serve the economic development of Europe to a large extent, in addition to growing individual interests. It can be said beyond a reasonable doubt that the content of the future aviation package, which has now come to the negotiating table, has high expectations.  We absolutely need a complex document that provides a long-term strategy for the sustainable development of the European aerospace industry and ensures its progress in the global market. At the same time, increasing traffic also has increasing environmental impacts, so it is of the utmost importance that we develop a future strategy in the knowledge of our responsibility for our environment. There is also a serious need to address social issues and problems relating to air transport. I am thinking here, first and foremost, of making EU airspace safe, but also of airing national borders for aircraft. For legislators, however, passenger safety must be a guiding principle.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ This motion for a resolution acknowledges the need for action to improve the competitiveness of European airlines. I have voted in favour of this motion for a resolution, which will facilitate a competitive European aviation industry through effective economic regulation.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the aviation resolution because I believe that the EU should step up efforts in the field of air safety. Against the background of the recent Germanwings aircraft disaster, I consider it important that the text calls on the Commission to take measures to improve the medical assessment of pilots and the safety, entry and exit procedures relating to cockpit doors. Every step must be done to prevent a plane crash caused by the suicidal intention of a mentally disturbed pilot from happening again.

name: Andrey NOVAKOV
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The aviation industry makes a major contribution to eu growth and employment and is closely linked to the competitiveness of the EU air sector. The European aviation sector suffers from various legal and financial burdens leading to a loss of its competitiveness. The aviation package would give the aviation industry the necessary boost. The document underlines the close link between competitiveness and innovation, as well as concrete steps to be taken. It is of the utmost importance to remove the burdens at national and European level borne by European airlines in order to strengthen the competitiveness of the sector. The implementation of the Single European Sky must be accelerated, EU air agreements with the Gulf states negotiated as soon as possible, compliance with the provisions relating to unfair pricing practices in the air transport sector must be ensured. The document highlights the role of small and regional airports in the EU as a way to combat congestion at larger and major airports through indirect connections. In this context, a long-term EU strategic plan is needed to address the challenges of regional airports within the Union.  International regulation of the air transport sector is needed for fairer rules. Full implementation of the SESAR programme in another important step.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that creating a level playing field and improving the competitiveness of the European aviation industry are very important. Furthermore, compliance with social standards is very important. Improving the medical assessment of pilots and safety procedures, as well as the entrance and exit of the cockpit team, are also necessary requirements to reduce sources of danger in air transport.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The aviation sector is large and expanding, contributing to both economic growth and job creation in the EU. The competitiveness of the EU aviation sector requires it to be modern, comfortable and secure. It is also important that the EU's periphery also has as many good connections as possible with the rest of the EU. In this respect, eu competition rules and state aid conditions should also be reviewed, especially in view of the fact that it is not very easy economically for small countries in the EU's periphery to create air connections, but this is still essential. There is no real competition and no one is harmed in the sense of competition rules. In addition, we need to consider how to better ensure that the rights of airline employees are protected in the event of an airline bankruptcy.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution. In particular, the new aviation package should lead to the growth of a more sustainable and competitive European aviation industry. It would also strengthen European airlines, airports and the aeronautics industry and ensure a level playing field on the global market. The new regulation must ensure that the aviation sector is competitive, clean and safe, and meets the needs of citizens and society. The aviation industry is a growing sector with highly qualified professionals. In this context, it is essential that the new package incorporates social provisions and introduces the necessary safeguards and widespread collective bargaining practices. It should be noted that innovation is a prerequisite for a competitive European aviation industry. It is also essential to remove the unreasonable burden on European airlines at EU and national level. Given the international dimension of the aviation sector, greater attention must be paid to negotiating comprehensive aviation agreements with the EU's main trading partners.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Writing. – The new aviation package, with the "Single European Sky 2", aims to complete the liberalisation of air transport in the EU and its Member States by completely handing over state infrastructure and air navigation management to business groups.  The "Single European Sky" aims to unifie airspace across the EU, abolishes the sovereign rights of EU Member States to control and manage their airspace and jeopardises their defence security, and is part of NATO's aggressive planning.  Part of this policy of the EU and the Member States for the benefit of monopolies is the privatisation of the 14 regional airports to which the SYRIZA-ANEL co-government is proceeding, a strategic choice of capital to increase its profitability.  This will have painful consequences for workers, redundancies, wage reductions, etc., worsening flight safety, expensive services for the popular family, while groups treasure. Workers must fight for radical changes in terms of economy and power, become the owners themselves of the wealth they produce, thus forcing the release from the EU, in order to become the popular needs criterion for production.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ We have voted against this resolution because it is wishing to interfere in the function of the Member Countries when determining the competitiveness of the industry. The resolution is also calling for the Commission to have an input in the efficient running of the airports when the UK has one of the most efficient airport operations in the world.  Furthermore, the resolution is looking at increasing the responsibilities of EASA when there is no necessity for this; the CAA has already had some regulatory responsibilities passed to EASA and further responsibilities must not be taken away.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 As a participant in the work of the ITRE Parliamentary Committee, I am particularly attentive to the development needs of the industrial sector in Europe. In particular, the aviation industry is a strategic element for economic growth (and consequently for employment opportunities) as it is one of the most sensitive and easily adaptable to current technological development. Furthermore, as a member of the ENVI Parliamentary Committee and being sensitive to environmental issues, I am in favour of the measures that will be implemented to reduce aircraft consumption and emissions. I call on this House to join forces to achieve these objectives, starting with the vote in favour.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒in 2012 I supported the proposal for a resolution by the EPP, ALDE and S&D aviation clubs. The new package of measures must enable the EU aviation industry, airlines and ports to have a more favourable and competitive position on the global market. The airline industry and airlines are increasingly less competitive with regard to subsidised airlines and carriers from third countries.  When taking into account the constant increase in passenger numbers and goods transported by air, this downward trend in the competitiveness of European airlines must be halted. Worryingly, since 2012, European airlines have laid off or plan to lay off more than 20,000 workers, with nearly 2.6 million jobs linked to the airline industry and airlines.  For all these reasons, it is necessary to develop a package of measures that will raise the competitiveness of the EU aviation sector, contribute to economic growth and job creation, raise the safety of passengers and crew members in European airspace, bring innovation to the air sector, such as monitoring the position of aircraft throughout the flight time and introducing remotely piloted aircraft systems, finally, but not least , air travel affects climate change and is responsible for around 13 % of Europe's carbon dioxide emissions from transport. This package of measures must also contribute to reducing carbon dioxide emissions.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Air transport in the EU is economically highly developed and supports 2.6 million jobs and contributes over 2.4% to gross national income. Airlines in the Union are facing increasing challenges in the internal and external markets, and the future Aviation Package will provide the necessary boost and improve the competitiveness of the aviation industry.  It is recommended to support innovation in the field of ATM, preparation of specifications of drone systems and introduce alternative energy sources, digitalisation and new business models. In this regard, negotiations with ICAO are encouraged with a view to creating international competitiveness rules that would be fair and equal for all. It is important to prevent disloyal competition and eliminate bad practice.  At the same time, it emphasises the need for professional, educational and adaptive workforce and for the introduction of preventive measures aimed at increasing passenger insurance. I believe that an open and measured approach is necessary to address the sensitive issue of aviation safety. It is necessary to respond to the needs of passengers and their possible expectations by regaining the confidence of passengers in aviation traffic. Consequently, I agree with a resolution that clearly underlines the need for a proactive policy to develop the aviation industry.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 The aviation sector makes a very high contribution to the EU economy of 2.4% of GDP. This is a rapidly evolving sector, set to grow by about 5% every year until 2030.  The European Commission intends to present, on 2 December, an aviation package aimed at identifying the challenges facing the aviation and related services sector. The aim of the joint motion for a resolution is to urge the Commission to propose policies which will support and develop the European aeronautical industry. Innovation, competitiveness, passenger rights, safety and the importance of clear and transparent rules on staff working conditions are all key issues that will have to be put at the heart of the EU executive's proposal.  I therefore hope that my vote in favour today will help to define an ambitious European strategy, capable of meeting the growing competition from non-EU countries.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 With regard to the Joint Resolution of the EPP, the Socialists and the Liberals abstained from voting because I believe that the current EU and national employment rules should be adhered to in order to ensure adequate skills and working conditions. In addition, modern and competitive economic models should be maintained as they help airlines to increase productivity and allow them to compete effectively in the wider market.  Due to the far too prescriptive nature and the potential harm of the provisions to the growth and competitiveness of the European aviation sector, I could not support the joint resolution

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ We have voted against this resolution because it is wishing to interfere in the function of the Member Countries when determining the competitiveness of the industry. The resolution is also calling for the Commission to have an input in the efficient running of the airports when the UK has one of the most efficient airport operations in the world.  Furthermore, the resolution is looking at increasing the responsibilities of EASA when there is no necessity for this; the CAA has already had some regulatory responsibilities passed to EASA and further responsibilities must not be taken away.

name: Dominique RIQUET
text: In writing. The European air sector, which accounts for 2.4% of the EU's GDP and 2.6 million direct jobs, is expected to double its traffic over the next 15 years. To accompany this progress, new rules must be defined to ensure safety, safety and environmental conditions. The competitiveness of the aviation industry as well as our airlines must not be forgotten. This is why measures to ensure fair competition between EU airlines, but also with those of third countries, must be adopted. In terms of infrastructure, we need to consider the appropriateness of regional airports in the development of territories and the de-cluttering of major airports.  Finally, in a sector where restructuring has never been greater in the last decade, it is the duty of Member States, through a social Europe, to ensure working conditions and social standards at a high level.  For example, I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the future Aviation package, which makes recommendations to the European Commission in its work. The new measures should enable the benefits of the growth of the aviation sector to be rebalanced for the benefit of our European airlines.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the future "Aviation" package. Aviation is a major economic sector for the European Union, accounting for 2.6 million direct jobs and more than 2.4% of GDP in 2012. But it faces many challenges: an increasingly competitive environment, a steady increase in passenger numbers, climate change, fluctuating oil prices, among others. We are waiting for the Commission's proposal by the end of 2015, and Parliament intends to weigh in on the debate and reiterate its priorities. One is to increase the competitiveness of the aviation sector by strengthening airlines, airports and the aviation industry in Europe, ensuring a level playing field in the global market or combating unfair competition. It is also necessary to accelerate the implementation of the Single European Sky as well as the negotiation of global agreements with the EU's main aviation trading partners.  Another point to note is that of safety, whether in airports, in airspace, in aircraft, for all phases of flight. I am thinking in particular of the medical monitoring of the pilots as well as the procedures for accessing and exiting the cockpits.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to develop measures to stimulate the air transport economy in the European Union while maintaining high standards of safety and the social sector. Given that certain working conditions in the aviation sector can have an impact on flight safety, it was essential that this "Aviation" package contain social provisions and provide for the necessary safeguards, as agreed at the high-level conference entitled 'A Social Agenda for Transport', organised on 4 June by the European Commission.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. European airports are easily undervalued to the detriment of other international airports for reasons ranging from non-regulation of air transport to lack of subsidies.  It is therefore important to establish comprehensive aviation agreements with the European Union's most important trading partners as a strategic objective, enabling European airlines to release national and Community charges, thereby enhancing the competitiveness of this important sector at European level. In this way, we are also contributing to greater cohesion of the regions as a strategic pillar for growth and jobs and for increasing turnover. By improving competitiveness and ensuring the sustainability of the sector, which foresees a doubling of air traffic by 2030, is an important basis for employment growth in the European Union, as the report in question maintains. For these reasons, I support the report of a motion for a resolution on aviation in and in the European airspace.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which aims to give the European Parliament's guidelines on the future Aviation package being drafted by the European Commission.  It is essential to stimulate the European Union's air transport economy by ensuring a level playing field, while maintaining high social and safety standards. The text also calls for the negotiation of comprehensive aviation agreements with the main trading partners of the European Union, but also for vigilance regarding the loss of competitiveness of European airlines and airports to subsidised carriers and airports in third countries. The future Aviation package should improve the management of airspace and services at airports, ensure the maintenance of current working conditions and social standards and, finally, strengthen the role of the European Aviation Safety Agency.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the future aviation package because I agree with the European Parliament's decision to increase the sustainability of the European aviation sector and improve its competitiveness.  The European Union must work to promote innovation in the field of air traffic management, remotely piloted air systems and alternative fuel solutions. In addition, the aviation package makes improvements concerning the safety of air transport, which is of fundamental importance to European citizens.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. On 2 December last, the Commission presented a set of documents called aviation package aimed at defining the future strategy of the EU aviation sector. This Joint Resolution of the PPE, S&D and ALDE Groups follows this line and emphasizes, as a matter of priority, strengthening the competitiveness of the sector, with little mention of the social aspects. In these circumstances, such competitiveness against third countries could be achieved through dumping. In an attempt to avoid this possibility, if the amendments tabled by the GUE/NGL Group, which reject privatizations and point to the need to preserve and strengthen the sector's jobs and working conditions, as well as the protection of workers and users in cases of airline failure, had been accepted in this vote, we would have voted in favour of the Resolution. But since they were rejected, we voted against.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this resolution, because it is aiming to interfere in the activities of Member States when determining the competitiveness of the industry. The resolution also calls for the Commission to have an input into the efficient running of airports when the UK has one of the most efficient airport operations in the world. Furthermore, the resolution is increasing the responsibilities of EASA when there is no need for this. The CAA has already seen some regulatory responsibilities passed to EASA and I do not believe this should continue.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I had the opportunity to speak about the future Aviation Package earlier, and my main concerns about the aviation industry concerned principally the issues in the UK. However, I will take this opportunity to express my support of the joint motion for a resolution from the EPP, S&D and ALDE groups. The S&D was able to strengthen the social dimension in employment in the aviation industry and allowed for the possibility to address precarious employment – zero-hour contracts – that are needlessly exploiting workers.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 The aviation industry is an important part of the EU economy. In 2012, the sector was linked to the activity of 2.6 million jobs and generated more than 2.4% of EU-wide GDP. Its importance and impact on all EU citizens has also grown in recent years, with up to 849.4 million passengers travelling by air in the EU in 2014. For this reason, I voted in favour of adopting the European Parliament resolution on aviation, which deals with improving the competitiveness of the aviation industry and improving the security of the level of safety in EU airspace.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ The aviation industry is one of the main drivers of growth and employment in the EU and is closely linked to the competitiveness of the aviation transport sector with annual revenues of around €100 billion and around 500 000 directly employed. European airlines operate in a highly changing and increasingly competitive environment, both internally and externally.  Innovation is a prerequisite for making the European aviation industry competitive and we should support at-air management innovation, remotely piloted aircraft systems (RPAS), solutions including alternative fuels, aircraft and engine design (higher efficiency, less noise), airport security, etc. It is therefore important to improve certain legal and financial rules if we are to remove unnecessary burdens on the European aviation sector.  The aviation package would provide a much-needed boost to the European aviation industry, increase the competitiveness of the sector, create a more level playing field and develop a long-term strategy for the European aviation industry. Bearing in mind that I support the implementation of proactive policies that would develop a favourable environment for the industry, I supported the proposal for a resolution on the future package of measures for aviation.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The european Commission's expected aviation package comes at a time when the sector is facing a number of challenges. European airports and airlines are exposed to competition from third countries, which subsidise their carriers to the detriment of EU companies. Air transport in the EU needs a strong incentive to create the conditions for a sustainable and competitive environment for airlines and airports.  I therefore agree with Parliament's resolution calling on the Commission to support innovative measures in the areas of air traffic management, alternative fuels, aircraft engines or airport safety. In addition, it cannot be forgotten that the aviation industry, as a fast-growing sector, attracts highly motivated employees. However, their working conditions do not always meet European social standards, as the airline also reduces its operating costs with atypical employment contracts, which put the employee at a disadvantage in many respects.  It is worth noting that the number of air passengers is constantly increasing and this sector has become an important part of the European economy in recent decades. Today, 5.1 million people are employed in the field of air transport in the EU and contribute EUR 365 billion to European GDP.
