It is therefore important for the Commission to break down barriers to the development of air transport. At the same time, however, it is essential to protect employees who become hostages to airlines in this competitive passenger battle.

name: Renato SORU
text: in writing. \u2012 With a view to the Presentation by the Commission of a package of aviation proposals by the end of the year, Parliament adopted with a resolution its position on the challenges facing this sector, calling for an impetus to support its competitiveness. To this end, it is crucial to ensure fair competition in the international aviation sector and to ensure a level playing field for airlines and airports in the EU, in particular through agreements negotiated with the EU's main trading partners that also address unfair practices that create market distortions, such as subsidies granted to third-country airlines. On the 'domestic' side, the resolution highlights the need to press for the implementation of the single European sky rules, aimed at remedying the current fragmentation of European airspace and removing obstacles for our airlines. Finally, I strongly support the importance of maintaining a high level of social standards and fair working practices, to protect workers in the sector and passenger safety. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider clear rules for new technologies to be key in this topic.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: Writing. \u2012 A competitive aviation sector is important for the EU both economically and socially. The aviation industry directly employs around 500 000 EU citizens. High competition in this industry over the past few years has led to a radical reduction in travel costs for the vast majority of EU citizens, which not only promotes tourism, but also increases the level of European integration by promoting personal contacts between EU citizens. It is therefore desirable to ensure that the aviation industry remains an emerging and competitive sector of the EU economy. The strategy for increasing competitiveness plays a big role in this proposal, which is why I support it. For example, as recommended in the resolution, it is necessary to remove the non-tariff barriers or burdens that the aviation industry has to face at both national and Eu level. The EU must also help the competitiveness of the European economy on the international stage. Many countries, such as some Gulf states, heavily subsidize and favor their national airlines, which then serve as their government's foreign policy tool. As European airlines do not receive similar support, AIRLINES from EU countries are at a significant disadvantage when competing. It is therefore necessary to ensure a level playing field in the world market for this sector.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: Written. 'Today, the N-VA delegation abstained in voting on the resolution on the future aviation package. The aviation sector is an important economic sector in the European Union. The resolution therefore rightly emphasises the need for this sector to be given every opportunity to compete on the competitive world market. This can be done by reducing regulatory pressure, through innovation and by better implementing existing legislation in all Member States. According to the resolution, the Single European Sky must be completed. These are calls the N-VA agrees to. After that, unfortunately, the resolution will again be in business as usual. For every problem, new European legislation must be introduced. This is diametrically opposed to what is stated earlier in the resolution. There are calls for more social regulation from Europe, while asking whether the principle of subsidiarity is being respected. Unfortunately, since the resolution contains calls for more stifling rules to be applied to this already over-regulated sector, in addition to good elements to strengthen the competitive position of the European aviation sector, the N-VA delegation cannot support the resolution.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ I supported this motion for a resolution, as I believe that the aviation package would provide the much needed incentive for a more sustainable and competitive European aviation industry, also support European airlines, airports and the aviation industry, and create a level playing field on the global market.  It is important to develop a long-term strategy for the European aviation industry. The aviation industry is one of the main drivers of growth and employment in the EU and is closely linked to the competitiveness of the aviation sector. At the same time, I would like to highlight how the EU's commitments and environmental objectives should be respected.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ The aviation sector is the only sector where pollutant emissions have increased since 1998 by around 30%. Also, the air transport sector is responsible for 3% of the world's total international CO2 emissions. The upcoming 21st century will be the first to be 100,0 By 2050, the International Air Transport Association has committed to reducing net CO2 emissions from air transport by 50% from 2005 levels by 2030.  For all of the above, the European Parliament considers that the aviation package, to be proposed by the end of this year, must contribute to the development of the European aviation sector and at the same time respect the EU's commitments and environmental objectives. It also highlights the need for fair taxation and compensation for air carriers with regard to EU emissions targets.  It is necessary to promote innovation and sustainability in the air transport sector, by the Commission and the Member States, in order to build an efficient, low-pollution industry. Given the importance of airport interconnections in Europe and the potential deployment of new infrastructure within the framework of economic and environmental balance, I fully support the European Parliament's resolution on the future aviation package.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: Writing. \u2012 Given that the proposal on the table calls for a significant increase in regulatory burdens that would damage the competitiveness of the aviation sector, I voted against.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \ I voted in favour of the joint resolution of the three EPP, S&D and ALDE political groups on aviation. The aviation legislative package will provide a much-needed incentive for the revival of the European aviation sector. With this report, we call on the European Commission to take into account certain problems in the context of a comprehensive approach to regulating safety, the environment and performance.  It is necessary to strengthen the competitiveness of airlines and airports in the European Union. The report also calls for the strengthening of aviation safety through air traffic control with satellite technology.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's joint resolution on the forthcoming aviation package on the grounds that it is a package of aviation measures that should create better conditions for a more competitive European aviation sector and ensure both the quality of service and the highest level of safety.  Consumers, airlines, airports and employees will thus benefit from new routes and airports, greater choices, lower prices and overall better quality of service and more jobs. It is also necessary to support innovations in air traffic control of remotely controlled aircraft systems (RPAS), the use of alternative fuels, aircraft and engine design (higher efficiency, lower noise), airport security (non-contact solutions and one-off security controls), digitisation and multimodal solutions (computer-controlled ground handling), while promoting environmental protection, such as global market measures to reduce CO2 emissions from international aviation.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted against the joint resolution as it did not include our main positions concerning our opposition to all forms of privatisation and liberalisation of the European aviation sector. At the same time, it ignores the need to develop employment and strengthen working conditions to protect workers and consumers as well as the need to take measures to protect them in the event of the bankruptcy of an air carrier.  On the contrary, the resolution calls for the implementation of a series of directives and policies, such as Single European Sky, which provides for the regulation, management and planning of Member States' airspace in a common European one, which significantly restricts the sovereign rights of States, while at the same time circumventing the foreign policy of the Member States.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The aviation sector is an important factor in the economic development of the European Union. It should be respected at a competitive level with environmentally friendly technologies and rules, with an increased level of security measures.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The aviation sector directly supported 2.6 million jobs in Europe and contributed more than 2.4% to EU GDP. Meanwhile, the draft also points to the regrettable fact that, in addition to the rising number of passengers, European airlines have eliminated more than 20 000 jobs since 2012. I agree with the resolution that an aviation package should provide a boost to a more sustainable and competitive European aviation sector, strengthen European airlines, airports and the aeronautical industry, ensure a level playing field on the world market and develop a long-term strategy for Europe's aviation sector.  I believe that the aeronautical industry can make a significant contribution to growth and job creation in the EU, but only if we can also strengthen competitiveness. From the point of view of implementation, I agree that innovation is a prerequisite for a competitive European aviation sector and that account should also be taken of workplace and consumer protection elements. It is precisely for these reasons that I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I co-signed and voted for the resolution on the future Aviation Package, which sets out the European Parliament’s expectations on the Commission proposal that will be delivered in the next weeks. The last months proved that improvements to the current state of play as regards competitiveness of the European aviation industry, international cooperation, social standards and safety of the airspace are much needed. I agree that tackling unfair commercial practices within and outside the EU is a priority as well as ensuring a level playing field between all operators, but protectionism is not the solution for European airlines. We need to conduct a real investigation into this matter and from that investigation alone address the problems.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I supported the proposal for a resolution by the European Conservatives and Reformists on the future aviation package, as I agree with the need to support the aviation industry and develop innovation, so that the European Union aviation sector faces the challenges it faces, which is precisely the goal of the proposed measures of this resolution.  In addition, I agree with the focus on improving the capacity and connectivity of all European Union airports, including small and regional airports, which can help less developed regions maintain competitiveness and large airports to avoid jamming.  I believe that the implementation of the Single European Sky should greatly contribute to addressing the various challenges, and I also support the call for air transport agreements with bric and ASEAN countries and Japan, the Persian Gulf countries and Turkey, which can generate additional profits for the aviation industry and the Economy of the European Union in general.  I believe that the package of measures should increase the competitiveness of the sector and ensure a long-term strategy for the European aviation industry, without a joint resolution contributing to the implementation of these objectives efficiently enough. So I voted abstention.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the motions for resolutions on the future aviation package, as I believe it has many positive effects, particularly for the European aviation industry. The proposals adopted can improve the competitiveness of this sector.  Innovation is certainly a prerequisite for a competitive European aviation industry, so it is right that we support them, particularly in the areas of air traffic management, the use of alternative fuels, remotely piloted aircraft systems, airport security, etc.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. On 2 December last, the Commission presented a set of documents called aviation package aimed at defining the future strategy of the EU aviation sector. This Joint Resolution of the PPE, S&D and ALDE Groups follows this line and emphasizes, as a matter of priority, strengthening the competitiveness of the sector, with little mention of the social aspects. In these circumstances, such competitiveness against third countries could be achieved through dumping. In an attempt to avoid this possibility, if the amendments tabled by the GUE/NGL Group, which reject privatizations and point to the need to preserve and strengthen the sector's jobs and working conditions, as well as the protection of workers and users in cases of airline failure, had been accepted in this vote, we would have voted in favour of the Resolution. But since they were rejected, we voted against.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly support the resolution we are putting forward today. In particular I support paragraphs 6 and 7, which are a clear message to Commissioner Bulc. On fair competition, DG MOVE and DG COMP have to become more closely involved, especially regarding state aid. It is quite evident that Regulation 868/2004 on protection against unfair pricing practice in the air transport sector has proven ineffective or at least inadequate as regards the kind of competition coming from Gulf carriers. The Commission knows very well that such amount of subsidies would clearly be considered illegal state aid if applied to any EU companies. The status quo is not an option. EU airlines must continue to restructure and become more efficient.  However, The EU must act fast with regard to unfair competition, ensure reciprocity and eliminate unfair practices, including subsidies and state aid to airlines from third countries that clearly distort the market. The EC should include and insert a binding and transparent fair competition clause in EU external aviation relations  Regarding the EU rules on the ownership and control of EU airlines, the EC should propose changes in the Aviation Package with regard to the vague concept of effective control. Regarding airports, I call on the Commission to establish a public list of ‘ghost’ and inefficient airports.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The aviation sector directly added 2.6 million jobs in 2012, although european airlines have eliminated more than 20 000 jobs since 2012. The number of air passengers is growing sharply, from 849.4 million in 2014 to 4.4% in 2013. EU airlines operate in a rapidly changing and increasingly competitive environment in internal and external markets. Transfers have been transferred geographically to other non-EU countries in recent years, and the question is how the EU can maintain its role as a primary tourist destination.  The resolution seeks answers to this: improving the competitiveness of the aviation sector, its international dimension, the social agenda of the aviation sector and ensuring a high level of security in European airspace. The EU internal market needs to be strengthened as the competitiveness of EU airlines and airports deteriorates compared to supported third-country carriers and airports. Proactive policy-making, ensuring a level playing field and a global approach are needed. More direct flights between the EU and third countries, for example between the EU and China, with a more pronounced involvement of regional airports. This can only be achieved through an effective and simplified visa policy. I voted in favour of the final proposal.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. On 2 December last, the Commission presented a set of documents called aviation package aimed at defining the future strategy of the EU aviation sector. This Joint Resolution of the PPE, S&D and ALDE Groups follows this line and emphasizes, as a matter of priority, strengthening the competitiveness of the sector, with little mention of the social aspects. In these circumstances, such competitiveness against third countries could be achieved through dumping. In an attempt to avoid this possibility, if the amendments tabled by the GUE/NGL Group, which reject privatizations and point to the need to preserve and strengthen the sector's jobs and working conditions, as well as the protection of workers and users in cases of airline failure, had been accepted in this vote, we would have voted in favour of the Resolution. But since they were rejected, we voted against.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on aviation because it is in line with the regulations on the implementation of the Single European Sky, aiming at improving the competitiveness of the aviation industry. The Aviation Package should provide a much-needed boost for a more sustainable and competitive European aviation industry, strengthen European airlines, airports and the aeronautic industry, ensure a level playing field in the global market and set out a long-term strategy for Europe’s aviation sector. I also agree that the negotiation of comprehensive aviation agreements with the EU’s major trading partners should be a strategic goal and that such negotiations should be launched or accelerated. The resolution also addresses the social agenda in the aviation sector, where it is important to underline the fact that certain working conditions in the aviation sector may impact flight safety and that the Aviation Package must include social provisions and provide the necessary safeguards. The main goal is to ensure a high level of safety in the EU airspace, which I think it is the most important aspect.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. I voted against this Resolution because it raises a privatization agenda and offers no solutions to the main problems facing the sector. With an exclusive focus on the competitiveness and internationalisation of the sector, this Resolution continues with the impetus for the development of the single European area, which entails liberalisation and privatization of the functioning of different national airspaces. Privatization of air services only creates problems for users, public coffers and even safety standards. Despite this, the Commission continues its neoliberal agenda, which only envisages the competitiveness and internationalisation of the sector. Nor does this Resolution address the most serious problems of social dumping and declining security standards in the sector. That is why I have decided to vote against this Resolution.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of the resolution on the future aviation package, as did a large majority of my colleagues. This resolution calls for a boost to the European aviation industry in order to keep it sustainable and viable. We can do this by removing the national obstacles further and thus creating a truly European whole. I therefore support this resolution because it calls on the Commission to support European airlines, to allow the various airports to compete with each other on equal terms and to do all this without compromising passenger safety.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. This resolution is part of the 'Single European Sky', an initiative to 'reform' European air traffic control. This initiative is divided into legislative packages of regulations, the first two of which were adopted in 2004 and 2009.  For Parliament, it is a matter of giving its opinion on the future package of measures for the aviation sector that the Commission wants to propose by the end of the year.  The Commission should continue its momentum, i.e. the liberalisation of the sector and the privatisation of airport services, under the guise of harmonising European control systems.  This resolution gives the Commission a blank-seing and follows the same neoliberal logic, calling for "removing regulatory barriers" and "removing the burdens on airlines", in defiance of the consequences this may have on the working conditions of airport staff and the safety of flights for all.  We know the song: I vote against it.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 Unsurprisingly, this European Parliament resolution remains in line with previous aviation packages and the Single European Sky. In other words, they end up supporting the Commission's positions and its proposals for the liberalisation and outsourcing of airport services. The resolution says, inter alia, in this regard: 'calls on the Commission and the Member States to accelerate the implementation of the Single European Sky by the adoption of the SES2+ package because the current fragmentation of European airspace carries additional burdens on European airlines.' Hence our vote against.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. A strengthened and, above all, more competitive EU aviation industry (whose main competitors are the state-subsidised airlines of the Gulf States) is of enormous importance and ultimately has a positive impact on passengers and the European economy.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I did not agree with the European Parliament resolution of 11 November 2015 on air transport.  Although I see a role for the EU in regulating air transport over Europe, there must be room for manoeuvre for the Member States. The resolution is far too detailed, bureaucratic and does not respect the principle of subsidiarity. Furthermore, the resolution is superfluous, since the Commission is in any case about to present its proposals.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I supported this resolution which prioritises improving the services provided to the traveller/consumer. By strengthening European airspace, it modernises safety rules and at the same time proposes a framework that supports the competitiveness of the sector.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Writing. – The new aviation package, with the "Single European Sky 2", aims to complete the liberalisation of air transport in the EU and its Member States by completely handing over state infrastructure and air navigation management to business groups.  The "Single European Sky" aims to unifie airspace across the EU, abolishes the sovereign rights of EU Member States to control and manage their airspace and jeopardises their defence security, and is part of NATO's aggressive planning.  Part of this policy of the EU and the Member States for the benefit of monopolies is the privatisation of the 14 regional airports to which the SYRIZA-ANEL co-government is proceeding, a strategic choice of capital to increase its profitability. This will have painful consequences for workers, redundancies, wage reductions, etc., worsening flight safety, expensive services for the popular family, while groups treasure.  Workers must fight for radical changes in terms of economy and power, become the owners themselves of the wealth they produce, thus forcing the release from the EU, in order to become the popular needs criterion for production.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 Resolution motions promote a set of measures to be inserted into the future Aviation Package. In general, the measures focus on increasing the competitiveness of EU aviation systems in the face of other realities (notably in the Middle East) for which the development of a number of areas would be essential, based on the deepening of the Single European Sky. The single European sky project has been inseparable from the intention of liberalising the air transport sector from its inception. The vision behind it is not the development of the sector according to a logic of prevalence of the public interest, but rather the conformation of airspace management to the interests of large airlines and the ongoing monopolistic concentration. The arguments which over the years have been aligned in favour of the 'single European sky' are subsidia to this objective and lack the basis. We voted against it.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The session of the European Parliament is interrupted. The meeting is adjourned. (The sitting was closed at 24.00)
